webTitle: Anyone know Dutch for reverse sweep?

fields.headline: Anyone know Dutch for reverse sweep?
fields.trailText: The Spanish towns of Javea and Benissa host the European Cricket Council's indoor championship this weekend. Vic Marks reports on attempts to spread the game beyond the old colonial boundaries.
fields.body:
The Spanish towns of Javea and Benissa host the European Cricket Council's indoor championship this weekend. I'm surprised that our ubiquitous Will Buckley hasn't spotted this and taken himself off to Spain in dogged pursuit of some more winter sun.

Jagmohan Dalmiya, the president of the International Cricket Council, won't be there either (he's been tied up in Singapore). But in a week when Dalmiya has been trumpeting the goal of the 'globalisation' of cricket, he would no doubt approve of the competition that this year includes the 'big boys' of the Netherlands and Denmark, as well as current holders, Portugal, plus teams from Germany, Italy, Austria, Greece, Sweden and Switzerland.

Dalmiya is eager for the game to spread beyond the old colonial boundaries - 'from Headingley to Cape Horn, from Jamaica to Japan' as he put it when announcing the ICC's 'cricket week'. The week in question - 2-9 April - will see a day-night match in Bangladesh on 8 April between Asia and the Rest of the World (though the Test schedules are now so intense it will be interesting to find out which players he can come up with). Meanwhile in Zimbabwe the emerging nations of Denmark, Holland, Ireland, Scotland and Kenya will join Zimbabwe A in a 15-match one-day series throughout that week.

Dalmiya has never been lacking in ambition, but there are signs that his dream of a global game is not so hopeless as it might seem. For example, the next World Cup in Southern Africa in 2003 will probably consist of 14, rather than 12, teams.

Already Bangladesh and Kenya, both hoping for full Test status, have been promised automatic qualification for that tournament. As a result they are not required to play in the ICC Trophy in Toronto next year, from which three other sides are likely to progress to the World Cup.

This is good news for the ICC's European Development Officer, Nigel Laughton, since there is a fair chance that all those places will be taken by three of the European sides, who head for Zimbabwe in April.

Next in the pecking order after Bangladesh and Kenya are reckoned to be Scotland, Ireland, Holland and Denmark, all of whom participate in the NatWest Trophy.

Laughton is one of five worldwide development officers employed by the ICC. Like everyone else at Lord's, he's keen on the implementation of a pyramid system, which ultimately allows any nation a route to a place in the World Cup finals. Before too long he anticipates zonal qualifying leagues for the World Cup, like those in soccer and rugby, rather than one massive meeting of associate members of widely differing ability for the ICC Trophy. The gathering in Toronto in 2001 may be the last of its kind.

Currently the ICC reckon that there are 116 cricket playing countries in the world, which can be divided into four groups: the nine full members; 26 associate members from Argentina to West Africa, where cricket is deemed to be 'firmly established and organised' (they have a vote and a hand-out); 20 affiliate members from Austria to Vanuatu, where cricket is played 'in accordance with the Laws of cricket' (no votes or money); 41 'new territories' from Afghanistan to Yemen, where presumably a bat, a pitch and a flannelled fool have been spotted. (I know, this doesn't add up to 116, but remember the West Indies alone comprise 15 separate nations).

In Europe, Laughton sets up development programmes, arranges translations of cricketing manuals (what is the Dutch for 'reverse sweep'?) and helps to provide well-qualified coaches. And he oversees 12 international tournaments. The European championship, to be held in Scotland in July this year, is the most prestigious. This is for the biggest minnows and there will be a smattering of ex-professionals and sponsored cars around.

Down the line there is the ECC Trophy for the affiliates. Last time this was held in Corfu and some unlikely duels developed. For example sports journalist Ralph Dellor was privileged to coach Austria, a thrill diluted slightly when his side were beaten by the eventual winners, Greece, who were coached by his son, Tim. This weekend Austria may be seeking some sort of revenge under a roof in a small town in Spain.

webTitle: No nous, no credentials, no credibility

fields.headline: No nous, no credentials, no credibility
fields.trailText: 'Designer managers' rarely succeed in their first appointment. Someone - and the name of Kenny Dalglish springs to mind - really should have saved such a good man from himself.
fields.body:
'Designer managers,' Dave Bassett once described them as. They are the players with big names and reputations who walk into jobs with major clubs before they have paid their dues, then flounder as their lack of experience and credentials are exposed. John Barnes is the latest example. Someone - and the name of Kenny Dalglish springs to mind - really should have saved such a good man from himself.

It is strange how hard-headed businessmen go all star-struck when they take over football clubs. Imagine a board meeting in the modern commercial world where the chairman tries to convince fellow directors that although the person doesn't have the appropriate qualifications and experience, his jib is cut rather impressively. For all its apparent trendiness, the British game can be stuck in the post-War establishment culture sometimes.

Only in these isles, too. While the top nations have always treated coaching as both an art and a science, and shown their respect for the profession by insist ing on proper training, Britain has largely treated it as a jobs-for-the-boys sideline, unnecessary if you've got good enough players. The manager's the bloke, with his successful playing career and ability to attract and motivate players.

Gradually it changes. Uefa are introducing licences that will be compulsory if players are to become coaches and get the top jobs though you can bet the game here will be dragged kicking and screaming into the system. The case of Barnes's contemporary, David Platt, is significant.

The former England captain was drummed out of Sampdoria, having tried his best to learn the job by spending nearly a year studying the methods of top European clubs, because he was not properly qualified. He was readily taken on by Nottingham Forest, though, where the board are under duress to inflict on him the Barnes fate.

In his defence, Platt has pointed to the success of his great friend Gianluca Vialli, who would never have been allowed to take on the player-manager's job at Juventus. Chelsea seem to be happy to be used as the Italian's apprenticeship for a position in his homeland. It is, though, rather easier to attract the top players to the best area of real estate in Europe, especially when up to £40,000 a week is on offer. Ruud Gullit found managerial life quite different in Newcastle.

One can hardly blame Barnes or Platt for wanting to start somewhere near the top. They might point out that the history of the game is littered with the sacked souls of great players frustrated at working with journeymen not fit to lace their boots and forced to endure the tight purse strings and petty politics of the lower divisions. Bobby Moore at Southend was one such.

But someone should also point out to the big names how important it has been for the very best of managers to survive such ordeals. Take Bill Shankly at Workington and Huddersfield among others, Alex Ferguson at East Stirling, George Graham - from whom Leeds United's David O'Leary spent time learning - at Millwall, Brian Clough at Hartlepool. Celtic's own glorious past should have told them something. Their greatest manager, Jock Stein, returned to them from Hibs via Dunfermline, to where he had gone to make the transition from junior coach to a manager.

Barnes, to be fair to him, apparently sensed as much last summer when he expressed an interest in the Wigan Athletic job. Kenny Dalglish did not in inviting him up to Glasgow. One problem has been that Dalglish was an exception to any rule about learning lower down, taking over Liverpool successfully from Bob Paisley when still a player. He had the boot room dynasty with him to smooth the path, however. Barnes was taking over a club still in need of repair unlike Dalgish 15 years ago.

There will be probably be little sympathy for Barnes, whose wealth will benefit by a £1 million pay-off, though no matter the money it always hurts when professional pride is stung. The problem for the game could be that a promising manager and coach is lost to TV work before he has even begun to return what he has learnt - and at times, his Celtic team did show some delightful touches.

Graham Taylor sympathises with his old Watford protégé but points out: 'The days have gone now where players go into management and are prepared to serve an apprenticeship. I served a five-year apprenticeship at Lincoln before I came to Watford first time around. I'm afraid these days that a lot of the bigger name players, who are on so much money, are not prepared to serve an apprenticeship.'

Taylor was speaking on the official website of the League Managers' Association, who have begun to recognise the problem of inexperienced, under- qualified managers. 'We believe it's almost impossible to succeed in a first appointment. They haven't got a clue,' says spokesman Olaf Dixon. 'The task for the LMA is to better prepare them.'

So far, apart from coaching badges, there have been such things as three or four-day summer introductory courses on management run by the PFA. They are now joining with the LMA to begin non-residential courses at the universities of Greenwich and East Lancs for professionals who want to move into management. Along with the Uefa licences, it is a start.

Of course, knowledge and character rather than paper qualifications will always be part of any successful manager's armoury - perhaps his key assets. Shankly, Ferguson et al show, however, that while much of that may be instinctive it can still be built. Gerard Houllier and Arsène Wenger also illustrate how beneficial it can be to look beyond the star domestic names to the well qualified elsewhere.

Even in these instant-gratification days that football so closely mirrors, it would seem, in fact, that the lesson of the greats - and being a great club Celtic should know it - is that humility and patience can pay, both for club and serious, rather than designer, manager.

webTitle: Sounds familiar: Celtic stars lacking bottle and class

fields.headline: Sounds familiar: Celtic stars lacking bottle and class
fields.trailText: Former managers of Celtic Liam Brady and Lou Macari believe trying to make up ground lost by poor club policy in the years gone by makes it difficult for any manager and John Barnes should have been given more time
fields.body:
Liam Brady

Celtic, from my experience, never moved with the times. As soon as Rangers decided they were going into the Big League Celtic were caught cold. They were lagging when the Taylor Report came out and are still playing catch-up. Trying to make up ground lost by poor club policy in the years gone by makes it difficult for any manager.

When I was there it was a complicated time off the field but in the past few years the club's infrastructure has been turned round. They have good people in charge and sound financial stability as well as a tremendous stadium and support. The root of their problems at the moment is simply down to the quality of their players.

Unless they correct that, the manager is always going to have problems. Celtic are not shopping in the same class of supermarket as Rangers, who have top-quality international players from top-quality countries - Germans, Dutch, Italians. Celtic are not buying from that end of the market. It was the same for me when I was there, looking for bargains who could do a good job for us. The statistics tell you those players are very difficult to find.

The youth ploicy has to improve in tandem so that in the long-term they don't have to go to the transfer market all the time. Their identity is not a team full of foreign players, and although Scottish players are not in the same abundance as they used to be, they are out there.

Those are the targets they need to aim for. But in my experience, and I think John Barnes felt the same pressure, Celtic supporters want it yesterday and not tomorrow.

It's a unique club with unique circumstances; a wealth of managerial experience doesn't give you any insight into what that job is all about. You are not only running a football team, you are almost the leader of a community in Scotland. And if the rival community fares much better they make the other suffer tremendously. It's hard for Celtic supporters to stomach what they are going through and the man they look to blame is the manager.

We didn't win the league in my first two years, and going into my third it didn't look likely the team were going to challenge Rangers. John has had even more pressure: as well as Rangers being so many points clear they've had the tremendous jolt of this Inverness Caledonian Thistle defeat. I hoped there wouldn't be a knee-jerk reaction - only a month ago John won manager of the month. I empathise with him very much.

Liam Brady was manager of Celtic from July 1991 to October 1993.

Lou Macari

All managers experience embarrassing results - my own worst one as Celtic manager was a home defeat by Motherwell. They were also in the Premier League, but at the time it was looked upon as a disaster.

I also remember playing for Celtic in the Scottish Cup Final, with Kenny Dalglish, and us losing to Partick Thistle. By any standards, though, losing at home to Inverness Caley has to be the worst Celtic result ever. We should not hide from that fact.

Even so, my own view about John Barnes is that he should have been given a fair amount of time. Unfortunately for me, I was only Celtic manager for about six months before Fergus McCann came in, got rid of the board who appointed me and obviously wanted rid of me as well. That I could understand. In Barnes's case, the people who are running the club now were the people who appointed him - and with less than a season in the post he should have been given the benefit of the doubt and a chance to see if he could improve Celtic's results.

The expectations at a club like Celtic are remarkable, although to be quite honest, I did not feel I was under a great deal of pressure there. The problem I had was that there were one or two players - who shall remain nameless - who were not 100 per cent committed to Celtic Football Club. That caused disruption.

I was reminded of that by the reports of what happened in the Celtic dressing-room at half-time on Tuesday (the clashes involving John Barnes and Eric Black with Jonathan Gould and Mark Viduka). It is difficult to avoid the impression that there is trouble in the camp.

No disrespect to Inverness Caley, but even on a bad night, and no matter what team Celtic put out, I cannot see how they can lose to a side like that if the players are giving their all and pulling in the right direction. So the finger should be pointed not so much in the direction of John Barnes, but the players.

Jock Stein was manager when I was a Celtic player, and because we relied on him for our livelihoods, he was very much in the driving seat. Some players were wary about even talking to him, let alone answering back. It is different now. Players are earning fortunes and have become a law unto themselves.

The additional problem for a club like Celtic is the number of foreign players there. How can you expect them to have any real appreciation of the culture of the club?

Talk to them about the importance of going out and playing for the green-and-white hooped jersey and - well, in most cases - it just does not register.

Lou Macari was manager of Celtic from November 1993 to June 1994.

webTitle: Fan power blows away old order

fields.headline: Fan power blows away old order
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons It seems beyond coincidence that John Barnes' sacking should come within 24 hours of a meeting between Parkhead's chief executive and the executive committee of the Celtic Supporters Association.
fields.body:
With around 60,000 counsellors in the stands at every home match, Celtic Football Club in times of trouble never, have far to look for advice. Those arbitrators are unlikely ever to be coordinated into one voice with a common point of view, but events of the past eight days indicate that, for the first time in 112 years, their exhortations may be having a significant influence on policy.

It seems to be not merely coincidental that the decision to sack John Barnes after only 29 games in charge should be taken within 24 hours of a meeting between Parkhead's chief executive, Allan MacDonald, and the executive committee of the Celtic Supporters Association.

The fans' representatives quite baldly insisted that MacDonald remove Barnes in the wake of appallingly feeble performances against Hearts and Inverness Caledonian Thistle; that was hardly unexpected and seems not enough in itself to have pushed MacDonald and the plc board towards the ultimate sanction against Barnes and his coaches, Eric Black and Terry McDermott.

Supporters, after all, have been bad-mouthing directors and calling for managers' heads everywhere for a century. One newspaper claimed on Friday - and there is no reason to doubt its veracity - that the supporters association had initially threatened to include in their press release a condemnation of MacDonald himself and the directors, holding them as culpable as Barnes for the shocking condition of the team.

It was said that MacDonald deflected them from this course with assurances that the matter would be swiftly dealt with. Even the alleged threats, however, would not in themselves be sufficient to force the chief executive and his board to dismiss the coaching staff.

What seemed of primary significance about that meeting last Wednesday was the fact that a Celtic chief executive should in the first place allow a supporters' delegation through the door for talks and, in the second, that he should spend three-and-a-half hours in their company.

That was surely unprecedented in the circumstances and was indicative of the seriousness with which MacDonald was treating the fans' disenchantment. This is easily understood; whatever troubles were occupying his thoughts, MacDonald is too astute to overlook the fact that those demanding an audience represented the club's largest group of shareholders.

The dispersal of the former owner/managing director Fergus McCann's shares last year left the supporters with a hugely significant 45 per cent of the equity.

McCann's intention from the moment of his takeover in 1994 had been to broaden the shareholders' base so that no individual or consortium would have overall control. In his first share issue in 1995, he persuaded 10,000 supporters to buy stock.

When he sold off his 50.3 per cent holding last November, the number of supporter/shareholders rose to around 17,000. Of possibly even greater significance is what is likely to happen on 30 June next year, when 18.5 million preference (non-voting) shares are due to be converted to ordinary (voting) shares.

Added to the existing 29 million ordinary shares, these will comprise just under 40 per cent of the equity. It is known that, at present, major players such as Dermot Desmond and financial institutions own just under 11 million preference shares. Because of transactions that may have taken place over the years, it is difficult to compute exactly how many of the remaining 7.5 million are in the hands of supporters. But it is reasonable to speculate that there could be enough to give them a controlling interest.

The likelihood of that number of supporters ever voting in unison over club policy seems remote. In any case, financial heavyweights on the plc board such as Desmond, Brian Quinn, Sir Patrick Sheehy and the non-executive chairman, Frank O'Callaghan, would quickly walk away if they were not allowed to direct.

Even so, the potential for the ultimate demonstration in fan power exists and Celtic supporters now have a more powerful voice than their counterparts at any British club of comparable stature. Of course, that voice will utter only sweet nothings if the team can be restored to dominance of the Scottish game.

There remain grave reservations about the commitment and the capabilities of Kenny Dalglish, who is to take charge until a successor to Barnes is appointed. Whatever credit Dalglish deposited in the Celtic supporters' bank as an incomparable player has been overdrawn.

For all that, Dalglish at the moment appears the most plausible candidate on the platform to reinvigorate a team whose morale has been lowered to the point of disappearance. Of all the noises heard in the aftermath of Barnes's departure, the most encouraging for Celtic supporters would be the swingeing indictment of the current players spoken by Dalglish on Thursday evening.

It was the first time in years that a Celtic manager had demonstrated the kind of willingness to light fires under gold-bricking players that is imperative in anyone assuming the most demanding job in the British game. The most discouraging sound the fans would hear came from the same man. It was Dalglish's stated intention to help the club find a new head coach as soon as possible. His reluctance to re-enter the the world of everyday team management seems not to have been diluted by his club's plight.

This has caused fans to ask perfectly legitimate questions about whether his concern is genuine. Dalglish has the credentials to make a telling difference at Celtic Park - and, not yet 49, it seems ridiculous that he should already have lost enthusiasm for the challenge.

Perhaps the most decisive action MacDonald and his board could take should be to inform Dalglish that, if he does wish to remain with Celtic, it will not be as director of football, but as head coach.

webTitle: Dalglish stamps his imprint on Celtic

fields.headline: Dalglish stamps his imprint on Celtic
fields.standfirst: Tactical changes reap rewards as three second-half goals sink Dundee and give comfort to beleaguered Bhoys
fields.trailText: Dundee 0 - 3 Celtic
fields.body:
A bizarre match in which the result seemed to be of less interest than signs of Kenny Dalglish's imprint on a distressed Celtic brought succour and points to a Parkhead support who had travelled through hail, rain and snow in the search.

Ultimately comfortable, the victory may have been more of a landmark than the points which went into the ledger. Demonstrating his insistence on being recognised as the most powerful authority in the Celtic dressing-room, Dalglish rejected the whip in favour of the cat o' nine tails. It covered six of the demoralised 11 who had succumbed to Inverness Caledonian Thistle on Tuesday.

Jonathan Gould, Regi Blinker, Eyal Berkovic, Olivier Tebily, Colin Healy and Mark Burchill all felt the sting of the lash, either demoted to the substitutes' bench or told not to bother showing up for work.

But the deepest significance of Dalglish's reformation resided in the tactical overhaul and re-deployment of certain figures which clearly gave Celtic a more solid look in midfield.

Famous for placing the first emphasis on defensive strength, Dalglish introduced Alan Stubbs, a central defender, to a middle position ahead of the three-man defence of Vidar Riseth, Johan Mjallby and Tom Boyd.

Stubbs was complemented by the tall, powerful Morten Wieghorst, restored after an eight-week absence in which he had a cartilage operation.

With this pair filling the hole which Hearts and Inverness CT had driven through in numbers, there was an immediate strengthening to Celtic's resistance. There was, too, a sense of urgency about the challenges on an eager and often threatening Dundee.

Previously victims of a dangerous habit - nonchalantly allowing opponents to gather the ball and turn into space - the Celtic defenders appeared to be under new instructions as their tackling was made almost before an opposite number could gather the ball.

Dalglish's 3-5-2 formation, too, allowed an extra striker, Ian Wright, to accompany Mark Viduka, who in recent weeks had been suffering from isolation.

There was not a great deal of improvement until the goals arrived, though. Dundee should have led early when Willie Falconer, unattended just six yards from goal, hastily stabbed the ball wide.

If Celtic spent most of the time failing to present real menace to goalkeeper Robert Douglas, they did come close through Stephane Mahe, whose vicious, dipping, 25-yard drive to the left of Douglas was pushed wide.

The goals that secured the points were, curiously, very easily gained. The first came when Lubomir Moravcik's centre from the left was helped on by Mahe, whose gentle loft on the ball acted as a deflection and allowed Mjallby to move between defenders and head home from three yards.

Dundee had no time to regroup before Viduka produced the second by running along the 18-yard line from the left and sending the ball low and slow to the left of Douglas. Healy then scored his first for the club with his first touch, having replaced Moravcik seconds before. Healy calmly chipped from 35 yards into the unprotected net after the ball had bounced off Douglas following a chase with Viduka.

fields.headline: Kidd 'return' talks
fields.trailText: Brian Kidd has been sounded out about a surprise return to Manchester United, writes Brendan Pittaway. Kidd has been out of football since being sacked as manager of Blackburn in November, but according to a source inside Old Trafford he has been courted by chairman Martin Edwards, who is thought to want Kidd back as United's director of football.
fields.body:
Brian Kidd has been sounded out about a surprise return to Manchester United, writes Brendan Pittaway. Kidd has been out of football since being sacked as manager of Blackburn in November, but according to a source inside Old Trafford he has been courted by chairman Martin Edwards, who is thought to want Kidd back as United's director of football.

No changes are imminent, but it appears United want Kidd for the role that had been earmarked for manager Sir Alex Ferguson when he retires in 18 months. Ferguson has a lukewarm relationship with Edwards, who is also chief executive of United, and last year he had a public falling-out with Kidd, his former assistant at Old Trafford.

The source said: 'It is felt that while Sir Alex's experience would be an obvious asset, any future manager could feel too intimidated and there would be the temptation for Alex to make his thoughts known if things weren't going too well.'

Kidd has been associated with United since being signed by Sir Matt Busby as a 15-year-old apprentice.

fields.headline: England flunk final test
fields.standfirst: Pollock fires South Africa to series win
fields.trailText: The England cricketers who had promised a fresh dawn achieved only a brave new dusk in their delayed day-night final against South Africa here yesterday.
fields.body:
The England cricketers who had promised a fresh dawn achieved only a brave new dusk in their delayed day-night final against South Africa here yesterday.

Chasing a rather puny- looking 150 to win their first one-day tournament in eight attempts, they were bowled out for 111 in 38 overs and lost by 38 runs. Only a last-wicket stand of 24 carried them past their lowest score in one-day internationals, the 93 they made against Australia in the 1975 World Cup semi-final.

In a match reduced to 45 overs, England had earlier had South Africa in desperate trouble at 21 for five. But their own batting was shattered by Shaun Pollock, who took five for 20 as South Africa made it nine wins from 12 against England in this country.

England's modest target was always more hazardous than it appeared on a pitch that had been sweating under the covers like a malaria patient over the previous few days. For a one-day match, the ball did too much when it was new. The movement was sometimes exaggerated, though given the conditions over the past week it would be harsh to blame the groundstaff for a lack of preparation.

But just when a little class and some character would have carried the day, England betrayed themselves with poor technique and a lack of resolve. When stern questions were asked, they looked bashfully away.

Nasser Hussain is not a natural one-day batsman but targets as small as this suit his intense and determined style. Here, though, he had scored only eight when he played a loose hook shot and was caught behind. Pollock was on his way.

In his next over he had Nick Knight, again caught behind from a poor stroke. The delivery was so wide that the umpire had already signalled it as such before raising his finger. Darren Maddy was then caught at slip in the same over, pushing sheepishly forward; 23 for three and Pollock had taken all the wickets for two runs in nine balls.

In situations such as this Mark Alleyne is hardly the ideal No5, despite his fine performance against the same opposition in East London. He managed only a timid six before pushing diffidently forward for Hansie Cronje to take the catch in the slips.

While all this was going on Graeme Hick, England's champion one-day batsman, was the source of increasingly far-fetched hopes. But when he was fifth out at 45 all realistic optimism disappeared.

Hick appeared happy to walk although there was some suspicion that Jacques Kallis, diving to his right in the slips, grounded the ball as he caught it. With 62 runs from six innings this has been a bad tournament for the Worcestershire batsman.

After that there was nothing. Mark Ealham, playing without conviction, was caught behind and at 72 for seven England were down to their limp tail when Craig White chopped Lance Klusener onto his leg stump.

England had made a sensational start to the match, taking five wickets for seven runs in the space of 21 deliveries. Hussain had won the toss for the first time in the tourna ment and chosen to bowl in the juicy conditions.

It was the bounce as much as the generous seam movement that betrayed South Africa's top order, forcing them to play from the crease. Darren Gough and Andrew Caddick produced an impressive opening burst without hinting at the carnage to come.

In his third over Gough found himself on a hat-trick. First he had Herschelle Gibbs caught at slip by Knight, wafting, and with his next ball he hurried one inside the bat of Kallis, trimming the bails.

In the next over Caddick bowled Neil McKenzie. Again the bounce surprised the opener, who played the ball onto his stumps with his bat handle and gloves. South Africa had lost three wickets with the score on 14.

Caddick burst through twice in his next over. He had Jonty Rhodes caught by the diving Hick at second slip and then extracted enough lift to find the top of Pollock's bat, White taking a fine catch at point.

South Africa were 21 for five in the ninth over and a crowd spoiled by the riches of recent years surprised themselves with their almost reverential quietness.

Cronje's lack of form had placed him under considerable pressure in recent weeks. But most of his runs have been scored at times of crisis and here he guided his side out of intensive care with a stand of 74 in 24 overs with Mark Boucher (36). Cronje clubbed four fours in his 56 from 113 balls, and at one stage jumped out of his crease to swat Ealham over mid-off for six.

When Boucher was sixth out at 95 in the 33rd over, the situation cried out for one of Klusener's famous depth charges. But this time Zulu could not oblige. He scored just 10 from 25 balls and, with wickets continuing to fall, South Africa mustered only 19 runs from their final five overs

Caddick, with four for 19 from nine overs, had produced his best one-day bowling figures. Gough, with three for 18, also made the most of the user-friendly conditions. They could scarcely have imagined that Pollock was to trump their efforts with a truly magnificent spell.

fields.headline: Cap'n Ince sets course
fields.standfirst: Boro to stay up, England must not blood kids too soon and he's ready for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Paul Wilson hears Paul Ince read the runes: Boro to stay up, England must not blood kids too soon and he's ready for Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Paul Ince sounded dangerously like one or two of Middlesbrough's previous big names when he bemoaned the fact the club were being sucked into the relegation battle last week, but the captain insists he was only doing what a captain has to do.

'I was upset after losing to Leicester last week, and perhaps that came across, but I couldn't very well come out and say I wasn't bothered by our recent results, could I?' said Ince. 'We are getting far too close to the relegation zone and we have to face the fact. You do get fed up when you're not winning, and your confidence suffers, which is worse. That's definitely what has happened to us, but it hasn't taken too many bad results to get us into this situation and it won't need too many good ones to get out of it. But we need to make a big push to turn things round.'

Ince suggests injuries and poor results at the same time have sapped morale, although just about every side in the Premiership have lost key players without managing to lose 4-1 at home to Derby and have fans questioning the manager's competence.

'I can understand the frustration,' Ince said. 'The fans are passionate here and if you don't match that passion you can be sure they'll let you know. But I don't think there was any reason to get on Bryan Robson's back. He's brought the club a long way forward. He wants to get into Europe, as we all do, and I honestly think this club could be at that level very soon. We just need to stabilise results and do ourselves justice.

'Maybe we won't make Europe now, maybe we haven't got quite got a strong enough squad, but we can still go forward. Last season we finished ninth. If we can better that this season it will be progress. No one at this club thinks we will be relegated, and no one will be satisfied if all we do is manage to stay up.'

To crack the Premiership elite, Ince reckons, you need either a run of luck with injuries or a squad large enough to give genuine options. Middlesbrough are not quite in the Chelsea or Manchester United league for strength in depth, and are not as practised as Spurs or Leicester at playing the percentages, so they tend to occupy the Premiership middle ground with teams like Aston Villa, Everton or West Ham, an uncertain band where six points can make the difference between comfort and calamity.

Ince's alarm last week, for instance, stemmed from the realisation that Boro had slipped to just one place and two points above Southampton. Yet the same table showed Boro level with Newcastle, generally perceived to be doing well under Bobby Robson, and only six points short of the runaway successes of Villa and Leicester with a game in hand. Three points against Villa tomorrow could make a turning point.

'We just need something to hang on to,' Ince said. 'We played really well for a point at Liverpool and thought we had done the same at Manchester United, but when your luck's out it's out.'

If Boro can survive their annual slump the necessary team-strengthening could be funded by chairman Steve Gibson selling a percentage of his shares to a media company, and as long as the club remain in the Premiership Ince can see only a rosy future.

'We have a great stadium and wonderful training facilities,' said Ince. Fabrizio Ravanelli was famously dismissive of Boro's facilities, but Ince, who has also been around a bit, believes the new Rockcliffe training ground to be the best in England. 'It doesn't quite match the one we had at Inter Milan, which even included a hotel, but this already beats anything I've seen in this country, and the hotel is in the pipeline.'

Next, Ince has his sights fixed firmly on Euro 2000, and the brief sequence of England friendlies commencing with Argentina at Wembley on Wednesday week, for which Kevin Keegan announces his squad on Thursday. At 32, he can no longer take call-ups for granted, but trusts Keegan will stick with his stated policy of valuing experience above birth certificates. The horrendous home defeat by Scotland was hardly a glowing advertisement for England's thirtysomethings, but Ince believes that was a one-off.

'It's always tricky going into matches when you know you don't need to score, and it was hard for us to hit the same tempo we managed to find in Scotland,' he said. 'But at one point everyone was talking about what a mammoth task we faced, then when we qualified we were told it was easy really and we shouldn't have made such hard work of it.

'International football is not as straightforward as it looks, it is a really big step from club level. That's why it would be wrong to pitch young players wholesale into matches, even friendlies. You need to learn from the players around you, you need to be nurtured and allowed to adjust gradually.'

This is not necessarily how other countries do it. The bright young thing on the verge of a first cap this time is Liverpool's Steven Gerrard, who according to his Anfield colleague Dietmar Hamann would be a regular for Germany by now. Ince remembers the clever and competitive Gerrard from his own time at Anfield - 'We used to play the reserves and you could see at once he was going to be a player' - and would not argue against his fast-tracking, as long as he can be brought into a reasonably settled side.

'I've no doubt that Steven Gerrard's time will soon come and probably Joe Cole's too, but you can't just pitch in all the kids - you lose all your experience, and then nobody gets a fair chance.'

Ince believes the old guard will see England right in Holland and Belgium, but then, two caps short of a half century, he would. He is happy playing in the holding position with occasional licence to get forward, despite Sir Alex Ferguson's criticism that he should be more disciplined and positionally aware.

'People like David Batty and me are supposed to be holding players, hard men and all that crap, but we both feel we have a little more to offer than that,' he explained. 'I feel there's more depth to my game than just sitting in front of the back four. In Euro 96, for example, I kept getting complimented on getting into the box and making things happen. You just have to pick your moments, and when you do go forward it's important someone sits in for you at the back. That hasn't always happened, but good players know what to do.'

England have good players, and Ince shares Glenn Hoddle's belief that they could have gone on to far greater things in France 98 but for the never-to-be-forgotten night in St Etienne against next week's opponents.

'When I think of Argentina I still think "Nightmare" [Ince missed a penalty too], but more and more I think what an incredible night. You never know what's going to be your biggest game or your best moment, but I know now I would have hated to miss that experience. The result is history, but that was a real World Cup night.

'I felt so good about the way I was playing, then I missed the penalty. Mind you, I don't think even that was as bad as celebrating Sol Campbell's "goal" and suddenly realising the match was still going on and Argentina had a four-against-three situation against us. What a heartstopper that was.'

England under Keegan, Ince claims, are positively relaxed. 'I think for various reasons we have struggled to show it on the pitch, but the England set-up at the moment is really comfortable and laid-back,' he said. 'Kevin Keegan has lightened it a little, he seems to have this knack of making everyone happy, almost carefree. He came into a difficult situation and got all the lads on his side. He's good at that. Everybody thinks the world of him.'
fields.bodyText: Paul Ince sounded dangerously like one or two of Middlesbrough's previous big names when he bemoaned the fact the club were being sucked into the relegation battle last week, but the captain insists he was only doing what a captain has to do. 'I was upset after losing to Leicester last week, and perhaps that came across, but I couldn't very well come out and say I wasn't bothered by our recent results, could I?' said Ince. 'We are getting far too close to the relegation zone and we have to face the fact. You do get fed up when you're not winning, and your confidence suffers, which is worse. That's definitely what has happened to us, but it hasn't taken too many bad results to get us into this situation and it won't need too many good ones to get out of it. But we need to make a big push to turn things round.' Ince suggests injuries and poor results at the same time have sapped morale, although just about every side in the Premiership have lost key players without managing to lose 4-1 at home to Derby and have fans questioning the manager's competence. 'I can understand the frustration,' Ince said. 'The fans are passionate here and if you don't match that passion you can be sure they'll let you know. But I don't think there was any reason to get on Bryan Robson's back. He's brought the club a long way forward. He wants to get into Europe, as we all do, and I honestly think this club could be at that level very soon. We just need to stabilise results and do ourselves justice. 'Maybe we won't make Europe now, maybe we haven't got quite got a strong enough squad, but we can still go forward. Last season we finished ninth. If we can better that this season it will be progress. No one at this club thinks we will be relegated, and no one will be satisfied if all we do is manage to stay up.' To crack the Premiership elite, Ince reckons, you need either a run of luck with injuries or a squad large enough to give genuine options. Middlesbrough are not quite in the Chelsea or Manchester United league for strength in depth, and are not as practised as Spurs or Leicester at playing the percentages, so they tend to occupy the Premiership middle ground with teams like Aston Villa, Everton or West Ham, an uncertain band where six points can make the difference between comfort and calamity. Ince's alarm last week, for instance, stemmed from the realisation that Boro had slipped to just one place and two points above Southampton. Yet the same table showed Boro level with Newcastle, generally perceived to be doing well under Bobby Robson, and only six points short of the runaway successes of Villa and Leicester with a game in hand. Three points against Villa tomorrow could make a turning point. 'We just need something to hang on to,' Ince said. 'We played really well for a point at Liverpool and thought we had done the same at Manchester United, but when your luck's out it's out.' If Boro can survive their annual slump the necessary team-strengthening could be funded by chairman Steve Gibson selling a percentage of his shares to a media company, and as long as the club remain in the Premiership Ince can see only a rosy future. 'We have a great stadium and wonderful training facilities,' said Ince. Fabrizio Ravanelli was famously dismissive of Boro's facilities, but Ince, who has also been around a bit, believes the new Rockcliffe training ground to be the best in England. 'It doesn't quite match the one we had at Inter Milan, which even included a hotel, but this already beats anything I've seen in this country, and the hotel is in the pipeline.' Next, Ince has his sights fixed firmly on Euro 2000, and the brief sequence of England friendlies commencing with Argentina at Wembley on Wednesday week, for which Kevin Keegan announces his squad on Thursday. At 32, he can no longer take call-ups for granted, but trusts Keegan will stick with his stated policy of valuing experience above birth certificates. The horrendous home defeat by Scotland was hardly a glowing advertisement for England's thirtysomethings, but Ince believes that was a one-off. 'It's always tricky going into matches when you know you don't need to score, and it was hard for us to hit the same tempo we managed to find in Scotland,' he said. 'But at one point everyone was talking about what a mammoth task we faced, then when we qualified we were told it was easy really and we shouldn't have made such hard work of it. 'International football is not as straightforward as it looks, it is a really big step from club level. That's why it would be wrong to pitch young players wholesale into matches, even friendlies. You need to learn from the players around you, you need to be nurtured and allowed to adjust gradually.' This is not necessarily how other countries do it. The bright young thing on the verge of a first cap this time is Liverpool's Steven Gerrard, who according to his Anfield colleague Dietmar Hamann would be a regular for Germany by now. Ince remembers the clever and competitive Gerrard from his own time at Anfield - 'We used to play the reserves and you could see at once he was going to be a player' - and would not argue against his fast-tracking, as long as he can be brought into a reasonably settled side. 'I've no doubt that Steven Gerrard's time will soon come and probably Joe Cole's too, but you can't just pitch in all the kids - you lose all your experience, and then nobody gets a fair chance.' Ince believes the old guard will see England right in Holland and Belgium, but then, two caps short of a half century, he would. He is happy playing in the holding position with occasional licence to get forward, despite Sir Alex Ferguson's criticism that he should be more disciplined and positionally aware. 'People like David Batty and me are supposed to be holding players, hard men and all that crap, but we both feel we have a little more to offer than that,' he explained. 'I feel there's more depth to my game than just sitting in front of the back four. In Euro 96, for example, I kept getting complimented on getting into the box and making things happen. You just have to pick your moments, and when you do go forward it's important someone sits in for you at the back. That hasn't always happened, but good players know what to do.' England have good players, and Ince shares Glenn Hoddle's belief that they could have gone on to far greater things in France 98 but for the never-to-be-forgotten night in St Etienne against next week's opponents. 'When I think of Argentina I still think "Nightmare" [Ince missed a penalty too], but more and more I think what an incredible night. You never know what's going to be your biggest game or your best moment, but I know now I would have hated to miss that experience. The result is history, but that was a real World Cup night. 'I felt so good about the way I was playing, then I missed the penalty. Mind you, I don't think even that was as bad as celebrating Sol Campbell's "goal" and suddenly realising the match was still going on and Argentina had a four-against-three situation against us. What a heartstopper that was.' England under Keegan, Ince claims, are positively relaxed. 'I think for various reasons we have struggled to show it on the pitch, but the England set-up at the moment is really comfortable and laid-back,' he said. webTitle: Why Hussain should carry the can

fields.headline: Why Hussain should carry the can
fields.trailText: We woz robbed! But not by Jacques Kallis, even if the catch he claimed at slip was a swindle. No, England can steal their own thunder quite effectively without any help from the oppo.
fields.body:
We woz robbed! But not by Jacques Kallis, even if the catch he claimed at slip was a swindle. No, England can steal their own thunder quite effectively without any help from the oppo.

Today they proved that they could have lost the Johnannesburg Test even if they had won the toss. And Allan Donald hadn't been playing. And the English fielders had caught everything that moved. This was a masterclass in self-destruction.

No-one can feel more let down than Darren Gough and Andrew Caddick, who took 7 for 37 between them and still finished on the losing side. But what was Nasser Hussain playing at when he took Gough off after he had bowled five overs and brought South Africa to their knees? When Hansie Cronje out-gambles you, by bowling Shaun Pollock straight through and keeping three slips in, you know you must be playing it safe.

The thinking was equally poor when England batted. South Africa had the flimsiest bowling attack they've fielded all winter, with Pollock the only potential matchwinner. Inevitably, he was allowed to win the match. Hussain and Nick Knight, the only bankers in the batting, both went for optimistic swipes when the required run-rate was only three an over.

Sure, you have to take the initiative and try to put the bad ball away, but in the circumstances this was brainless cricket. It puts one in mind of the equivalent match in 1998-99, when England threw away a winning position against Australia in the first Carlton & United final. Hussain, if you remember, triggered a collapse when he gave Shane Warne the charge. He has had an excellent tour as a batsman and a passable one as a captain. But in both those finals, he should carry the can for England's failure.

webTitle: Mad or sad? Colly is an  insecure threat to Leicester

fields.headline: Mad or sad? Colly is an  insecure threat to Leicester
fields.trailText: Alan Smith believes more should have a system whereby players are sent to a psychological specialist to see if they are suitable for their needs and will 'fit in'.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's state of mind has been the subject of great debate over the past year or so, and it amazes me that more clubs do not follow our lead at Fulham and check out a player's mental as well as physical health before they sign them.

We have a system whereby players are sent to a psychological specialist, basically to see if they are suitable for our needs and will 'fit in'.

It is the sort of thing that is commonplace among big companies in other industries, yet football clubs had never taken it on and no others do it as far as I know.

It started here when we had a problem with a young player who had been with us for a year. We sent him to the occupational health expert employed by Harrods and he discovered that the boy simply could not cope with living in London because he came from a rural part of Ireland. We had to let him go, and it ended up costing us a fair amount of money.

Nothing like the huge loss Aston Villa will have incurred in transferring Collymore to Leicester last week, though, but John Gregory obviously feels there is nothing more he can do with the player.

I know what it is like. When I was Steve Coppell's assistant at Crystal Palace, we signed Stan from Stafford Rangers. Even then, his ability with the ball was never in doubt but there was a question about his attitude, which had lingered from his time as an apprentice at Wolves.

We did not regard it as a great gamble because he cost us only £100,000 and we were paying him just £120 per week. He was also only 19 and there are plenty of other kids of that age who have attitude problems. But with Stan it was different. You could see it even at Stafford, where he would let his head drop during games, and it didn't get any better at Palace.

He couldn't cope with the dressing room banter, especially from some of the sharp-witted Londoners who were quick to take the mickey out of him.

Views about Stan tend to be polarised, that he is either an ultra-sensitive soul who needs love and affection, or that he is simply mad. I would suggest that the truth is somewhere in between, and part of the problem is that he is insecure and not too bright.

I found that if you put a comforting arm around his shoulder he would be fine, but you cannot do that all the time. He could be exasperating, too. We once sent him on loan to Swansea and he returned three hours later complaining that he could not find the place.

On another occasion, I was trying to motivate him for a reserve team friendly at Slough by comparing it to a big cup game, whereupon he told me that he didn't think he would be able to play because he had appeared in the same competition for Stafford Rangers!

Sometimes it wasn't so amusing. Wally Downes, one of our coaches, was never short of a word and accused Stan after one game of not trying, which led to an almighty fight. Stan just couldn't cope with criticism.

The final straw came in a match against Arsenal at Highbury, where Steve Coppell gave him a chance to prove himself. When Stan indicated he wanted to come off after only 15 minutes, Steve turned to me and said: 'That's it - let's cut our losses.'

We eventually got our money back when we sold him to Southend almost two years later. Since then, a number of managers have tried to change him, just like a succession of blondes have thought they could change Rod Stewart, for example.

It will be fascinating to see how Martin O'Neill handles him at Leicester, because they are both unpredictable, moody characters. Leicester are renowned for their great team spirit, and I would worry about the effect Stan might have on them.

Like most managers, I tended to avoid signing certain players if others told me it would be risky in that respect, although there were exceptions. At Palace, I took Paul Stewart on loan from Liverpool against advice. People said he would be trouble, that he was arrogant and disruptive, but perversely his arrival gave my young team an extra dimension and he helped us win the First Division title. He was also very popular with the other players, which is an area where Stan has had a big problem throughout his career.

I wish Stan well, and I hope he gets his career back on track. But he is not a teenager any more and must know that only he can sort himself out, both on and off the pitch.

webTitle: £1m for whole team but I'm not smug

fields.headline: £1m for whole team but I'm not smug
fields.trailText: All clubs make mistakes in their buying of players, but when one looks at cases like that of Stan Collymore, any manager would need to be made of stone not to break out in a cold sweat.
fields.body:
All clubs make mistakes in their buying of players, but when one looks at cases like that of Stan Collymore, any manager would need to be made of stone not to break out in a cold sweat.

On the basis that the most embarrassing boobs are those where the players concerned not only fail to produce the form expected of them, but have to be sold on at a huge loss, it has taken Manchester City some time to live down their disastrous Seventies signing of Steve Daley from Wolves. But City have since found themselves in good company in this department - and never more so than now. To most people, the new leaders of the post-war bad-buy league are Aston Villa, who bought Collymore for a club record fee of £7 million in May 1997, but last week transferred him to Leicester in a deal which will bring them no more than £500,000. To add insult to injury, it has been pointed out that if one takes his reported £20,000 a week wages into account, each of the 15 goals he scored for them (in just 61 first-team appearances) cost them £600,000.

However, no manager or club chairman can afford to gloat over this, nor any of the other recent transfer deals that have gone wrong. I think my transfer-market record at Coventry has been quite good. Not all the players I have signed have done well enough here to bring us a profit on the deals, but any money that we have lost can hardly be described as a fortune - at least in relation to a number of cases elsewhere - and my overall trading picture is far from scary. As far as the transfer market fees are concerned, the process of getting the team Coventry have now has cost us little more than £1m.

At this stage, one of the signings of which I am particularly proud is that of Robbie Keane, whom we bought from Wolves for a club record fee of £6m. My only reservation about Robbie concerned his ability to adjust to the Premiership, but that doubt was swept away in his opening matches for us. Initially, many felt that £6m was far too much to pay for someone so young, especially as Sir Alex Ferguson had only been prepared to pay £500,000 for him. But now, Robbie is being looked upon as a bargain.

I cannot boast about any of this, though. Far from applauding my shrewdness as a wheeler-dealer, I prefer to hold my hands up and admit that I have been lucky. When I look at the problems that new players have brought other managers and clubs, my reaction is: 'There but for the grace of God...'

All transfer deals inevitably carry an element of risk, not least because of the obvious problems of players adjusting to a different environment, injuries and managerial changes. In the latter respect, it is hardly unusual for a player signed by one manager to be viewed in a different light by his successor. At Tottenham, for example, two of the foreign players signed by Christian Gross - Moussa Saib and Paolo Tramezzani - have both struggled to get into the team under George Graham, Tramezzani, who was bought for £1.4m two years ago and made just six appearances, has recently had his contract terminated and Said is on loan in Saudi Arabia.

There can be little doubt that the trend of foreign players in England has caused that transfer risk factor to become more pronounced than ever. Most of them have the skill to make an impact in England, but one is on more dangerous ground when it comes to temperament and personality. For obvious reasons, the homework a manager can do on a prospective foreign signing is relatively limited.

I still remember the Belgian defender Regis Genaux, who was brought to Coventry from Standard Liege by my predecessor Ron Atkinson in August 1996. He seemed an excellent signing and technically he was tremendous. But, because of the influence of his girlfriend - who apparently had wanted him to go to Italy - our off-field dealings with him were difficult to say the least. Within a few weeks of my becoming player-manager, he was sold to Udinese, fortunately for the £750,000 we had paid for him.

Not that I am suggesting that managers can only be let down by foreign signings. British players, too, can land you in the mire. I think most managers would agree that the present generation of players - fortunate to be earning their living at a time when the quest for success at club level has reached the level of desperation - have greater power than their predecessors, and require more careful handling.

In the old days - before the explosion in wages and the Bosman ruling - one could be reasonably sure that any clash between manager and player would be kept from the public, and an apology on either side would be enough for the affair to be quickly forgotten. This is not the case today. If one speaks to a player in a manner he does not like, it no longer comes as a surprise for him to 'down tools' and force his club to let him go.

It is easy to state that every club should stand firm in this situation. But the reality of it is that, because of the contracts that some of these players are on, a transfer deal that will enable them at least to cut their losses is by far the most sensible option.

Of course, the blame for some transfer mistakes must be laid entirely at the manager's doors. However, I cannot stress enough that, no matter how many times one might have watched a player beforehand - or how many people with whom one might have discussed him - you can never discount the possibility of ending up with egg on your face.

Personally, I think that one can watch a prospective signing too much. It is asking the impossible of any player to shine on every occasion you see him in action but it is amazing how easily one below-par performance can cause you to change your mind about him. Still, I know one person who will not worry about my being over-cautious: my chairman.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText:
Graham 'notorious' - Davis
Paul Davis - former Arsenal hero, now youth team coach - has revealed how George Graham banned players from using agents at Highbury during his years in charge - at the same time as taking huge backhanders from Norwegian agent Rune Hauge.
fields.body:
Graham 'notorious' - Davis
Paul Davis - former Arsenal hero, now youth team coach - has revealed how George Graham banned players from using agents at Highbury during his years in charge - at the same time as taking huge backhanders from Norwegian agent Rune Hauge.

Davis, in a strong attack on Graham ahead of today's game with Liverpool, also criticised his former manager for driving out senior players and alienating young Andy Cole. Arsène Wenger, though, is commended for being, by way of contrast, 'nice'.

'The influence of reputable agents, on the whole, is good for players now,' says Davis. 'But back then Graham would say: "No I'm not talking to any agents." He would allow a parent to sit in on meetings, but they were never the best people to represent the player. It happened a lot.

'Arsenal players at the time took things they didn't like passively. Because I was a senior player and not content and voiced my opinion he eased me out. The other seniors were people like Steve Williams, Charlie Nicholas, Graham Rix and Kenny Sansom. George moved them on very quickly and I was the only one who stayed.'

The same approach also led to Graham releasing Andy Cole to Bristol City. 'I tried to encourage Andy to stay but he didn't get on with management. He was quiet and single-minded and that lack of communication didn't help the situation. He had a personality clash with Graham and had it been a different manager, like Wenger, he might have stayed.'

Davis also says Wenger was not serious when he conceded the title to Manchester United last weekend. 'Wenger is nice and expresses himself in a quiet, articulate way. He was only kidding - he likes playing mind games.

'Arsenal are still capable of winning it, especially if we beat Liverpool [today]. Of course, it's up to United to keep dropping points, but it's far, far from over.'

The icon, his wife and the director Scandal at 1860 Munich. Davis, in a strong attack on Graham ahead of today's game with Liverpool, also criticised his former manager for driving out senior players and alienating young Andy Cole. fields.headline: Dispute clouds Cameroon win
fields.trailText: Cameroon became the champions of Africa for the third time yesterday with a dramatic penalty shoot-out victory over the hosts Nigeria.
fields.body:
Cameroon became the champions of Africa for the third time yesterday with a dramatic penalty shoot-out victory over the hosts Nigeria.

The 4-3 win, after the match had finished 2-2 following extra-time, was steeped in controversy after Victor Ikpeba's fourth penalty for Nigeria was not awarded by the Tunisian referee Mourad Daami despite appearing to cross the line after hitting the underside of the crossbar.

Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu had earlier seen his penalty, Nigeria's third, saved by Boukar Alioum.

After Marc-Vivien Foé of West Ham had spurned the first chance to win the game for Cameroon, placing his penalty wide of the post, Liverpool's Rigobert Song held his nerve to seal victory.

Nigeria had recovered from two goals down to force the game into extra-time. Samuel Oto'o silenced the 40,000 fans at the Surulere Stadium with a superbly taken goal in the 27th minute. The Real Madrid teenager controlled a quick free-kick before turning past Furo Iyenemi and firing a shot into the far corner.

Cameroon quickly doubled the lead when Nigeria's goalkeeper Ike Sharunmu let a shot from Patrick Mboma squirm through his legs.

Twice Cameroon spurned chances to put the result beyond doubt. Oto'o hit a shot at the legs of a defender after Sharunmu stumbled outside his penalty area, before Mboma's 41st-minute header struck a post.

The hosts scored a desperately needed goal just before half-time when Chukwu Ndukwe made the most of poor Cameroon marking to finish from close range. Then Jay-Jay Okocha marked his return to the team after a one-match suspension with a stunning 25-yard shot to make it 2-2 within 90 seconds of the restart.

Cameroon had beaten Nigeria in the African Nations Cup finals of 1984 and 1988 but they squandered several more chances to seal a comfortable victory this time, with Eto'o especially unlucky to see a 51st-minute shot bounce back off the post.

"All credit to the players because they could have easily lost faith after Nigeria made it 2-2," said Cameroon's coach Pierre Lechantre. "But they came out fighting and showed how determined they were to win this cup."

Nigeria, unbeaten at home for 19 years and defending an 11-match unbeaten run in the tournament, took the game to Cameroon in extra-time, Babangida and Ikpeba both coming close to scoring as penalties loomed. But they could not put an end to Cameroon's jinx over Nigeria.

Meanwhile South Africa's Mark Fish announced his retirement from international football after South Africa's 2-1 victory over Tunisia in the third-place play-off, citing distaste for the South African federation as the reason for his decision. The Bolton defender, who has 58 caps, said he was unhappy with the treatment of the coaching staff and the way football is run in South Africa.

Nigeria (4-4-2): Shorunmu; Okpara, Iyenemi, West, Babayaro; Oliseh, Adepoju (Ikpeba, 96min), Okocha, George (Babangida, 70); Kanu, Chukwu (Aghahowa, h-t).

Cameroon (3-5-2): Alioum; Song, Kalla (Mettomo, 93), Njanka; Foé, Wome, Njitap, Mayer, Olembe; Mboma, Eto'o (Job, 72).

Referee: M Daami (Tunisia).

fields.headline: Explain... goal celebrations
fields.trailText: Football has come a long way in a short amount of time, but the goal celebration has, from nothing, become an artform in just a few years. Originally the over-emotional outburst were treated with disdain by the authorities. 'Kissing and cuddling should be stopped and players continuing to act in this way should be charged with bringing the game into disrepute,' proclaimed the Football League in 1975. In 1982 Fifa got in on the act, stating that the 'exuberant outbursts of several players at once jumping on top of each other, kissing and embracing, should be banned from the football pitch'.
fields.body:
Football has come a long way in a short amount of time, but the goal celebration has, from nothing, become an artform in just a few years. Originally the over-emotional outburst were treated with disdain by the authorities. 'Kissing and cuddling should be stopped and players continuing to act in this way should be charged with bringing the game into disrepute,' proclaimed the Football League in 1975. In 1982 Fifa got in on the act, stating that the 'exuberant outbursts of several players at once jumping on top of each other, kissing and embracing, should be banned from the football pitch'.

It didn't work. Players liked kissing each other so much that no amount of official declarations were going to stop them. In 1996 Fifa were forced to back down, revising their rules to allow 'reasonable celebration' but warning that 'choreographed celebrations' were not to be encouraged. It didn't stop anyone, although the taking-off-the-shirt trick swiftly became unpopular.

Celebrations really came of age at the 1990 World Cup, where Roger Milla's grinding hips, an expression of joy which would today be considered restrained, inspired argument the world over. Professional footballers, used to a life of quiet backslapping and the odd high-five, watched and learned.

Four years later the World Cup brought us Bebeto's 'rocking cradle', Maradona's 'run to TV camera like a crazed animal on drugs' and Yekini's 'arms through net'. The celebration had arrived.

According to Fifa regulations, many shouldn't be allowed at all. Any 'gestures which are provocative, derisory or inflammatory', for example, should immediately be punished with a yellow card. Which would have put Mike Reed in a bad position last week, when his delighted, fist-pumping salute at Patrik Berger's thunderbolt against Leeds could be described as any of the above. But then he could hardly give himself a yellow card, could he?

fields.headline: Giving it the Max
fields.standfirst: Fulham's new signing thinks of himself as 'the Johnny Haynes of PR' - in a game that needs him
fields.trailText: Fulham have signed PR guru Max Clifford. Will Buckley hears what he intends to do for Craven Cottage plus views on Glenn Hoddle, Manchester United and the Beckhams.
fields.body:
'I hate public relations.' (Pause) 'I loathe public relations.' (Pause) 'I detest public relations.' In such a way did Matthew Parris introduce a programme entitled Bad Ideas of the Twentieth Century. He had a point. It is hard not to sigh when the phone rings and a public relations executive - and however junior they're always executives - spouts away down the other end. They make a living, in the main, by peddling the blindingly obvious. And you have to pretend to be interested, sometimes fascinated, in what they have to say. It's very tiring. Little wonder Matthew Parris found it so hard to keep his loathing under control.

But then there's Max Clifford. He has been called 'a sewer' by the Daily Telegraph's Janet Daley, 'that little turd' by Edwina Currie, 'a sleazeball's sleazeball' by David Mellor who, even by his amazing standards, pompously wrote about Clifford, 'I should recall some sage advice I was given at the Foreign Office - never get into a pissing competition with a skunk.' A PR receiving bad PR - that's more interesting. Except, of course, to be slagged off by a bunch of Tories has for a while been excellent, gold-plated, top-of-the-range publicity. Certainly more than sufficient to outweigh any qualms raised by his association with clients such as OJ Simpson.

We meet at his home in Walton-on-Thames. It is on a salubrious estate but is not at all flash or glitzy. All the pictures are of Max with his family. There isn't one of him with a celebrity. For someone in his field this is remarkable. They usually define themselves by their clients and fill their walls with pictures of their shoulders rubbing against those of their celebrated pals. The only famous name and telephone number on Clifford's walls is Mr Blair.... and he's the local plumber.

Clifford has recently been appointed by his old mucker Mohamed Al-Fayed - 'We get on so well because we beat them at their own game' - to 'get involved in a media capacity' with Fulham. 'Football has changed so much, and the media impact on the game has become greater. It's common sense to bring in someone who knows the field.' But don't Fulham already have a good image? 'Yes, they're many people's second favourite club. But with success the picture becomes different and Mo is hoping they will be one of the most successful clubs in the country.'

Clifford used to support Fulham as a boy. His hero was Johnny Haynes and in more fanciful moments he compares his PR work to Haynes's midfield work - creating something out of nothing, splitting the defence with a pass, and allowing someone else to score a goal. At about the same time, he started his PR career by playing water-polo and then being paid for writing up his own exploits in match-reports for the local paper. He might have become a journalist but, by his own estimation, wasn't cynical enough.

Instead it was public relations. In his early career at EMI Clifford represented the Beatles before they were famous and later many others - Antonia de Sancha, Bienvenida Buck et al - who became famous only because of his efforts. His first client was Don Partridge who had one hit with Rosie, presumed to be about his girlfriend but in fact about a transvestite who used to hang around Soho mincing, 'I'm Rosie, chase me.' Don is now on his fifth or sixth marriage, still drops in on the Cliffords out of the blue, and is still touring Scandinavia.

Nearly 30 years on, Clifford is making his football debut. He claims never to have represented a footballer or football manager, not even George Graham, but also claims to possess 'a vivid imagination and an ability to lie with conviction.' Why has it taken so long?

'I was approached by other clubs, but they didn't interest me because the people involved came from a different century. Football has only just started to wake up to the need for PR. The Royal Family only woke up to the fact two years ago and the Tories still haven't worked it out.' While talking to him it soon becomes apparent that if football had been less dozy and Clifford had been approached by various stars then things might have turned out differently for them. Here is how he would have handled some of the major stories of the last year:

Glenn Hoddle: 'I'd have said "Glenn, I know what you mean but if you say it this way you will destroy yourself." Then I'd have tapped into all the disabled groups that he's worked for and got that across. He shouldn't have had to go - although there used to be an arrogance about the way he played and there's an arrogance about the way he comes across.'

United in Rio: 'Manchester United justified their FA Cup exit and the devaluation of that competition by claiming that it was very important PR for the 2006 World Cup bid. When it turns out to be an abysmal PR exercise they can't complain and say we're here to play football. Although, admittedly, Martin Edwards employed his own particular brand of PR to build relations with the local community. Honestly, for Martin Edwards to go to Brazil and then be surprised when he is caught out is unreal.'

United generally: 'It's increasingly obvious that Manchester United have a very resentful relationship with the media. In particular, Alex Ferguson has a hate-hate relationship with the media. This can only lead to aggravation and problems. The problem is that football clubs only understand football. End of story.'

Those Beckhams: 'David Beckham needs protection and he's not getting it. Footballers are the new pop stars and there should be someone doing for him what we did for the Beatles, protecting him and teaching him the media game. By all accounts he's a nice lad, but he has a manager who doesn't help him handle the media and a wife who's a headline-grabber. The more he turns things over inside his head, particularly if he feels he's being unfairly represented all the time, the more likely he is to behave petulantly on the pitch.'

Football generally: It should not be about take, take, take. Forget PR, footballers should want to have a kick-around and visit kids in hospital. The more they put back the better it is for them, the people, the club. The growing problem in the game today is that people and clubs are starting to lose touch with the ordinary people who are the back bone of the game. They need to get more women and more families involved. The FA could and should be doing a lot more. They don't seem to understand the problems and what you have to do.'

This sounds like a pitch for new business but Clifford maintains he doesn't pitch; he waits for clients to come to him. Then it comes down to how much he likes them, whether they will take his advice and whether they trust him. 'The whole art of my business is knowing more about my client than anyone else,' he says. Such an approach is unlikely to attract star footballers. One, because they tend to be distrustful of outsiders. Two, because Clifford, unusually for a PR, doesn't appear to be all that taken with celebrities. He fell out with dour magician David Copperfield because when required to be ceaselessly sycophantic he couldn't resist winding him up. 'The better I got to know him, the less I wanted to.'

His business, which was once about promotion, is now more about protection. The footballers who are likely to come to him are those who are trying to avoid the press rather than plug themselves within it. Perhaps a player who was about to be outed as gay?

'If the story was definitely coming out I'd say to him you've got no choice, we have to make the best of a bad situation. You know that a footballer will get a very difficult time and it will be up to him with your help to try and win over the public. We all know how difficult that will be. We've all stood on the terraces. The thing to do is to try and endear him to the public. Have a sense of humour about it.'

This is a quality markedly absent among those that play for and those that run football clubs. A shame, really, instead of reading about Newcastle board members' taste in prostitutes, we might have enjoyed headlines such as 'Freddie Shepherd ate my hamster'.
