He fell out with dour magician David Copperfield because when required to be ceaselessly sycophantic he couldn't resist winding him up. 'The better I got to know him, the less I wanted to.' His business, which was once about promotion, is now more about protection. The footballers who are likely to come to him are those who are trying to avoid the press rather than plug themselves within it. Perhaps a player who was about to be outed as gay? 'If the story was definitely coming out I'd say to him you've got no choice, we have to make the best of a bad situation. You know that a footballer will get a very difficult time and it will be up to him with your help to try and win over the public. We all know how difficult that will be. We've all stood on the terraces. The thing to do is to try and endear him to the public. Have a sense of humour about it.' This is a quality markedly absent among those that play for and those that run football clubs. A shame, really, instead of reading about Newcastle board members' taste in prostitutes, we might have enjoyed headlines such as 'Freddie Shepherd ate my hamster'.

webTitle: Sky will be pushed to the limit

fields.headline: Sky will be pushed to the limit
fields.trailText: Sky are reported to be planning a bid to retain live Premiership rights that, if it is successful, will leave them so strapped 'they won't really be able to afford much else'.
fields.body:
Sky will make a bid to retain live Premiership rights that, if it is successful, will leave them so strapped 'they won't really be able to afford much else'.

This is the view of a highly placed television source who says the race for the new contract, which starts with the 2001-02 season, has only two serious contenders with NTL, the giant telecommunications and media group, likely to push Sky 'to the very edge'.

The Premiership chairmen, who meet on Thursday, are expected to call for bids to be received before the end of March with a decision on who televises League matches from August 2001 due to be made in June.

So far, only Sky have ever shown Premiership matches live, their initial five-season deal in 1992 having been followed by a four-season one that cost them £670 million. The new deal will be for three, seasons at the most - clubs will not want to commit themselves for any longer given the pace of technological change - and could see television's first £1 billion contract.

If Sky were to lose out it would be a defeat that would fundamentally change their business, live football being responsible for the company's strong financial position. And Rupert Murdoch knows he has a formidable opponent in NTL boss Barclay Knapp, whose £17.5 billion organisation are 'playing for keeps' in trying to win the Premiership deal.

NTL's cable network, which is growing all the time, would provide the platform for showing Premiership matches.

But the collective contract - the one involving all 20 clubs that Sky and NTL are fighting over - for, say, 60 live matches per season will be only half the story. Manchester United, in particular, will be keen to hold back rights to the majority of their games for their own channel.

There is also the question of highlight rights, which the BBC are desperate to retain to keep Match of the Day alive. 'These rights are like the ravens and the Tower for the Beeb' was how it was put to me last week. And they can expect ITV to push them all the way, even if it is just a scam to make them spend all their money.

fields.headline: 'Slaves' on a fortune
fields.standfirst: Many go on to earn thousands a week, but Fifa want to halt exodus of 'under-age' African players
fields.trailText: Fifa want to halt the 'hideous slave trade' that plunders the continent of its brightest hopes with measures that many claim ignore the benefits to Africa of players moving abroad.
fields.body:
Somewhere in northern Malaysia there are 12 teenaged footballers living in one large room and hoping to be selected to play for the local team so that someone will notice them and give them a contract. They are not being paid.

Somewhere in Holland an illegal immigrant is sleeping on the floor of one of the country's top agents, living on no more than expenses and again hoping for a deal at any club that can pay him a decent wage.

And somewhere in Spain there's a footballer who does have a contract, but not the one he thought he was signing, which would have taken him to Real Mallorca. His paperwork ties him for 10 years to a company, not a club, and he has already been moved to two second-division sides he had no interest in playing for. His pay is so poor he has been home to try to coax some money out of the club who sold him.

All these players are from Ghana, and there are hundreds more from other African countries dotted around the world. One of them, a 17-year-old international prospect from Togo, has disappeared altogether after signing up for a Swiss agent. His country wanted him for Olympic duty but no one has heard of him for four months.

All are victims of what the top man in African football calls 'a hideous slave trade' that plunders the continent. It started slowly in the late Eighties when African teams started to excel at the under-17 and under-20 World Cups, and the players are moving ever younger - many of them 15 and 16. Issa Hayatou, president of the Confederation of African Football (CAF), is scathing about agents and the youth academies springing up all over Africa. He backs up his argument by recalling the 1998 Belgian government inquiry into a 'slave trade' scandal in which club directors signed up young players as their personal property from which to make as much profit as possible.

Sepp Blatter, president of Fifa, agrees with Hayatou. 'It's time to fight against the exodus of young players to Europe,' he told The Observer. 'We must create an age barrier before which a player cannot be transferred to another continent.' He promises new regulations by the end of June, after which no player under the age of 18 will be allowed to transfer to Europe. But there will be legal problems with such a ban and there is a flaw in the slave-trade argument - because many of the 'slaves' earn more than £20,000 a week and hundreds are on a six-figure salary.

Roger Milla, Africa's most famous player, is not so forthright. 'Perhaps it's not normal for players to move to Europe when they're 15 or 16, but if you don't get paid in your own league, or you are paid very little, you'll want to move somewhere where you can get rich,' he says. The two main reasons to move early, explains Milla, are the hopeless state of domestic leagues and national FAs that allow clubs to get away with not paying their players on time, or paying less than agreed; and the families. 'A young player in Europe can send money back to his extended family,' says Milla. 'That's very important. It means far more than most Europeans can imagine.'

The point is emphasised outside her home by Gloria Osei Kuffour, the wealthiest grandmother on the Ainet Road in Kumasi, Ghana. Ten years ago she was no better off than any of her neighbours in this busy shopping area; then one of her four children, Samuel, was taken away from her. In 1991 a European agent caused a sensation by selling Samuel and two of his team-mates in Ghana's under-17 team to Torino. There was uproar in Italy because the players were so young.

Gloria remembers it well. 'Was I sad when he went. Sad? No, I was happy. Very, very happy.' But wasn't he a slave? She throws back her head and laughs, loudly. Gloria answers these questions while standing next to her BMW, having recently returned from a trip to Germany, where Samuel now plays for Bayern Munich. 'When Samuel was a young boy he was very good at football and I wanted to help him. I sold our television to pay for some boots, and the other children didn't complain because they wanted to help him too. I always pray to God to help my son become a big man. I helped him... now he can help me.'

Gloria has discussed this with the mother of Tony Yeboah, once a Leeds striker, who left Ghana for Germany when he was a teenager and plays now for Hamburg. Life was hard for Yeboah, who spoke no German or English, but his mother was 'very, very happy too,' said Gloria, a football lover who supports her local club and watches Samuel play for the national team when she can.

Kuffour himself is not sure Fifa are doing the right thing. 'It's every man for himself,' he says. 'I'm very happy with the way things turned out for me. I'm able to look after my family very well, I play for one of the best clubs in the world - I can't complain about anything.'

The other two who signed for Torino have also prospered in Europe. Mohammed Gargo, Kuffour's partner in central defence for Ghana, is earning Serie A money at Udinese - who have half a dozen young Africans in their youth team - and Emmanuel Duah has ended up at Leiria in Portugal. 'They've got no complaints,' said Kuffour.

He is more than happy with the man who did that controversial deal, Domenico Ricci, who is still his agent nearly 10 years later. Ricci's company, African Football Management, is probably the most active in the market - or at least the respectable part of it - and has been the target of much of Hayatou's invective. Ricci, an Italian who is married to a Zairean, has 60 African players in Europe but sees himself as anything but a 'slave trader'.

He laughs off much of the criticism and turns the argument around to blame Fifa and CAF for introducing a 'racist law' themselves - the regulation that requires licensed international player agents to post a bond of 200,000 Swiss francs (about £80,000). His point is a good one when one trawls the official Fifa list of 534 licensed agents. There's one in Egypt, and for the continent of Africa that's it. More than 300 African players in the top division of western Europe's best leagues, many hundreds more at lower levels around the world - and not a single black African agent on their own continent.

Not that that stops Africans doing deals. France and the USA have licensed agents from Africa, and there are unofficial 'local managers' doing deals with the Europeans. In eight days in Ghana I was asked three times if I was an agent, and if I wasn't did I want to have a go anyway and sell players in Europe. Telephone numbers were foisted upon me, and one man almost begged me to extend my stay and take up his offer.

'Sure, there are good agents and bad agents,' says Ricci, 46. 'Some of the unlicensed locals have no real idea how to operate, and some of the Europeans are unreliable too. But it's no good Hayatou and his executive at CAF just blaming the agents for taking money out of the game. If there's an exodus to Europe they should first of all be asking: Why? CAF is hiding behind reality. The young players are leaving because in Africa there's no money, too little competition. They should be working to make the whole structure of African football more professional. Hayatou says we're taking away, but we're investing. And look at CAF - they're not working for the development of African football, they just want as many years as possible on the Fifa or CAF executive so they can make more money and build a bigger house.

'What have they done to help African agents? The bond is too expensive. The Fifa agent law is racist and CAF should have done something about it when it was introduced. They need African agents to work with the African mentality, but CAF are only interested in lining their own pockets.'

They are not the only ones. The chairmen of professional leagues in South Africa and Cameroon have ended up in jail, and four of the top five officials at the Ghana FA have recently been found guilty of corruption in transfer deals. A Ghanaian club owner declared a transfer at $250,000 when he received $800,0000 - and this sort of thing is commonplace.

One man who knows all about the subject is Prof Pierre Lanfranchi, an expert in the development of football worldwide and a consultant to Fifa. 'National federations cannot even build a middle-term plan for development,' says Lanfranchi, Regius Professor of history at De Montfort University, Leicester. 'There are absolutely no foundations to the professional game in Africa.' Fifa aim to start putting those foundations in place by keeping promising young players at home, at least for another couple of years.The plan is that this will raise standards and attract sponsorship. 'At least it's worth a try,' says Blatter.

Ricci, who played for Cagliari and Torino in the Italian second division before coaching in Zaire, says the boys he sold to Torino were all old enough and happy enough to move.

'Is a boy going to refuse a move like that?' asks Ricci at his office in Brussels. 'You cannot compare Africans to young players in, say, Russia, Norway or Croatia, who can stay in their own leagues until they're 20 and beyond and still learn a lot. If you stay on as a professional in Africa till you're 22, you'll never get to Europe. The infrastructure is so poor - coaching, pitches, equipment, travelling, administration - that you'll have no chance of developing.'

The benefits to Africa of players moving to Europe, says Ricci, are slowly beginning to surface. When a player returns to Africa he can help. 'The leagues have improved in the last 10 years, because the links to Europe are closer,' says Ricci, who believes the best are in South Africa ('which has an infrastructure and is completely unlike the rest of the continent'), Ivory Coast, Nigeria and Ghana.

If Nigeria is one of the best, it still has its problems. Of the 17 clubs in the top division only one, Julius Berger FC, paid their players their full wages on time last season. Julius Berger was also the only club to have a home-based player in the squad of 22 for the Nations Cup, which Nigeria hope to win against Cameroon today. Apart from one in Tunisia, all the others earn thousands of pounds a week in Europe.

A visit to a boys' game at Nsawom, a run-down town of shacks and rusty corrugated iron near Accra, showed what the boys must overcome to make it to the top. The pitch, hemmed in by school buildings and a community centre, was 90 per cent red dust and 10 per cent grass, and was unmarked. There was a dry stream bed running the length of the sloping, pot-holed pitch. The goals were knocked up from off-cuts and the crossbars sagged markedly. Both goalkeepers were barefoot. When a defender went in for a tackle - and how they flew in to the challenge - he would emerge with the ball from a great cloud of dust. Yet the level of skill was exceptional.

They were lucky to have a ball according to Abedi Pele, former African Footballer of the Year and the best player to have come out of Ghana. 'When I was a boy we played on dirt with a bunch of rags for a ball,' he says. The club who sold him, Tamale, have clearly not made enough to plough back into the grass roots; they have no grass. They play all their matches on gravel and have the worst facilities in the Ghanaian league.

Abedi and Ricci are agreed with Fifa that investing in youth football is the best way to bring about long-term improvement. And that's what they are doing, along with many other individuals and top European clubs. As with the agents, there are good and bad youth academies opening up all over the continent. Abedi has just opened one near Accra, Ricci's company have four in West Africa, Cameroon's state brewery has set up an academy, there's another nearby run by a Greek club owner, and the big money is coming from Ajax (Ghana and South Africa), and throughout West Africa Feyenoord, Paris St Germain and Monaco. English clubs have yet to catch on, though Manchester United have bought a controlling interest in Fortune FC, the South African second-division side previously bankrolled by Quinton Fortune, and one of Arsenal's international scouts has had a look at how things work in Cameroon. An English-backed academy cannot be far away. One top-class player every five years would cover the running costs.

These academies, if well run like the Ajax set-up at Obuasi, will offer boys not only top coaching, but an education. There will be structured schooling, occasional visits to Europe and, whether the Fifa age barrier works or not, the boys will at least be well prepared to move on.

'We must leave the players here until they're older,' says Blatter. 'If the young players remain it will be the first step in attracting investment in football here.'

Gloria Kuffour, meanwhile, has a message to the mothers of Africa. 'I want all of you to help your boys learn football. Help them. Give them everything you can.'

webTitle: Italian thoroughbred or Inter bench jockey?

fields.headline: Italian thoroughbred or Inter bench jockey?
fields.trailText: It almost made you think that Roberto Baggio was right about reincarnation. The little Buddhist appears to have been reborn as his brilliant young self.
fields.body:
It almost made you think that Roberto Baggio was right about reincarnation. The little Buddhist, 33 years old next Friday, who had been rotting away on Inter's bench, appears to have been reborn as his brilliant young self. In the space of eight days last month he scored three goals, and now the T-shirts say: 'Baggio Must Play in Euro 2000'.

His comeback has sparked something of a theological controversy. The Italian papers are using the Catholic concept of Resurrection. Baggio responds that he 'was never dead', which would seem to conflict with his view that, 'Life is an endless cycle for those of us who believe in reincarnation.'

The view that he was gone forever was widely held. The Italian game has become rather like the fashion business, where nobody can remember last season's look. At Inter, a club that got through four managers last season and even lost their president, Massimo Moratti, for two months in the summer, Baggio had become the footballing equivalent of the beehive hairstyle or the pierced belly-button. He was almost always on the bench. 'Players play on merit at Inter,' lectured the club's technical director, Gabriele Oriali.

At Christmas, when Inter signed three new foreign players, they tried to, flog Baggio to Arsenal, Liverpool, Japan, Rangers, even - the ultimate slight - to Tottenham. Then virtually every Inter forward fell injured or suspended and the club's manager, Marcello Lippi, never yet seen in a Baggio T-shirt, brought him on as a sub against Verona. Baggio scored the winner. 'It's a goal for all those people who thought I wasn't playing because I wasn't fit,' he said.

Four days later in the Italian cup against Milan, he gave away the opening goal with a silly back pass but then hurriedly scored the equaliser before Lippi took him off. Three days after that against Roma, he set up Christian Vieri's opening goal before scoring with a semi-overhead volley to win the match. The watching Gerard Houllier must have realised then he would not be taking Baggio back to Anfield. The player said: 'It has been quite a week.'

Yet it was somehow inevitable that when Inter played Parma last Sunday he should be back on the bench. Lippi brought him on for only the last 27 minutes. webTitle: Why this charm is utterly offensive

fields.headline: Why this charm is utterly offensive
fields.trailText: Fans going to Euro 2000 will be given a guide to local cultural attractions. This, we are told, will encourage them to sample life in the towns and cities they visit. Who are they kidding?
fields.body:
A few months before every World Cup or European Championship we are given the news that the FA are to do something about hooligans. This year we are told that England fans are to go on a charm offensive. Are they trying to insult our intelligence?

I still have a souvenir from my first trip abroad with England to Italy in 1980. It was a piece of card from the FA with a few useful Italian words on it and a plea for good behaviour, as we were ambassadors for our country. The moron in the campsite in Turin, a founder member of the England Travel Club who yelled at the shop assistant 'Speak English, you fucking Eyetie' obviously hadn't read it.

He is almost certainly going to Holland and Belgium with the newly named England Members Club. Most of the 27,000 members won't actually be travelling because they haven't got enough 'loyalty points' to get tickets. You get loyalty points for length of membership and for every game you go to. You can bet a ticket to the final that the moron from Turin has tickets, because he 'loyally' follows England everywhere. The nutters who boo and scream racist abuse during a visiting team's anthem at Wembley will be there too because they 'loyally' go to every England home game and will also have gained enough loyalty points.

Just to show that the FA has learned very little since the England fans were teargassed in Turin in 1980, the fans going to Euro 2000 will be given a guide to restaurants, museums and other cultural attractions. This, we are told, will encourage them to sample life in the towns and cities they visit. Who are they kidding?

During the World Cup in France the people who caused the most trouble inside the stadiums were those in the section allocated to the England Members Club. The FA say that they are anxious to appeal to the majority of England fans who deplore violence. But the older fans, and those with children, who do not cause trouble abroad will not have enough 'loyalty' points to get tickets.

All England fans who love to see their team play abroad but hate the atmosphere created by so many of the nutters will agree with Mark Perryman, no relation to Steve. Mark is a fans' spokesman for the Members Club who says he wants England fans to follow the example of the Tartan Army. He said this week that the majority of England fans need to separate themselves from the right-wing 'No Surrender' brigade. That's fine in principle but in practice that 'No Surrender' brigade - they sing 'No surrender to the IRA' - often is the England Members Club, as anyone at Hampden Park last year will testify.

Like many of my friends I've now left the Members Club and have booked tickets for Euro 2000 on the internet. The majority of England fans in France were not in the Members Club and probably wouldn't want to be. The fact is that it is now fairly easy to get tickets from other sources. If you want you can even get tickets for the Germany game in the German end. Ex-Olympic athlete Ainslie Bennett's corporate hospitality company have been openly advertising them, and tickets for England's other games.

But as we move closer to the opening of Euro 2000 we can expect all sorts of exaltations from the Government and the FA. Remember those Government adverts on the telly before the World Cup in France when we were told that if your name was not on the ticket then you wouldn't get in? That was just a lie, and no one will ever believe the authorities again when they tell us 'don't travel without a ticket because you won't get one'. But that won't stop them telling us. They will probably also tell us that you can only get tickets through an official Euro 2000 package or the England Members Club. I'll bet that in a few weeks' time Jack 'Boot' Straw will announce a 'hooligan summit' and announce that there will be tough new measures to deal with hooligans.

This will be good PR, but just as new measures failed for the World Cup in France they will probably not work for Euro 2000. The Government is simply not serious about doing anything, just keen to be seen to be doing something. Yet with the decision on England's bid for the 2006 World Cup coming so soon after Euro 2000, so much will depend on the fans' behaviour.

With all the national newspapers and broadcasters sending out special 'Hoolie Watch' reporters the FA and the Government must be hoping that hostility to the German bid will lead to a 'toning down' of media reports on the inevitable outbreaks of violence.

webTitle: In with a title shout? The fat lady is singing

fields.headline: In with a title shout? The fat lady is singing
fields.trailText: The bookie Fred Done paying out on another Manchester triumph before Valentine's Day isn't funny, idiotic or provocative any more. It's just deeply depressing.
fields.body:
Somewhere in an office in Isleworth, west London, Sky executives must have brainstormed themselves into a thudding headache trying to find a cunning plan to rescue the Championship run-in. They will have been delighted with the news from Newcastle and Leeds yesterday, but the television men cannot manufacture a tantalising climax themselves, and the overall impression is that the challengers simply cannot match the leaders. In the past few seasons the title has not been decided until May. But February? Come on.

The bookie Fred Done paying out on another Manchester triumph before Valentine's Day isn't funny, idiotic or provocative any more. It's just deeply depressing.

All right, so the logic of maths and the legend of fat ladies keeps alight the dim possibility of Fergie releasing his grip on the trophy. Realistically, though, it must be some sort of sign if every aspiring manager has patently quit dreaming, for this season anyway. Writing yourself off can be a cute psychological ploy - David O'Leary's self deprecation clearly helps to eke the best from his side, while only last week Gerard Houllier claimed there were a handful of teams in a class above Liverpool before witnessing a thrilling, super-charged performance. But there comes a time to end the mind games and be brutally honest.

Arsène Wenger summed it up when he contemplated how his players were coming to terms with what lay ahead: 'They are not stupid. They know we are nine points behind Manchester United with 14 games to go. We need to win nearly every game and they must lose five.' It doesn't get much more brutal, or honest, than that, even if it is four defeats now for United.

What a damning indictment on the Premiership that none of the four strongest clubs clinging to United's shirt tails - Leeds, Arsenal, Liverpool and Chelsea - could make a better contest of it. They all invested bravely on their squads, all possess a number of high-calibre players to admire, and have all at times lulled us into thinking they might possess enough balance and depth to go the distance. What makes United's expected procession even more galling for their rivals is the fact they haven't had to reach their peak to see off the rest.

Liverpool and Leeds have both enjoyed surges but also mini-slumps, while Arsenal and Chelsea remain domestically baffling, and nowhere near as efficient as talent and experience suggest they should be. So why have they yielded so much ground to the Champions?

Is it that the ever-powerful ogre of Old Trafford is now too potent for anyone to pursue? Wenger points to the positive effects of an attitude bred by the Treble that makes them feel untouchable. 'I think they are playing less well than last season but they have this belief that nothing can happen to them. At the moment they are the only team who can be very average yet win their games.'

Wenger has been hurt by his own team's failings. After two seasons slugging it out alongside United, first finishing a point above and then a point behind, the current gap gnaws. 'I only think that I want to win the Championship and if this one is not possible then I want the next one. I just know one thing: I have won it and I want to win it again. And I think I will.'

But for now qualification for the Champions League is paramount. For players who expect to home in on major honours, it is difficult to adjust the sightlines and refocus on a lesser target. But if they are not careful they will find their current top-three status usurped by a Liverpool side eager to profit from hot form and hoodoo status at Highbury.

Should Liverpool sneak into a Champions League position that would exceed even optimistic expectations from what is supposed to have been a transitional season. They are the team with most to gain from the weeks ahead. If they don't make it they can still take heart from making significant progress this year. As for the other three hoping to join Europe's elite, for the London aristocrats of Arsenal and Chelsea, together with the boys from Leeds who have led the table for so long, missing out will spell devastation. And the scary thing is that even then they are only missing out on the Premiership's consolation prize.

fields.headline: Ipswich stay in the hunt
fields.trailText: Ipswich 2 - 1 Huddersfield
fields.body:
Marcus Stewart, Ipswich's £2.5million signing from Huddersfield, scored the 73rd minute winner to break the hearts of his former team-mates in this hard-fought promotion battle.

Following a cross from Jamie Clapham on the left, Stewart opened his account with a precise left foot finish after David Johnson had split the defence with a canny decoy run.

James Scowcroft opened the scoring for Ipswich in the 28th minute with his 13th goal of the season. He struck from eight yards after Matt Holland's header had rebounded off the inside of the post.

Clapham almost increased the Ipswich lead in the 35th minute with an angled drive that goalkeeper Nico Vaesen did well to halt.

Huddersfield almost took the lead in the 12th minute when the dangerous Clyde Wijnhard tried a drive from a narrow angle on the right that beat Richard Wright for pace but clipped the bar. In the 47th minute Steve Jenkins fouled Scowcroft in the penalty area. The resulting spot-kick was taken by Johnson whose shot was brilliantly saved by Vaesen who tipped the ball for a corner.

A minute later Vaesen again saved well from Tony Mowbray and in the 51st minute coped with a header from Wayne Brown.

Ipswich paid the penalty for their miss from the spot when Huddersfield drew level in the 56th minute. Dean Gorre had an easy finish after Wijnhard had flicked on a probing through ball from Scott Sellars.

In the 70th minute Stewart missed a great chance to restore Ipswich's lead after being set up by Johnson but he made amends three minutes later.

During the four minutes added on at the end Wright dived to save at Wijnhard's feet and substitute Gary Croft was carried off on a stretcher after a heavy challenge from Jon Dyson.

fields.headline: Reid: 'It was like Billy Smart's'
fields.trailText: Coventry 3 - 2 Sunderland
fields.body:
Press cuttings from a few weeks ago setting Sunderland's chances or qualifying for the Champions' League now look as ridiculous as those predicting that the Millennium bug would bring down the world's banking system.

The only thing the bug seems to have affected is Sunderland's ability to deposit points into their Premiership account. Just four League defeats in 19 matches before Christmas, they have now not one in seven since the calendar flicked into 2000.

A late rally put some gloss on this performance but couldn't disguise the alarming gaps in their defence which meant they had conceded the match to Coventry before there was 20 minutes on the clock.

The early elimination of Morocco from the African Nations' Cup made Moustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo less than popular with their countrymen back home and they were probably pleased to be sent to Coventry.

Their return certainly helped ignite the Sky Blues who had won only once during the four matches they had been away, including crashing out of the FA Cup two weeks ago when 2-0 up against Charlton in their previous home match.

It took Hadji little more than a minute to help banish those painful memories for the Highfield Road faithful. He won a free kick which Gary McAllister rolled into his path and he had plenty of time to line up a rasping shot which the Sunderland keeper Thomas Sorensen was unable to hold.

Robbie Keane was on hand to convert the rebound from six yards for his 11th goal of the season.

Even the early departure of Stephen Froggatt, following a bad challenge from Nicky Summerbee, failed to disrupt Coventry and they doubled their lead in the 13th minute. McAllister's corner eluded everyone in the middle and Hadji stole in at the back post for an easy tap- in.

Sunderland's woeful defence sealed their side's fate five minutes later when they gifted a third to the home side. A simple flick header from McAllister caused so much confusion that Hadji and Cedric Roussel were more or less able to have a fight over who was going to put the ball into the net. The Belgian won the argument and gleefully slid his effort past Sorensen for his fifth goal in three games.

Even this failed to wake Sunderland up from their nightmare and Coventry had more opportunities before half-time. It took Niall Quinn, a striker, to save some of his side's embarrassment in the 41st minute when he headed Gary Breen's attempt off the line after his defenders had again dealt poorly with a McAllister corner.

Sorensen recovered some of his self esteem two minutes before the break when he saved well at Chippo's feet.

Initially, even the interval break didn't see to throw Coventry off their stride and Keane spurned another chance in the 57th minute after a neat build up. It would have killed the game completely. That suddenly looked like it could be more expensive than he'd thought when within seconds Sunderland had gone up the other end and scored.

Gavin McCann fired in a cross which Kevin Phillips volleyed into the net for his 23rd goal of the season.

Fears of another Charlton-style collapse were heightened in the 88th minute when Alex Rae pulled a second back for Sunderland and seconds later it needed a fingertip save from the Coventry keeper Magnus Hedman to push a Kevin Kilbane shot on to the post.

Sorensen recovered some of his self esteem two minutes before the break when he saved well at Chippo's feet. Initially, even the interval break didn't see to throw Coventry off their stride and Keane spurned another chance in the 57th minute after a neat build up. It would have killed the game completely. That suddenly looked like it could be more expensive than he'd thought when within seconds Sunderland had gone up the other end and scored. Gavin McCann fired in a cross which Kevin Phillips volleyed into the net for his 23rd goal of the season. Fears of another Charlton-style collapse were heightened in the 88th minute when Alex Rae pulled a second back for Sunderland and seconds later it needed a fingertip save from the Coventry keeper Magnus Hedman to push a Kevin Kilbane shot on to the post.

webTitle: Olsen's flying circus on downward spiral

fields.headline: Olsen's flying circus on downward spiral
fields.trailText: Chelsea 3 - 1 Wimbledon
fields.body:
Just like John Cleese's Norwegian Blue, the Wimbledon manager Egil Olsen says he has been pining for the fjords lately. Last night he was duly left as sick as a parrot as his side surrendered a lead to an off-colour Chelsea fortunate to claim three points.

Olsen's latest signing from his homeland, Andreas Lund, put the Dons ahead on his debut but late goals by Gustavo Poyet, George Weah and the substitute Jody Morris gave the scoreline an unjust look to increase Wimbledon's woes in the bottom half of the table and keep Chelsea's recent momentum going.

The Dons had deserved it but Chelsea were stung, quickly responding with two goals in two minutes. First, Emerson Thome slung forward a hopeful ball which Weah headed back to Poyet for a fierce volley home, out of the blue, from 20 yards. Then Gianfranco Zola found Morris with a neat pass and from his cross, Weah rose unmarked at the far post to head home.

Finally, the turnaround was complete when Zola teed up Morris to drive home a powerful shot from 22 yards. It was a contest of contrast; one side in form and on the way up having recorded 10 games unbeaten, the other slipping towards the relegation zone after losing three of their last four games. At least, that was the billing.

There was a time when Wimbledon would have come here scenting blood and points, Chelsea uncomfortable under their high ball onslaught. This is not quite the same club, however, and also being short of confidence and long on injuries meant that the Dons were content to contain rather than put Chelsea under pressure. Consequently, where Wimbledon might once have supplied such a tall centre-forward as Lund, signed in midweek - apparently for £2.5 million - with a series of crosses, now he had to operate alone ahead of a five-man midfield.

Dining off scraps, in the shape of hopeful balls pumped up to him, he still managed to impress fitfully, working manfully in the team's cause. Twice in the first half he pulled away from Frank Leboeuf to get in headers from right-wing crosses but so eager to shine was he that he sent both well wide.

That and a scuffed volley by Robbie Earle was more than Chelsea managed in the opening 45 minutes. Constantly trying to put Weah through, the timing of the pass against Wimbledon's offside trap was mostly wayward and Neil Sullivan went largely untroubled in the visitors' goal.

After an hour of such dross, the crowd got its wish when Zola was introduced. At first, it looked as if things were not improving, particularly when Wimbledon took the lead. The substitute Neil Ardley robbed Dennis Wise on the left and from his cross, Carl Cort headed down for Lund to volley home emphatically.

fields.headline: Di Canio the star turn
fields.trailText: West Ham 5 - 4 Bradford
fields.body:
If Bradford end up relegated, this will surely go down as the one that got away. In an extraordinary game, Paul Jewell's side led 4-2 with 26 minutes remaining, but succumbed to a three-goal burst inspired by Paolo Di Canio, who had earlier asked to be substituted after being denied a penalty.

The Italian was persuaded to stay on by his manager, Harry Redknapp, and subsequently scored a penalty, watched teenage prodigy Joe Cole equalise and then set up Frank Lampard for a dramatic late winner. It was perhaps no surprise that we should have witnessed four goals by half-time, given that both sides were fielding their third-choice goalkeepers, although neither Aidan Davison of Bradford nor West Ham's Stephen Bywater could be blamed.

Bywater did not start the game, but was called into action early on when Shaka Hislop was injured within two minutes of the start, the West Ham goalkeeper suffering a suspected broken leg as he slipped when clearing the ball. And the 18-year-old had little chance when Bradford took the lead on the half-hour. Peter Beagrie swung in a corner from the right and Dean Windass was unmarked to power home a header from barely five yards, the ball flying in off Bywater's hand.

West Ham were back in the game in the 35th minute when Trevor Sinclair shot home on the turn after good work by Steve Lomas and Lampard. And the home side then went ahead in stoppage time when John Moncur scored with a 25-yard shot after Di Canio had played a free-kick across to him.

The Italian was none too popular with the Bradford supporters, who thought he dived in search of a penalty - and referee Neale Barry agreed with them. But the Lincolnshire official had no doubt that Moncur pushed Saunders in the fifth minute of stoppage time, and Beagrie converted the subsequent penalty to make it 2-2.

If the first half was action-packed, it seemed positively dull with what happened in the following 45 minutes. The second-half was only two minutes old when Bradford regained the lead. Jamie Lawrence bundled the ball over the line from close range after the unfortunate Bywater dropped a long shot from Gunnar Halle. Three minutes later, Lawrence scored again, looping a 20-yard shot over the stranded keeper.

Then came an extraordinary incident involving Di Canio. The Italian striker was denied another dubious penalty and his protest was remarkable. He started to take off his shorts and then gestured at the West Ham bench that he wanted to be substituted. As Di Canio trudged to the halfway line with his head bowed, Dean Saunders ran to the other end and hit the West Ham woodwork from a tight angle.

Harry Redknapp, West Ham's manager, implored Di Canio to continue and instead sent on Paul Kitson to replace full-back Gary Charles. Within seven minutes, Kitson won a penalty, a decision that led to more shenanigans from Di Canio, who wrestled the ball off Lampard to take the kick and scored.

Six minutes later West Ham were level when Joe Cole scored his first goal at Upton Park. Di Canio then made up for stealing the penalty from Lampard by setting up a great chance for the young England midfielder, who shot home with his left foot from 18 yards for the winning goal in the 84th minute.

webTitle: Kennedy shines for City while Dalglish junior toils in his dad's shade

fields.headline: Kennedy shines for City while Dalglish junior toils in his dad's shade
fields.trailText: League review
fields.body:
While Kenny Dalglish was taking the first step to wards restoring Celtic's self-esteem, his son Paul had a less enjoyable afternoon as a member of the Norwich team beaten 3-1 at Manchester City

These are frustrating days for Dalglish junior, who will be 23 on Thursday. He has hardly set the Nationwide League alight since his move from Newcastle to Norwich - initially on loan - last March. This season, he has scored only two goals for them, and last week, Norwich's manager Bruce Rioch felt it necessary to publicly implore the club's supporters to be patient with him.

Rioch, whose own son, Greg, is now at Macclesfield, says: 'It was only when Greg had about 70 senior matches under his belt that he really started to feel comfortable as a first-team player, and I think this will be the case with Paul.

'The problem for him has been that because of the nature of his previous clubs [Celtic, Liverpool and Newcastle], he has not had much first-team experience. Before he joined Norwich, he started played only seven full games for Newcastle and two for Bury on loan. Even now, his total stands at just 23. So it's not fair to compare him with other players of his age. At Norwich, for example, a number of the players who are younger than him have made more first-team appearances.

'We signed him because of his potential - we did not sign him as a ready-made first-team player.'

How long will it be before he puts himself in the latter category? Rioch puts it this way. 'He has a lot of pace, and we are working hard with him in terms of educating him on centre-forward play. Just because he has a famous name, that doesn't mean that he understands the game in the same way that his father did. What it does mean is that he probably needs to work harder than anyone else. However, I feel that if he really wants it badly enough, he has the ability to do well.'

But Dalglish had his work cut out to shine at Manchester City, of only because of Norwich's negative approach. Still, he did show his determination, with an early tackle which brought him a booking. As for scoring ability, he was was put in the shade - as was everyone else - by City's Mark Kennedy.

The left-winger clinched victory for the home team with two goals in the last 10 minutes.

As far as the First Division championship race is concerned, those Kennedy goals were rendered particularly important because of Charlton's win over Wolves and Ipswich's 2-1 victory over Huddersfield. Ipswich owed their success to a goal by Marcus Stewart, who was making only his second appearance for them following his move from - Huddersfield.

At the other end, Swindon got a goalless draw at Blackburn - albeit with the help of a large slice of luck.

In the first half, especially, Blackburn, had as number of chances to put Swindon firmly in their place. They were twice denied by the woodwork, with headers from strikers Nathan Blake (22 minutes) and Ashley Ward (37 minutes), bouncing to safety as the Swindon goal enjoyed a charmed life.

That charmed life was also evident in the second half.

Fulham scored only their third goal in nine matches in overcoming Portsmouth 1-0. Their scorer was BJarn Golbaek, their recent signing from Chelsea.

A goal by Lee Hughes - his 12th of the season - gave West Brom a 1-0 win against Crewe, their first in 13 matches.

Bolton and Gillingham, with one eye on next weekend's FA Cup quarter-finals, had mixed fortunes in their clashes at Birmingham and Oldham. Bolton lost 2-1, after being ahead, and had their key Icelandic forward Eidur Gudjohnsen sent off for a foul in the last minute. But Gillingham, the lowest-placed of the Nationwide teams in the FA last eight, won 3-1.

fields.headline: Trophy in Dons' sights
fields.trailText:
Scottish League Cup semi-final
Dundee United v Aberdeen
fields.body:
After an autumn spent grubbing around desperately at the bottom of the Scottish Premier League, Aberdeen have a great chance to put some gloss on their season by sealing a cup final appearance this afternoon.

The Dons go into this afternoon's League Cup semi-final with Dundee United at Dens Park on the back of a run of just two defeats in their last nine Premier League games, a run which has lifted them off the bottom of the table for the first time this season.

Manager Ebbe Skovdahl said: 'The team are in good spirits. The two matches we lost in our recent run were to the Old Firm so we have nothing to fear going into the game.'

Much will depend on the performance of the Dons' Moroccan Hicham Zerouali, who was outstanding in Aberdeen's 2-1 win over St Johnstone last Saturday.

However, third-placed United will remain favourites, although their confidence took a battering in last Saturday's 4-0 home defeat by Rangers, their first reverse since returning from the Premier League's winter shutdown.

United could recall coach Maurice Malpas in the absence of Jason De Vos - who is away on international duty with Canada - as he has been playing for the club's second string.

Their midfielder David Hannah has admitted that morale was shaken after the defeat by Rangers, but expects the mauling to spur them on against Aberdeen.

'Everyone was disappointed with the way we played against Rangers because we didn't perform as we can,' said the former Celtic man. 'But this game will give us the lift we need.'

At just 26, Hannah is already one of the elder statesmen at the club, testimony to the youthful nature of Paul Sturrock's side. But it is a role he is thriving in.

'I've won the league with Celtic and I've played in a lot of big games for both Celtic and United,' said Hannah. 'Hopefully I can help the younger players come through to book our place in the final.'

fields.headline: Spencer supplies finish
fields.standfirst: Relegation-threatened Kilmarnock pay the price for missed chances
fields.trailText: Kilmarnock 0 - 2 Motherwell
fields.body:
A spirited performance from 10-man Motherwell, in particular from veteran goalkeeper Andy Goram, compounded struggling Kilmarnock's relegation fears.

The home side had dominated proceedings before being stunned by two second-half goals from John Spencer and Stephen McMillan.

Kilmarnock, clearly keen to put their shock midweek defeat by Alloa in the Scottish Cup behind them, started the fresher side thanks in part to the return of skipper Ian Durrant and the arrival of former Celtic star Tosh McKinlay, who started his first match for Bobby Williamson's side.

Goram was immediately called into action as Kilmarnock went in search of an early goal. Twice in the opening few minutes the Motherwell keeper made good saves from Ally Mitchell and Gary Holt.

But the Kilmarnock defence then had a let-off in the ninth minute when Holt's misguided header fell to Spencer. Colin Meldrum was off his line quickly to clear the danger. Despite that, Kilmarnock still looked the side most likely to score and Mitchell came close with a powerful shot from 20 yards that whistled over Goram's bar.

At the other end, Lee McCulloch beat Meldrum to Don Goodman's cross but his header was well off target. Then an angled drive by Michael Jeffrey flew just wide of Goram's right-hand post with the keeper struggling to reach the ball.

Kilmarnock opened strongly again after the interval with Durrant and Jeffrey both firing shots at Goram.

But in a breakaway shortly afterwards McCulloch should have given the visitors the lead. After being sent clear by Spencer he hit his shot against Meldrum's legs with the goal at his mercy.

On 53 minutes, Motherwell were then reduced to ten men when Goodman was yellow-carded twice in three minutes for fouls on Durrant and Gus MacPherson.

As Motherwell struggled to keep pace, Kilmarnock continued to dominate but still could not find their way through. Christophe Cocard almost did the trick in 65 minutes but Goram dived to his left to save the Frenchman's deflected shot.

A minute later Motherwell took the lead against the run of play when Spencer drove the ball through a ruck of defenders low into the net. A disputed free-kick 25 yards out led to Motherwell's second goal in 73 minutes, Stephen McMillan's shot taking a deflection and leaving Meldrum with no chance.

The result leaves Kilmarnock a point adrift at the bottom of the Premier League. Now Williamson has a big task in raising his players' morale for Wednesday night's League Cup semi-final against another team with a great deal to prove, Kenny Dalglish's Celtic.

fields.headline: Resurgent Royals take grudge game
fields.trailText: Reading 2 - 0 Millwall
fields.body:
Reading have turned round a wretched season with a run of results in keeping with their splendid surroundings.

A first goal of the season by the captain Phil Parkinson and a solo gem three minutes from the end by Nicky Forster, who ran 40 yards before shooting into the bottom corner, produced a well deserved victory in front of the biggest home crowd since the season's opening day

Reading fans have not had much to cheer about this season, but they are certainly not lacking a sense of humour.

In the midst of a grim winter run of 13 matches without a league win, they staged a 'pants protest' to mark their displeasure at the team's performances.

Yesterday, the supporters were waving inflatable bones to show their satisfaction at the improvement which has coincided with Martin Allen joining his boyhood club as assistant manager. Allen took over when John Gorman left to join Glenn Hoddle at Southampton and Reading immediately sprang from the bottom four by taking seven points from three matches.

Martin Butler, a £750,000 signing from Cambridge United, also made an immediate impact with two goals in his first two appearances, but he made an inauspicious start to his first home game with a second-minute booking for a challenge on Scott Fitzgerald.

Retribution came quickly from Stuart Nethercott, who was shown the yellow card for clattering Butler and with little more than half an hour gone three of Nethercott's team-mates, David Livermore, Richard Sadlier and Tim Cahill, went into John Kirkby's book.

The tackles went flying in and the aerial challenges became more fierce, and there was a sixth first-half caution, this time for the Reading substitute Andy Bernal.

Quite clearly there was an edge to a fixture which Millwall won 5-0 at the New Den in November on their way into the top four.

Reading manager Alan Pardew said before kick-off: 'Most of my family are from the Bermondsey area and it was a horrible occasion for all of us.'

In between the bookings, Nicky Forster, who has struck an immediate understanding with Butler, had a clear shooting chance on the edge of the box but he hit it straight at Tony Warner.

From a slightly more difficult situation, Livermore had his drive blocked. Then, a dangerous cross from Darren Caskey brushed off the shirt of Nethercott and Warner was grateful to see the ball deflected straight into his arms.

When Peter Grant missed from six yards, it was almost punished by Cahill's run and low, angled shot which drifted a foot wide of the far post.

Thankfully, both sides settled into some quality football after the interval, with near misses at both ends. A one-handed save by Scott Howie denied 15-goal leading scorer Neil Harris, after a surging run by Paul Ifill. Then, a flying save by Warner kept out a close-range header from Forster.

Twice, the goalkeeper was embarrassed - first when he failed to hold on to another Forster header and had to show quick reflexes to grab the ball at the second attempt as Grant came steaming in.

Two minutes later a deflected shot by Matt Robinson fell out of Warner's grasp for a corner. The goalkeeper redeemed himself by turning aside a fierce shot by Forster, but he was powerless after 64 minutes when Phil Parkinson turned in a low cross by Forster.

Allen took over when John Gorman left to join Glenn Hoddle at Southampton and Reading immediately sprang from the bottom four by taking seven points from three matches. Martin Butler, a £750,000 signing from Cambridge United, also made an immediate impact with two goals in his first two appearances, but he made an inauspicious start to his first home game with a second-minute booking for a challenge on Scott Fitzgerald. Retribution came quickly from Stuart Nethercott, who was shown the yellow card for clattering Butler and with little more than half an hour gone three of Nethercott's team-mates, David Livermore, Richard Sadlier and Tim Cahill, went into John Kirkby's book. The tackles went flying in and the aerial challenges became more fierce, and there was a sixth first-half caution, this time for the Reading substitute Andy Bernal. Quite clearly there was an edge to a fixture which Millwall won 5-0 at the New Den in November on their way into the top four. Reading manager Alan Pardew said before kick-off: 'Most of my family are from the Bermondsey area and it was a horrible occasion for all of us.' In between the bookings, Nicky Forster, who has struck an immediate understanding with Butler, had a clear shooting chance on the edge of the box but he hit it straight at Tony Warner. From a slightly more difficult situation, Livermore had his drive blocked. Then, a dangerous cross from Darren Caskey brushed off the shirt of Nethercott and Warner was grateful to see the ball deflected straight into his arms. When Peter Grant missed from six yards, it was almost punished by Cahill's run and low, angled shot which drifted a foot wide of the far post. Thankfully, both sides settled into some quality football after the interval, with near misses at both ends. A one-handed save by Scott Howie denied 15-goal leading scorer Neil Harris, after a surging run by Paul Ifill. Then, a flying save by Warner kept out a close-range header from Forster. Twice, the goalkeeper was embarrassed - first when he failed to hold on to another Forster header and had to show quick reflexes to grab the ball at the second attempt as Grant came steaming in. Two minutes later a deflected shot by Matt Robinson fell out of Warner's grasp for a corner. The goalkeeper redeemed himself by turning aside a fierce shot by Forster, but he was powerless after 64 minutes when Phil Parkinson turned in a low cross by Forster.

fields.headline: New high at Valley
fields.trailText: Charlton 2 - 0 Wolves
fields.body:
It was Gay Day down at the nearby Dome yesterday, and things are also looking pretty bright for Charlton. Unbeaten at home since November, with a stranglehold on the First Division leadership, they equalled a club record of eight consecutive League wins yesterday in front of another sell-out Valley crowd with this convincing dismissal of play-off contenders Wolves.

Alan Curbishley received his manager of the month award before kick-off but instead of this precipitating the traditional fall after pride, second-half goals from Graham Stuart and Steve Brown allowed Charlton to record their second win over Wolves in a month.

Those are the only league defeats the Midlanders have suffered this millennium as they reached the top six, but Charlton's swift readmission to the Premiership looks increasingly certain after this sequence of 10 consecutive wins in all competitions.

Wolves respect for Charlton's strengths was illustrated by the placing of striker Michael Branch wide on the right to curtail the attacking instincts of Chris Powell, the leaders' left-back, leaving Ade Akinbiyi as a lone forward. Still Curbishley's men found avenues to get beyond the Wolves' defence.

It was Powell who almost gave Charlton the advantage after 24 minutes. Anthony Barness's cute chip found Andy Todd in more space than perhaps he realised, the defensive midfielder chesting the ball away from goal before hooking it back over his own head, where Powell arrived late only to head back beyond the far post.

Wolves' attacking options were further limited when Andy Sinton limped out of the fray injured.

Andy Hunt has scored hat-tricks in each of his last two games and could feasibly have had another even by the interval yesterday. He was released into acres of space 12 minutes before the break, composed himself and shot true and low, only to find Michael Oakes in his path.

The Charlton goalkeeper also had to be alert on a rare Wolves foray. Steve Brown's ill-conceived pass allowed Branch to sprint clear, but Kiely sprinted out from his goal to make a crunching midfield tackle.

Hunt weaved his way past Wolves defenders, but his shot was saved by Oakes. Then, on the stroke of half-time Branch scampered down the right and reversed an inviting pass for Darren Bazeley, who sent Neil Emblen into the clear, but the Wolves midfielder to shoot wide.

The cost of that ghastly miss was felt within three minutes of the restart, when Graham Stuart, taking up the virus-hit captain Mark Kinsella's baton, swept home Martin Pringle's neatly-conceived square ball from 12 yards.

The second was struck home from just inside the area with malevolent glee by Steve Brown, catching Ludo Pollet's clearing header. Paul Simpson crashed a late free-kick against the underside of the crossbar, but by then Charlton were probably wondering what odds they would get on a League Championship and FA Cup double.

fields.headline: Stan's promising return
fields.trailText: Watford 1 - 1 Leicester
fields.body:
He played like a man unburdened, unperturbed, unwilling to be provoked. Like he had said, he just wanted to play. The body language was revealing. He clasped high fives with Emile Heskey; he proffered a relaxed thumbs-up to the travelling Foxes; he loitered with intent in the attacking third, arms aloft, beckoning for the ball. After 11 months in the Premiership wilderness and Lord knows how long lost in a mental desert, Stanley Victor Collymore had come out to play.

He enjoyed no fairy tale comeback but equally importantly had no nightmares. And there were enough positive impulses to suggest one of the enigmas of the English game might just be unravelled by Martin O'Neill and his close-knit Leicester collective. Probably the most expensive mistake in the history of British football (copyright Aston Villa) looks like a Filbert Street steal.

Naturally fatigue took its toll but he managed 90 minutes in the thick of it, shaking hands with all and sundry and looking every inch the self-contained, composed professional at the finish.

He came close to a winner with two menacing second-half headers. First he rose to head Impey's centre on to the bar before a smothering save from Chris Day spoiled Stan's script.

Perhaps the most encouraging aspect for City was the instant connection he struck with fellow frontmen Heskey and Tony Cottee. The prospect of a match-fit Collymore settled into this team and supported by a full-strength midfield is mouthwatering for Leicester. It's easy to imagine how he might benefit from the probing of a Neil Lennon or Muzzy Izzet (both left out to eliminate the risk of a yellow card which would leave them banned for the Worthington Cup Final).

As well we know this Leicester team is confident and capable. With half-time approaching they took the lead their periods of domination deserved, even if it needed a generous hand from Watford along the way. Steve Palmer's blunder, as he glanced the ball against his own woodwork, alarmed the home defence and City capitalised. Cottee bundled back across the face of goal and there was Matt Elliott to hook the ball over his shoulder and in with an almighty thump.

Leicester were not the only ones laying out the welcome mat. Watford welcomed back two of their most dangerous players: Peter Kennedy and Nordin Wooter, returning from lengthy injuries, combined to craft an equaliser shortly after the break. The Irishman's free kick was nodded goalwards by the dreadlocked Dutchman, and Steve Walsh's attempted clearance only diverted the ball in.

Watford's best chance to seal the points fell to Allan Smart, who had already squandered a hat-trick of first half chances, but he blazed over.

fields.headline: Shearer hell for Reds
fields.standfirst: Keane sent off and big strikers on mark as Newcastle inject new life into the title chase
fields.trailText: Newcastle 3 - 0 Man Utd
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at St. James's Park
fields.body:
Bobby Robson paid Manchester United lavish compliments before this game and must have ended up wondering what all the fuss was about. The bookmaker who has been paying out early on title bets will also be feeling a trifle concerned, particularly as Roy Keane now faces suspension after being dismissed for two bookable offences.

This was only Newcastle's second victory over Manchester United in a dozen attempts, but it was instant success for Robson in a much more emphatic manner than anyone had anticipated. Two second half goals by Alan Shearer gave the home side the margin they deserved, Manchester United could easily have conceded more.

Surprisingly this was a first competitive meeting for two of the most respected managers in English football, Newcastle's 5-1 thrashing at Old Trafford last August having been caretaker Steve Clarke's only match in charge. Few would deny Newcastle have bucked up their ideas since then, though until this result they have never quite been able to stop worrying about their proximity to the relegation positions.

No such problems for Manchester United, six points clear and in the title driving seat, as Robson conceded before the game. To continue the motoring theme the leaders began like one of David Beckham's fanciest possessions being taken through its paces by an eager salesman. Every one of the visitors' attacking options had been demonstrated to Newcastle within the first 10 minutes, as Manchester United pressed forward in numbers and threatened to overrun their opponents with the slick precision of their passing.

Only five minutes had elapsed when Teddy Sheringham anticipated a clever ball from Paul Scholes to shoot a couple of feet too high, then Warren Barton rescued his bewildered defence with a timely interception when Sheringham had two men spare on his left. With Andy Cole particularly impressive, chasing an England recall as well as his 100th Manchester United goal, Beckham put a chance over the bar in the 20th minute and saw a threatening cross cut out by Nikolaos Dabizas at the last moment with two attackers shaping for a tap in.

Newcastle's own attacking efforts looked primitive in comparison, with some steady build-ups from the back wasted by careless final balls, and the alleged Duncan Ferguson-Alan Shearer partnership looking almost ungainly. That was until the 27th minute, when Newcastle took the lead and the game turned on a moment which made nonsense of all that had gone before. The home side played a ball up in the direction of their twin strikers, as they had been doing all afternoon, but in this occasion Shearer beat Mickael Silvestre and found Ferguson with a headed flick. The big man had his back to goal and was on the edge of the penalty box, but one graceful swing of his left boot later Mark Bosnich was beaten high to his left and the ball was coming to rest in the Manchester United net. There was a slight pause before the roar arrived, as if the crowd had difficulty registering immediately what had just happened.

The same appeared to be true of Manchester United, who did not quite fall to pieces after going behind, but could not have complained had they trailed by two or three at the interval. The lively Kieron Dyer saw a deflected shot strike a post four minutes later, Kevin Gallacher shot too high, and Gary Speed missed an inviting target from the edge of the area with Bosnich stranded. Most of the ground actually cheered for that one, not realising the ball had flashed the wrong side of an upright.

Keane picked up his first yellow card for dissent in the 45th minute, and there was still time for Shearer to give Ferguson another good shooting chance, although this time his aim was less deadly.

Ferguson was withdrawn just past the hour - just before Manchester United objections that a Cole flick had crossed the line by the time Steve Harper dropped on it led to them losing their heads completely.

Keane was at pains to offer a sporting handshake to Harper after the pair collided at speed two minutes later, but could have no real objections when a late tackle from behind on Rob Lee brought a second booking in the 65th minute, and neither did he raise any. Cole, however, gave a passable impersonation of his captain's previous style in chasing Stephen Lodge all over the pitch, and was lucky to escape with only an additional yellow.

The Shearer show started shortly afterwards, at exactly the point the normally reliable Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was introduced to do his lucky charm act. He trotted on just as Shearer was measuring a 25 yard drive which beat Bosnich low to his left, and - against 10 men - the game was effectively up.

That did not prevent Shearer and his public enjoying a second, four minutes from time, but credit for this particular piece of icing on the cake belonged to Helder, who brought the ball elegantly out of defence, and to Didier Domi, whose pinpoint cross from the left wing will probably be the last the England captain sees until after next week's Argentina game.

fields.headline: Saints find new spirit
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 0 - 1 Southampton
fields.body:
Wednesday's manager Danny Wilson says he always sees the glass half full rather than half empty. After this game even he must reconcile himself to the bitter dregs of relegation. Southampton outfought them, outran them and generally looked a different proposition from the soft touch they're thought to be away from home. A solitary goal is no true reflection of Glenn Hoddle's side's superiority. Wednesday's misery was compounded when Gilles De Bilde missed a penalty.

The cliché about a game being a six-pointer had some relevance here. It has been a desperate season for Wednesday. But there are a few rays of hope. Before this game they had only lost once this year in the league, and that to Manchester United. Danny Wilson was named manager of the month for January and, looking to the future, they have, like West Ham United, a fine youth squad.

That said, a minor disaster at Derby last week (throwing away a 3-1 lead with a minute of normal time remaining) and dark mutterings of a merger with city rivals United are enough to sustain an air of gloom around the club.

Glenn Hoddle's first away game saw a side with only one change from last week's home winners: Hassan Kachloul for Boa Morte. There was still no sign of the unfit Le Tissier.

At this stage last season Southampton were in a similar situation to Wednesday. They escaped relegation with a prolonged run of good performances, losing only two of their final nine home games. But away from The Dell the Saints are poor value, and hadn't won at Hillsborough in almost 10 years.

They started the game brightly enough and with Wednesday's defence looking ponderous, Matt Oakley picked up a loose ball and forced a good save from Pavel Srnicek. The resulting corner was only partially cleared and Jo Tessem might have hit his shot more tellingly when he was given the chance to test Srnicek again.

Wednesday's responded with a break by De Bilde after Petter Rudi intercepted a poor pass by Chris Marsden and set the side's top scorer on a run, which ended when he was nudged off the ball by Richards in somewhat dubious circumstances.

Then Andy Hinchcliffe curled a free kick from five yards outside the area which Paul Jones was obliged to tip over the bar one-handed.

Southampton, with Marsden in a pivotal midfield role, played attractive one-touch football and looked the side more likely to provide a goal. In a sustained period of attacking, Marian Pahars and Davies both came close to getting the crucial final touch.

So it came as little surprise when they took the lead in the 27th minute. Once again the Wednesday defence was at fault in failing to clear a corner and when Oakley collected the ball he hit a lethal dipping cross to the near post which Tessem swept in from close range.

Two minutes later Wednesday wasted an ideal chance to draw level. De Bilde, about to shoot, was brought down by Jones. De Bilde took the penalty himself and Jones redeemed his error with an excellent one-handed save diving to his right.

The keeper was having one of those days when he looked genuine international class. The leggy Sibon shrugged off a challenge by Francis Benali and hit a rasping shot only to see Jones rise to the challenge with another fine save. Moments later he kept out a header from the same player with equal panache.

Danny Wilson was obviously unhappy with some of his player's performances and when Rudi hit a wasteful cross into touch he was promptly replaced by Danny Sonner. It almost produced a goal. Hinchcliffe took a free kick on the left, Sibon headed on and Sonner should have scored instead of hoofing the ball over the bar.

Southampton though were in control. More aggressive, quicker to the ball, they capitalised on Wednesday's lack of spirit. As the Yorkshiremen struggled to get men forward, the Saints would have seven men back and then, through Marsden and Kachloul, be ready to break at pace. It left Wednesday looking somewhat clueless.

webTitle: Everton lucky to keep home run

fields.headline: Everton lucky to keep home run
fields.trailText: Everton 2 - 1 Derby
fields.body:
Everton maintained their unbeaten home record in the League, but were somewhat fortunate to do so in a game dominated for long periods by the visitors.

In Joe-Max Moore, they seem to have unearthed a striker of real pedigree, who provides a genuine alternative up front, but more significantly perhaps, the win takes them to 36 points, virtually guaranteeing Premiership survival.

Derby's midfield injury crisis forced manager Jim Smith into promoting Giorgi Kinkladze to the starting line-up, only the second Premiership game he has begun since his loan move from Ajax. He controlled the midfield straight from the kick-off, immediately starting the move that set free Stefanio Eranio, who fell in the box after clashing with Nicky Barmby, but no penalty was given. Kinkladze's superb reverse ball to Branko Strupar then opened up the Everton defence, Thomas Myhre managing to smother it at his feet.

But it was Everton who scored in their only two significant attacks of the first half. Strupar lost possession in midfield, Barmby picked it up and was fouled on the edge of the box.

Referee Uriah Rennie played a great advantage, which allowed Mark Pembridge to slip the ball to Moore, who fired a brilliant low angled drive past Mark Poom, the American's fourth goal in five games.

Derby should have equalised when Myhre pulled off a stunning save from Eranio, but Everton scored from the penalty spot on the stroke of half-time. As Derby defended a corner, Spencer Prior held an arm up against Richard Gough, who fell to the ground. Michael Ball sent Poom the wrong way from the resultant penalty.

Jim Smith replaced both his strikers at half-time, youngsters Malcolm Christie and Marvin Robinson coming on for Strupar and Dean Sturridge respectively. He then brought on Israeli international Avi Nimni 12 minutes later, who scored with his first touch, capitalising on Richard Gough's error to run clear and chip Myhre for his first goal for the club since moving from Macabi Tel Aviv.

Barmby should immediately have regained the two-goal advantage when Kevin Campbell delightfully set him up on the edge of the box, but he wasted the chance, firing wide with only Poom to beat.

Derby, whose five-match unbeaten run came to an end here, pushed hard for an equaliser in the final minutes, but, despite a long spell of pressure, failed to carve out any clear-cut chances and it was Everton who looked the more likely to score on the break.

He controlled the midfield straight from the kick-off, immediately starting the move that set free Stefanio Eranio, who fell in the box after clashing with Nicky Barmby, but no penalty was given. Kinkladze's superb reverse ball to Branko Strupar then opened up the Everton defence, Thomas Myhre managing to smother it at his feet. But it was Everton who scored in their only two significant attacks of the first half. Strupar lost possession in midfield, Barmby picked it up and was fouled on the edge of the box. Referee Uriah Rennie played a great advantage, which allowed Mark Pembridge to slip the ball to Moore, who fired a brilliant low angled drive past Mark Poom, the American's fourth goal in five games. Derby should have equalised when Myhre pulled off a stunning save from Eranio, but Everton scored from the penalty spot on the stroke of half-time. As Derby defended a corner, Spencer Prior held an arm up against Richard Gough, who fell to the ground. Michael Ball sent Poom the wrong way from the resultant penalty. Jim Smith replaced both his strikers at half-time, youngsters Malcolm Christie and Marvin Robinson coming on for Strupar and Dean Sturridge respectively. He then brought on Israeli international Avi Nimni 12 minutes later, who scored with his first touch, capitalising on Richard Gough's error to run clear and chip Myhre for his first goal for the club since moving from Macabi Tel Aviv. Barmby should immediately have regained the two-goal advantage when Kevin Campbell delightfully set him up on the edge of the box, but he wasted the chance, firing wide with only Poom to beat. Derby, whose five-match unbeaten run came to an end here, pushed hard for an equaliser in the final minutes, but, despite a long spell of pressure, failed to carve out any clear-cut chances and it was Everton who looked the more likely to score on the break.

webTitle: PM pleaded with LibDem leader to save Michael

fields.headline: PM pleaded with LibDem leader to save Michael
fields.trailText: February 13 2000: Tony Blair pleaded with the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy to save the career of his man in Wales, Alun Michael, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Tony Blair pleaded with the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy to save the career of his man in Wales, Alun Michael, it emerged yesterday.

The Prime Minister telephoned Kennedy 'several times' hoping to persuade the Liberal Democrats to withdraw their support from the 'no confidence' motion in the Welsh Assembly that forced Michael out of office last week. The final call was made less than 24 hours before Michael quit to avoid being publicly sacked.

Blair warned him that the whole devolution process - which Labour and the Liberal Democrats supported against Tory opposition - could be undermined if Michael were brought down.

But Kennedy, who visited Cardiff yesterday to speak in memory of Lloyd George, retorted that devolution implied that decisions such as the choice of a First Secretary had to be made locally.

On Tuesday, the popular Rhodri Morgan will be voted into office to succeed Michael. All three opposition parties have signalled that they will back his appointment, which many politicians see as the start of a new era in Welsh politics. Plaid Cymru Assembly member Phil Williams claimed: 'In the streets of Wales there is a feeling that our man is in now.'

He said Morgan's election would be welcomed by nationalists, despite the risk that they will suffer in the polls if Labour is led by a local leader with a popular touch.

Morgan is expected to hold talks with other parties about the possibility of informal co-operation around a jointly agreed political programme, but he is unlikely to offer them any Cabinet seats.

He needs to build bridges with a minority in the Welsh Labour leadership who stayed loyal to Michael to the bitter end. By the time he was forced from office last Wednesday, Michael could count on the backing of only five of his 27 fellow Labour assembly members. Three have since resigned their positions as party whips, accusing the chief whip Andrew Davies of having plotted against Michael.

His defeat is expected to harden opinion in the national Labour Party against using complicated electoral colleges to choose candidates for the leadership of the Scottish and Welsh assemblies or for city mayors.

In the original contest between Michael and Morgan for the top Welsh post, Morgan won the higher number of votes, but Michael was elected because he had more support from MPs and union leaders using the block vote.

Labour General Secretary Margaret McDonagh has accepted that the use of an electoral college in Wales and in the London mayoralty contest has provoked a backlash.
