webTitle: Bitter last hours of Blair loyalist

fields.headline: Bitter last hours of Blair loyalist
fields.standfirst: Fallen First Secretary Alun Michael was hopeful of rescue by Liberal Democrats
fields.trailText: February 13 2000: Fallen First Secretary Alun Michael was hopeful of rescue by Liberal Democrats
fields.body:
Alun Michael is out walking the hills this weekend, contemplating his political future and perhaps privately regretting that he ever accepted Tony Blair's call to make Wales his political home.

There is a lot of sympathy for the fallen First Secretary, whose first political love always seemed to be Westminster. Having sacrificed a job as Home Office Minister after Ron Davies's 'moment of madness' on Clapham Common, Michael was seen as representing Westminster in Wales, not vice-versa.

By the end, he stood on a ledge of political support so narrow it took only a slight push to send him down. Yet he seemed blind to how precarious his situation was. Almost to the end, he thought he could survive, either by striking a pact with Welsh Liberal Democrat leader Mike German to avert the prospect of a 'no confidence' vote, or by whipping Labour assembly members into line so he could face down the assembly if the other three parties combined against him. Three setbacks in his final 36 hours of office finally destroyed him.

Strike one came when Labour assembly members came together for their normal monthly meeting on Tuesday morning. Chief whip Andrew Davies said the crisis in the assembly was growing. The situation was that a successful 'no confidence' vote would force Michael to resign, but leave his Cabinet in office for the few days it took Labour to reinstate Michael or choose a replacement.

But Davies warned that the opposition parties were planning to use what Rhodri Morgan called 'the Nagasaki after the Hiroshima' by stripping Cabinet of delegated powers. Moreover, assembly chairman Dafyd Elis Thomas was adamant Michael could come back once after a vote of 'no confidence' but if the assembly ousted him again, that would be the end. In effect, Michael was told that, if he clung on, he would provoke a crisis which would put Wales temporarily back under direct Westminster rule.

But Michael did not trust his chief whip to give disinterested advice. Davies had openly supported Morgan against him in the contest for the Labour leadership and he suspected Davies of manipulating the crisis to bring in the leader he wanted. A week earlier, Davies had been loudly berated in the assembly building by Michael's political adviser, Julie Crowley, for alleged disloyalty. Michael listened in silence - obviously believing Crowley was right.

Strike two came late that night. Michael presumed that his Liberal Democrat opposite number, Mike German, would be amenable to a deal which could avert the vote of 'no confidence' altogether. He was even prepared to offer the Liberal Democrats two seats in Cabinet, after opposing any coalition government.

His overtures had the powerful backing of Tony Blair, who rang the Liberal Democrat, Charles Kennedy, several times pleading for Michael's political life. His last call was on Tuesday evening. Kennedy replied that devolution implies that these crises must be sorted out locally, without London interference.

Still Michael did not give. For about three hours on Tuesday night, he waited in an upstairs room in the assembly with Welsh Secretary Paul Murphy and Rhodri Morgan, hoping German would drop in to talk. The door was open. There was a bottle of wine ready.

But downstairs the six-strong Liberal Democrat group were so hostile to a deal that they refused even to allow German to go upstairs to say goodnight. In an extraordinary snub, they sent German's adviser, Mike Hines, to tell Michael's adviser that there was no prospect of a deal. The embarrassed Hines found himself drawn into the room to meet the three most important politicians in Wales. 'I said, "the group's not talking - they're saying enough is enough". It was a bit hard to tell someone that that's the end,' Hines said.

Still Michael did not give. The next morning he came up with a strategy seemingly modelled on John Major. Facing a crisis in his own party in 1995, the Tory PM resigned, daring opponents to run a candidate against him. Michael decided that he, too, would resign, pre-empting the assembly's vote of no confidence. There would then have to be a new election of a First Secretary. Michael intended to run and, provided he had the backing of the 28 Labour assembly members, he was sure to win. He relayed his plans to Downing Street and was promised Blair's support.

Then the third and fatal strike. No sooner had he stepped down than support for Michael among Labour assembly members vanished. At 1.50pm, ten minutes before the assembly session was due to begin, he was told he could count on the support of only six out of 28 members of the Labour group. The six were Michael himself, group chairman Ann Jones, three whips who resigned in the wake of Michael's fall - Lorraine Barrett, Huw Lewis and Janice Gregory - and Lynn Negal, who is married to Lewis.

Completing Michael's humiliation, Dafyd Elis Thomas let the 'no confidence' vote go ahead. When the Welsh Cabinet decided later that day to nominate Rhodri Morgan as the acting First Secretary, the game was up. One Labour politician who played a prominent role in bringing Michael down said yesterday: 'His heart was always in Westminster. The tragedy is that he did his master's bidding. There is a great deal of sympathy for him.'

fields.headline: Heart of the matter
fields.standfirst: There's more to a romantic meal than heart-shaped pizzas and puddings - try the aphrodisiac option or something more voluptuous
fields.trailText: There's more to a romantic meal than heart-shaped pizzas and puddings - try the aphrodisiac option or something more voluptuous
fields.body:
Something depressing happens to restaurants on St Valentine's Day. The usual buzz of people having a great time that is such an essential part of going out to dinner is lost to the deathly drone of whispering couples. Prices often go up, and something takes over even the most cold-hearted of chefs, encouraging them to turn out food contrived into heart shapes - particularly when it comes to desserts. Much better, I think, to stay at home and cook a meal for the one you love.

I really don't think we have to get carried away with heart-shaped cake tins and pizza moulds at home, either. A candle on the table will do. A white china dish of coeur à la crème would be charming, but anything more runs the risk of looking contrived and, frankly, a bit naff. But this doesn't mean the meal need not be romantic. I have always felt that any meal for a St Valentine's night should be sensual and fragrant - voluptuous, even.

Special as this date is, and has been so since the 15th century, I don't think it is an excuse for the cook to show off. I get suspicious when people go to too much trouble. It's as if they are trying to hide something. It is, though, a meal for which we should perhaps go to a little more trouble than usual, otherwise it might seem as if we cannot be bothered. (This is one meal in the year that is something of a minefield.) Going so far as to remember your lover's favourite food is probably a good start. Getting their name right might be another.

If it's just sex you're after, simply feed them oysters, something (anything) with lots of chillies, and drink Champagne all the way through. You can't go wrong, at least it always seems to work for me. But if there is more to it than that, then I suggest you think about a meal that is quietly pleasing, rather than something that has such blatantly aphrodisiac overtones.

OK, so no meat. This is a meal about love, so how can you kill something for it? Anyone who feels they cannot get through an entire meal without some will just have to content themselves with slipping a slice or two of prosciutto into the antipasto. No fish, because this year St Valentine's Day is on a Monday when all good fish shops are traditionally shut, though, in truth, this practice is somewhat outdated. So it is down to vegetables and fruit and some bolstering starch. Something sounds right about this to me.

This should, surely, be a fragrant meal. I want to eat something that is heady with spices but not especially hot, which means using the cooler spices such as coriander and cumin, and herbs such as basil and mint. I think there has to be garlic. If both of you eat it, neither will notice its presence later.

I have chosen aubergines as the star ingredient in my Valentine's meal. This, you understand, is purely for its deeply sensual texture and nothing to do with the recipe that appears in Norman Douglas's classic Venus in the Kitchen, long out of print, that promises to enlarge the male organ for the period of one moon. The fact is that the spongy flesh of the aubergine soaks up olive oil to the point where it becomes positively silken. There is no other vegetable I know that does this. It also takes spices rather well. Cream, basil and mint take this vegetable, or fruit as it really is, away from its Middle Eastern origins, but add a certain voluptuousness.

This year, I shall make a rhubarb tart, and not just for its appropriate colour. The forced, pretty pink stalks around at the moment are as tempting as any tropical fruit, and they quickly cook to a juicy, almost satin-like texture. Their clean sharpness is welcome after the richness of the aubergines and cream. Those for whom rhubarb holds no passion might like to substitute apples or pears, or perhaps make a St Valentine's Day dinner for someone who does.

A light antipasto
As the main course is quite rich, I think a plate of salty ham and ripe fruit will be more welcome here than anything else.

4 to 6 thin slices of San Daniele or Parma ham
1 ripe papaya
a ball of buffalo mozzarella
a small handful of baby spinach leaves or watercress
olive oil and lemon for dressing the leaves

You could offer this on two plates, but I am far more tempted to place it all on one and put it in the centre of the table, for both diners to help themselves. The papaya will need halving, peeling and the seeds removing; like melon, its flavour will be improved by the saltiness of the ham. Slice it thickly into fragile wedges. The mozzarella should be sliced and drizzled with a little olive oil and seasoned with black pepper. Anything other than the simplest olive oil and lemon juice dressing would be too much for the baby spinach leaves, so they just need tossing gently in a little of both and seasoning with a grind or two of salt and black pepper. Put a small pile of leaves on to the plate, a cluster of papaya wedges, the slices of seasoned mozzarella and the ham.

Baked aubergines with basil, cream and cumin
A silken-textured and fragrant dish, rich with cream and olive oil. The quality of the oil is essential, as so much of it is soaked up by the aubergines, and it is visible too in the finished dish. Don't even think of using anything other than olive oil. I used a fruity, but not particularly expensive Greek oil for this. You will need some rice to soak up the juices. Serves 2 with the rice

2 large (but not enormous) aubergines
olive oil, a good fruity one
2 medium-sized onions
1 tsp coriander seed
1 tsp cumin seed
2 large cloves garlic
a small bunch of basil - about 25 large leaves
a few sprigs of mint - say 30 leaves

Wipe each aubergine, then slice them in half lengthways and then again. Cut each piece into thick chunks. Warm some olive oil in a shallow pan - the amount will depend on how much your aubergines soak up, but you can expect to need at least a breakfast cup full - and let the aubergines soften and colour. What you are after are tender lumps of aubergine lightly golden on their cut sides. Lift the aubergines out with a pair of tongs on to kitchen paper to drain. Don't be tempted to miss this step, otherwise the finished dish will be too oily.

Peel and chop the onions and garlic and fry them gently in the aubergine pan, adding more oil if they are sticking. In another, smaller shallow pan, toast the whole spices. Added to the pan over a moderate heat, they will be toasted in seconds. They should barely colour. Tip them in to a coffee or spice grinder and whiz them to powder, or crush them in a mortar with a pestle, then stir into the onions. Tear the herbs up a bit and add them to the cream. Toss the onions and aubergines together, season them with pepper and jumble them into a baking dish.

Pour over the cream and herbs and bake in a preheated oven at 180C/gas mark 5 until golden and bubbling. It should be ready in about 30 to 40 minutes.

Upside-down rhubarb tart
Serves 6

for the pastry
200g plain flour
120g butter, cut into small chunks
2 tbsps caster sugar
1 egg yolk

for the filling
1kg rhubarb
30g butter
3 tbsps of sugar (or more to taste)
2 tbsps of sugar to finish

Put the flour into a large bowl and rub the butter into it with your fingertips until it resembles fine breadcrumbs. If you have a food processor, you can blitz the flour and butter for a few seconds instead. I tend to use the hand method simply because I like the feel of the butter and flour between my fingers. Stir in the sugar and the egg yolk with your hand and bring the dough together to form a firm ball. You won't need any water. Set the pastry aside for a while to rest.

Chop the rhubarb into thick pieces and rinse it briefly under running water. Put the 30g of butter into a 23-25cm frying pan, scatter over the 3 tablespoons of sugar and pile in the rhubarb. Warm the pan over a moderate heat, letting the butter and sugar melt and the rhubarb give up some of its juices. Now pour off some of the juice, reserving it for later, then roll or press out the pastry to fit the top of the tart tin and gently press it into place, patching up any tears or holes with bits of spare pastry.

Bake in a preheated oven at 200C/gas mark 6 for 35 to 40 minutes until the pastry is pale gold and the rhubarb is bubbling. Let it stand for 20 to 30 minutes, before turning out on to a heatproof dish. Dust the rhubarb with sugar and place under a preheated grill until caramelised. Serve with cream and some of the reserved juices.

Chop the rhubarb into thick pieces and rinse it briefly under running water. Put the 30g of butter into a 23-25cm frying pan, scatter over the 3 tablespoons of sugar and pile in the rhubarb. Warm the pan over a moderate heat, letting the butter and sugar melt and the rhubarb give up some of its juices. Now pour off some of the juice, reserving it for later, then roll or press out the pastry to fit the top of the tart tin and gently press it into place, patching up any tears or holes with bits of spare pastry. Bake in a preheated oven at 200C/gas mark 6 for 35 to 40 minutes until the pastry is pale gold and the rhubarb is bubbling. Let it stand for 20 to 30 minutes, before turning out on to a heatproof dish. Dust the rhubarb with sugar and place under a preheated grill until caramelised. Serve with cream and some of the reserved juices.

fields.headline: Students catch e-nterprise bug
fields.standfirst: Business schools adjust to capitalise on the Net gold rush, reports  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: Last week, 250 people crammed into London Business School's 'E-posium', a student-run enterprise fair dedicated to e-commerce. The week before, Cranfield Management School became 'the first in Europe', possibly the world, to make setting up a dot-com firm an integral part of students' MBA studies.
fields.body:
Last week, 250 people crammed into London Business School's 'E-posium', a student-run enterprise fair dedicated to e-commerce. The week before, Cranfield Management School became 'the first in Europe', possibly the world, to make setting up a dot-com firm an integral part of students' MBA studies.

After hitting big firms and consultancies, enterprise fever is now sweeping business schools and universities faster than a dose of Hong Kong flu. In the past year, LBS has spawned 10 businesses, some of them Internet-based, from its entrepreneurship courses and related start-up incubator.

LBS, where entrepreneurship has just achieved parity with finance and strategy as a discipline in its own right, operates its own investment fund, Sussex Place Investment Management, which can share in the upside of the ventures created.

Oxford and Cambridge are likewise in on the act. Oxford is planning its second Venturefest, an enterprise and innovation fair sponsored by heavyweights such as McKinsey and HSBC. Isis Innovation has produced a number of biotech start-ups, and the Said Business School has made new business development a major part of its MBA.

Cambridge, New Labour's favourite enterprise model, is basking in applause for having landed an 'international enterprise partnership' with the US's Massachusetts Institute of Technology, set up with government backing of £68 million.

No one denies that the pace of development has been dramatically accelerated by Internet frenzy. 'Conventional approaches to research and teaching are too slow for Internet space,' says Gerard Burke, who developed the Cranfield project. 'We needed a new way to derive and disseminate knowledge quickly, and at the same time forge a leadership position.'

To get its e-fledglings airborne Cranfield has set up an incubator which will provide access to third-party seed capital as well as other support for MBA entrepreneurs. In return it will take a small stake in their start-ups.

Just a fad? The schools accept that today's sky-high Internet valuations may be due an adjustment and that many of their Internet shooting stars will crash to earth - indeed, learning from failure, a small element in traditional courses, is an essential and salutary part of the experience. 'The first thing we impress on students is that an idea isn't the same as an opportunity,' says John Bates, who runs the LBS Foundation for Entrepreneurial Management.

But the business schools are unanimous that, under the e-froth, something fundamental is changing. On the demand side, careers offices report that students no longer want to spend their careers working their way up through big corporations.

And on the supply side, in business schools as in the economy as a whole, 'there's no question but that the time for entrepreneurship has come,' says Michael Hay, who set up the foundation.

Historically, he says, entrepreneurship was the Cinderella of business studies, wrongly confused with the management of small businesses. But as Internet opportunities expand, it is coming into its own. The emphasis can only grow in the future as even large companies are forced to reinvent themselves along more entrepreneurial, Internet-enabled lines. 'Think of it as an underground river that has always been there,' says Hay. 'Now that it's had the strength to burst through to the surface, it won't go underground again.'

For business schools, whose courses and products are running into increasing competition from internal company 'universities' and (ironically) the Internet, entrepreneurship is a godsend: it's slippery, it's difficult for companies to research and teach themselves - and it's something that everyone really, really wants.

At Warwick Business School's centre for small and medium enterprises, Professor David Storey says that compared with North America, UK entrepreneurship initiatives, although growing, hardly register. Almost every developed country in the world is beating a path to the US to see how it's done.

But it is still a 'hugely significant thing'. Storey argues - and aggregate figures don't contradict him - that past attempts to improve British management performance by formally training people already in business hasn't worked. 'The evidence that training reduces failure is very weak indeed,' he says.

On the other hand, trying to influence people while they are in the education system seems a more promising route. 'It's not a question of trying to convince everyone to set up their own firm - that's bizarre,' he says. 'But everyone should be aware of the entrepreneurial option.'

Storey's prognosis is supported by LBS research which suggests that until now UK managers have been slow to spot opportunities.

Remedying the entrepreneurship deficit would have a knock-on effect for the whole economy. 'Part of our problem in the past has been that bankers and advisers knew nothing about the entrepreneurial, small-business mindset,' notes Storey. 'But it's fundamentally different from that of large firms. A small firm is no more a big one in miniature than a caterpillar is a scaled-down butterfly.'

Cambridge is attracting praise for its innovative MIT link - even from normally jealous academics at competing institutions. 'Nowhere in the UK has there been a more successful clustering of science and business evolution, and the building of that into company formation,' says one. 'If it can learn from MIT's staggering success in generating firms that grow from small to large to world beating, it would be a massive benefit to the economy.'

 simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Jellyworks chairman walks away from £20m
fields.trailText: The chairman of Jellyworks, the Internet wonder stock, mysteriously walked away from a £20 million profit on share options before he abruptly quit last week.
fields.body:
The chairman of Jellyworks, the Internet wonder stock, mysteriously walked away from a £20 million profit on share options before he abruptly quit last week.

The revelation comes amid questions over Jellyworks' investments, strategy and expertise. The firm floated on the Alternative Investment Market just two months ago, but has soared on Internet fever since.

Ed Guinan, 52, who left the company on Thursday, was entitled to 20 million shares at 10p each before January 31; the market price is 111p. But, The Observer has established, he failed to take up the option and the chance to double the fortune he has already made.

So far Jellyworks has been tight-lipped over Guinan's departure. Its broker, Fiske & Co, also declined to shed any light on why he passed up the option. 'No comment,' said broker Deric Homes. He also stonewalled questions about a boardroom clash with the Barclay brothers, who have invested in the firm.

Jellyworks' publicity machine made great claims about Guinan, an former US Toyota salesman-turned-Wall Street trader, and about co-founder Jonathan Rowland, the 24-year-old son of veteran City investor David Rowland.

But The Observer has established that most of Guinan's ventures listed in Jellyworks' prospectus have been less than successful. He left Transmedia, a restaurant payment-card operation, following poor performance, according to ex-colleagues. Transmedia's UK operation accumulated losses of £2.6m by 1998; Countdown, a discount card company, made losses of £1.9m.

A linked venture, Purchase Point, that aimed to supply restaurants online, never got off the ground. Guinan is understood to have raised funds for Purchase Point, but according to Companies House, it has never traded.

Fraser Milne, a water purifier supplier, made losses in 1996, the last accounts filed. The firm - which was owned by International Advance Inc, Guinan's Delaware-based holding company - was dissolved last year.

Official filings also raise questions about one of Jellyworks' investments, MatchNet, a UK dating agency based in Beverly Hills. MatchNet has raised over £2m since 1998, but its UK website is still under construction and the two founders have sold most of their shares. A major shareholder in MatchNet is VMR, a German investment house, in which Jellyworks bought a £21m stake last month.

Neither Guinan nor Jonathan Rowland returned calls this weekend.

webTitle: Yes or No, Mugabe can't lose

fields.headline: Yes or No, Mugabe can't lose
fields.standfirst: The vote to reform Zimbabwe's constitution will not end corruption
fields.trailText: Elderly white ladies with blue-rinsed hair queue up next to young black men with cell phones to vote in the constitutional referendum at a polling station in Harare's leafy Highlands suburb.
fields.body:
Elderly white ladies with blue-rinsed hair queue up next to young black men with cell phones to vote in the constitutional referendum at a polling station in Harare's leafy Highlands suburb.

Across the city in Mufakose township a group of women in 'Vote Yes' T-shirts sing traditional songs outside the polling station. Voting officials ask the women to move further away and not to sing so loudly because it may influence those voting. Police are very much in evidence to prevent violent clashes between 'Yes' and 'No' supporters.

All the contrasts and contradictions of Zimbabwe lined up yesterday and today to vote on the new constitution prepared by President Robert Mugabe and his Constitutional Commission.

'We Zimbabweans are deciding our future,' said Mercy Ndoro after casting her ballot. 'But I'm sorry that we don't have a better choice. I don't think this constitution will change things. It will just give us more of the same.'

Ndoro described how she went to a public hearing by the Constitutional Commission in October last year. 'It was very exciting. Everybody wanted to say what to put in the constitution,' said Ndoro. 'They said "Less power to the President. No more Congo war. No more corruption. Let's have a smaller cabinet."

'People were so enthusiastic. They thought they could make a change.'

Similar views were voiced at scores of public hearings across the country. But with the release of the constitutional draft in December, hopes for change were dashed.

'The same people are disappointed and angry,' said Ndoro. 'They can see the President will continue to have all the power. They know nothing will be done about corruption.'

Twenty years ago, the people of what was then known as Zimbabwe-Rhodesia voted in the country's first majority-rule elections. The elections sealed the end of the bitter and bloody Rhodesian war and brought Robert Mugabe to power.

Today Mugabe has jettisoned the soothing words of racial reconciliation that brought him worldwide respect. He routinely excoriates whites, foreigners and gays for the country's problems. Mugabe, 75, is determined to stay in power and the constitution he is presenting to the nation would allow him to continue as President for another 12 years.

Despite the high level of disappointment and a spirited 'Vote No' campaign, it is likely the draft constitution will be approved by voters. While a strong 'No' vote is expected in the cities, Mugabe should get a substantial 'Yes' vote in the rural areas, where 70 per cent of Zimbabwe's 12 million people live.

The referendum is a preliminary to parliamentary elections in April. Zimbabwe is suffering an unprecedented economic crisis which has caused a desperate fuel shortage, threatens a power shortage and has caused rising popular discontent. Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party will not be able to maintain its current domination of parliament, in which it holds 147 of 150 seats, but the new constitution will assure Mugabe a firm control.

Zimbabwean civic groups two years ago began to press for the creation of a new constitution. But the crafty Mugabe, in June last year, took charge of the reform drive. While mouthing the words and going through the motions of consulting the population, he manufactured a draft constitution which maintained the status quo.

The entire process of consulting the population and drafting a constitution took less than six months. It was a hasty, rushed job in comparison to the two years that neighbouring South Africa took to produce their well-respected constitution. Appearing on national television a few nights ago to make a special appeal for a 'Yes' vote, Mugabe sported freshly dyed hair and a Savile Row suit. But his withered hands and his twitchy mannerisms revealed an elderly man trying to assert his authority.

He promised to rid the country of corruption, neatly omitting that the corruption stems from his family and his cabinet. In earlier interviews he said if journalists wrote negative reports about the army, then he would not stop the army from kidnapping and torturing those journalists. This is exactly what happened to two journalists a year ago.

webTitle: Is this the year Oscar stops looking back?

fields.headline: Is this the year Oscar stops looking back?
fields.standfirst: Period pieces have dominated the Oscars for a decade, but this year the pattern might be broken with a shift towards films set in present-day America.  Mark Morris  rates the possible nominees and wonders if time is up for history.
fields.trailText: Over the next few weeks people will eagerly tell you American Beauty has the Best Picture Oscar in the bag. After all, it's hard to think of a film that has ever come out to such a rapturous reception from critics and public alike. It's the screamingly obvious choice. But here's some advice: put your money on The Talented Mr Ripley.
fields.body:
Over the next few weeks people will eagerly tell you American Beauty has the Best Picture Oscar in the bag. After all, it's hard to think of a film that has ever come out to such a rapturous reception from critics and public alike. It's the screamingly obvious choice. But here's some advice: put your money on The Talented Mr Ripley.

You see, Ripley has history on its side. In the Nineties only one film with a wholly contemporary setting won the Best Picture award: that was The Silence Of The Lambs in 1992. But that film broke all the Academy Award conventions so thoroughly - going for terror rather than tears - that it remains the exception that proves the rule.

Otherwise the likely Best Picture contenders this year represent a voyage through time that starts with Forrest Gump 's dash through recent US history and goes all the way back to Braveheart, rewinding through World War Two ( The English Patient, Schindler's List ), the Edwardian era ( Titanic ), the West ( Unforgiven, Dances With Wolves ) and Elizabethan England ( Shakespeare In Love ).

Last year there wasn't one nominee set in the present: Shakespeare In Love beat Saving Private Ryan, The Thin Red Line, Life Is Beautiful and Elizabeth.

It is possible there are people who really think all the best films of recent times have been period pieces of some kind - but probably only James Ivory and his closest friends. And there are cruel critics who point out that for many members of the self-selecting Academy Of Motion Picture Arts And Sciences, World War Two is a contemporary event and the sinking of the Titanic the recent past.

But you get closer to the truth by examining the institutional logic of the Academy. The Oscars function as a third way in cinema. Unlike the critics, the Academy is not keen on Martin Scorsese and doesn't look kindly on subtitled films. Unlike the filmgoing public, the members aren't drawn to big explosions, horror movies, Austin Powers or sexually frustrated teenagers.

Instead the Academy is the defender of a middlebrow notion of quality. There's a reassurance about costume dramas, a feeling that they will never become dated. You can feel the sheer craft of the production - costumes, sets - in a way you can't with a realistic contemporary film - one of the reasons The English Patient beat Secrets and Lies and Jerry Maguire.

History is a McDonald's-free zone. In movies, more often than not, the past looks exquisite. But this year it looks like the pattern will be broken. (Or so we predict.) The picturesque past is likely to be represented solely by The Talented Mr Ripley. The Hurricane does stretch back to the Forties but largely takes place in an early Eighties setting which looks and feels present-day - no clunky Rubik's cube references here - and its story of an African-American abused by the forces of law and order is fiercely relevant.

After that we are talking about the acutely present-day America of The Insider and American Beauty, the bizarre but undoubtedly modern Being John Malkovich and the outside choice of The Sixth Sense.

If we are right about the nominees, the Academy will have to try to branch out a little. There is, of course, a chance we are calling it wrong, and either The Green Mile - Frank Darabont's sprawling follow-up to The Shawshank Redemption - or The End Of The Affair may sneak on to the nomination list. Both must have looked like Oscar certs in the making, but the wisdom is that their perceived flaws, and the advantages of the films on our shortlist, are just too apparent.

So if we are following history, Ripley should have it: it basks in its gorgeous Italian locations, has a soundtrack full of jazz - and the luxury of Gwyneth Paltrow and Cate Blanchett in supporting roles. Anthony Minghella has the pedigree of having already directed a Best Picture (The English Patient).

On the surface it looks perfect. But the feeling is that The Talented Mr Ripley is a little too nasty. Whereas The English Patient had the tear-jerking moments that the Academy loves, Ripley has murders that go unpunished, not to mention a creepy gay (anti) hero.

And then there is the way the story relies heavily on a notion that Americans would rather not admit: that they, too, have a vicious, distorting class system.

In fact, most of the Oscar contenders have an eye on the drawbacks of the land of the free. American Beauty - accurately dubbed Fight Club for grown-ups - takes apart the everyday lies of the American Dream while The Insider explores its institutional corruption. Even Being John Malkovich - a film too original to be 'about' anything - takes the insanity of celebrity-obsessed culture as one of its starting points.

This year it looks like the Academy is going to have to pick a film that says something harsh about America - or choose The Sixth Sense. And even that film - in the scenes set in the dreary, faded flat that Haley Joel Osment and Toni Collette live in - has a mood that harks back to the social realism of the era when Kramer Vs Kramer (1979) and Ordinary People (1980) won Best Picture in successive years.

If the Academy can't have distant Scottish warriors or Shakespeare, how about The Hurricane, the story of the struggle to free boxer Rubin Carter from wrongful imprisonment? At least it has a swelling climax, plenty of moments where even cynical audiences will shed tears, and a feelgood ending: all ideal Oscar ingredients.

The problem with The Hurricane is that it has been charged with taking just a little too much poetic license. No one is claiming that Carter was guilty all along, but an argument is raging about who was responsible for freeing him, and just how it happened.

The Insider, too, has all the drawbacks of a recent true story - too many credible witnesses springing up, claiming the real story was very different. So if we rule out Being John Malkovich as too daring and The Sixth Sense as too crowd pleasing - that brings us back to American Beauty after all.

American Beauty is clever, bleak, funny and very much of the moment. All in all, the kind of film that never wins the Best Picture Oscar. This time it just might. But don't write off Ripley: for the Academy, living in the past is a hard habit to break.

The Hurricane does stretch back to the Forties but largely takes place in an early Eighties setting which looks and feels present-day - no clunky Rubik's cube references here - and its story of an African-American abused by the forces of law and order is fiercely relevant. After that we are talking about the acutely present-day America of The Insider and American Beauty, the bizarre but undoubtedly modern Being John Malkovich and the outside choice of The Sixth Sense. If we are right about the nominees, the Academy will have to try to branch out a little. There is, of course, a chance we are calling it wrong, and either The Green Mile - Frank Darabont's sprawling follow-up to The Shawshank Redemption - or The End Of The Affair may sneak on to the nomination list. Both must have looked like Oscar certs in the making, but the wisdom is that their perceived flaws, and the advantages of the films on our shortlist, are just too apparent. So if we are following history, Ripley should have it: it basks in its gorgeous Italian locations, has a soundtrack full of jazz - and the luxury of Gwyneth Paltrow and Cate Blanchett in supporting roles. Anthony Minghella has the pedigree of having already directed a Best Picture (The English Patient). On the surface it looks perfect. But the feeling is that The Talented Mr Ripley is a little too nasty. Whereas The English Patient had the tear-jerking moments that the Academy loves, Ripley has murders that go unpunished, not to mention a creepy gay (anti) hero. And then there is the way the story relies heavily on a notion that Americans would rather not admit: that they, too, have a vicious, distorting class system. In fact, most of the Oscar contenders have an eye on the drawbacks of the land of the free. American Beauty - accurately dubbed Fight Club for grown-ups - takes apart the everyday lies of the American Dream while The Insider explores its institutional corruption. Even Being John Malkovich - a film too original to be 'about' anything - takes the insanity of celebrity-obsessed culture as one of its starting points. This year it looks like the Academy is going to have to pick a film that says something harsh about America - or choose The Sixth Sense. And even that film - in the scenes set in the dreary, faded flat that Haley Joel Osment and Toni Collette live in - has a mood that harks back to the social realism of the era when Kramer Vs Kramer (1979) and Ordinary People (1980) won Best Picture in successive years. If the Academy can't have distant Scottish warriors or Shakespeare, how about The Hurricane, the story of the struggle to free boxer Rubin Carter from wrongful imprisonment? At least it has a swelling climax, plenty of moments where even cynical audiences will shed tears, and a feelgood ending: all ideal Oscar ingredients. The problem with The Hurricane is that it has been charged with taking just a little too much poetic license. No one is claiming that Carter was guilty all along, but an argument is raging about who was responsible for freeing him, and just how it happened. The Insider, too, has all the drawbacks of a recent true story - too many credible witnesses springing up, claiming the real story was very different. So if we rule out Being John Malkovich as too daring and The Sixth Sense as too crowd pleasing - that brings us back to American Beauty after all. American Beauty is clever, bleak, funny and very much of the moment. All in all, the kind of film that never wins the Best Picture Oscar. This time it just might. But don't write off Ripley: for the Academy, living in the past is a hard habit to break.

webTitle: Fast Forward: The loafer's guide to popular culture

fields.headline: Fast Forward: The loafer's guide to popular culture
fields.standfirst: A Clockwork Orange
fields.trailText: The loafer's guide to popular culture. We consume it, so you don't have to. This week: A Clockwork Orange
fields.body:
The banned movie? Stanley Kubrick's version of the 1962 Anthony Burgess novel was first released in January 1972, when censor Stephen Murphy - already in trouble for giving Sam Peckinpah's Straw Dogs a certificate - brought down the wrath of middle England when he passed Kubrick's film as suitable for over-18s.

So it wasn't suppressed by the censor? The film was quietly withdrawn by the director when its 61-week run ended - a ban that only came to light in 1979, when the National Film Theatre asked for a copy to show in a retrospective. Kubrick was responding to the press campaign and a series of alleged 'copycat' crimes - including two separate incidents in which youths beat a tramp to death, claiming to be influenced by the film.

So what's the story? It is set in an undetermined future very similar to the present (much of it was filmed on location at Thamesmead, Wandsworth Bridge roundabout, Brunel University - chosen by Kubrick as the cutting edge of late-1960s architecture). Malcolm McDowell stars as Alex, the amoral hero who, according to the film's own press material, is interested in 'rape, ultraviolence and Beethoven'. He and his gang commit random acts of violence, but the state responds with a brutality that is even worse, brainwashing Alex with aversion therapy, and parading him gruesomely before the media.

Is the violence still shocking? To a soundtrack of Rossini, a tramp and a wealthy art collector are beaten to death. But it is all deliberately distant and choreographed, intended as a satire on violence.

So what's the problem? In both book and film, the charismatic Alex takes on a life of his own. You are meant to be repulsed, but instead are seduced. Nadsat, the slang invented by Burgess, renders Alex and his thugs poets, their words concealing their deeds: horrorshow (good); groodies (breasts); yarbles (testicles); tolchock (to hit). Noting teddy boys' subversion of upper-class Edwardian dress codes, Burgess dressed his thugs in bowler hats and umbrellas. The film's most enduring image is McDowell peering from under the brim of his hat: a pin-up for disaffected youth.

Is it Kubrick's masterpiece? Anything taboo is exciting, but A Clockwork Orange has dated far faster than, say, 2001: A Space Odyssey. Now that Kubrick is dead, you can see for yourself - it returns to UK cinemas in March, and censor Andreas Whittam Smith has granted an 18 certificate.

webTitle: Everyone's talking about...  Deborah Kara Unger's big cover-up

fields.headline: Everyone's talking about...  Deborah Kara Unger's big cover-up
fields.trailText: If Alfred Hitchcock were still alive he would put in an urgent call to Deborah Kara Unger's agent. Unger, the Canadian star of Crash and The Game, would be perfectly cast as the glacial blonde lead in one of his beguiling thrillers.
fields.body:
If Alfred Hitchcock were still alive he would put in an urgent call to Deborah Kara Unger's agent. Unger, the Canadian star of Crash and The Game, would be perfectly cast as the glacial blonde lead in one of his beguiling thrillers.

That is why it's a surprise to see her playing an altruist in The Hurricane, a biopic charting the struggles of the Sixties' champion boxer Rubin Carter (Denzel Washington) to overturn his wrongful conviction for murder. At the centre of the film is Carter's stirring relationship with a black teenager and the three members of a Canadian commune who played an important role in securing his eventual release.

As a member of the commune, Unger embodies the type of saintly qualities seldom seen outside Hollywood movies, possibly because they don't exist. It's a 180-degree turn from her previous role as the duplicitous junkie wife of Mel Gibson in Payback.

But Unger has made her name playing ice-cool femmes after a quirky start to her career. She finished high school and inspired by antipodean cinema became the first Canadian to study at the Australian National Institute of Dramatic Art. On graduation she was taken on by Gibson's agent and found a steady flow of work in Australian television dramas and movies. In the early Nineties she moved to North America, starring in the little seen but favourably received psycho-sexual drama Whispers In The Dark (1992) and as Christopher Lambert's lover in the woeful Highlander III (1994). Then she won the role that made her famous and infamous.

In David Cronenberg's controversial Crash, which brought new meaning to back-seat car frolics, she began the movie with her naked breast pressed to an aeroplane. She proceeded to lick the paint, while her lover licked her. Then she went home and calmly swapped infidelity tales with husband, James Spader. It was, literally, the role of a lifetime.

She nearly didn't make it to Hollywood to make the movie. American immigration officials didn't believe her when she arrived in LA without a work permit.

They were unimpressed by the script proffered by the putative star and, after reading a particularly graphic section, they sent her back to the Canada claiming she was seeking entry to film a porn flick. The critically well-received Crash opened doors and Unger was inundated with sexy roles. But when director David Fincher was looking for a 'career waitress' type to star in his complex thriller The Game, he picked Unger to star opposite Michael Douglas after first considering Jodie Foster.

After auditions with Daniel Day-Lewis, Robert De Niro, Al Pacino and Tom Cruise, Unger, 33, was shocked to get the female lead in The Game. She was equally happy to find a role that didn't require her to bare all again. 'It was terrific to be in a movie where I got an entire wardrobe,' she said.

Later this year she appears opposite Ralph Fiennes in the historical romance Sunshine and takes the sole leading role in the indie picture The History of Luminous Motion. Her future looks bright, too.

Five things you should know about Deborah Kara Unger

1 The American Screen Actors Guild asked her to change her name because another actress is called Deborah Unger.

2 She didn't have a showbiz background: her mother was a nuclear scientist and her father a gynaecologist.

3 She began her career performing in telethons.

4 Of Crash she says: 'I was terrified every day because of all the sex scenes.'

5She now lives in Los Angeles 'just east of the "D" in the Hollywood sign'.

fields.headline: It's a bubble. Who'll squeak?
fields.standfirst: Fund chiefs risk the sack unless they pile in. But a crash will hit savers too, says  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: When FTSE International meets on 8 March to decide who is in and out, up and down, in the stock market, construction company BICC's lowly £330 million market capitalisation means it could be demoted to the small-cap index - of the smallest companies in the market. But Baltimore Technologies, a supplier of secure systems for the Internet and now worth £3.4 billion, could be elevated to the FTSE 100 index - of the largest ones.
fields.body:
When FTSE International meets on 8 March to decide who is in and out, up and down, in the stock market, construction company BICC's lowly £330 million market capitalisation means it could be demoted to the small-cap index - of the smallest companies in the market. But Baltimore Technologies, a supplier of secure systems for the Internet and now worth £3.4 billion, could be elevated to the FTSE 100 index - of the largest ones.

Yet eight years ago, BICC sat squarely in the FTSE 100. Last year its sales totalled more than £3bn, and its profits are likely to have been more than £50m.

Baltimore is better known as a city on the east coast of the United States than as a business. This is hardly surprising given that, until last December, the company was in the FTSE Fledgling index of those too tiny even to count as small. Its total sales last year were probably less than £25m and it lost a similar amount.

BICC and Baltimore are just two of the more extreme examples of the split that is emerging in the stock market between new and old economies. Any company associated with the new technologies of the Internet and the mobile phone - such as Vodafone, ARM Holdings, or service companies such as FI Group - are in huge demand. What has been attracting less attention, however, is the knock-on effect of this on the constituents of the old economy.

Whole swathes of the stock market, including such sectors as retailing, property, engineering, construction and leisure are being largely ignored by investors desperate to put their money into high technology. Companies as disparate as Invensys and Next, British Land and Bass are seeing their ratings plunge to unprecedented lows.

The plunge looks as though it is accelerating. Last week alone, companies such as BICC, Mayflower, and BBA lost more than 10 per cent of their value - yet nothing within them had changed.

The falls were blamed on Vodafone. Victory in its bid for Mannesmann means that it will now represent 14 per cent of the FTSE100 index, and many institutions found themselves short of shares. To get their weightings up, they had to sell something, and it was old-economy stocks that suffered.

But last week's moves were part of a deeper rebalancing of investors' portfolios. They are looking to the future and concluding that the Internet is changing everything. Inflation is disappearing and the web is adding to that pressure.

Companies in the old economy can no longer rely on pushing through price increases to drive their profits up. But few of them can bank on volume rises, either: businesses such as chemicals, retailing and much of the rest of manufacturing industry are seeing low growth, or none at all. The only way to keep profits growing is to keep costs falling - hence the spate of mergers among old-economy companies.

Companies in the new economy, by contrast, are growing fast. Baltimore may not be making profits - few of the new technology stocks are - but it is expected to almost double its sales this year. The City is banking on that sales growth eventually translating into healthy profit rises. But the change has taken many investors by surprise. Their portfolios are still heavily weighted to the old economy, and they are struggling to increase their exposure to the fashionable sectors.

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson calculates that, at the end of September (the latest figures available) British institutions were 10 per cent under weight in both telecommunications services and software and its services.

By contrast, they were at least 30 per cent overweight in old-economy sectors such as construction, packaging and cars. Funds without a sufficient weighting in new economy sectors - and that includes almost every institution - are underperforming, and rushing to buy. The greater the rush, the more prices rise and the more stock the institutions need to get their weightings right.

David Rough, group director of investments at Legal & General, says it has become irrelevant whether technology stocks will perform well enough to justify their share prices. 'Given how funds have performed over the past two years, you cannot justify not holding these stocks. If your job, your bonus and your performance are measured on how well you are performing, you can't go on saying the emperor has no clothes forever.'

And he points out that the performance of some of the engineers had been poor, while many were simply too small to attract much attention. To reverse the declines, they had to do something: such as buy in their shares or merge with rivals. If they survive long enough, that is: recent French bids for Marley and Blue Circle underline how vulnerable the old-economy companies have become. A growing number of commentators think the rise in technology stocks looks like a bubble, and warn that it will burst. That may be bad news for investors who have paid inflated prices to get their hands on technology shares, but it probably means shares in the old economy 'will not fall as fast', said Rough.

'Sure there is a bubble,' said Andrew Lapthorne of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. 'But it still makes more sense to be invested in the bubble companies than it does in the old-economy stocks.'

That may be true for the fund managers: if they continue to avoid technology stocks, they may be out of a job when the bubble bursts. The rest of us, whose pensions and savings are funding the institutions' dash for growth, may be less lucky. We could find ourselves holding the booby prize.

fields.headline: Bitter and twisting
fields.standfirst: Neil Jordan captures the spirit of the bitterly comic and cruel landscape that is Greeneland The End of the Affair
fields.trailText: Philip French: It's about faith, transcendence and the possibility of sainthood in the modern world. It's also full of self-loathing and mockery and the chilly Ralph Fiennes has not only those disturbingly penetrating eyes we associate with Greene, but also the 'splinter of ice in the heart' that Greene thought a writer should have
fields.body:
'The subject is sexual passion, a rarer subject than you might think on the screen and the treatment is adult: there isn't, thank God, any love in it.'

I might have begun my review of Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair with that sentence. It was in fact written in 1937 for the short-lived magazine Night and Day by my favourite movie critic, Graham Greene, about a British film he admired called Brief Ecstasy, directed by a Frenchman, Edmond Gréville.

'The story of the struggle between tenderness and sexual desire,' this melodrama concerned the adulterous affair between a handsome adventurer and the beautiful wife of a kindly, well-off older man who was incapable of satisfying her.

Brief Ecstasy anticipates the now much publicised postwar affair that Greene had with Catherine Walston, the young wife of a rich left-wing landowner, which provided Greene with the plot of The End of the Affair, the 1951 novel published long before the affair was over.

It is wrong, however, to read the book as autobiographical, though the character of its narrator, the novelist Maurice Bendrix, began a series of painful self-portraits that continued with the journalist Fowler in The Quiet American and the architect Querry in A Burnt-Out Case.

The End of the Affair is a curious, very literary novel, cruel, bitterly comic, self-lacerating, a Catholic book written, so Greene's friend Evelyn Waugh claimed, to beguile Protestants by its paradoxes. It was also the first time Greene used a first-person narrator and told his story in a complicated series of flashbacks. Both conventions are observed in the adaptation by his fellow Catholic novelist Neil Jordan, who is consistently true to the book's spirit while making several crucial changes.

The End of the Affair begins in 1939 when the critically esteemed, commercially unsuccessful writer Bendrix (Ralph Fiennes) meets Sarah (Julianne Moore), the attractive young wife of the mild-mannered senior civil servant Henry Miles (Stephen Rea), whom Bendrix is studying as the subject for a novel.

They immediately embark on a passionate love affair, the entirely carnal nature of which Jordan captures in their furtive, unlyrical couplings. The affair ends abruptly in 1944 during an air raid when a flying bomb explodes on Clapham Common in south-west London and Sarah, thinking Bendrix is dead, makes a pact with God to forgo her lover if He will spare his life.

Two years later, the embittered, rejected, jealous Bendrix, supposedly acting on the complaisant husband's behalf, and not understanding why he was rejected, hires a private detective to investigate the identity of his rival, only to discover - from a purloined diary - that he is in fact God.

Jordan, with his designers and cinematographer, skilfully re-creates that austere corner of Greeneland that is wartime London to which the passports are ration books and Catholic missals. But the Second World War merely serves to frame the action.

Although they're both excited by the possibility of imminent death in the form of a German bomb ending their love, Bendrix the agnostic novelist and Sarah his Catholic lover are wholly indifferent to this vast, global conflict in their pursuit of sex and salvation.

Jordan (unwisely in my view) turns the childhood accident that makes Bendrix unfit for military service into something more heroic, a wound suffered in the Spanish Civil War, but otherwise The End of the Affair is Casablanca or any other morally-inclined war picture turned on its head.

Duty and patriotism don't figure at all in the lovers' thoughts, and only dimly for the decent Henry, whose chief motivation is the progress in his public career from OBE to CBE to KBE, those political baubles Greene despised.

The End of the Affair is about the novelist as God, and God as a novelist who gives his characters free will. It's about faith, transcendence and the possibility of sainthood in the modern world. It's also full of self-loathing and mockery and the chilly Ralph Fiennes has not only those disturbingly penetrating eyes we associate with Greene, but also the 'splinter of ice in the heart' that Greene thought a writer should have.

When Bendrix takes Sarah to see a film based on one of his books, the movie they see is Twenty-One Days, the Laurence Olivier-Vivien Leigh picture Greene scripted and subsequently reviewed for the Spectator, remarking: 'Meanwhile, let one guilty man stand in the dock swearing never, never to do it again.'

Julianne Moore and Stephen Rea, both affecting flawless English accents suitable to the period, are equally good. But the movie's chief touch of everyday humanity comes in the comic interludes involving Ian Hart as the touchingly clumsy private detective, Parkis, so called out of homage to Dickens, a reading of whose Great Expectations persuaded Greene to attempt a first-person narrative.

Greene did some rewriting on the novel for its 1974 appearance in the Collected Edition, turning the birthmark on the face of the atheistic preacher Smythe, that the saintly Sarah 'cured' by her touch into a possibly psychosomatic condition.

Jordan has continued this process, conflating the characters of Smythe and the fearsome Father Crompton into a single, benevolent priest (though retaining the name Smythe), and transferring the birthmark from the atheist to the private detec tive's schoolboy son, thus reducing the number of 'miracles'.

More debatably, Jordan has Bendrix and Sarah briefly revive their affair after the war and make a trip to Brighton before her death. In addition, he has Sarah aware of her secret childhood baptism as a Catholic, which makes things easier for rationalists in the audience and renders unnecessary the appearance of Sarah's mother, the prototype for Augusta Bertram in Travels With My Aunt .

I was more sorry not to see on the screen the encounter between Bendrix and the offensive young critic Waterbury, one of the novel's funniest episodes.

There is little doubt where Graham Greene would have stood on the current conflict between the producers of The End of the Affair and the British censors. He was a consistent opponent of censorship and as a movie critic regularly attacked the Hollywood Production Code and the BBFC, admittedly a rather more ridiculous body in his day. Jordan retains quite a lot of Greene's dialogue, including a joke Bendrix makes in borrowing Parkis's son to deceive Smythe. 'This scene,' he reassures the detective, 'will have a Universal certificate.'
fields.bodyText: 'The subject is sexual passion, a rarer subject than you might think on the screen and the treatment is adult: there isn't, thank God, any love in it.' I might have begun my review of Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair with that sentence. It was in fact written in 1937 for the short-lived magazine Night and Day by my favourite movie critic, Graham Greene, about a British film he admired called Brief Ecstasy, directed by a Frenchman, Edmond Gréville. 'The story of the struggle between tenderness and sexual desire,' this melodrama concerned the adulterous affair between a handsome adventurer and the beautiful wife of a kindly, well-off older man who was incapable of satisfying her. Brief Ecstasy anticipates the now much publicised postwar affair that Greene had with Catherine Walston, the young wife of a rich left-wing landowner, which provided Greene with the plot of The End of the Affair, the 1951 novel published long before the affair was over. It is wrong, however, to read the book as autobiographical, though the character of its narrator, the novelist Maurice Bendrix, began a series of painful self-portraits that continued with the journalist Fowler in The Quiet American and the architect Querry in A Burnt-Out Case. The End of the Affair is a curious, very literary novel, cruel, bitterly comic, self-lacerating, a Catholic book written, so Greene's friend Evelyn Waugh claimed, to beguile Protestants by its paradoxes. It was also the first time Greene used a first-person narrator and told his story in a complicated series of flashbacks. Both conventions are observed in the adaptation by his fellow Catholic novelist Neil Jordan, who is consistently true to the book's spirit while making several crucial changes. The End of the Affair begins in 1939 when the critically esteemed, commercially unsuccessful writer Bendrix (Ralph Fiennes) meets Sarah (Julianne Moore), the attractive young wife of the mild-mannered senior civil servant Henry Miles (Stephen Rea), whom Bendrix is studying as the subject for a novel. They immediately embark on a passionate love affair, the entirely carnal nature of which Jordan captures in their furtive, unlyrical couplings. The affair ends abruptly in 1944 during an air raid when a flying bomb explodes on Clapham Common in south-west London and Sarah, thinking Bendrix is dead, makes a pact with God to forgo her lover if He will spare his life. Two years later, the embittered, rejected, jealous Bendrix, supposedly acting on the complaisant husband's behalf, and not understanding why he was rejected, hires a private detective to investigate the identity of his rival, only to discover - from a purloined diary - that he is in fact God. Jordan, with his designers and cinematographer, skilfully re-creates that austere corner of Greeneland that is wartime London to which the passports are ration books and Catholic missals. But the Second World War merely serves to frame the action. Although they're both excited by the possibility of imminent death in the form of a German bomb ending their love, Bendrix the agnostic novelist and Sarah his Catholic lover are wholly indifferent to this vast, global conflict in their pursuit of sex and salvation. Jordan (unwisely in my view) turns the childhood accident that makes Bendrix unfit for military service into something more heroic, a wound suffered in the Spanish Civil War, but otherwise The End of the Affair is Casablanca or any other morally-inclined war picture turned on its head. Duty and patriotism don't figure at all in the lovers' thoughts, and only dimly for the decent Henry, whose chief motivation is the progress in his public career from OBE to CBE to KBE, those political baubles Greene despised. The End of the Affair is about the novelist as God, and God as a novelist who gives his characters free will. It's about faith, transcendence and the possibility of sainthood in the modern world. It's also full of self-loathing and mockery and the chilly Ralph Fiennes has not only those disturbingly penetrating eyes we associate with Greene, but also the 'splinter of ice in the heart' that Greene thought a writer should have. When Bendrix takes Sarah to see a film based on one of his books, the movie they see is Twenty-One Days, the Laurence Olivier-Vivien Leigh picture Greene scripted and subsequently reviewed for the Spectator, remarking: 'Meanwhile, let one guilty man stand in the dock swearing never, never to do it again.' Julianne Moore and Stephen Rea, both affecting flawless English accents suitable to the period, are equally good. But the movie's chief touch of everyday humanity comes in the comic interludes involving Ian Hart as the touchingly clumsy private detective, Parkis, so called out of homage to Dickens, a reading of whose Great Expectations persuaded Greene to attempt a first-person narrative. Greene did some rewriting on the novel for its 1974 appearance in the Collected Edition, turning the birthmark on the face of the atheistic preacher Smythe, that the saintly Sarah 'cured' by her touch into a possibly psychosomatic condition. Jordan has continued this process, conflating the characters of Smythe and the fearsome Father Crompton into a single, benevolent priest (though retaining the name Smythe), and transferring the birthmark from the atheist to the private detec tive's schoolboy son, thus reducing the number of 'miracles'. More debatably, Jordan has Bendrix and Sarah briefly revive their affair after the war and make a trip to Brighton before her death. In addition, he has Sarah aware of her secret childhood baptism as a Catholic, which makes things easier for rationalists in the audience and renders unnecessary the appearance of Sarah's mother, the prototype for Augusta Bertram in Travels With My Aunt . I was more sorry not to see on the screen the encounter between Bendrix and the offensive young critic Waterbury, one of the novel's funniest episodes. There is little doubt where Graham Greene would have stood on the current conflict between the producers of The End of the Affair and the British censors. He was a consistent opponent of censorship and as a movie critic regularly attacked the Hollywood Production Code and the BBFC, admittedly a rather more ridiculous body in his day. Jordan retains quite a lot of Greene's dialogue, including a joke Bendrix makes in borrowing Parkis's son to deceive Smythe. 'This scene,' he reassures the detective, 'will have a Universal certificate.'

fields.headline: Godfather's girl gets a life
fields.trailText: Hip, cool and happily married, Sofia Coppola has energed from the shadow of her famous father to become an accomplished film director
fields.body:
Last summer's most exclusive wedding? Not Edward and Sophie's; nor Posh and Becks's; and you can forget Zoë Ball and Norman Cook's shindig at Babington House. The coolest invitation of all - so cool that the tabloids didn't even know about it, let alone gate-crash it - was to celebrate the union of Sofia Coppola and Spike Jonze: Hollywood's two newest, sharpest directors. The party was held at her family estate in the Napa Valley; her father, Francis Ford Coppola, served wine from 1971, the year of her birth. 'This is the last of my very best wine,' he announced. 'It's called Sofia.'

The guests were as hip as could be: Anna Sui, Marc Jacobs, Kirsty Hume, Donovan Leitch, Tom Waits, Zoe Cassavetes... After the party, the couple left for a honeymoon in Bora Bora, having completed their films, Sofia's The Virgin Suicides and Spike's Being John Malkovich, to critical acclaim.

Still, it hasn't always been easy being Sofia Coppola. Ten years ago Sofia was the object of almost universal derision after her father cast her as Al Pacino's daughter in The Godfather Part III. After that public humiliation, she buried herself in her studies, emerged briefly as a model, then kept her head below the parapet for several years with Milk Fed, her own fashion label, a tiny clothes shop in LA and a sideline in photography.

But Sofia Coppola was drawn back into the family business when she fell in love with Jeffrey Eugenides's novel, The Virgin Suicides . She turned it into a screenplay and then found herself directing it, with Kathleen Turner and James Woods in starring roles. The film's premiere in Cannes last year received exceptional reviews and, when we met the day after the its screening at the London Film Festival, the response was equally positive. 'People told me they liked it,' she says, so quietly that I have to lean forward to hear her. 'But they were surprised they liked it. I suppose that's inevitable - some people find it hard to separate my history from who I am.'

Today she appears to be an extraordinarily ordinary girl: young, skinny, dark, shy, like a sixth-former who's been let off school for the afternoon. I'm beginning to wonder if she really is Sofia Coppola (her husband has an alarming habit of turning up in weird disguises or staging fights in front of journalists). After a while, she seems so effortlessly cool, you can't keep your eyes off her: battered jeans, white Aertex top, tiny diamond stud earrings and sneakers.

Like its director, The Virgin Suicides is mysterious, in a gentle sort of way. That, perhaps, is what makes it so beguiling. It doesn't shriek, nor does it offer a pat plot and a conventional finale. 'I like the fact that the story doesn't answer everything,' says Coppola. 'There are things in life that you can't understand.'

The Virgin Suicides tells the tale of the Lisbon sisters, five suburban golden girls who kill themselves, observed by a chorus of unnamed neighbourhood boys who, despite their best efforts, remain unable to comprehend the reasons for these deaths. 'I never had a sister,' says Sofia, 'but like anyone who has experienced that kind of loss, that there's no reason for...' Her voice trails away into silence, before she adds: 'You can't spend the rest of your life looking for a reason.'

Sofia Coppola's 22-year-old brother, brother, Gian Carlo, died in a boating accident in 1986. His girlfriend was pregnant at the time and their daughter, Sofia's niece, is now 13. Clearly, it's an age that Sofia remembers vividly. 'I found it really frustrating,' she says. 'You look like a little kid, yet in your head you're a grown-up.'

Later, Sofia says that she doesn't want people to assume that she only made the film because of the death of her brother. But clearly, Eugenides's novel, with its landscape of inexplicable tragedy and teenage grief that blasts adult lives apart, had a profound effect on her. 'I read it maybe five years ago, just after it came out. It wasn't like I was looking for a movie to make, but I loved the book,' she says, with uncharacteristic emphasis. 'It was like someone understands you, has written it just for you. A year or so later, I heard that somebody else was trying to make a film out of it - a guy who was adding sex and violence - and I thought, "Oh no, that doesn't sound right," so I decided I'd sit down and write a screenplay myself.'

She had no experience and no training, other than a lifetime of listening to her father talk about the art of filmmaking. 'I thought about going to film school, but then I realised I learnt more from my dad,' she says. 'It's so contagious, his enthusiasm.'

Sofia's screenplay was sufficiently impressive to persuade the producers to hand the project over to her. Interestingly, she has turned what might have been a work of desolation into something more hopeful. 'The Lisbon sisters taught the boys about love - and that's uplifting,' she remarks. 'I didn't want the film to be gruesome, and I didn't want people to leave the cinema feeling sad.'

It is tempting to speculate what her father might have felt about the story, having lost his own child in a savage stroke of fate. 'I didn't tell him about it at first,' she says, cautiously. 'I wrote it in secret. And then I gave it to my dad to read, and he was really moved by it.'

You can see why appearing in her father's film would have been such a torment; and also why she needs to frame emotions elsewhere, through her own lens.

'It is really comforting to see someone expressing something you can relate to,' she says. 'That way, you feel less alone...'

We say goodbye, but bump into each other again the following evening at a party. She's there without Spike, looking smaller than ever. Slowly, a group of people gathers around her: glamorous models, famous photographers, film stars. She is at the centre, looking out, watchful, quiet, compelling. No husband at her side; certainly no need for her father's directions... Suddenly, Sofia Coppola looks very powerful indeed.

 Justine Picardie@Vogue/ The Condé Nast Publications Ltd. A full version of this feature appears in the March edition of Vogue.

The Virgin Suicides opens in May.

fields.headline: One man's poisoner...
fields.standfirst: Andrew Motion turns away from poets and towards a painter, forger, wastrel - and killer in Wainewright the Poisoner
fields.trailText: Andrew Motion turns away from poets and towards a painter, forger, wastrel - and killer in Wainewright the Poisoner
fields.body:
Wainewright the Poisoner

Andrew Motion

Faber and Faber £20, pp305

Having written biographies of Philip Larkin and John Keats, Andrew Motion has chosen as his next subject a nearly unknown and semi-criminal artist, Thomas Griffiths Wainewright, now forgotten to all but specialists of early Australian painting. It is a curious choice. As if burdened by the fame of his previous subjects, Motion must have wanted to write about someone who was more of a tabula rasa. The book is constructed as if it were Wainewright's autobiography, written during his last days as a convict in Tasmania, and then interspersed with lengthy footnotes which give detailed historical material relating to each of the chapters. It is an odd conceit for a biographer, but one which enables Motion to get (literally) into his subject's mind.

Wainewright was the grandson of Ralph Griffiths, the editor of an eighteenth-century periodical, the Monthly Review, who made a fortune from the publication of John Cleland's erotic novel, Fanny Hill. He was educated at school in Greenwich by Fanny Burney's brother and, after a period with the Bedfordshire Regiment of Foot, trained as a painter under Thomas Phillips, perhaps best remembered for his portrait of Byron, a version of which is in the National Portrait Gallery.

During the early 1820s, Wainewright and his wife Eliza rented lodgings in Great Marlborough Street. He did a little bit of painting in a post-Fuseli manner, exhibited regularly at the Royal Academy, dealt in Old Master prints, made friends with a number of his better remembered contemporaries, including William Hazlitt and Charles Lamb, and wrote articles for the London Magazine under the pseudonym 'Janus Weathercock'. His problem was that none of these activities provided sufficient funds for an extravagant life, even when supplemented by the interest from a family trust. To solve the problem, he chose to forge the signature of his trustees in order to obtain access to the capital left to him by the terms of his grandfather's will.

Wainewright thought that he could improve his situation by giving up his lodgings in Great Marlborough Street in order to live with his uncle in a large-ish house in Chiswick. But his uncle died shortly afterwards, leaving him his estate, but also the cost of running the house. At this point, he began to turn desperate and was believed by his contemporaries to have required his sister-in-law to take out substantial life insurance and then to have poisoned her.

Since Motion is writing from the viewpoint of Wainewright, he makes out that the so-called poisoning was food-poisoning, as if his sister-in-law had died from a surfeit of beer and lobster. But the evidence of the multiple insurance claims must be said to count against him. He was forced to leave England for France, but, in time, his deception as far as the forgery was concerned caught up with him and he spent a period in Newgate prison before being transported to Tasmania. He was never tried for murder but pursued for the rest of his life by a widespread assumption that he was a poisoner.

In Tasmania, when eventually released from penitentiary labour, he undertook effective pencil drawings of some of the citizens of Hobart Town, which convey some of the rigours of early settlement life and, given the degree interest in relics of early Australiana, have given Wainewright his posthumous fame.

What obviously attracted Motion to Wainewright is the way in which his life represents the underbelly of the romantic movement. All the romantic poets were interested in extremes of emotion and there were frequent undertones in their writings of sadism and death. But for most of them, these interests were theoretical. Wainewright is the living epitome of the idea of evil.

But the problem of writing the book from Wainewright's perspective is that Motion manages to make Wainewright sound comparatively anodyne, as if poisoning one's sister-in-law and forging signatures were everyday events. This removes some of the drama from Wainewright's life. And while it was presumably an interesting exercise to write the whole book from the mindset of the subject, in the end one begins to long for more critical detachment and less of the orotundities of early nine teenth-century prose style.

The obvious point of comparison for the book is the work of Peter Ackroyd. Like Ackroyd, Andrew Motion has a brilliant ear for language and a creative feel for the circumstances of early nineteenth-century art, literature and London. In terms of its literary genre, his book is substantially more of a fiction than, for example, Ackroyd's biography of Blake, but less so than his Dan Leno and the Limehouse Golem. But I am not persuaded that Motion, in contrast to Ackroyd, has a novelist's gift for narrative. In the end, his book is clever, but not compelling, a brave attempt to re-invent the life and attitudes of an intriguing historical figure, but a book which falls between the different literary requirements of fiction and of history.
