fields.headline: Truly, madly, Ripley
fields.standfirst: The Talented Mr Ripley is hotly tipped for the Oscars. Its director explains why he believes that there's a little bit of Patricia Highsmith's murderous hero in all of us...
fields.trailText: The Talented Mr Ripley is hotly tipped for the Oscars. Director Anthony Minghella explains why he believes that there's a little bit of Patricia Highsmith's murderous hero in all of us...
fields.body:
Just after I graduated from university, I was commissioned to write a small play for a local theatre company. The opportunity came on the back of a fledgling excursion into writing when, as a student, I had sufficient hubris to present a musical, which I also directed, acted and sang in. I cringe at the thought of it.

Nevertheless, playwright Alan Plater, then chairman of the theatre company, saw enough in my crude efforts to give me the chance to work with professional actors. I duly wrote the play and directed it. My chief memory of the experience was at an early performance on tour in Grimsby, where our audience comprised mainly elderly coach parties.

The play began with a bleak monologue in the dark. I thought it extremely dramatic. After a few minutes, the audience felt moved to complain noisily of what they assumed was an electrical failure. Then they proceeded to head for the exit. Alan's programme notes described the play as being in the spirit of Patricia Highsmith. I had never heard of Highsmith, but thought I should find some of her work. The book I stumbled across concerned the exploits of a young American living in Europe called Tom Ripley.

Almost 20 years later, Sydney Pollack, another mentor, asked me to adapt The Talented Mr Ripley for his company. At that time, I was marooned in my attempts to make The English Patient and felt - on the basis of my one, specious, and not entirely auspicious connection to the author - that it might be something to consider.

In the Ripley novels, of which The Talented Mr Ripley is the first, a person can live or die, sometimes literally, on the strength of their choice of cocktail. Taste is everything. Highsmith rarely describes the physical geography, eschews adjectives, sketches out a moment in impatient and irritable prose. There seems little distance between her own baleful view of the world and that of her protagonist's, who travels through a handful of novels, behaving badly, never caught.

You enter into an airless, claustrophobic world with Tom Ripley. Almost no other character is fully alive, and his cool, dislocated perspective lures the reader in, convincing us that what objectively might be heinous makes perfect sense inside Ripley's head. The world, experienced through this skinless sensibility, is an alarming place - Ripley feels so intensely, can be giddy with excitement or despair. He is always an outsider, straining for companionship but destined to be alone.

His actions are an extreme response to emotions all of us recognise: the sense that there is a better life being lived by somebody else, somewhere else, someone not trapped inside the hollow existence in which we find ourselves. It's one of the things which makes us human. We've all been Tom Ripley, just as we've all known a Dickie Greenleaf, the man who has everything, whose attention makes us feel special. We've all basked in the sunshine of that attention and felt the chill of losing it.

It was this unsettling connection to Ripley and the anxiety that what happens to him is familiar, at least in nightmares, that prompted me to make this film. Not the empathy for a hero, but the queasy recognition that this plausible misfit is not so far from one version of ourselves; not approval but an acknowledgment that this is where we might end up without the reassuringly tight belt of morality around our waists.

In adapting the novel to film lay the challenge of exciting the audience to commit to the material as I did as a reader, to inhabit each step of Ripley's journey. Adaptation for film is, by definition, a process of editorialising. The dramatist is obliged to make innumerable decisions - what is the book about? How will it fit into the prescribed length of a movie? How to dramatise the secret thoughts the novelist can describe but the film can only suggest; where to begin; how to end; how to collect the tone of the prose.

The answer to these questions must inevitably speak as loudly about the preoccupations of the film-maker as they do about the contingent issues of phrasing the material and organising the story for a film audience. Part of the business of reading is to create an inner cinema on which the events play out. And we can be sure that for each reader the film is different. Adaptation is, finally, sharing one's inner cinema with an audience - this is how it felt to me; this is what I thought I was reading. The dramatist becomes an enthusiastic messenger, bringing news from somewhere else, remembering the best bits, exaggerating the beauty, relishing the mystery, probing the moral imperative, watching for gasps or tears, orchestrating them and, ideally, prompting the captive cinema audience to make the pilgrimage back to the book, which remains blessedly itself.

What the reader knows is that Ripley's clean slate is an illusion. The rebirth is a temporary disguise and, worse, one that condemns the impostor to a constant fear of exposure.

To be uncovered as a sham is the very thing which prompts Ripley to sham in the first place. And so the film came to hinge on a central premise - Ripley's credo that it is better to be a fake somebody than a real nobody. It becomes a story about class. The novel is about a man who commits murders and is not caught. And so the film is about a man who commits murders and is not caught. But it departs in one crucial sense by concluding that eluding public accountability is not the same thing as eluding justice.

He ends the movie alone, free, in a hell of his own making. Just as in Dante, where purgatory is some karmic reflection of life - flatterers pitched in manure, adulterers chasing for ever - so in annihilating self, assuming someone's identity, Ripley is condemned never to be free to be truly himself. Its ambitions were to maintain the narrative ambivalence of the novel - not telling an audience what to think, not opting for an announced moral closure, but intensifying the consequence of Ripley's actions on the soul.

A signal adjustment to the novel is that Ripley does not plan to kill Dickie; quite the reverse. The death scene begins with Ripley revealing the depth of his feelings for Dickie, horribly miscalculated, cruelly rejected. Dickie dies in an eruption of rage and it is his own capacity for violence which exacerbates a reflexive swing of an oar into a do-or-die struggle. It's an accident which provides Ripley with a defining opportunity.

And, as so often in this story, it's an opportunity he seizes as much in shame as in calculation. His journey to purgatory begins with the borrowing of a jacket, because he doesn't possess a decent one of his own. It continues, for what he feels are the same reasons, with the borrowing of an identity.

Peter Smith-Kingsley, mentioned only in passing in the novel, becomes a fully-fledged character in the film. His acceptance of Ripley suggested itself as a required irony, a way of dramatising what Highsmith called the annihilation of Ripley's past and himself; in killing Peter he murders his own chance of happiness. Peter, the most centred character in the film, also serves as a reminder that Ripley's pathology is not explained by his sexuality. Similarly, Herbert Greenleaf's relationship with Dickie developed into a crucial strand. The film's mechanism of lies and escape depends on a father's lack of faith in his son, a prejudgment that makes him incapable of seeing Ripley's hand in what has happened. In this way, Ripley can appear to be the better version of Dickie, the son Herbert wishes he had.

No one in this story sees truth in front of them because of the distortions of their own prejudices and preconceptions. Only Marge Sherwood, in a more substantive role than the novel allows, has a sufficiently uncluttered spirit to both welcome Ripley and then suspect him. But the collusion of men, such a feature of this story and of the times, undermines her. They are too busy covering up, preferring to interpret Marge's unerring radar for the truth as the misguided forensics of heartbreak.

Meredith Logue, a new character for the film, gives Ripley the chance to create his own version of Marge, just as he creates his own version of Dickie. Her presence also accentuates that this is principally a story about young people, each of whom has run away from something, making themselves up in the context of a foreign country, partners as Meredith observes giddily, in disguise . The foreign country is Italy.

For two generations before Ripley, Americans had been coming to Europe to explore issues of identity and sexuality. It's no accident that Highsmith had settled in Europe in the Fifties and would have been a contemporary of Marge and Meredith. Nor is it an accident that her book is loosely based on The Ambassadors.

The idea of the Grand Tour, of exploring the Old Country, of soaking in the culture of Europe, continues to exert an irresistible tug on American travellers long after Europe's culture has been conquered and transformed by America. Italy, a substantial character in this film, its landscape largely intact from the Renaissance paintings which celebrate it, its history as the artistic and classical heart of the Continent, has particular appeal.

'Was it, in short, ever well to be elsewhere when one might be in Italy?' wrote Edith Wharton. By locating the movie a year or two later than the novel, there was an opportunity to explore a significant moment in Italian history, where a thin veneer of the modern had glossed but could not hide the primitive mores of the country.

Italy is a place I love above all other places, but it's always possible to detect a darker note under its breezy melodies. And this dissonance seemed to speak of the film itself, apparently sybaritic, but lounging on a volcano. Mongibello, the name Highsmith gave to the fictional village on the Amalfi coast where Dickie and Marge are living, is a local name for Vesuvius.

Finally, a film called The Talented Mr Ripley had to address Ripley's talents. If Ripley is blessed and cursed by one thing, it is his ability to turn on a sixpence, to reel off the most elaborate and plausible riffs of fantasy. In identifying this, the importance of music grew in my mind, replacing the more literary motif of painting in the novel. Music for period, music for place, music for argument. And so the screenplay also became a kind of libretto, working out relationships in musical terms, pitting Dickie's identification with jazz, its mantra of freedom and existentialism, against Ripley's classicism and asserting that, just as in music, where truly great extemporising begins with Bach and Mozart, so it is Ripley who proves to be the more genuine improviser.

When I adapted The English Patient, I was accompanied on an adventure that involved wholesale reimagining of Michael Ondaatje's novel. Patricia Highsmith died as I began writing the first draft of Ripley and before I could meet her. If I were to have pleased anybody with this adaptation, I would have liked it to have been her and I worked with her own pungent words about fiction as a touchstone. She imagined Ripley sitting at the typewriter with her as she wrote her novel. I imagined her sitting with me as I wrote my screenplay.

'If a suspense writer is going to write about murderers and victims, about people in the vortex of this awful whirl of events, he must do more than describe brutality and gore. He should be interested in justice or the absence of it in the world, good and bad, and in human cowardice or courage - but not merely as forces to move his plot in one direction. In a word, his invented people must seem real.'

fields.headline: Come out, wherever you are
fields.standfirst: Stonewall's chief executive is polite and stoic - the antithesis of Peter Tatchell. But her determination to promote tolerance is bringing about a quiet revolution
fields.trailText: Stonewall's chief executive is polite and stoic - the antithesis of Peter Tatchell. But her determination to promote tolerance is bringing about a quiet revolution
fields.body:
This is the real face of gay Britain. Peter Tatchell may be the face you see more often: Peter mouthing off, Peter getting angry, Peter terrifying the Lords with his proposals to legalise gay sex in public toilets and introduce gay orgy-suites into the back rooms of pubs. But the face which has actually changed life in Britain today, and irreversibly so, is this Sapphic Ms Pepperpot, a stoic little 56-year-old with a grim and polite determination.

Angela Mason - née Angela Weir, for Mason, the name she uses, was actually the surname of the man she once, briefly, and rather erroneously, married - doesn't do it in the streets and frighten the horses. Instead she argues, quietly and with what even the Mail, to which she's become something of a hate figure, accepts as 'eloquence', for gay rights. She has been doing this for the past eight years as chief executive of Stonewall; and she's winning.

It can only be a matter of time now before Section 28 is repealed. And she has just returned from witnessing, in the House, a vote, backed by Michael Portillo, to lower the age of consent for gay sex. The laws are changing, and, more importantly, the mood of the country has changed, apparently irrevocably. We are looking, together, at a Gallup poll in that day's Telegraph which concludes that 'an almost universal tolerance of homosexual relationships now obtains in this country'. It's a conclusion you couldn't have safely forecast when she started at Stonewall, before Beth Jordache's screen kiss, before Queer as Folk . It's a conclusion you couldn't have begun to dream of when she first came out, in 1971. And much of the consciousness-altering has been done by this woman and her colleagues, who have eschewed the more gaudy approach of groups such as OutRage! in favour of quiet, intense political lobbying based on the simple idea of equality. It has, over the past few years, made Stonewall one of the most astoundingly successful lobby groups in Britain in terms of objectives achieved. Which is not bad going for a former anarchist who once stood in the dock of the Old Bailey facing bombing charges.

What seems to motivate her most is not anger but remembered sadness, continued worry. It's all to combat the 'fear, and the loneliness' of growing up gay with no one to talk to about it, be it teachers or friends or lovers; feeling always on the outside, ever dislocated, always alone.

'I'm of a generation that was completely in the closet,' she says, remembering growing up in the Forties and Fifties in the Isle of Sheppey. 'I thought then, I thought for a long time, that if I was open about - no, if I even acknowledged - my sexuality then that would condemn me to a lonely, miserable, isolated existence.'

When did she first realise she was a lesbian? 'I was quite young, actually. I think most people have some sort of dawning sense at least somewhere around puberty and that was certainly the sense for me.' Did she have any relationships? 'No, it was all in my head. I think that was a very typical experience of men and women of my generation.'

She couldn't confide in lovers; nor could she confide in friends. 'Absolutely no one. No one at all. Which was terrible, because if I had had someone to go to, it would have been just wonderful. It would have made me happier. It would have made me a better person.' Better in what way? 'Because to have a very important part of yourself just not operating, for a long period of time, does at an important level distort you. You are a less rounded person. I think all lesbians and gay men who come out, particularly those who come out later in life, have to go through what is almost a process of healing.'

Confusion continued until she was married, to scriptwriter William Randolph Mason, in 1971. 'Like many lesbian women I'd had boyfriends. And I had one particularly close boyfriend, and I was completely torn at the time about whether, you know, I could make it with him, we could make it together, or whether I ought to be out and open. It all sort of happened very quickly, all happened together.'

Around the same time, she was becoming increasingly involved in anarchist and feminist politics at the London School of Economics - accused at one stage, and acquitted, of being part of an Angry Brigade bombing campaign - and she had begun seeing Elizabeth Wilson, active in the Gay Lib movement. The timing was all wrong, but she came out anyway. She and Elizabeth are still together, and live with Angela's daughter by artificial insemination, who is now 15. Her daughter, she adds, gallantly anticipating the faintly crass question I'm about to ask, has a boyfriend.

How did her husband take it ? 'It was quite difficult.' Her dark little eyes slide away from mine. 'He was understanding. In a way. Actually, it was his friends who took it badly. They thought you can't do that. You can't be like that. I think they thought I was doing it to be wilful or something. So, it was a hard time, but still coming out was wonderful . Absolutely wonderful.'

As, she says, is the mood today. 'The tolerance is a great thing, and I think it's still shifting in the right direction. Particularly among young people, there's been a shift in ethical values: they don't derive their moral values from the establishment any more - the church, or Westminster, or whatever - but have a sense of individual morality. There's also a growing tolerance among the parental generation, because that's getting younger all the time, of course. It's all a big generational issue.'

The country may be mainly on her side, then, but did she know who her enemies were? 'My main worry is the linkings with some Christian groups. Baroness Jay's campaign against us last year was actually very well organised, and partly because of the links with these groups. And I do worry that might bring, in the future, increasing fundamentalism, of an American kind. This could happen. You see, it's like with politics today: it's much more difficult for a leader like Hague to lead a "broad church" because his congregation is increasingly narrow. And the same process taking place in the actual churches.'

What, I wonder, about the enemy within? About Peter Tatchell and other more militant campaigners, and the potential negative publicity, particularly the demand this week that 'since recreational sex is a natural activity and a popular pursuit, all laws which seek to control it should be abolished.' She peers at the newspaper, grimacing quietly.

'I think this is not helpful. I am not campaigning for recreational sex. I am campaigning for equality. There needs to be some public sex offence which protects people from nuisance. You need to protect the public.'

She has talked, non-stop, for a long time, but she pauses, for a long while, when I ask my last question: how did she think her life would have worked out had she not come out? 'I would have had some kind of nervous breakdown.' She knows, because she gets the calls, still, every day, from some of the thousands of Angela Masons in this country who stayed in.

Around the same time, she was becoming increasingly involved in anarchist and feminist politics at the London School of Economics - accused at one stage, and acquitted, of being part of an Angry Brigade bombing campaign - and she had begun seeing Elizabeth Wilson, active in the Gay Lib movement. The timing was all wrong, but she came out anyway. She and Elizabeth are still together, and live with Angela's daughter by artificial insemination, who is now 15. Her daughter, she adds, gallantly anticipating the faintly crass question I'm about to ask, has a boyfriend. How did her husband take it ? 'It was quite difficult.' Her dark little eyes slide away from mine. 'He was understanding. In a way. Actually, it was his friends who took it badly. They thought you can't do that. You can't be like that. I think they thought I was doing it to be wilful or something. So, it was a hard time, but still coming out was wonderful . Absolutely wonderful.' As, she says, is the mood today. 'The tolerance is a great thing, and I think it's still shifting in the right direction. Particularly among young people, there's been a shift in ethical values: they don't derive their moral values from the establishment any more - the church, or Westminster, or whatever - but have a sense of individual morality. There's also a growing tolerance among the parental generation, because that's getting younger all the time, of course. It's all a big generational issue.' The country may be mainly on her side, then, but did she know who her enemies were? 'My main worry is the linkings with some Christian groups. Baroness Jay's campaign against us last year was actually very well organised, and partly because of the links with these groups. And I do worry that might bring, in the future, increasing fundamentalism, of an American kind. This could happen. You see, it's like with politics today: it's much more difficult for a leader like Hague to lead a "broad church" because his congregation is increasingly narrow. And the same process taking place in the actual churches.' What, I wonder, about the enemy within? About Peter Tatchell and other more militant campaigners, and the potential negative publicity, particularly the demand this week that 'since recreational sex is a natural activity and a popular pursuit, all laws which seek to control it should be abolished.' She peers at the newspaper, grimacing quietly. 'I think this is not helpful. I am not campaigning for recreational sex. I am campaigning for equality. There needs to be some public sex offence which protects people from nuisance. You need to protect the public.' She has talked, non-stop, for a long time, but she pauses, for a long while, when I ask my last question: how did she think her life would have worked out had she not come out? 'I would have had some kind of nervous breakdown.' She knows, because she gets the calls, still, every day, from some of the thousands of Angela Masons in this country who stayed in.

fields.headline: Wounded Amazon will reign
fields.standfirst:
The Net giant will survive last week's record losses and sackings to become an industry blueprint, predicts Nick Paton Walsh

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: There is no better place to see the scale and immaturity of Amazon.co.uk than at its new distribution centre, Marston Gate, a warehouse with a solid, pedestrian design a world away from its voguish website. A 30-minute taxi ride from Milton Keynes train station, it is one of three grey monoliths on a building site just off Junction 13 of the M1. The warehouse is vast - about 250,000 sq ft - and has yet to be filled with items from the old warehouse in Slough. Next door, the JCBs are busy constructing another Amazon.co.uk warehouse twice the size. The current warehouse, however, still lacks a canteen.
fields.body:
There is no better place to see the scale and immaturity of Amazon.co.uk than at its new distribution centre, Marston Gate, a warehouse with a solid, pedestrian design a world away from its voguish website. A 30-minute taxi ride from Milton Keynes train station, it is one of three grey monoliths on a building site just off Junction 13 of the M1. The warehouse is vast - about 250,000 sq ft - and has yet to be filled with items from the old warehouse in Slough. Next door, the JCBs are busy constructing another Amazon.co.uk warehouse twice the size. The current warehouse, however, still lacks a canteen.

In many ways Marston Gate reflects the global operation, Amazon.com. Like the company, it is expanding so fast it can't keep up. Behind the sleek website and hype of e-commerce, there is a drab factory floor of a business, that needs to do such dull things as stack and post books, and even turn profits. Here, the seamlessness of the virtual world comes adrift.

Last week the knives were out for Amazon, after the company was forced to admit a huge rise in losses and 150 redundancies at its distribution arm in the United States. If a company announces redundancies for 2 per cent of its workers, and has achieved a 543 per cent annual rise in its losses over the last quarter, one can be excused for thinking there's a problem.

But Amazon is at the forefront of the school of e-commerce thinking that says that the more you're spending on marketing and developing your company - as opposed to declaring a profit - the better position you are engineering for yourself in the market. Last week it happily announced losses of $323 million; investors cheered and celebrated; the stock rose from $69.44 to as high as $79 in after-hours trading. But when the redundancies were (reluctantly) announced, the stock fell to $60.

Few found the Internet madness of the first rise - or the slump that followed the redundancies - surprising. Amazon's history - the soaring stock, the relentless losses - epitomises the story of e-commerce. The redundancies were to many the result of its trebling its stateside staff during the expansion of the past year, and, quite simply, doing a bit of housekeeping - growing up, so to speak.

The current Amazon line, delivered with a taciturn confidence, is that the redundancies were part of an 'ongoing process of organisational review', and that we shouldn't draw any conclusions until the review is over. They'd diversified into selling DVDs, pharmaceuticals and DIY, and were now consolidating.

Meanwhile, Amazon declared that it had finally broken into profit in book sales, despite the fact that books accounted for less than half of its sales in the last financial quarter. US books revenue has risen by 66 per cent in the past year; and net sales have increased by 169 per cent to $1.64 billion.

Nevertheless, ran the rumours, if Amazon is sacking people, it has clearly miscalculated, and is struggling to make a flawed business model work. Such was the scope of Amazon's diversification that its ambition may well have overreached itself. Rob Zegelaar, director of venture capitalist Atlas, is among those who believe Amazon's frantic diversification may have been a little unwise: 'It's not as knowledgeable about the new segments as it is about books. It will face fierce competition in these new areas.'

Last week, Amazon chose to raise money by selling debts denominated in euros, giving investors greater security and securing a cash fund for the years ahead - one it will doubtless need.

Amazon is already having to tackle the might of Bertelsmann's online bookstore, bol.com, and the associated m-commerce (mobile-based) competition that its merger with Vodafone will bring. But by undercutting its competitors on price, Amazon has retained an impressive market share. This served to strengthen its brand and made it the Net's first household name.

However, it is unlikely that Amazon's prices will remain artificially low: the company has to adjust to a long-term presence in the consumer market. 'Its margins were under pressure from day one,' says Zegelaar. He thinks investors are growing tired of consumer-oriented e-commerce, because it involves too many small transactions and high marketing costs. 'Amazon are suffering from this,' he says. 'The new interest is in business-to-business ventures.' Marketing costs are lower because the service has a smaller client base and a higher yield.

So Amazon may have to change its working model. As Zegelaar suggests, it may have to split into several smaller, more focused companies (one for each product type, perhaps). These would be able to devote themselves exclusively to securing their own markets. It is as unlikely that the Amazon we see in two years' time will resemble the obsessively expanding hybrid of today, as it is that the company will be the 'Atari of the Internet age' - a dinosaur soon to be swept away by the next wave of leaner, e-commerce ideas. The brand and its market position are too strong.

Dot.com companies repeatedly emphasise that that profits are not a burning issue at this stage because money is constantly reinvested. Nevertheless, Brent Hoberman of lastminute.com does regard Amazon's breaking into profit within book sales, as important: 'It's a vindication of e-commerce. They've done it; they've proved it; they've taken market share from the established players. They are pulverising Barnes and Noble in that field.'

It is important for both him and Amazon that e-commerce shows itself capable of turning a profits, if only to silence the growing crowd of sceptics. Hoberman sees little reason for Amazon founder Jeff Bezos to stop expanding while there are these online opportunities: 'Bezos would be stupid not to steal every march he can, and he's far from a stupid man.'

But as the competition grows, those opportunities dry up. Few analysts doubt that Amazon will survive, and that its eventual model will become an industry blueprint. For this e-commerce can be grateful - Amazon will be learning lessons for the rest.

webTitle: 'It's not a typical Academy Award-winning movie'

fields.headline: 'It's not a typical Academy Award-winning movie'
fields.standfirst: Sam Mendes on the Oscar buzz
fields.trailText: The American Beauty director is shocked to be in the running for an Oscar
fields.body:
When Steven Spielberg [head of the Dreamworks studio which financed American Beauty] first saw the film, he said: 'You've made a classic movie here.'

My reaction was: 'Okay, that's it, I can go home now. I don't need to hear anymore - that's the best I'm gonna get.'

I haven't heard much about the Oscar campaign yet but the talk about winning is very flattering, and brilliant for a movie like this because it doesn't have a major star. So hopefully when it arrives in other countries with Oscar buzz attached there will be considerably more chance that people are going to see it.

When I first heard the Oscar talk I thought it was premature. There was another two months' worth of movies coming out with Oscar potential. I thought to myself, 'Who the hell am I to think I've got a great chance?'

I still find it hard to believe the film is in the running. It's not a typical Academy Award-winning movie. It's dark, it's weird. It starts with the main character wanking in the shower. It's not a Tom Hanks kind of movie and, of course, there are no costumes.

When we were filming there were fights every day about how much time I was taking, and how much money I was spending. I knew I was spending more than I should, but I wouldn't give up because I knew the film would be really good. It seems absurd now - the arguments were often over a hundred dollars here or there.

fields.headline: Field of dreams
fields.standfirst: Is there a more welcome sight than a spring meadow covered in a blanket of purple and white crocuses?
fields.trailText: Is there a more welcome sight than a spring meadow covered in a blanket of purple and white crocuses?
fields.body:
The first crocuses are appearing in the orchard, breaking ground with their splayed tips of leaf sheathed in a milky tourniquet. But, unlike daffodils or tulips, the leaves hardly mean anything. Other than this first wispy presence, crocuses seem to rise from the ground as nothing but flower. I think that this is what makes them an annual miracle, as opposed to the seasonal ritual of daffodils and snowdrops.

We planted our crocuses this autumn (late, as ever), by lifting turves and placing them, like woody marbles, on the ground before covering them back over with the turf. You order a thousand crocuses as an attempt at big-impact gardening - make a statement, bold grouping and all that - and they arrive in a bag about the size of a kilo of sugar. A thousand crocuses are a mere dapple. You can lose a thousand in a corner of a small garden.

I think a mass of crocuses in grass in March sunshine is one of the most memorable floral high points of the year. And, like snowdrops and daffodils, crocuses create a direct and meaningful connection between the back garden and the landscape at large, even via a window box or a pot on a windowsill. In fact, crocuses grow very well in pots, and look particularly good planted cheek by jowl in a shallow, terracotta pan. It is worth buying the species crocuses for containers, rather than the much brasher Dutch cultivars, because they are subtle and delicate, and deserve close inspection.

Crocus laevigatus is usually the first to appear and will certainly have done so by the time you read this, pushing up lilac or white flowers in any mild period from Christmas onwards. Crocuses are too far from the nose to be thought of as scented - they do enough without that bonus, but these smell lovely.

C tommasinianus is likely to come next, the lavender flowers flopping open in the sunshine. This has two great advantages for the ordinary garden: unlike most crocuses, it will grow well in dappled shade (in other words, in the lee of a deciduous tree or shrub, but not under an evergreen hedge) and it also seeds itself everywhere. I can't think of anything nicer than crocuses popping up unbidden all over my garden. You can get cultivars that vary from the streaked lilac of the species, such as C tommasinianus f albus, which is white, as is 'Eric Smith', or a good purple, such as 'Ruby Giant' (not ruby at all, but a reddish purple).

C chrysanthus and C biflorus (the two are very closely related) will be hard on their heels, with the many cultivars that have been made by crossing them. Inevitably, these hybrids are vigorous and big, which, given the essential smallness and delicacy of a crocus, need not be a bad thing. C 'EA Bowles' has a good lemon yellow and, having just seen a picture of it, I am tempted to add it to our spring garden for next year. And I like the idea of 'Zwanenburg Bronze', which is described as 'yellow inside and a rich bronze brown outside'.

This, of course, is exactly the right kind of time to choose your crocuses for next year. Read about them now, hunt out examples of the ones you like the sound of in a garden (and this is where places such as Wisley or Kew act as invaluable references) and see it in the flesh, and then place an order in early summer. Not the instant hit of garden-centre shopping, but the best way to do it. Snowdrops and aconites are an exception to this rule, and are best bought 'in the green', which is while they are still flowering. But not crocuses.

C vernus is the one you are likely to come across in parks and large gardens, bejewelling great swathes of grass. There is a particularly spectacular planting at Kew. C vernus has provided the stock for most of the named varieties of the big, satiny crocuses, looking almost like stunted tulips in some form of purple, white or yellow. Most of these have been bred by the Dutch, who long ago cornered the bulb market. I visited a bulb warehouse outside Amsterdam once and was staggered at the scale of the operation. Dozens of forklift drivers wearing hairnets, shifting pallets of bulbs, which arrived by the lorry-load from local farms.

With so much yellow and orange about in spring, the eye craves the balance of some blue. There are a hundred variations on purple and lilac, but no crocus is really blue, especially when put against the blue of scilla or muscari. But C baytopiorum comes close. I have not grown it, but from photographs it appears to be a very pale turquoise, with darker veins which create a bluish effect.

C sativus has always had enormous commercial significance as the source of saffron. As most people know, the spice - or in medieval times, the drug - is made from the dried stigmas of the flower, with over 4,000 flowers needed to produce one ounce of saffron. There is a fascinating connection between saffron and the only naturalised crocuses in Britain - the spring-flowering C vernus ('The Nottingham Crocus') and autumn-flowering C nudiflorus ('The Halifax Crocus'). These are to be found growing wild around Nottingham, the north Midlands, Lancashire and Yorkshire, and if their sites are plotted on a map, they are shown to be all along the routes and tracks between Benedictine monastries and their outlying farms. The Benedictines came from Cluny in France, where C nudiflorus grows wild. They were keen and sophisticated gardeners, and may well have attempted to grow the crocus as a substitute for its close relative C sativus, in order to try and make saffron from it.

Other sites, which seem to have no clear geographical connection, turn out to have belonged to the Knights Hospitallers or the Knights of St John of Jerusalem, who would have brought the corms back with them from the crusades. Presumably, these too, were part of a deliberate attempt to introduce the corms to create a supply of saffron or saffron-substitute. Unlike most other crocuses, it spreads by underground runners, which potentially makes it viable for the enormous harvest needed to give you any chance of creating a supply of saffron. The manner in which these crusader crocuses spread so widely is a perfect example of how to treat crocuses in grass in the garden. The Trent meadows in Nottingham, where the C vernus are spread like a million spatters of paint, are Lammas land. This means that they were used primarily for hay and not allowed to be grazed between the beginning of February and midsummer. In that time, the crocus leaves appeared, the flowers bloom and set seed, and the leaves slowly fed the new corms before dying back, the whole process unchallenged by the tightly nibbling teeth of sheep or the crushing hooves of cattle. The ground was grazed hard over winter so that the spring crocuses grew in short grass, visible and unswamped.

So, plant your crocuses by lifting turf, spreading the corms out before covering them over again, give the grass a late-autumn cut and clear the clippings and then don't cut again until midsummer. That way your dapple will become a smother.

Your roots: How to make the most of your crocuses

As ever with plants, the closer you can make their growing conditions to their original habitat, the happier they will be, and many crocuses comes from Greece and the hot, thin soils of that part of the Mediterranean. They belong to the Iridaceae, or iris, family, which includes, as well as irises and crocuses, gladioli, montbretias and freesias. Give them good drainage and plenty of sunshine and they will not worry too much about the quality of the soil.

Crocuses are not bulbs but corms, which is in reality just a short stem stuffed like a hamster cheek with sustenance. Inside the corm, the flower is fully formed and the food supply is principally used to develop the roots and leaves and is completely consumed by the process of flowering.

The new leaves then store next year's food in another corm, which develops on top of the old one. This is why, as any fool knows, you never cut back the leaves of any corm or bulb until it is dying back on its own steam. The new corm has roots that contract and pull it down to the depth of the previous, now thoroughly squashed one. It dries out over the summer and starts developing new roots sometime in the autumn. The best time to plant spring bulbs is at the end of summer, to give these new roots maximum time to get established.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

I keep a garden diary, not for your consumption, but for mine. It is incredibly useful to me. The records are brief and often insufficient, but never inaccurate. So I can go back to 13 February 1998 and read, 'Exquisite morning, big full moon in blue sky, thrush singing. Snowdrops, hellebores and crocus perfect. Planted two 'Doyen du Comice' pears and onion sets of 75 x turbo, 75 centurion F1, 75 Stuttgart giant and 50 'Sturon'. Sarah potted nine regale lilies and did bonfire. Best Feb weather ever. HOT! 17C.'

Funnily enough I have no recollection of the day. Without my diary it would have been lost. And why only 50 of 'Sturon' when there were 75 of the others? Then last year, 13 February went like this: 'Grey damp day. Very raw. Twenty-two hazel bundles delivered, eight more to come. Visited Bryansground and Usk Castle. Both v good. Venison for dinner with chard, red cabbage and apple, roast potatoes, damson sauce. V good.' I am beginning to sound like Parson Woodeford.

The truth is, I remember a year ago clearly. We had American visitors checking the garden out for a photo shoot and it looked as bleak and unappealing as it possibly could do. Dead.

On 13 February 1989, writing about our previous garden, I read that 'the wind has streamed the branches off the trees all day, rattling the glass in the windows like false teeth. I have done nothing all day. I realised in the middle of last night that the paths in the kitchen garden are far too deeply dug out. The earth from the beds will be constantly spilling on to the finished paths. I can't think why I didn't work this out before. Too pleased with myself. Shit.' I was harder on myself in those days. I am more forgiving now. I also typed everything then, clacking away in the dark, hoping not to wake the children.

I miss the punchy solidity of my typewriter, but am irretrievably tied to the computer. The garden diary, however, is now always written with a fountain pen. If I write at the end of a day's gardening, I can scarcely hold the pen with my lumpen fingers, let alone shape words clearly. But it does encourage brevity.

The point is, that this is all gardening. The garden runs through our lives like a river through a field, like air in our lungs. The garden does not end in space any more than it does in time. Gardening does not stop or start in the garden. The flowers grow as much in our minds as in the soil. There are very few nights when I do not lie in the dark, with everyone sleeping inside this creaking, bony house, and go through the garden, seeing it with the clarity of a dreamer, taking it to pieces and putting it together again, mending everything in my head.

Snowdrops and aconites are an exception to this rule, and are best bought 'in the green', which is while they are still flowering. But not crocuses. C vernus is the one you are likely to come across in parks and large gardens, bejewelling great swathes of grass. There is a particularly spectacular planting at Kew. C vernus has provided the stock for most of the named varieties of the big, satiny crocuses, looking almost like stunted tulips in some form of purple, white or yellow. Most of these have been bred by the Dutch, who long ago cornered the bulb market. I visited a bulb warehouse outside Amsterdam once and was staggered at the scale of the operation. Dozens of forklift drivers wearing hairnets, shifting pallets of bulbs, which arrived by the lorry-load from local farms. With so much yellow and orange about in spring, the eye craves the balance of some blue. There are a hundred variations on purple and lilac, but no crocus is really blue, especially when put against the blue of scilla or muscari. But C baytopiorum comes close. I have not grown it, but from photographs it appears to be a very pale turquoise, with darker veins which create a bluish effect. C sativus has always had enormous commercial significance as the source of saffron. As most people know, the spice - or in medieval times, the drug - is made from the dried stigmas of the flower, with over 4,000 flowers needed to produce one ounce of saffron. There is a fascinating connection between saffron and the only naturalised crocuses in Britain - the spring-flowering C vernus ('The Nottingham Crocus') and autumn-flowering C nudiflorus ('The Halifax Crocus'). These are to be found growing wild around Nottingham, the north Midlands, Lancashire and Yorkshire, and if their sites are plotted on a map, they are shown to be all along the routes and tracks between Benedictine monastries and their outlying farms. The Benedictines came from Cluny in France, where C nudiflorus grows wild. They were keen and sophisticated gardeners, and may well have attempted to grow the crocus as a substitute for its close relative C sativus, in order to try and make saffron from it. Other sites, which seem to have no clear geographical connection, turn out to have belonged to the Knights Hospitallers or the Knights of St John of Jerusalem, who would have brought the corms back with them from the crusades. Presumably, these too, were part of a deliberate attempt to introduce the corms to create a supply of saffron or saffron-substitute. Unlike most other crocuses, it spreads by underground runners, which potentially makes it viable for the enormous harvest needed to give you any chance of creating a supply of saffron. The manner in which these crusader crocuses spread so widely is a perfect example of how to treat crocuses in grass in the garden. The Trent meadows in Nottingham, where the C vernus are spread like a million spatters of paint, are Lammas land. This means that they were used primarily for hay and not allowed to be grazed between the beginning of February and midsummer. In that time, the crocus leaves appeared, the flowers bloom and set seed, and the leaves slowly fed the new corms before dying back, the whole process unchallenged by the tightly nibbling teeth of sheep or the crushing hooves of cattle. The ground was grazed hard over winter so that the spring crocuses grew in short grass, visible and unswamped. So, plant your crocuses by lifting turf, spreading the corms out before covering them over again, give the grass a late-autumn cut and clear the clippings and then don't cut again until midsummer. That way your dapple will become a smother. Your roots: How to make the most of your crocuses As ever with plants, the closer you can make their growing conditions to their original habitat, the happier they will be, and many crocuses comes from Greece and the hot, thin soils of that part of the Mediterranean. They belong to the Iridaceae, or iris, family, which includes, as well as irises and crocuses, gladioli, montbretias and freesias. Give them good drainage and plenty of sunshine and they will not worry too much about the quality of the soil. Crocuses are not bulbs but corms, which is in reality just a short stem stuffed like a hamster cheek with sustenance. Inside the corm, the flower is fully formed and the food supply is principally used to develop the roots and leaves and is completely consumed by the process of flowering. The new leaves then store next year's food in another corm, which develops on top of the old one. This is why, as any fool knows, you never cut back the leaves of any corm or bulb until it is dying back on its own steam. The new corm has roots that contract and pull it down to the depth of the previous, now thoroughly squashed one. It dries out over the summer and starts developing new roots sometime in the autumn. The best time to plant spring bulbs is at the end of summer, to give these new roots maximum time to get established. My roots: A week in Monty's garden I keep a garden diary, not for your consumption, but for mine. It is incredibly useful to me. The records are brief and often insufficient, but never inaccurate. So I can go back to 13 February 1998 and read, 'Exquisite morning, big full moon in blue sky, thrush singing. Snowdrops, hellebores and crocus perfect. Planted two 'Doyen du Comice' pears and onion sets of 75 x turbo, 75 centurion F1, 75 Stuttgart giant and 50 'Sturon'. Sarah potted nine regale lilies and did bonfire. Best Feb weather ever. HOT! 17C.' Funnily enough I have no recollection of the day. Without my diary it would have been lost. And why only 50 of 'Sturon' when there were 75 of the others? Then last year, 13 February went like this: 'Grey damp day. Very raw. Twenty-two hazel bundles delivered, eight more to come. Visited Bryansground and Usk Castle. Both v good. Venison for dinner with chard, red cabbage and apple, roast potatoes, damson sauce. V good.' I am beginning to sound like Parson Woodeford. The truth is, I remember a year ago clearly. We had American visitors checking the garden out for a photo shoot and it looked as bleak and unappealing as it possibly could do. Dead. On 13 February 1989, writing about our previous garden, I read that 'the wind has streamed the branches off the trees all day, rattling the glass in the windows like false teeth. I have done nothing all day. I realised in the middle of last night that the paths in the kitchen garden are far too deeply dug out. The earth from the beds will be constantly spilling on to the finished paths. I can't think why I didn't work this out before. Too pleased with myself. Shit.' I was harder on myself in those days. I am more forgiving now. I also typed everything then, clacking away in the dark, hoping not to wake the children. I miss the punchy solidity of my typewriter, but am irretrievably tied to the computer. The garden diary, however, is now always written with a fountain pen. If I write at the end of a day's gardening, I can scarcely hold the pen with my lumpen fingers, let alone shape words clearly. But it does encourage brevity. The point is, that this is all gardening. The garden runs through our lives like a river through a field, like air in our lungs. The garden does not end in space any more than it does in time. Gardening does not stop or start in the garden. The flowers grow as much in our minds as in the soil. There are very few nights when I do not lie in the dark, with everyone sleeping inside this creaking, bony house, and go through the garden, seeing it with the clarity of a dreamer, taking it to pieces and putting it together again, mending everything in my head.

webTitle: A Mann most likely to...  and other prize tips

fields.headline: A Mann most likely to...  and other prize tips
fields.standfirst: The Oscar nominations are announced on Tuesday, setting off the annual bunfight. Akin Ojumu meets leading contender Michael Mann
fields.trailText: The Oscar nominations are announced on Tuesday, setting off the annual bunfight. Akin Ojumu meets leading contender Michael Mann
fields.body:
Size matters when it comes to winning Oscars. Academy Award voters favour epic cinema above everything else. That's why it's surprising that director Michael Mann, one of this year's front-runners in the Best Picture and Director categories, hasn't been nominated before.

Among contemporary American directors, few have his flair for grandeur. Films like The Last of the Mohicans and Heat combined the scale of David Lean with, occasionally, the intimacy of an Ingmar Bergman film. He says: 'That's what gets me going. I like the larger scale. I like to see human drama played out when the stakes are big.'

His latest film, The Insider , provides another opportunity to see Mann at work. Beaten by American Beauty at the recent Golden Globe Awards, the film got some of the best reviews of last year and, equally important in the eyes of the Academy's earnest voters, it has a big message. If American Beauty is the early Oscar favourite, The Insider is currently running a close second. Based on a true story, the film tells the intriguing tale of how Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino), a TV producer on America's foremost current affairs show 60 Minutes , persuaded Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe), a former tobacco company scientist, to reveal the industry's dirty tricks on air in 1995. It was a spectacular coup until network CBS, fearing a huge lawsuit, pulled the incendiary interview.

The result is an excellent whistle-blower thriller in the mould of previous Oscar-feted films, All The President's Men and The China Syndrome, a nicely-paced, meticulous exposé of the Establishment. But Mann, who first heard about the case from his friend Bergman, was attracted to the project for its more intimate qualities. 'What really struck me was the opportunity to bring audiences into the raw experience of what happens to a protagonist like Jeffrey Wigand. He finds himself in conflict with a large Fortune 500 corporation and realises they're out to ruin his life. That's more powerful than a typical melodrama.'

Mann was particularly struck by Wigand's complex character. 'I was also attracted to this piece because here is a guy who has behaved very courageously, but he's not a saint. He's deeply human with mixed motivations, and that allowed me to access him emotionally in a strong way because he was flawed.'

Mann speaks in a distinctive, nasal New York accent. As his reputation suggests, the director is a no-nonsense operator. At the start he shakes hands briskly before beating me to the draw with his own dictaphone. He inserts a fresh tape, presses the record button and says quietly: 'The Observer.'

Despite the film's subject matter, which requires a fair amount of exposition, and the fact that much of the two-and-a-half hours running time takes place in offices and over phone lines, Mann has created a fascinating visual accompaniment to the talking heads. The news gathering process has never looked so alluring. During one pivotal phone conversation with Bergman, the beleaguered Wigand sits in a soulless Louisville hotel room. The producer is on holiday and attempts to reassure Wigand via mobile phone, while walking knee deep in the sea under an expressionist, bright blue Bahamas sky.

'The phone calls are liberating because you can put two people in different places and create juxtapositions which keep you emotionally involved in what's going on,' says Mann. 'I think audiences are dead intelligent, not just cognitively, and they can take in everything in the frame.'

But don't call him a great visual stylist. The man who created the vivid Eighties cop show Miami Vice and showed characters' inner tension through interior design in Heat, bristles at the suggestion. 'Style is for commercials,' he insists.

But there are Mann trademarks that characterise much of his cinema and television work: modern interiors, imposing cityscapes, stately camera movement and an interest in crime and punishment. Mann disagrees again. 'The only common factor is that the same person is behind the camera. I'm not consciously aware of doing it. Each film is its own adventure.'

Surprisingly, the director showed little interest in cinema until near the end of his studies at the University of Wisconsin in the mid-Sixties. Then the literature student planned to do a PhD and become an academic. 'It felt wrong,' he says now. 'Even when I tried to convince myself to do it. It felt too passive. I tried writing and I was terrible.'

Instead he wandered into a film history class. 'I thought someone was going to give me three credits for going to the movies. I was there like a shot.' A few months later Mann had discovered his vocation and won a place at the London International Film School.

He began his career as a documentary maker, but by the late Seventies, and after a few tips from a screenwriter pal, he was writing episodes of Starsky and Hutch. In 1981 he made his first feature, The Thief, a slick thriller starring James Caan about an expert crook fighting to retain his independence. It was followed in 1983 by the incoherent supernatural thriller, The Keep - the blot on his CV.

In this period he also made two well-received TV movies, The Jericho Mile and LA Takeover, which was eventually remade as Heat. LA Takeover took 19 days to film whereas the climactic bank shoot-out in Heat took 12 days on its own. Mann was eager to stop working in television and advance his movie career. When his agent passed him the outline for what would become Miami Vice he nearly turned it down.

The show was a revelation when it was first aired in 1984. The cop show boasted sharp camera angles, a hip rock soundtrack and a carefully co-ordinated, predominately pastel colour scheme. It was new style of drama and became an instant hit. Mann is modest about one of the decade's defining series. ' Miami Vice looked so good because the rest of the stuff on air at the time was shows - like The Dukes of Hazzard - which were pretty antique. Its success was more down to the fact that everything else was so far behind contemporary culture and all we were was current.'

Mann was single-handedly responsible for the Miami Vice look. He scoured DIY shops to find the right pastel shades and as a staunch rock fan regulated the show's frenetic score. His reputation for meticulous attention to detail continued with Manhunter (1986) and its chilling aesthetic. The film that introduced moviegoers to Hannibal Lecter, then played by Brian Cox, was a disturbing and gripping thriller about the hunt for a serial killer led by a detective blessed with unusual powers of empathy.

In the last 10 years Mann has emerged as one of America's leading directors, equally adept at manipulating the camera or actors, despite releasing just two films. He waited six years after Manhunter before producing The Last of the Mohicans, a captivating eighteenth century romantic adventure starring one the decade's best matched screen couples, Daniel Day-Lewis and Madeleine Stowe.

It was shot on location in South Carolina and the arduous filming schedule enhanced Mann's reputation as a combative personality, even among directors. He ran his crew like a drill sergeant. 'I expect everyone to be as aggressive and adventurous as me or they should go to work for someone else,' he says bluntly.

On The Last of the Mohicans everyone mucked in. 'When we were climbing a mountain I had a camera case on my shoulder and so did Daniel Day-Lewis. We were climbing at twilight to spend half the night on that mountain shooting a scene. So, yeah, I take what I do dead seriously.'

The film was shunned unfairly when the Oscar nominations were announced for 1992. Probably a greater injustice occurred in 1996 when his superb, sprawling cops and robbers movie, Heat - bringing together Al Pacino and Robert de Niro for the first time - was also passed over in the major categories.

Given his hardly prolific output - only four films in the last 15 years - it may be some time before Mann gets another chance at picking up a gold statuette. Rumours circulate that he is set to adapt Steven Pressfield's novel Gates of Fire: An Epic Novel of the Battle of Thermopylae , about a battle in 480 BC when 300 Spartan warriors held off a 50,000-strong Persian army. But don't think about booking tickets - Mann has yet to make up his mind.

He sighs: 'It's frustrating for me that I'm not more prolific. I would like to be in pre-production next month. I love making films. But finding something I want to shoot is a struggle. A project really has to engage me. It's gotta be of a certain quality. It's gotta be ambitious and it's gotta be something I haven't done before. So I'll probably spend another year in agony.'

 The Insider opens 10 March

fields.headline: The control-freak gets his comeuppance
fields.standfirst:
The resignation of Alun Michael should give Tony Blair pause for thought. But will he be wise enough to heed its lessons?
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The resignation of Alun Michael should give Tony Blair pause for thought. But will he be wise enough to heed its lessons?
fields.body:
Britain is becoming a more federal country, and hurrah for that. Alun Michael's dramatic resignation last week or the Scottish revolt on Section 28 sweeping south - even if it leads to a defeat liberal Britain deplores - are both signs that the national politics centred on Westminster is breaking down.

The stale order built around a state whose formal power centre remains the Westminster-based crown, is crumbling, with consequences no one can predict. But in a country where better-educated, better-off individuals are more keenly aware of their rights than ever and less willing to accept decisions handed down from above, every chance for the system opening up can only be welcomed.

New Labour's attitude to all this is profoundly ambiguous, an ambiguity for which there is a growing political price. Tony Blair could only secure his coup in capturing the Labour Party if he paid a proper debt to John Smith's legacy and that meant devolution for Scotland, and because Wales could not be neglected, a measure of devolution for the principality. But Mr Blair did not want to own up to being a constitutional radical; he gave up as little power as he could so that both parliaments remain in thrall to London, and he refused to locate this tremulous move to a more federal political structure within any overarching move to revitalise British democracy.

Instead, he portrayed devolution as a cosmetic adjustment and bent party rules to make sure that his own men - Donald Dewar in Scotland, Michael in Wales and Frank Dobson in London - were in place to administer the quarrelsome provinces under ideological control from London; imperial viceroys rather than independent voices.

As a result, he could, in true Third-Way style, tell the British Right that there was no threat to the Union because, as he once famously acknowledged, the Scottish Parliament was little more than a glorified local authority while stressing to the Left that, whatever its reservations, Scotland and Wales now had institutions called parliaments with a modicum of political power, and London was about to acquire a mayor. But this looking two ways at once has earned him the sobriquet simultaneously of being a control-freak, a loyalist to constitutional minimalism and menace to the Union, while gaining little political credit for what by any standard is an important constitutional innovation. Third-Way politics has the advantage of being all things to all men, and works well when there is little political flak. In harder political weather, it is exposed as having no ideological anchorage, no firm allies and no principled compass to inform political action.

Thus, last week, the steer from Downing Street was that the control freak had learned his lessons. Mr Blair is said to be relaxed at last week's events in Wales, and whatever his former opposition to Rhodri Morgan as Wales's First Minister, he will live with what happened. He thinks that Scottish politics is richer for its parliament. And if he had his time again, the deep briefings continue, he would not try so openly to fix London's Labour vote for Frank Dobson.

Indeed, the idea of the electoral college, in which party members' single votes count for only a third of the total vote beside other (fixable) thirds from unions and MPs and MEPs, is for review. One member, one vote is the way Labour's candidates for high office should be selected in future.

It's a welcome change of tack, but the political rewards are small, largely because both the party and public believe the conversion has been forced upon New Labour by political exigency. The new political reality is that the party's reputation for central control is so detested that any local intervention is counter-productive. There is a new 'curse of Blair' that has done for Michael, is weakening Dewar and has imperilled Dobson. A tactical retreat is a political imperative.

The difficulty is that the urge to control is now hard wired into the quick of New Labour's being; that the party leadership are control-freaks has become part of the accepted wisdom, largely because it is true. The Blairites do not trust the Labour Party; they fear its instincts for social justice, redistribution of income and dislike of capitalism could resurface and imperil the Blairite project. Worse, as they see it, there is an all-powerful media with scant respect for accuracy and which descends on any form of open debate with the blood lust of vultures. The party has to be run tightly with minimal dissent otherwise it will be cracked open by the media as Major's Tories were.

Anybody who dares to challenge this view is asked to reflect on last week's political coverage; there were precious few voices congratulating the Welsh political institutions for coming of age and revitalising Welsh democracy. Rather, there was delight that the Blair bandwagon had come off the rails and vicious pleasure in the hazards of trying to open up British democracy.

The Blairites may damn the media for its disdain for honest reporting and lack of accountability (accusations that are not wholly wide off the mark) but their current political predicament is largely their own making. They never sold devolution as it should have been. Indeed, the Blair administration must be the world's least convinced constitutional reformers, whose instincts are to recoil from democracy and qualify liberty - even as they launch the most substantive constitutional reform programme since women won the vote .

Freedom of information is offered on niggardly terms. The preferred 'new' House of Lords is one that is wholly appointed. And so on. If Blair had dared, he could have argued that Britain's entire political system and language of political debate needed wholesale redemocratisation. He could have presented his individual reforms as part of a principled package in which the consistent thread was the widening of democracy. Having surrendered the power, he could have distanced himself from the choices London, Scotland and Wales made. He could have urged the press to be fairer with a clean pair of hands. And he could now be on the offensive - and more adequately representing the spirit of our more democratic times.

But he is not. Reform minimalism is combined with a cynical approach to the presentation of wider policy that it is polluting the integrity of government and compromising what it is doing. This week, the Trade and Industry Select Committee will damn the DTI for its 'regrettable habit' of dressing up old policies as new and systematically misleading the public; the Education Select Committee has said the same about David Blunkett's famous £19 billion spending which is not £19bn at all. The public's expectations are falsely raised; the gap between what is supposedly and actually happening grows wider.

What is urgently required is not the appearance of action and the simulation of principle, so allowing retreat from any initiative if it seems to be running into trouble, but the real thing. A government with a reputation for courage and principle could have ridden last week's reverses with ease. Instead, the Government looked weak over events that were comparatively trivial and which, paradoxically, symbolised a political vitality that its own reforms aimed to create. It is not a happy portent for more testing events.

Third-Way politics has the advantage of being all things to all men, and works well when there is little political flak. In harder political weather, it is exposed as having no ideological anchorage, no firm allies and no principled compass to inform political action. Thus, last week, the steer from Downing Street was that the control freak had learned his lessons. Mr Blair is said to be relaxed at last week's events in Wales, and whatever his former opposition to Rhodri Morgan as Wales's First Minister, he will live with what happened. He thinks that Scottish politics is richer for its parliament. And if he had his time again, the deep briefings continue, he would not try so openly to fix London's Labour vote for Frank Dobson. Indeed, the idea of the electoral college, in which party members' single votes count for only a third of the total vote beside other (fixable) thirds from unions and MPs and MEPs, is for review. One member, one vote is the way Labour's candidates for high office should be selected in future. It's a welcome change of tack, but the political rewards are small, largely because both the party and public believe the conversion has been forced upon New Labour by political exigency. The new political reality is that the party's reputation for central control is so detested that any local intervention is counter-productive. There is a new 'curse of Blair' that has done for Michael, is weakening Dewar and has imperilled Dobson. A tactical retreat is a political imperative. The difficulty is that the urge to control is now hard wired into the quick of New Labour's being; that the party leadership are control-freaks has become part of the accepted wisdom, largely because it is true. The Blairites do not trust the Labour Party; they fear its instincts for social justice, redistribution of income and dislike of capitalism could resurface and imperil the Blairite project. Worse, as they see it, there is an all-powerful media with scant respect for accuracy and which descends on any form of open debate with the blood lust of vultures. The party has to be run tightly with minimal dissent otherwise it will be cracked open by the media as Major's Tories were. Anybody who dares to challenge this view is asked to reflect on last week's political coverage; there were precious few voices congratulating the Welsh political institutions for coming of age and revitalising Welsh democracy. Rather, there was delight that the Blair bandwagon had come off the rails and vicious pleasure in the hazards of trying to open up British democracy. The Blairites may damn the media for its disdain for honest reporting and lack of accountability (accusations that are not wholly wide off the mark) but their current political predicament is largely their own making. They never sold devolution as it should have been. Indeed, the Blair administration must be the world's least convinced constitutional reformers, whose instincts are to recoil from democracy and qualify liberty - even as they launch the most substantive constitutional reform programme since women won the vote . Freedom of information is offered on niggardly terms. The preferred 'new' House of Lords is one that is wholly appointed. And so on. If Blair had dared, he could have argued that Britain's entire political system and language of political debate needed wholesale redemocratisation. He could have presented his individual reforms as part of a principled package in which the consistent thread was the widening of democracy. Having surrendered the power, he could have distanced himself from the choices London, Scotland and Wales made. He could have urged the press to be fairer with a clean pair of hands. And he could now be on the offensive - and more adequately representing the spirit of our more democratic times. But he is not. Reform minimalism is combined with a cynical approach to the presentation of wider policy that it is polluting the integrity of government and compromising what it is doing. This week, the Trade and Industry Select Committee will damn the DTI for its 'regrettable habit' of dressing up old policies as new and systematically misleading the public; the Education Select Committee has said the same about David Blunkett's famous £19 billion spending which is not £19bn at all. The public's expectations are falsely raised; the gap between what is supposedly and actually happening grows wider. What is urgently required is not the appearance of action and the simulation of principle, so allowing retreat from any initiative if it seems to be running into trouble, but the real thing. A government with a reputation for courage and principle could have ridden last week's reverses with ease. Instead, the Government looked weak over events that were comparatively trivial and which, paradoxically, symbolised a political vitality that its own reforms aimed to create. It is not a happy portent for more testing events.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Man Who Knew Too Much | Austin Powers - The Spy Who Shagged Me | Body Double | The 13th Warrior | Rushmore | Never Been Kissed | The Hi Lo Country
fields.trailText: The Man Who Knew Too Much | Austin Powers - The Spy Who Shagged Me | Body Double | The 13th Warrior | Rushmore | Never Been Kissed | The Hi Lo Country
fields.body:
The Man Who Knew Too Much
(1934, PG, Carlton Silver Collection, VHS/Retail)

First time on video for the thriller that established Hitchcock as the "Master of Suspense". Beginning with a murder and kidnapping in Switzerland, it switches to London where anxious parents Edna Best and Leslie Banks hunt for their lost daughter as Peter Lorre's espionage ring plans a political assassination. A deceptively simple film packed with memorable moments and bizarre touches. Superior to the glossy 1956 remake.

Austin Powers - The Spy Who Shagged Me
(1999, 12, Entertainment, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

Mike Myers's second extravagant comic pastiche of the Sixties spy movies starring Myers as a wild cross between the womanising upper-class Bond and the hornrim-spectacled Harry Palmer, with a touch of the dandyish TV detective Jason Love and the fashion photographer from Blow-Up. Myers also plays megalomaniac villain Dr Evil and an obese Scottish lecher, and despite some amusing moments the picture's immense popularity in the States is as puzzling as its writer-star's confused aims.

Body Double
(1985, 18, Col-TriStar, DVD/Retail, Rental)

Brian De Palma's audacious reworking of familiar Hitchcockian themes and situations is set in Hollywood and features super-wimp Craig Wasson as a second-rate actor who becomes the Rear Window, Vertigo-style fall guy of a nasty plot involving skin-flick actress Melanie Griffith. Clever, nasty, long unavailable, and never shown on terrestrial TV.

The 13th Warrior
(1999, 15, Warner, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

Directed by hi-tech action specialist John McTiernan and based on a novel by Michael Crichton, this strikingly staged, dramatically muddled adventure yarn is set in the ninth century and appears to be providing the historical background to Beowulf. Antonio Banderas plays a banished Arab aristocrat who joins forces with a party of barbaric, big-hearted Norsemen to free their Scandinavian homeland from a marauding horde of ruthless cannibals who dress in bearskins and take no prisoners. Heavily influenced by Kurosawa's samurai pictures, the battles are impressively staged in the rain or at night in British Columbia.

Rushmore
(1999, 15, Buena Vista, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

Wes Anderson's off-the-wall take on The Graduate has been proclaimed an instant cult classic. I can't see it, but you can now check it out at home. The unappealing Jason Schwartzman plays a disturbed 15-year-old son of a hairdresser in the New South who creates havoc in an exclusive private school, then in a municipal high school. Bill Murray and British actress Olivia Williams are on hand, providing bemused support.

Never Been Kissed
(1999, 12, Fox-Pathé, VHS/Rental)

Produced by its star, this aimiable high school comedy (there was one every week last year) features Drew Barrymore as a 27-year-old blue-stocking big-city journalist making up for her sad schooldays when assigned to go undercover to report on teenage mores.

The Hi Lo Country
(1998, 15, Universal, VHS/Rental)

Intelligent, deeply moving modern Western, set in 1946 New Mexico to which pre-war pardners Woody Harrelson and Billy Crudup return from military service to discover suave cattle baron Sam Elliott is on his way to monopolising a mechanised corporate range. Refusing to sell their small spreads, the pair join an independent old-time rancher to defy progress and drive their steers to railheads instead of trucking them. Directed with an unsentimental feeling for the cowboy's life by Steven Frears, handsomely photographed by British cinematographer Oliver Stapleton, and scripted by Walon Green, author of The Wild Bunch, this is professional film-making in the tradition of Ford and Hawks. Last year's most undervalued picture.
