webTitle: Cabinet split on moral code for children

fields.headline: Cabinet split on moral code for children
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Schools will be forced to teach children that marriage is the "proper" relationship under legally binding plans being drawn up by the Government.
fields.body:
Schools will be forced to teach children that marriage is the "proper" relationship under legally binding plans being drawn up by the Government.

But the proposals have provoked a furious Cabinet row, with one senior Minister arguing that this will make children of one parent families feel inadequate.

Some Ministers believe that legally obliging schools to give pupils such guidance is the only way to defuse the row over repealing Section 28 - the section of the Local Government Act which bans promotion of homosexuality in schools.

Education Secretary David Blunkett promised repeal would be accompanied by tough guidance forcing schools to promote marriage. But his remarks, or the spin provided by his department's officials, have prompted a personal intervention from Culture Secretary Chris Smith.

Smith, the first openly gay Cabinet member, phoned Blunkett to ask whether government policy is being shifted towards 'promoting' heterosexuality. He and others are now anxious that any new code sent to schools does not implicitly denigrate homosexuality or heterosex ual partners who raise children outside marriage.

Ministers have committed themselves to overturning last week's Lords defeat when peers voted by 210 to 165 to retain Section 28. Although it has not led to a single prosecution, Downing Street recognises that repeal, promised in Labour's manifesto, is a binding commitment to the gay community.

Stonewall, the gay rights group, said it will take a balanced approach to any new proposals. 'Schools should be free to teach that a family is an important part of life,' said a spokeswoman. 'But families come in all shapes and sizes and in the gay community people cannot marry. The variety of family life should be taught.'

The National Union of Teachers said members were insulted by the implication that they promote any form of relationship over another. A spokeswoman said: 'Teachers want their professional judgment to be respected and to have the ability to respond to the needs of the children in their class. To say the only secure way to bring up a family is within a man-woman marriage is to give a really bad message to the kids who come from one-parent families or families where the parents are not married.'

Blunkett is discussing the code with church representatives, including the Bishop of Blackburn, the chairman of the Church of England's Board of Education. The bishop wants the code to be legally binding and to stress that 'marriage should be promoted as the fundamental building block of society and of family life' and 'the proper context for the nurture of children'. He said the guidance was necessary because simple repeal of Section 28 would send a signal that homosexual relations had parity with heterosexual relations.

Ministers have not yet said whether they think the code should be legally binding or take the form of a circular. The 1996 Education Act already requires teachers to give 'due regard to moral considerations and the value of family life'.

Blunkett has already set out the principles of the proposed code. It closely follows the guidance drafted last September for the new National Curriculum which sets out that children should be taught about the importance and nature of marriage and family life in bringing up children. It adds that marriage and the family are the key building blocks of community and society. It stops short of stating marriage is 'the proper context' for the nurturing of children, the wording sought by the Churches.

Blunkett appeared to address Smith's concerns by implying the code would be neutral in its judgment of heterosexuality and homosexuality. The code would make it clear that it is not a teacher's job to promote a particular sexual orientation. Teachers would instead be asked to help pupils to understand human sexuality.

webTitle: Two funerals and a book deal

fields.headline: Two funerals and a book deal
fields.standfirst: Emma Dally has written a memoir about the death of two of her brothers - one from Aids, the other a suicide. Some say it's exploitation. She doesn't care
fields.trailText: Emma Dally has written a memoir about the death of two of her brothers - one from Aids, the other a suicide. Some say it's exploitation. She doesn't care
fields.body:
John Dally died on 25 August 1994. He was 35, gay, and had found out that he was HIV positive in 1986. In the summer months before his death, as his life tapered away, his family and friends collected at his bedside in Islington, north London, to administer watermelon and diamorphine. This was a grim, often abrasive reunion, a last gathering of the clan before John's final departure. Now his sister Emma Dally, a novelist and publisher, has written a memoir of John's illness - which indirectly describes the suicide of their eldest brother several years before - called Dying Twice.

The death memoir was the cultural and publishing sensation of the past decade. Think of the voices from the brink: Oscar Moore, Jean Dominique-Bauby, Ruth Picardie and John Diamond. Dally's book, like John Bayley's account of the decline of his late wife Iris Murdoch, is a commentary from the sidelines, and perhaps critics - and this genre has plenty of those - will say that as a mere sibling, her experience is somehow less valid than his. Dally does not care. Like her book, she is direct, unapologetic and disconcerting. 'I thought it was essential to write about death in a very down-to-earth way... I get so sick of all the euphemisms.'

She turns 46 tomorrow, and has already been to the funerals of two of her brothers. She does not see why she should be delicate about this, why she should apologise for writing about it. 'When I sold the book, I got a bigger advance for it than I had for my novels,' she says, with a brusque satisfaction that is, inevitably, shocking. 'My editor says it's extraordinary how death has become a kind of trendy subject. A few years ago, no one would have touched it, but now everyone's interested.'

How does that make her feel?

'That I'm on the cutting edge,' she fires back. 'Commercial trends reflect cultural changes, don't they, reflect what people are thinking. I've no problem with that.'

At the beginning, there were six Dally children: Simon, Mark, Emma, Jane, John and Adam. Their father, Peter, was a psychiatrist; their mother, Ann, a doctor and medical journalist. The children were raised in London and at the family bolthole, a house in Sussex called Wiblings. Emma was five when John was born. Two years later, Adam came along. 'I still despised dolls because I did not need them,' she writes. 'I had real babies to dress and bathe and play with. I loved to give them their bottles, swing them casually on my hip the way I had seen the housekeeper and my mother do it, and push the pram down the road as though I was a mother myself... Babies dominated the household, and I loved them.'

Emma, the little mother, did well at school, went to Oxford and then followed her eldest brother Simon into publishing. John's dyslexia foxed the system, and he left school without A-levels before setting up a courier company with Adam. At 24 he was driving a silver Mercedes, sending back his food at Le Gavroche, and being hailed as the quintessential Eighties entrepreneur in the press. When he told his family he was gay, it was no big deal, but since this was the early Eighties, and the papers were beginning to report on a new disease that afflicted gay men, Emma was relieved when he settled down with the fashion designer Jacques Azagury.

Then Simon, their oldest brother, became ill. In 1988, he was diagnosed with manic depression. He stole some antiquarian books from a private collection and was arrested. A few weeks before the court case, he joined the rest of the family at Wiblings where, on Easter Sunday, he lay down on the front lawn and shot himself. His body was found by Emma and her husband, the food writer Richard Ehrlich, when they and their daughters returned from a walk. The date and place were not random, fuddled choices, says Emma. Like her father, she thinks Simon's death, there in the garden, 'was in a way a criticism of the family for not helping him. Family meant so much to him, but he hadn't been helped. That was typical Simon.'

After Simon's death, during the grieving, there were arguments over money. John and Adam's courier business was in trouble, and there was a legal wrangle over Simon's estate; it also transpired that they had persuaded their mother to put up Wiblings as collateral. An 'operatic' row was brewing. By the time the news spread about John's HIV status, the siblings were split down the middle, and Mark and Jane were not speaking to their younger brothers. 'Someone asked me whether my family was particularly dysfunctional,' says Emma, 'and I don't think it is in the slightest. It's just very large, full of people who say what they think.'

This is not a book about family grief: the Dally parents, now divorced and both based in the country, are in many ways striking in their absence. It's a story about brothers and sisters and a handful of friends behaving well and very badly in awful circumstances (falling out for imperceptible or enormous reasons, and scrabbling to make it up in time) while John, charming, naive and utterly impractical, sinks deeper into the disease.

In her book, Emma recounts all of this without bothering to clamber on to the higher ground. If some of the participants, including John, sometimes come across as careless, greedy or insensitive, she comes across as priggish and stubborn. In that way, it's a strangely dispassionate narrative, and more authoritative for it. 'I just knew that if I was going to do it right, I had to be frank about it all. In a sense I had this set view of how people should behave around someone who's dying which was just as bad as anything else. There isn't actually a set plan of how to react. Some people think they grieve more than others - but people grieve in very different ways.'

Though John's circle will never be the same after his death, most of his friends have maintained links with the Dallys. The exception is Jacques Azagury. Despite the fact that their relationship had ended by then, Jacques spent the last months with John and the family, but severed links after the funeral and another row concerning finances. While Emma was putting the book together, he rebuffed her attempts to communicate with him. 'I don't think there's any unresolved business,' says Emma briskly. 'No, and I don't feel that he wants to be friends. He didn't feel the warmth for me that I felt for him, that was obvious in the end, and that was very sad. But there's nothing to make up. We couldn't be friends. It was a horrible way for things to end.'

So who has Emma written the book for? Partly for people with terminal diseases, especially gay Aids sufferers ('This Section 28 thing drives me bonkers. All these church people talking about homosexuals as though they're a different breed. It's unbelievable') and their families. Partly for herself ('Writ ing helps you work out what you think and feel about things. Until I did it, things were in a great big muddle'). But mostly for John ('Simon had two nice obituaries, and Johnny didn't').

The book was her mother's idea. If the suggestion hadn't been made, Emma is not sure whether she would have thought of it. She's not expecting an easy ride, but she doesn't give the impression of being particularly anxious about the reception, either from critics or family members. Writing about death, she says, one is guaranteed to offend. 'People get very upset about it. Who are they to say whether you can write something or not? But that's the wonderful thing about taboos. They get people worked up, so they lose sight of everything.'

She talks combatively, as if looking forward to a scrap. 'There is this funny thing when people die, about who owns the information. And I have to keep reminding myself that I'm entitled to have my perception of this, and to write about it. And even if people get angry and say, "It wasn't like that" - well, it wasn't like that for them, but this is my view." If you grow up as one of six siblings, even if you end up losing two of them, you learn how to fight your corner.'

 Dying Twice: A Sister's Tale is published by Little, Brown at £16.99

In that way, it's a strangely dispassionate narrative, and more authoritative for it. 'I just knew that if I was going to do it right, I had to be frank about it all. In a sense I had this set view of how people should behave around someone who's dying which was just as bad as anything else. There isn't actually a set plan of how to react. Some people think they grieve more than others - but people grieve in very different ways.' Despite the fact that their relationship had ended by then, Jacques spent the last months with John and the family, but severed links after the funeral and another row concerning finances. While Emma was putting the book together, he rebuffed her attempts to communicate with him. 'I don't think there's any unresolved business,' says Emma briskly. 'No, and I don't feel that he wants to be friends. He didn't feel the warmth for me that I felt for him, that was obvious in the end, and that was very sad. But there's nothing to make up. webTitle: 'One of us was bound to lose it'

fields.headline: 'One of us was bound to lose it'
fields.standfirst: Stephen Thompson dealt and used drugs - now he's a first-time author.  The Observer  asked him to revisit the east London 'front line' he fled 10 years ago
fields.trailText: Stephen Thompson dealt and used drugs - now he's a first-time author. The Observer asked him to revisit the east London 'front line' he fled 10 years ago
fields.body:
I had misgivings about going back. I'd always imagined returning on a summer's day, driving a convertible BMW, roof down, shades on... instead, it's winter, it's wet and I arrive by train. I leave Hackney Downs station and head straight for Downs Park. It's a Sunday afternoon and I'm hoping to find some of my old crew playing football. The local teams are pouring on to the pitches. Then it happens. I'm recognised and surrounded. I experience the panic of the tourist who strays off the beaten path. I feel like I don't belong.

They question me frantically. 'Where have you been?' 'What's happened in the last 10 years?' I fire back my own questions, inquiring after so and so. 'Six feet under', 'banged up' and 'cracked out' come the replies. But before I can pursue any of their stories the whistle sounds and the game begins. I'm abandoned without so much as a 'see you later'. Standing on the touchline, the sole spectator, I marvel at all the wasted talent on show. Eventually I slip away unnoticed.

Many of these same guys were with me at Hackney Downs comprehensive in the early Eighties. It was a riotous time. Literally. I remember the morning I walked in late, smoking a spliff. It was the first time I'd attended social studies in three weeks. 'What do you think you're doing, Stephen?' said Mr Wilson. 'Put that thing out right now.'

'Fuck you, Wilson.'

'Right, Stephen, that's it. Would you kindly leave?'

'Nah,' I replied.

Tension filled the classroom. I sat at my desk, next to Big Man. We gave each other five and chuckled to ourselves. I gave Big Man the spliff and he sucked on it twice and mashed it under his foot. Wilson marched over to my desk: 'Get out!'

'Make me,' I said.

He grabbed me by the neck and tried to drag me from my chair. It kicked off. Big Man was on him and in a flash we had him on the floor and were pounding him with kicks and punches. He was a strong man but no match for a couple of strapping 13-year-olds. To protect his vitals, he curled himself up like a foetus, but that didn't stop us laying into him. We only came to our senses when we noticed the claret dripping from his smashed nose.

I wasn't expelled, merely suspended for the next two terms. In that time, I had to attend all sorts of meetings with Mum, who had to take God knows how many (unpaid) days off work. She was raising a family of four singlehandedly and needed every penny. But her commitment to my education was unflagging. The next couple of years were a complete waste of time. At 15, I left without any qualifications. I couldn't wait to see the back of the place.

Now closed, after being dubbed the worst school in Britain, Hackney Downs comp stands as a haunting symbol of squandered opportunity. Nearby is Sandringham Road, the old 'front line', where I spent years dealing. I hardly recognise it. Gone are the derelict shop fronts, the West Indian takeaways, the 'community' centre, the shebeens, the abandoned cars, the people, the noise. My most abiding memory of that time is the sense of camaraderie that existed between the dealers. In those days, the front was a no-go area, and if the police came anywhere near it we'd rain missiles down on them. And if one of our ranks got arrested, the rest of us would march on Stokey Station, demanding his release.

Things always seemed to happen on Sandringnham Road. One day, in the mid Eighties, I was hanging with my crew - Manny, Muff, Skinner, Stroller and Big Man. It was a quiet day, no trade to speak of, but a gorgeous midsummer afternoon. A few yards along the pavement, two 10-year-old boys were playing football. Their mothers were inside Lion's takeaway. After a few minutes, a ball rolled into the road. One of the boys ran after it and straight into an oncoming car. The car hit him with such force that he was lifted clean out of his little trainers and dragged beneath the car a full 50 yards before the driver was able to stop.

For a few seconds, we all froze. Shock turned to horror and then to anger. The driver of the car held his head in his hands as the mother cradled her son and wailed uncontrollably.

Big Man punched the driver in the jaw. He staggered and fell. The rest of us were about to pounce on him when the mother ordered us to leave him alone. So we lashed out at his car. The police soon arrived in full riot gear only to see us comforting a grieving mother. The child lived, but would never again have the use of his arms or legs. Those kind of things happened on Sandringham Road. Back then.

Now the 'front' a residential street like any other, complete with sleeping policemen. I sit on the front wall of a newly-built row of maisonettes. A young white couple walk by, wearing trainers. In another time, I'd have propositioned them to buy drugs. They eye me suspiciously and I realise how conspicuous I must look. I hurry away before anyone has a chance to call the police.

I head for Jessup's, an illegal gambling house just off Kingsland High Street. Walking into the dingy old basement is like stepping back in time. Hardly anything has changed, least of all the decor. The clientele, mostly immigrants who came over in the Sixties, sit around playing kalouki, a Jewish card game. Weed smoke hangs heavy in the air. This is a subterranean world where time stands still, a sanctuary for the disaffected and the disillusioned. I can see now why I spent so much time hanging out there.

Although I'm recognised and acknowledged, there's none of the exuberance I encountered earlier in the park. Mine is just an old face resurfaced, like so many others. Where I've been and what I've been up to is of no interest to these old timers. I spend the next hour warming myself in front of the gas heater.

The last time I'd been to Jessup's was a little different. It was at the height of my addiction in the late Eighties. My mate Narrow and I had been free-basing in my flat for five hours non-stop. We hadn't eaten or slept in days. One of us was bound to lose it and it just happened to be me. I'd just smoked my umpteenth rock and Narrow was preparing the pipe for his. My electricity supply had been cut and we were smoking by the light of a solitary candle. Perhaps it was a trick of the gloomy light but Narrow took on a monstrous aspect that terrified me. He appeared to be growing before my very eyes. I screamed and backed into a corner. Narrow moved towards me, his words soothing, his arms outstretched. Paranoid, I knocked him out of the way and ran for my life.

I fled like a madman. Eventually, exhausted, I found myself outside Jessup's. It was as though I'd been directed there by divine intervention. Everything I needed just then could be found inside its walls: peace, safety, and the counsel of wise old men.

I move on, heading north up Kingsland Road and into Stoke Newington, a real dump when I was growing up but now gentrified. I catch sight of the police station. It's now a gleaming, high-tech building - the stuff of design awards. Very different from the dilapidated hellhole it was in the Eighties.

I leave Stokey Station, turn down a side road. Every other house has a sign outside it. I get to Church Street and realise I could just as easily be in Islington. There are even bookshops, unheard of in my day. I'm about to go into one of these when I turn to see a silver Golf GTI pulling up beside me. The driver quickly gets out, rushes up to me and slams me up against the bookshop window. It's only when he speaks that I realise he doesn't intend me any harm, that he is, in fact, Manny, one of my old sparring partners.

Manny and I go back to his house to catch up. I go first, and Manny listens attentively, asking questions, getting me to repeat things. He's particularly interested in my rehab stories. I tell him about the urine samples, about the midnight curfew, the therapy sessions, the cold turkey, the anxiety attacks, the panic attacks, the sleepless nights. Manny congratulates me on my 'great escape', then tells me how, for a time after I left, he got into cocaine trafficking. He mentions so many airports, in so many exotic locations, I become enthralled. But that's behind him now, he says. He's been 'legit' these past few years. Using his ill-gotten gains, he now runs a secondhand car dealership, specialising in German cars. 'Need a Beamer, I'm your man.'

I ask about the others. 'Muff's doing a nine stretch. Aggravated burglary. If he's lucky he'll hit road in 2006. Skinner's in and out the nuthouse. Drugged up to the eyeballs. Stroller's selling bone from his drum. Bigman's brown bread. Took on some Yardies.' Manny crosses himself and says: 'RIP.'

It's gone 10 when I arrive back at Hackney Downs Station. It's only five minutes until the next train but I'm anxious to quit the deserted platform. In the half-light at the far end of the platform, I notice a spectral figure standing with hunched shoulders, protecting himself against the fierce wind.

I make the mistake of staring at him too long and groan when I see him approaching. He's dressed in rags. He wreaks of stale alcohol. I'm about to shoo him away when it dawns on me that I know him. His name's Sparkle (because of all the gold he used to wear) and he was a player way back when. Without thinking I shout: 'Sparkle, man! What happened to you?'

As though he and I had seen each other every day for the past 10 years, he says: 'Lend us a fiver, Fats.' I look him up and down, waiting for him to say he's only joking. When it's obvious he isn't, I shake my head and delve into my pocket. I've got £3.50. For a moment, I think I'll need it to get back to Notting Hill, but then I remember I'd bought a travelcard. I hand him the money and watch him disappear down the steps and presumably out of the station. Seconds later my train pulls in.

As I'm about to get on, I think: if he wasn't waiting for the train, what was Sparkle doing on the platform?

 Stephen Thompson's Toy Soldiers is published by Sceptre this week, £10

webTitle: Turning a man into a fish is never surreal

fields.headline: Turning a man into a fish is never surreal
fields.standfirst: The daughter of Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann explains to Gaby Wood why life may be farce as a form of freedom
fields.trailText: The daughter of Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann explains to Gaby Wood why life may be farce as a form of freedom
fields.body:
Somewhere near the middle of Linn Ullmann's first novel, Before You Sleep, the narrator and her father discuss her sister's troubles. 'What's the point of marriage if he's not making her happy?' she asks. The father replies: 'I don't understand who told you that the point of anything is to be happy.'

It seems perfect that this line should have been written by the daughter of Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann. Linn Ullmann smiles when I mention it: 'Yeah. My father said that to me once.' But she is quick to dismiss any easy associations: 'If people want to make connections with my father's work - to detect Bergmanesque themes in it - that's OK,' she says. 'But it's hard for me talk about what is a natural influence. Obviously there's an influence but I don't know in what way or to what degree. Both my parents are great storytellers.'

It must be one of the questions she is asked most frequently, and she responds with gracious discretion. 'It's not a dramatic thing that I choose not to speak about my parents,' she explains. 'If they come up in conversation, I'll talk about them. But it's important to make clear that this book is fiction, and it has very little to do with them.'

Ullmann herself is so engaging that she quickly makes curiosity about the rest of her family fall away. We meet at her apartment in Oslo, where she lives with her nine-year-old son. It's a large, light place full of books and comfortable corners for reading. She has a firm handshake and a sharp mind - her conversation tumbles out, sparkling and thoughtful, as if she spends a lot of time testing the logic of impossible-seeming things. Her English is impeccably American, learnt at a school for professional children in New York, and perfected over years of postgraduate study at NYU. She has a lovely, pixie-ish face and her mother's lips.

Before You Sleep is a wonderful novel, a meandering family narrative, told by a dishonest heroine and peopled with haunting snapshots. It comes across, in the main, as realistic, since Karin, the narrator, is chatty and imaginative and carries the reader along with her. But every now and then a surreal element is introduced - a lover turns into a mackerel, for example; or an image recurs like a muted nightmare - a husband wakes up in the night and sees a rock in the bed between him and his wife; or a perfectly simple event seeps through the rest of the book and becomes a character's whole foundation - Karin remembers her suicidal sister as a child, standing on the balcony of their home, throwing all her belongings down to her classmates, who are eagerly catching them in the snow. Here is a young girl throwing away her life, trying to get rid of the parts of herself that she can separate, and for her friends it's just raining gifts. 'Please,' Karin shouts, 'Please. Can't you please stop? These are Julie's things, not yours.'

As a writer, Ullmann has an extraordinary touch, and it's interesting to hear her speak so eloquently in person. Part of this is the way she talks about the act of writing itself - she imagines a book in terms of its 'lighting', its colours. She uses an almost filmic language: 'I had an idea of the structure before I had all the story: I knew that the first part would be carnivalesque, this long party that never ends, intoxicated almost. And I always knew that the ending would be very quiet and very still and very naked, and tender, and black in some ways - black and white in equal measure.' And as a critic of her own work she exhibits some of the nonchalant, freewheeling logic of her narrator (Ullmann is a critic as well as a novelist, and still has a regular column in the Norwegian daily paper Dagbladet).

'I don't find the fact of Carl turning into a fish particularly surreal,' she tells me. 'I guess it depends on whether you've experienced that or not. The idea that your lover turns into a fish - I don't even find it that imaginative. It's a literary archetype. But there have been a lot of responses to that scene. One guy came up to me and said, "I totally identify with that because once I was a mackerel." And another time,when I gave a reading in a fishing region in the north of Norway, a burly guy who looked like a fisherman got up and said, "You know, that scene you wrote about the guy turning into a mackerel - I don't believe it, it's totally unbelievable." And I said, OK, I can understand that. "The thing is," he said, "Karin puts him in a bowl of fresh water - mackerel is a salt water fish. He would never have survived!"

'So,' Ullmann concludes, laughing, 'where you start believing is all a matter of perception.'

Ullmann is not exactly Karin ('all of the characters are parts of me,' she says), but some of the pleasure in talking to her is exactly the pleasure in reading her book - just have a cup of coffee with her and you can see that sensibility at work. Listen, for example, to why she has never managed to pass her driving test: 'If it was just me and the car, I think I'd be fine. But the driving instructor kept telling me to make friends with the traffic and I just did not trust it. I mean, you know what it's like if you're a critic, you read every sign as potentially ironic. I was supposed to go right and I'd go left - it was ridiculous. Also, I took driving lessons at a critical point in my life, when things were changing a lot, and I took everything the instructor said to mean something very deep. So he'd say, "You can't brake and accelerate at the same time", and I'd nod slowly, thinking, no, you can't, can you? Or he'd say, "You drive like you just want to get out of here", and I'd shout, "Yes, I do! Doesn't everyone want to be anywhere but here?".'

This is Ullmann's slant on life - anything might be funny, or fatal; there is metaphysical potential all around us. She tells me about the films she grew up with, films which mean a lot to her. 'I cherish the movies,' she says. Bergman's eight children, of whom Ullmann is the youngest, still visit him every summer on Faro, the island he has made his home. He has converted a barn into a cinema, and he screens a movie a day, except on Saturdays, when there are two.

Ullmann says she has 'a thing about musical comedies - Singing In the Rain - I love the idea that they're doing this just for us to be happy!' Others she defends with more rigour. Fellini's Amarcord, for example. And then there are some films which seem, as our conversation drifts, to explain everything - about the way Ullmann thinks and writes, about the rules she may have lived by: farce as a form of freedom, catastrophe waiting to happen. 'You know,' she says, 'if someone said to me, "I don't like Chaplin's Modern Times", I'd think, What do we have to talk about? What is your life?'

It comes across, in the main, as realistic, since Karin, the narrator, is chatty and imaginative and carries the reader along with her. But every now and then a surreal element is introduced - a lover turns into a mackerel, for example; or an image recurs like a muted nightmare - a husband wakes up in the night and sees a rock in the bed between him and his wife; or a perfectly simple event seeps through the rest of the book and becomes a character's whole foundation - Karin remembers her suicidal sister as a child, standing on the balcony of their home, throwing all her belongings down to her classmates, who are eagerly catching them in the snow. Here is a young girl throwing away her life, trying to get rid of the parts of herself that she can separate, and for her friends it's just raining gifts. 'Please,' Karin shouts, 'Please. Can't you please stop? These are Julie's things, not yours.' As a writer, Ullmann has an extraordinary touch, and it's interesting to hear her speak so eloquently in person. Part of this is the way she talks about the act of writing itself - she imagines a book in terms of its 'lighting', its colours. She uses an almost filmic language: 'I had an idea of the structure before I had all the story: I knew that the first part would be carnivalesque, this long party that never ends, intoxicated almost. And I always knew that the ending would be very quiet and very still and very naked, and tender, and black in some ways - black and white in equal measure.' And as a critic of her own work she exhibits some of the nonchalant, freewheeling logic of her narrator (Ullmann is a critic as well as a novelist, and still has a regular column in the Norwegian daily paper Dagbladet). 'I don't find the fact of Carl turning into a fish particularly surreal,' she tells me. 'I guess it depends on whether you've experienced that or not. The idea that your lover turns into a fish - I don't even find it that imaginative. It's a literary archetype. But there have been a lot of responses to that scene. One guy came up to me and said, "I totally identify with that because once I was a mackerel." And another time,when I gave a reading in a fishing region in the north of Norway, a burly guy who looked like a fisherman got up and said, "You know, that scene you wrote about the guy turning into a mackerel - I don't believe it, it's totally unbelievable." And I said, OK, I can understand that. "The thing is," he said, "Karin puts him in a bowl of fresh water - mackerel is a salt water fish. He would never have survived!" 'So,' Ullmann concludes, laughing, 'where you start believing is all a matter of perception.' Ullmann is not exactly Karin ('all of the characters are parts of me,' she says), but some of the pleasure in talking to her is exactly the pleasure in reading her book - just have a cup of coffee with her and you can see that sensibility at work. Listen, for example, to why she has never managed to pass her driving test: 'If it was just me and the car, I think I'd be fine. But the driving instructor kept telling me to make friends with the traffic and I just did not trust it. I mean, you know what it's like if you're a critic, you read every sign as potentially ironic. I was supposed to go right and I'd go left - it was ridiculous. Also, I took driving lessons at a critical point in my life, when things were changing a lot, and I took everything the instructor said to mean something very deep. So he'd say, "You can't brake and accelerate at the same time", and I'd nod slowly, thinking, no, you can't, can you? Or he'd say, "You drive like you just want to get out of here", and I'd shout, "Yes, I do! Doesn't everyone want to be anywhere but here?".' This is Ullmann's slant on life - anything might be funny, or fatal; there is metaphysical potential all around us. She tells me about the films she grew up with, films which mean a lot to her. 'I cherish the movies,' she says. Bergman's eight children, of whom Ullmann is the youngest, still visit him every summer on Faro, the island he has made his home. He has converted a barn into a cinema, and he screens a movie a day, except on Saturdays, when there are two. Ullmann says she has 'a thing about musical comedies - Singing In the Rain - I love the idea that they're doing this just for us to be happy!' Others she defends with more rigour. Fellini's Amarcord, for example. And then there are some films which seem, as our conversation drifts, to explain everything - about the way Ullmann thinks and writes, about the rules she may have lived by: farce as a form of freedom, catastrophe waiting to happen. 'You know,' she says, 'if someone said to me, "I don't like Chaplin's Modern Times", I'd think, What do we have to talk about? What is your life?'

fields.headline: Panoramic view
fields.standfirst: From the front cover to the rear index - which links poems with the events of the century - Scanning the Century drips readability.
fields.trailText: From the front cover to the rear index - which links poems with the events of the century - Scanning the Century drips readability.
fields.body:
Scanning the Century: The Penguin Book of the Twentieth Century in Poetry
Edited by Peter Forbes
Penguin £12.99, pp596
Buy it at BOL

A plethora of fin-de-siècle poetry anthologies arrived last year, and Forbes's work is almost certainly the best. From the front cover - Misrach's retro Chrysler Newport on the Bonneville Salt Flats - to the rear index, which links poems with the events of the century, it drips readability. This is not a book to carry into a party or a pub - it will be stolen, as mine was, three times.

Forbes, editor of the Poetry Review, has taken a huge, inspired gamble and won. He decided to lump the poems of the past century into categories parametered by time and politics. It could have been a shambles, but it isn't. It manages to be two fine things: a definitive anthology of the century's poetry and an education.

Poetry is often viewed as needlessly inward and ignorant of circumstance, but Forbes has seen the power of the brains at work here and set every poem within its temporal milieu, be it revolution, Holocaust or Thatcherism. The prescience of the writers is, in hindsight, astonishing. Read Brodsky at the start or Fenton at the end, and marvel at the way poets of all nations have quietly beaten journalists, politicians, satirists and tyrants at their own game, a few years before they even started playing.

There will be quibbles because of Forbes's imposed strictures, but the strictures are loose, and this writer's only complaint is that no room could be found in the Thirties chapter for MacNeice's 'London Rain', perhaps the most priapically honest poem written in the past 100 years. And there's no Rilke. But every reader who finds one favourite lacking will find five new ones to embrace.

This is a book which, while gently celebrating the power of poetry, more rightly emphasises the genius of those who chose, while struggling through mankind's best and worst century, to write poetry.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Jeremy Seal's tiptoe through snake country turns out not to be a book about snakes after all, plus Temptresses, Fruit of the Lemon, The Last Kabbalist of Lisbon and Fair Exchange
fields.body:
The Snakebite Survivors' Club
Jeremy Seal
Picador £6.99, pp377

This is an energetic romp, or rather tiptoe, through every conceivable type of snake terrain. Seal visits India (for cobras), Australia (taipans), Africa (black mambas) and America (rattlesnakes). But in some respects, this isn't a book about snakes at all; they're just the wriggly pegs from which Seal hangs his observations.

He's excellent on the unexpected ways in which different cultures reveal themselves; from the invariably barking first colonial settlers (one new Australian's letter home concludes with a poignant, not to say optimistic, request for 'snails' and 'hedgehogs'), to the wily ways of Indian snake charmers who train their cobras not to strike by aiming them at heated saucepans: 'Soon enough they get a jolly hot nose. After that, they don't strike any more. Well, not often, anyway.'

Temptresses: the Virago Book of Evil Women

Shakrukh Husain
Virago £6.99, pp212
Buy it at BOL

Jeremy Seal records an African belief that we're reincarnated as snakes (according to status, of course - commoners come back as humble grass snakes). Applied to mythology's most evil women, this superstition seems quite reasonable, what with Melusine's hissy fits, Lamia 'all slither and venom' and, of course, Eve's new best friend.

Husain's demon ladies have their unorthodox moments, such as Sheba extolling the virtues of hairy legs to an unconvinced Solomon, but on the whole they're all tail and no tooth. 'Eve,' Husain tells us, 'always makes me think of a non-conformist living in a smug, conventional suburb. She needs a subversive friend, or a therapist, to encourage her to make the choices.' Nothing like a therapist for taking the sting out of a story.

Fruit of the Lemon

Andrea Levy

Hodder Headline Review £6.99, pp340
Buy it at BOL

Faith Jackson's parents were born in Jamaica, a place she's never been to and knows little about. She's grown up in grey north London and wants nothing more than to be ordinary, but in Britain in the Eighties Faith cannot seem to live a colourless life. The odd way in which racism manages to inflect the most banal situations gives rise to some wry black comedy, comedy that turns to tragedy when Faith witnesses a violent attack.

Seeking comfort, she visits Aunt Coral in Jamaica - 'This me niece, cha!' - where she discovers a family tree of cheerful complexity, and with it a new confidence in her identity as a 'bastard child of Empire'.

If Levy's structure is a sometimes a little stilted, her command of voices, whether English or Jamaican, is fine, fresh and funny.

The Last Kabbalist of Lisbon

Richard Zimler
Arcadia £11.99, pp318
Buy it at BOL

Berekiah Zarco lives in early sixteenth-century Portugal. He's supposedly a 'New Christian', forced to convert from Judaism after King Manuel's 1497 decree. But in fact he's a Kabbalist Jew, as is his uncle Abraham.

Mystic powers are no defence against mystery assassins, however, and Uncle is soon found naked and dead in a sealed room. Berekiah's detective challenge is rather complicated by Lisbon's sudden eruption into gross anti-Jewish violence, and the reader who wishes to join the hero in his hunt for the murderer must wade through pages of graphic bloodletting (whipping with broken glass, anyone?), while keeping a look out for lots of symbolist clues.

The Last Kabbalist has many similarities with The Name of the Rose, but Eco's postmodern sophistication is here upstaged by a brasher, uglier focus on sex and violence.

Fair Exchange

Michèle Roberts

Virago £6.99, pp246
Buy it at BOL

Michèle Roberts's novel was inspired by William Wordsworth's affair with Annette Vallon at the beginning of the French Revolution. But it's not a straightforward reanimation of famous lives; instead her invented poet Saygood's affair with Mademoiselle Villon leans here and there on the stories of both Wordsworth and Mary Wollstonecraft. Her feckless poet and his abandoned lover feel somehow abstract though, perhaps because of the balance Roberts has had to find between retelling and invention.

The prose comes most sharply into focus when it inhabits the minds of the servants, who, just for once, occupy the foreground, and Roberts's descriptions of the rhythmic continuities of nineteenth-century domestic routine - fruit-picking, jam-making and nursing the sick - are among some of the finest moments in this ambitious novel.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Poetry, fiction, love letters, music - all that you need for Valentine's Day listening
fields.body:
A Lover's Gift from Him to Her

Read by Michael Sheen

Buy it at BOL A Lover's Gift from Her to Him

Read by Laura Paton
Buy it at BOL

Naxos

Running time 1hr15mins

CD £9.99; cassette £8.99

These two tapes are elegant collections of poetry, fiction, love letters - and deeply sensuous music. From the languid Elgar to the emotional climax of a Puccini aria, the music is superb. Michael Sheen is both seductive and vigorous - 'Shall I compare thee with a Summer's day?' rings with Shakespeare's argument; in 'Rigs O'Barley', Robert Burns's pleasure of conquest is caught in the smile of Sheen's voice, while in 'None but thee shall be my paramour', he gives full vent to Marlowe's lust. Laura Paton has great range: she fires Katherine Mansfield's wild plea in her letter to John Middleton Murray with passion: 'I want you! Without you, life is nothing!' and follows it with hushed tenderness in speaking Héloïse's words of stolen pleasures with Abelard.

The Nation's Favourite Love Poems

Read by Judi Dench, Michael Williams, Charlotte Attenborough and Paul Rhys

BBC

Running time 2hrs 10mins, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

In its Valentine's Day purple box with a 'To my own favourite love' card tucked inside, this is a lovely gift. It's nearly twice as long as the tapes above, but it lacks zest - Donne's tough, masculine teasing in 'The Flea' is here presented in a submissive female voice. But with 80 love poems linked by music, all the favourites are here, and if the warm glow of perfect diction and reverential tones are enough for you, then curl up and be seduced.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.standfirst: Juan Rulfo's Pedro Paramo was a profound influence on Márquez, and in Margaret Sayers' new translation his prose is limpid and magical
fields.trailText: Juan Rulfo's Pedro Paramo was a profound influence on Márquez, and in Margaret Sayers' new translation his prose is limpid and magical
fields.body:
Pedro Paramo
Juan Rulfo
Serpent's Tail £6.99, pp122
Buy it at BOL

'I came to Comala because I had been told that my father, a man named Pedro Paramo, lived there. It was my mother who told me. And I promised her that after she died I would go see him...' If these opening sentences sound eerily reminiscent of Gabriel García Márquez, that's not surprising: Márquez has cited this extraordinary short novel - a classic of Spanish literature - as the book that most profoundly influenced his early years. Mario Vargas Llosa and Carlos Fuentes also acknowledge their debt.

As the narrator's dead mother sends her son out into the world on the quest for his father, the novel metamorphoses into an extraordinarily evocative and haunting journey through hell, the Comala of past and present and the place where Pedro Paramo - father, overlord, lover and murderer - once held sway. Rulfo's complex prose, scrupulously translated by Margaret Sayers Peden, is at once limpid and magical, dragging the reader on a strange and mesmerising journey through dreams and memories into a series of encounters with the ghosts of Comala.

This is a legendary novel by a master storyteller, and Rulfo, who is hardly known in Britain, is a legendary Mexican author whose quiet life of exemplary privacy was revered by fellow writers. He died in 1986. This new paperback edition is an important literary event.

webTitle: A little bit of learning goes the wrong way

fields.headline: A little bit of learning goes the wrong way
fields.standfirst: Pankaj Mishra's The Romantics tells the story of the sentimental education of a young Brahmin in Benares
fields.trailText: Pankaj Mishra's The Romantics tells the story of the sentimental education of a young Brahmin in Benares
fields.body:
The Romantics
Pankaj Mishra
Picador £14.99, pp277
Buy it at BOL

Pankaj Mishra had already made his name as the editor who discovered Arundhati Roy and the critic who trashed Salman Rushdie, a good indication of his tastes in Indian writing. His own first novel is quite unlike either, and is closest in style to the measured, unshowy prose of Amit Chaudhuri.

The story unfolds slowly, calm as the pace of life in Benares, the small city that is the novel's setting. Samar, the narrator, is a young Brahmin recently arrived from university, an innocent abroad relating the course of his sentimental education.

Benares is a microcosm of modern India; an ancient Hindu site of pilgrimage in the throes of modernising and expanding. Here Samar takes a small room with the sole intention of reading, garnering wisdom from Schopenhauer, Flaubert and Edmund Wilson. A quiet, earnest 19-year-old, he has seen little of life outside his books; even his book learning, he discovers, pales in the presence of the confident opinions expressed by the foreign travellers who pass through Benares.

He meets Miss West, the kind of capable, worldly-wise Englishwoman who would not be out of place in a Paul Scott novel, whose assured manner and privileged lifestyle hide a secret sadness. Through Miss West, he meets Catherine, the French girl who introduces him to sex and with whom he falls disastrously in love. Outside their little expat enclave, Samar makes a tentative friendship with Rajesh, a student agitator at the local university who keeps pistols under his bed and fuels the political unrest which sees students in violent skirmishes with the police.

The Romantics is a sensitive and introspective novel, ultimately a meditation on hope and failure. People, events and emotions are filtered unrelentingly through Samar's growing self-awareness; there is little direct speech and much of his own observations and reflections. As a result, however, he is the only character with any real solidity. His great love, Catherine, remains frustratingly insubstantial; her conversations and opinions summarised by Samar as if the author were afraid to break the rhythm by offering more than one voice. Mishra's evocations of Indian landscape and customs are vivid and thoughtful; his prose clean and unhampered and his descriptive passages to be savoured. Yet there is a sense that once you have finished this novel the impression it leaves is curiously evanescent.

fields.headline: Helm and high water
fields.standfirst: John Kinsella on two collections bound up with gender and class, Alan Jenkins' The Drift and Jo Shapcott's Her Book
fields.trailText: John Kinsella on two collections bound up with gender and class, Alan Jenkins' The Drift and Jo Shapcott's Her Book
fields.body:
The Drift
Alan Jenkins
Chatto & Windus £8.99, pp64
Buy it at BOL

Her Book
Jo Shapcott
Faber & Faber £8.99, pp125
Buy it at BOL

In his fourth collection of poetry, The Drift, Alan Jenkins utilises well-honed prosodic skills to stabilise memory, to anchor sense in the flow of recollection. The nautical 'drift', the sea and water, are ever present, most specifically in the context of the boat, the youthful romanticism of the poetic bateau ivre struggling against the harsh truth of social necessity, the effects of time and growing middle-aged. There is something refreshingly honest about the poet's self-analysis. What is mine, what is family inheritance, who does memory belong to? But it's not as easy as that. There are possibilities of negotiating in the grey area between thought and writing, cognition and speech.

This is also poetry of class - what constitutes our social environment, or more specifically, a specific English upbringing. The love poems in this tight collection are powerful for the same reason: assessing how memory alters and recreates a relationship. They are not weighed down by sanctimonious regret.

These are really poems of self-psychoanalysis. In the elegiac 'Brighton Return', we read: 'to you he was the chosen one, the brother you'd never had'. There is a vague, suppressed sexuality at work here, but it is left aside for the safer ground of recollection. Both this and 'The Short Straw' lament the physical loss of someone once very close and the loss of personal vision. Jenkins recognises that his address to the dead is an address to what's deadened in himself.

The book exhibits the tension between the poet maudit and the 'citizen' he has become. It's this ambivalence that drives the craft, the currents moving below the surface that draw up the new, the unpredictable, that will free memory from guilt:

Your verse bobs like a little yacht
in heavy seas, dismasted, it veers and bobs and weaves
as if it were the Galatea at the mercy of great waves
as if the helmsman were unfit
(From 'Salt')

'Street Life' is almost Conradian in its resignation to the presence of darkness in the human soul - 'I paid her twenty quid and pushed it up her, dry and tight.' This is informed and learned poetry, but always available, familiar, and non-pedantic.

What links this collection and Jo Shapcott's work distinctly is the motif of gender and the environment of class. But Shapcott is an altogether different poet, doing no less than rewriting the English poetic canon - challenging sources, verse structure and the primacy of the patriarchal voice.

Shapcott has a brilliant sense of how the line can be played against to enhance meaning, to make a point about tone and speed by turning before we expect her to. Like all great satirists, she is both part of the culture she is analysing, and able to step, momentarily, outside it.

Her Book is a 'compendium' of Shapcott's three previously published books. It isn't a large oeuvre but then there is no excess. Shapcott anticipates her critics at every turn. The conflation of poetry, sexism, language, the media and even economics is brilliantly conveyed in her well-known 'Mad Cow' poems.

A small, neat poem that might be read as a mini ars poetica is 'Watching Medusa', bearing in mind Cixous's essay 'The Laugh of the Medusa'. 'Struck dumb', the Medusa-watcher tells us: 'I cannot speak or move/ in case I do wrong to her and/ close the sweet hissing mouths.' In a Shapcott poem, Tom and Jerry can be acting out a storyline in England - 'swished my axe at Jerry, belted after him/ into the Bloody Tower, my back legs/ circling like windmills in a gale'; nothing is sacred.

The sun constructed an avenue
to the bedside table
and now the housefly played
boomerang in and out of the light.
Hilary surprised herself by breaking wind.
Secretly, her large smell
made her feel real and salty
as a merchant adventurer.

webTitle: Where next for the travel writer?

fields.headline: Where next for the travel writer?
fields.trailText: Whatever happened to travel writing? Twenty years ago, you could not open a magazine or go into a bookshop without encountering some kind of travel book. Where once Britons had ruled as proconsular administrators, now they travelled as reporters with notebooks and typewriters, collecting material for the fulfilment of publishers' contracts.
fields.body:
Whatever happened to travel writing? Twenty years ago, you could not open a magazine or go into a bookshop without encountering some kind of travel book. Where once Britons had ruled as proconsular administrators, now they travelled as reporters with notebooks and typewriters, collecting material for the fulfilment of publishers' contracts.

It was around this time that Sarah Anderson opened her Travel Bookshop in Notting Hill Gate. Still in business, this indispensable bookshop celebrates its 21st birthday this year.

The travel writers of the Eighties used to hark back to their English literary forebears - Robert Louis Stevenson, Evelyn Waugh, Graham Greene, V.S. Pritchett and Eric Newby - but this self-identification was not wholly honest. The real reason why they, and their publishers, were enthusiastically promoting the genre of travel writing was due, in a very considerable degree, to the overnight success of a little-known American novelist from Medford, Massachusetts, Paul Theroux.

Theroux burst into the consciousness of the average book buyer in 1975 with the publication of The Great Railway Bazaar, an unputdownable account of a journey by train across Europe, Asia and the Far East. Before that, he had a coterie following in literary circles and his fourth novel, Saint Jack (1973) had done quite well.

The Great Railway Bazaar, however, was a huge bestseller and its successor, The Old Patagonian Express, his account of another train journey, this time through the Americas, revealed an appetite for the far-flung, and also a means by which housebound writers short of experience could get their shoes dirty and live a little, at no great expense or risk.

All at once, in the sincerest form of flattery, there seemed to be dozens of pocket Theroux hopping on to boats, risking life and limb on motorcycles, and even camels, to make exotic peregrinations across wild tracts of terra incognita.

The new magazine Granta, on the look out for a marketable genre, actively promoted this kind of writing. When it became clear that not all these reports were - shall we say? - as scrupulously truthful as they might have been, travel writing was declared to be a kind of metafiction - half fabulous invention, half prosy catalogue. The high priest of this new cult was Bruce Chatwin who, as Theroux himself has written, was not much exercised about drawing the line between the novelist's imagination and the traveller's reportage.

Today, the great travel-writing boom of the Seventies and Eighties is over. Chatwin is, sadly, long gone and Theroux, who once made his home in London, now lives, like Stevenson, in the Pacific. He does, however, remain an inveterate traveller and his latest collection, Fresh-Air Fiend: Travel Writings 1985-2000 (Hamish Hamilton £20, pp453), reminds us why his initiative sparked a gold rush and why, now that the bonanza is over, his work remains the standard by which other travel writing must be judged.

Fresh-Air Fiend is, as its subtitle suggests, not really a new book, though it is is artfully arranged to look like one. It is, essentially, a collection of picked-up pieces transporting the puckish, dyspeptic figure of Theroux swiftly around the globe from Hawaii to the Yangtze, and from Christmas Island to Cape Cod. Possibly the most interesting part of the volume is the prefatory essay in which Theroux identifies himself as 'a perfect stranger', an instinctive outsider who percipiently notes Oliver Sacks's observation that: 'In the Kabbalah the first act in the creation of the universe is exile.'

As well as supplying notes towards an autobiography, Theroux also reprints some revealing essays on his, and other people's, travel books. He reminisces about his friendship with Chatwin and Graham Greene. He names Apsley Cherry-Garrard's The Worst Journey in the World as his 'favourite travel book'.

He admits that before it 'occurred' to him to write such a travel book, he found the genre 'a bore' written and read by 'bores'. He adds in a kind of credo: 'I had done enough travelling to know that half of travel was delay or nuisance... the truth of travel was interesting and off key, and few people ever wrote about it.'

For many readers, Theroux himself remains their favourite travel writer, a lonely pioneer who, possibly at the expense of his fiction, which is now somewhat overshadowed by his travelogues, brought fresh intelligence and energy to a genre in sore need of inspiration.

webTitle: Not as pretty as he's painted

fields.headline: Not as pretty as he's painted
fields.standfirst: Philip Sidney's life was an extraordinary mix of bisexual revelry, shady networking and literary skill. Reading Alan Stewart's biography, you'd never guess it
fields.trailText: Philip Sidney's life was an extraordinary mix of bisexual revelry, shady networking and literary skill. Reading Alan Stewart's biography, you'd never guess it
fields.body:
Philip Sydney - A Double Life
Alan Stewart
Chatto & Windus £20, pp400
Buy it at BOL

The dustjacket of Alan Stewart's book, showing Philip Sidney's face as a head joined at the ear to its own mirror image, suggests that he has something wonderfully novel to say about the 'double' nature of his subject's life. Since a previous book was called Close Readers: Humanism and Sodomy in Early Modern England, I hoped to find that he had gazed less nervously than previous biographers have done at the profoundly 'grey area' of Sidney's sexuality.

The fussed-over darling of many older men, in England and on the Continent, Sidney was sometimes accused of 'unmanly' behaviour by these same men. The great statesman and diplomat Hubert Languet, who acted as his mentor during the three years of his Grand Tour, remarked after his only visit to England that 'the habits of your court seemed to me somewhat less manly than I could have wished'.

Stewart records an even more thought-provoking comment by Sir Francis Walsingham, who got to know Sidney during his momentous year in Paris, a year that reached a climax in the St Bartholomew's Day massacre, that the 19-year-old was 'in danger of a very lewd practice' because of the 'evil practice' of his personal servants. However, Stewart suggests only that Walsingham, wise and well-travelled diplomat though he was, 'instinctively distrusted' Sidney's servants because one of them was a denizened Italian, one a Welshman.

Nor is anything made of the mild oddity that in this period in which advantageous marriage was a virtually compulsory career move for any ambitious courtier, neither of Sidney's close courtier friends, Fulke Greville or Edward Dyer, ever took this step.

Indeed, like many other aspects of his extraordinary short life, testimony to Sidney's sexuality is scarcely examined, neither Aubrey's claim that he had an incestuous career with his sister, nor ample evidence in Sidney's own writings that his enthusiasm for the Ciceronian virtue of male friendship included an acknowledgement of physical attraction, as when the older of the two young heroes of the Arcadia is attracted to his cousin and best friend when he is dressed up as an Amazon.

Another possibility, I hoped, was that Stewart might have investigated the 'double' nature of Sidney's life in the sense of 'duplicity', perhaps giving Sidney and his huge network of political and diplomatic correspondents the sort of John Le Carré-wards make-over that Charles Nicholl devised for Christopher Marlowe in The Reckoning (1992).

Given Sidney's insistence on including within his circle both English Catholic exiles and continental Catholics, there might have been room for exploring the possibility that, as John Buxton once hinted, Sidney was some sort of spy, who used his charm and linguistic ability to win the trust of such men, in the hope of rewards at home. But this avenue isn't opened either.

Stewart's treatment of religious and political issues is disappointingly simplistic. Sidney is flatly described as coming from 'a prominent Protestant family', which hardly takes into account the fact that his parents had been flourishing courtiers during the reign of Mary Tudor, so flourishing, indeed, that baby Philip had Mary's consort Philip of Spain as his godfather.

Nor does Stewart face the implications of the undoubted facts that Sidney's father saved the life of the Jesuit Edmund Campion in 1571, hurrying him out of Ireland to avoid arrest; that Philip himself went out of his way to talk to Campion in Prague in 1577; and that his uncle, the Earl of Leicester, actively intervened to improve the conditions of Campion's imprisonment in the Tower in 1582. If the Queen repeatedly showed suspicion of the Sidney circle's true allegiance, either to her own authority or to the reformed religion, perhaps she had good reason.

It turns out that, as in the Edwardian music-hall song, 'You can't tell what's inside the pot by the label on the jam'. The concept of a 'double life' seems to have been an afterthought or marketing device. I spotted a single remark in the penultimate chapter that 'Philip Sidney now had a dual persona, soldier and poet', with reference to his patronage of Justus Lipsius. But if that is meant to support the 'doubleness' of the title, it is not convincing.

Much is made of Sidney's activities as a 'networker' - rather than 'soldier' - but virtually nothing of his writing. For instance, his slippery and much-debated poem on monarchy and tyranny is described as 'a fairly simple beast fable'. Even more astonishingly, Astrophel and Stella, probably the most intricate and formally sophisticated sonnet sequence ever written, 'appears... to be a simple unrequited love story', and the few quotations from it are treated as if they offer unproblematic biographical data.

Readers not already familiar with Sidney's creative writings will be sadly misled if they look here for some sense of their scope and tone. On the radical revision of the Arcadia, Stewart says that 'he had only got as far as redrafting the first two books, and was working on the third'. This gives no adequate sense either of the huge length of the revised Book Three or of its utter originality - as a piece of entirely new writing, exploring areas of human consciousness and frustration that were not to be touched again until Hamlet.

Stewart's own style is not that of a man who is sensitive to literary effect; it is slangy without being vivid. Minutes away from that fatal musket shot during the skirmish near Zutphen, Sidney is described as being 'unfazed'. Words like 'pragmatic' and 'ironic' regularly paper over vast chasms of thinking or thoughtlessness. Extensive footnotes set up expectations of scholarly rigour which are undermined by blunders such as the attribution of Sidney's Italian model Arcadia to 'Sansovino' rather than 'Sannazaro'.

This rather rushed-seeming survey unhappily endorses T.S. Eliot's claim that Sidney was a dead bore. First, he got around a lot and then died young in a foreign field. But why should we care?

webTitle: Oh I say! What a dreadful shot

fields.headline: Oh I say! What a dreadful shot
fields.standfirst: Tony Hawks goes on a mission to teach foreigners about positive living in Playing the Moldovans at Tennis
fields.trailText: Tony Hawks goes on a mission to teach foreigners about positive living in Playing the Moldovans at Tennis
fields.body:
Playing The Moldovans at Tennis
Tony Hawks
Ebury £9.99, pp249
Buy it at BOL

It begins with a bet in a south London pub. Comedian and media 'personality' Tony Hawks accepts a challenge from his friend Arthur Smith, also a comedian and personality, to play the entire Moldovan football team at tennis. By way of a forfeit, the loser would sing the Moldovan national anthem naked on Balham High Street.

Smith has a theory that people who excel at one sport can probably reach a high level of proficiency in another; at least one member of the Moldovan team, he argues, would be good enough to beat Hawks at tennis. Hawks, who fancies himself as a useful amateur player, believes that in this sport, at least, a modicum of basic technique is essential. Such is the banal argument that produced this book. Evidence of Hawks's extreme literal-mindedness has already been provided by his bestselling account of hitchhiking around Ireland with a fridge - also the result of a wager. So it should come as no surprise that in a rush of egocentric whimsy, he decides to prove Smith wrong and travel to Moldova to search out the members of the team.

Unfortunately, Hawks has several disadvantages as a travel writer. He knows nothing about the country he is visiting, seems little interested in finding much out and doesn't appear to like foreign people. His descriptions of Moldova, therefore, concentrate on its greyness, the bureaucracy, its lack of restaurants and how miserable and pessimistic the people are, as if no one who has written about this part of the world has ever thought these things before.

This becomes irritating very early on. When Hawks arrives on the main boulevard in Moldova's capital, Chisinau, he informs us that the atmosphere 'was hardly one of geniality' and that 'laughter was not the order of the day'. But he is determined not to tell the reader what it is like. Not much like southern Europe is about us much of a clue as he's prepared to give.

One might think that a lengthy stay in another part of the world would wrench someone out of this kind of parochial Anglo-comedy mindset. But not Hawks. He even finds it funny when he sees a football fixture between FC Agro and Dynamo Bender. It really is quite pathetic.

Incredibly, rather than trying to learn something from his time in an alien culture, Hawks decides he has a mission to teach.He is convinced that his own rather cheesy take on Victorian self-help philosophy is something that will help the Moldovans he meets pull themselves up by their bootstraps. He believes that by taking on the near impossible task of finding, playing and beating the entire Moldovan football team, he will prove that it pays to be positive about life.

Hawks's first book sold 150,000 copies, so clearly people like his brand of patronising optimism. If this book makes people feel as smug as Hawks about not being Moldovan, then I'm sure it will be a great success.

If this book makes people feel as smug as Hawks about not being Moldovan, then I'm sure it will be a great success.

fields.headline: Worlds without ends
fields.standfirst: Tom Paine's Scar Vegas and Other Stories is a book with its heart planted almost too firmly in the right place
fields.trailText: Tom Paine's Scar Vegas and Other Stories is a book with its heart planted almost too firmly in the right place
fields.body:
Scar Vegas and Other Stories
Tom Paine
Review £12.99, pp243

This book's heart is planted almost too firmly in the right place. It is dedicated to Ken Saro-Wiwa; it exudes heart-on-its-sleeve sympathy for the underprivileged and in-your-face contempt for the power-élite. Even its authorial signature conjures up reverberations greater than itself - 'Call me Tom Paine, not Thomas, as in The Rights of Man, nice ta meetcha.'

Yet despite their undeniable odour of political correctness, many of these stories possess genuine prose momentum. And unlike most young writers just setting out to map their personal territory, Paine isn't afraid to roam wildly beyond the tidy confines of his own front yard.

Paine's most memorable characters are political animals, whether they know it or not. In 'The Mayor of St John', a lovelorn former schoolteacher in the Virgin Islands gets caught up in a long-standing conflict between drug-runners, real-estate developers and donkeys. In 'The Battle of Khafji', a group of marines are turned into the wrong kind of heroes by the media circus of Desert Storm. And the well-tended, former Princetonian of 'Will You Say Something, Monsieur Eliot?', who sets sail single-handedly from the Bahamas to test his mettle, crashes into a raft of dying Haitian boat-people, where thirst and gangrene reduce everybody to the same common (and supremely human) condition. In Paine's universe, politics isn't a choice you make - it's a place where tempests toss you.

In the best of these stories, Paine takes a good narrative idea and runs with it. When the blackballed Melanie Appleby of 'A Predictable Nightmare on the Eve of the Stock Market First Breaking 6,000' loses her charge cards and her credit-rating, she ends up sleeping in the strip-mall courtyards of El Paso and consorting with an underworld of free-market entrepreneurs who sound a lot like the guys who exiled her from corporate Manhattan. 'The genius of the free market,' she recalls writing for her MBA at Stanford, 'is the accuracy with which it assigns a market value to all things.'

In 'General Markham's Last Stand', a marine corps lifer decides to strut his cross-dressing stuff at his own retirement party, thus mocking all the gung-ho-movie machismo his fellow officers brought home from Vietnam. Like Robert Stone or Thom Gunn, Paine often writes about men who are fed up with being men. But that doesn't mean they'll let anybody push them around, either.

These globe-hopping stories describe a multinational universe of disenfranchisement and hard luck. In 'Ceausescu's Cat', two brothers fight the good fight against the Romanian dictator in 1989, only to find themselves exiled and disappearing into the wide, UFO-haunted deserts of America.

And in the title story, an ex-con named Johnny Loop has learnt the world's game so well that when he goes west, he doesn't expect to find anything more (or less) revelatory than good air-conditioning and cold beer. For Loop, the world is filled with signs - stars, slot-machine cherries, televised football, pretty girls in bars - but none of them has 'fingered' him for anything special (until, unfortunately, one of them does). The only choice in a wide world overseen by corporate office buildings and radiating broadcast towers, Paine argues, is where do you want to be ripped off - in Bali, St John or Las Vegas?

There are times when Paine almost achieves something great in one of these stories, but then he falls just short of an ending. Sometimes, a story trails off into a half-hearted epiphany. At other times, it concludes with a corny, cinematic acclamation: we should save the boat-people, the police shouldn't beat up peaceful protesters, Las Vegas (like capitalism) reduces everybody to a commodity, macho, rape-oriented guys aren't nice, and so on.

While it's hard to dispute the points Tom Paine makes along the way, they ultimately detract from the fictional worlds he nearly succeeds in creating. He has done well; he can do better.

webTitle: Fast-food fiction never quite hits the spot

fields.headline: Fast-food fiction never quite hits the spot
fields.standfirst: Carol Shields' new collection of short stories, Dressing Up for the Carnival, leaves Tobias Hill wondering whether her prose has become a little too vibrant
fields.trailText: Carol Shields' new collection of short stories, Dressing Up for the Carnival, leaves Tobias Hill wondering whether her prose has become a little too vibrant
fields.body:
Dressing Up for the Carnival
Carol Shields
Fourth Estate £13.99, pp198

This is a book about drag, about the ways people remake themselves, what gets revealed and what hidden in the process. There is the childless woman pushing a pram down the street, the boy with a key who owns nothing, the quiet receptionist in a passionate yellow skirt. 'We cannot live without our illusions,' thinks one character, an anonymous, middle-aged citizen in his wife's lace-trimmed nightgown.

This is Carol Shields's third collection of short stories. Her reputation as a novelist tends to overshadow the fact that she also writes drama, poetry, short fiction and literary criticism. There are 22 stories here, none of them more than a dozen pages, some much shorter. Many are too short for their own good.

'She is no longer just Tamara,' Shields writes of the yellow-dressed receptionist, 'but a woman in a yellow skirt. A passionate woman dressed in yellow. A Passionate, Vibrant Woman About To Begin Her Day, Her Life.' This is vibrant prose, breaking out in italicised and capitalised exclamations. There are times when it becomes so vibrant that you wonder why it doesn't slow down.

Her writing has always been finely balanced, accuracy a counterweight for tenderness. In these stories, the precision is often absent and the balance disturbed. She is not a hard writer, but in her best work she has the measure of her characters and her gaze is unswerving. In this collection, it is the opposite, never settling on one thing for more than a moment. The shortest stories often leave a sense of subjects snatched at or avoided. This is fast-food Shields.

When the illness of an author is made public, as Shields's cancer has been, it inevitably presents critics with a dilemma: is a review ever for the author? Sense says not, but in the book world this is less than the whole truth. It is difficult to write a bloodlessly honest review of Dressing up for the Carnival because while there is good in it, it is not Shields's best work and a significant part of the problem lies in the absence of darkness.

The predominant atmosphere of these stories is a strained positivity, particularly near the beginning of the book. 'Happiness' is a word that crops up with an alarming frequency. Many of the stories are happiness trips, landscapes without shadows. There is something in this for Shields as much as for her readership, and this raises a question that echoes the first: is a story ever for the storyteller? To which the broad answer is no; public prose is for the public.

Shields is too good a writer not to recognise these problems herself, and two of the stories - 'A Scarf' and 'Edith-Esther' - examine them directly. Both feature novelist protagonists, though the fictions they create are quite different. Reta Winters has written the feelgood My Thyme Is Up, 'a fresh, bright, springtime piece of fiction', though 'there was, my daughters postulated, maybe too much over-the-top sweetness about the thyme seeds Alicia planted in her window-box.' Alone on tour, Reta discovers that: 'The radio stations avoided novels unless they had a "topic" like cancer.' She herself is a giver, with something for everyone - a scarf for her daughter, conversation for a friend - and everything in return.

In contrast, the eponymous heroine of the second story is an author whose work is 'Bleak... or when she wants to treat herself more kindly, austere.' Edith-Esther 'had refused to offer her readers the least crumb of comfort' and her comeuppance is a matter of poetic justice. There is a sense in this book that, at the moment, Shields would rather be the first author than the second. Little is gained in the decision for the reader and much lost.
