webTitle: The Marcel wave goes on and on

fields.headline: The Marcel wave goes on and on
fields.standfirst: As we stride confidently into the new millenium Marcel Proust's examination of memory and the past continues to exert its strange fascination
fields.trailText: As we stride confidently into the new millenium Marcel Proust's examination of memory and the past continues to exert its strange fascination
fields.body:
Marcel Proust: Selected Letters Volume IV 1918-1922
Edited by Philip Kolb, translated by Joanna Kilmartin
HarperCollins £40, pp518
Buy it at BOL

In The run-up to the new millennium much was written about new dawns and striding confidently towards a pan-European future. Yet even before we had seen out January, the literary world was renewing its homage to Marcel Proust, a novelist celebrated for directing his attention towards the past.

January 2000 saw the publication of the final volume of Proust's selected letters in English, coinciding with the release of Chilean director Raoul Ruiz's film Time Regained (based on the closing volume of Proust's monumental novel, In Search of Lost Time), and a major exhibition of Proust manuscripts and memorabilia at the Bibliothèque Nationale in Paris. Later this year, there will be an English edition of Jean-Yves Tadié's new biography.

Why the clamour now? In September 1922, two months before his death, Proust wrote to the critic René Gillouin reproaching him for asserting in his review of the most recently published volume of In Search of Lost Time that Proust was suffering from a 'severely neuro-pathological condition'. Alas, responded Proust, his illness was all-too real: 'Unfortunately for me, your diagnosis of my condition in your splendid article is incorrect.'

Still, Proust, an assiduous carper at reviewers who misrepresented him, was by and large complimentary, congratulating Gillouin on 'the exceptional beauties, the profound insights' of his review. 'We never cease to be surprised,' Gillouin had written, 'at what M. Proust reveals to us about ourselves simply through talking aloud in our presence. On the other hand, his illness introduces a strongly morbid element, tackling certain aspects of reality which, till now, have been the subject of treatises by doctors and psychiatrists, or else obscene books carried under a raincoat. M. Proust's writing is the literary equivalent of Freud's psychoanalysis.'

It is, I suggest, just these qualities detected by Gillouin which account for today's resurgence of interest in In Search of Lost Time and for the curious place it occupies in the vanguard of work which commands twenty-first-century critical attention.

Proust's long, meandering masterpiece is absorbed with the way we hold in our minds memories of a lifetime of experiences, some trivial, some conventionally memorable. The past is the residual trace of events in the mind - we are each the accumulation of our past, nothing is lost or forgotten, everything that lies behind us in time goes towards the construction of our present self. The responsibility for all lasting memory resides within us.

History is past events refracted through our mental lens - Proust likened it to looking backwards through a telescope. The frivolous figures on the same scale as the fundamental. At the same time, In Search of Lost Time is a kind of Freudian 'talking cure' in which the richness of the narrator's stream of consciousness justifies his present state of lassitude. And the story-telling is a project in its own right - it literally keeps him alive.

At the end of the final volume, Marcel compares himself to the narrator in the Thousand and One Nights - as long as he keeps telling his stories, he stands a chance of living to see the next day dawn. For the reader, entering wholeheartedly into the remembered life of Marcel means coming to terms with the dashed hopes and emotional disappointments of an entire generation.

Faced with the inevitability of death, Proust's narrator dedicates himself to leaving posterity a record of the memorial history his mind has assembled with a kind of brittle brilliance. Even so, as Proust observes in a footnote to the final segment of Time Regained: 'No doubt my books too, like my flesh and blood, will eventually die. But one must resign oneself to death. One accepts the thought that in 100 years even one's books will not survive.'

In Search of Lost Time resonates compellingly for an age which has seen the emergence of a whole new genre of plangently self-scrutinising writing in the form of the testimonies of a generation living in the shadow of HIV - culturally telling writing which includes Edmund White's The Farewell Symphony and Derek Jarman's Modern Nature.

Like these, Proust's tale of a man in a fragile state of health for whom Parisian high life and its erotic and intellectual attractions prove fatally irresistible, retrospectively romanticises recklessness. It addresses a prevailing tendency in fiction and non-fiction to rank the historically insignificant, passive onlooker's personalised view above more conventionally grand narratives.

These are themes whose general celebration surely sends out profoundly pessimistic messages about ourselves, entirely at odds with the triumphalism of the Millennium Dome. We might link them with the decision of the Whitbread judges and the South Bank Show to award their annual prizes to Seamus Heaney's version of Beowulf, an Anglo-Saxon poem from the first millennium, and obsolete cornerstone of old-fashioned university courses in English literature.

Beowulf is a saga of a warrior's struggle against evil. Yet the poem's dominant tone is one of loss and regret. And indeed, since Tolkien's influential essay on the poem in 1936 it has been consistently read as a lament for Beowulf's society and its values, a poetic evocation of a lost world, rather than an emotional rallying point for our future. Heaney has explained that, for him, 'poetry helps us to live our lives in the face of destruction'.

But when did we decide, as a critical community, to abandon the optimism and hope with which we greeted 2000? I, for one, continue to hold those cultural and political high hopes, and for all my long-standing attachment to In Search of Lost Time, would prefer to leave it to gather dust on my bookshelves than celebrate it in terms such as these. For the Proust revival belongs to the post-millennial backlash, a fundamental failure of nerve at the beginning of a new era.

fields.headline: Chilled out in the Caribbean
fields.standfirst: Neil Bissoondath's The Worlds Within Her is an ambitious novel with no rough edges
fields.trailText: Neil Bissoondath's The Worlds Within Her is an ambitious novel with no rough edges
fields.body:
The Worlds Within Her
Neil Bissoondath
Heinemann £14.99, pp417
Buy it at BOL

Turbulence is the theme of Neil Bissoondath's The Worlds Within Her - its idol, its goal. The novel begins with Yasmin, a middle-aged Indian, preparing to return her mother's ashes to the Caribbean island where they both grew up. Yasmin inhabits the suburbs - of Montreal, of the imagination. During the day she works as a television newsreader where she twists her mouth into whatever expression of sadness or wry amusement is appropriate for the video footage being broadcast. At night she goes home to her husband Jim, stolid and older than her. He offers her anchorage, a life hoovered free of danger. Or so she had once thought: her daughter has recently been killed in a car accident.

The Caribbean that Yasmin encounters is a post-coup warzone. The buildings are scorched, the shops looted, the roads blocked. There's little immediate comfort to be had at the house of Cyril and Penny, her uncle and aunt. They find her cold and her manners rather affected. Even one of the servants, the surly fundamentalist Ash, scorns her lack of interest in Hinduism. He can't understand how Yasmin can worship reason or why she uses it to insulate herself from the loyalty he thinks she owes to the Hindu diaspora.

Bissoondath intercuts Yasmin's tentative attempts to compile her own oral history with the confessional reminiscences her mother Shakti had spilled out to the bed-bound Dorothy Livingston, one of the few friends she made in Canada. We learn that Yasmin's father was a surveyor-turned-politician whose oratory had stirred islanders to clamour for revolution.

He was corrupt (naturally), and the passion of his rhetoric did not carry over into his emotional life. He married Shakti for the prestige that her family's elevated social standing would bring. He insisted that dustjackets trivialise the books they cover, but didn't actually read any of the canonical hardbacks with which he lined his study. This belief that books do not need to be decorated mirrored his tendency to muffle emotions, to withhold from his daughter the affectionate display and mad love that all children require. Nor is Yasmin's mother, an anglophiliac snob who eats toast using a knife and fork, any better.

In consequence, Yasmin finds it very hard to 'give out', to deal with feeling. Bissoondath has taken a big gamble in centring the novel around such a palpably dislikeable character. Her heart seems to be permafrozen. While she is eager to ascribe loneliness to people around her, she seems oblivious to her own isolation. By the moment of revelation 40 pages from the end which is meant to humanise Yasmin and her parents, our emotions have long congealed into indifference.

The repellence of its characters is not the novel's main flaw. Rather, it is the language. It has been flossed of all the gleeful impurity that vitalises Caribbean writers such as Patrick Chamoiseau and Earl Lovelace. One longs for bumps and glitches, the verbal equivalent of the roustabouting anti-teleology that the book seems to endorse at a thematic level. Instead, Bissoondath strives for pellucidity.

Unfortunately, though, the dialogue - and there's reams of it - too often exhibits the kind of over-articulate earnestness familiar to anyone who has ever watched one of those made-for-TV movies about, say, high-powered New York businesswomen who abandon husband and high-flying law company for a life helping out dirty-faced, golden-hearted refugees.

Bissoondath's anaemic prose also degeographises the novel. We learn little new about Canada, the Caribbean or, indeed, London. Both Yasmin's father and uncle spend time, as marginalised politician and pre-independence law student respectively, in the English capital. It is portrayed - all too generically - as the landmark-clotted, small-gardened, racist antithesis of a Caribbean island which, equally predictably, is lushly chaotic and marginal.

The Worlds Within Her is, none the less, a weighty novel, not only in size but in the important themes it addresses. These include transmigration, the relationship between memory and history, the extent to which personal identity is a fixed category. It is, in short, a rather typical postcolonial novel. And, as with most typical postcolonial novels, one finishes it feeling slightly better educated, slightly moved, slightly impressed. The breadth of Bissoondath's ambition and his philosophical and historiographical insights are laudable. What he lacks, though, is a feeling for hysteria, triviality, bad taste. He needs not just to write about turbulence, but to write turbulently.

Or so she had once thought: her daughter has recently been killed in a car accident. The Caribbean that Yasmin encounters is a post-coup warzone. The buildings are scorched, the shops looted, the roads blocked. There's little immediate comfort to be had at the house of Cyril and Penny, her uncle and aunt. They find her cold and her manners rather affected. Even one of the servants, the surly fundamentalist Ash, scorns her lack of interest in Hinduism. He can't understand how Yasmin can worship reason or why she uses it to insulate herself from the loyalty he thinks she owes to the Hindu diaspora. Bissoondath intercuts Yasmin's tentative attempts to compile her own oral history with the confessional reminiscences her mother Shakti had spilled out to the bed-bound Dorothy Livingston, one of the few friends she made in Canada. We learn that Yasmin's father was a surveyor-turned-politician whose oratory had stirred islanders to clamour for revolution. He was corrupt (naturally), and the passion of his rhetoric did not carry over into his emotional life. He married Shakti for the prestige that her family's elevated social standing would bring. He insisted that dustjackets trivialise the books they cover, but didn't actually read any of the canonical hardbacks with which he lined his study. This belief that books do not need to be decorated mirrored his tendency to muffle emotions, to withhold from his daughter the affectionate display and mad love that all children require. Nor is Yasmin's mother, an anglophiliac snob who eats toast using a knife and fork, any better. In consequence, Yasmin finds it very hard to 'give out', to deal with feeling. Bissoondath has taken a big gamble in centring the novel around such a palpably dislikeable character. Her heart seems to be permafrozen. While she is eager to ascribe loneliness to people around her, she seems oblivious to her own isolation. By the moment of revelation 40 pages from the end which is meant to humanise Yasmin and her parents, our emotions have long congealed into indifference. The repellence of its characters is not the novel's main flaw. Rather, it is the language. It has been flossed of all the gleeful impurity that vitalises Caribbean writers such as Patrick Chamoiseau and Earl Lovelace. One longs for bumps and glitches, the verbal equivalent of the roustabouting anti-teleology that the book seems to endorse at a thematic level. Instead, Bissoondath strives for pellucidity. Unfortunately, though, the dialogue - and there's reams of it - too often exhibits the kind of over-articulate earnestness familiar to anyone who has ever watched one of those made-for-TV movies about, say, high-powered New York businesswomen who abandon husband and high-flying law company for a life helping out dirty-faced, golden-hearted refugees. Bissoondath's anaemic prose also degeographises the novel. We learn little new about Canada, the Caribbean or, indeed, London. Both Yasmin's father and uncle spend time, as marginalised politician and pre-independence law student respectively, in the English capital. It is portrayed - all too generically - as the landmark-clotted, small-gardened, racist antithesis of a Caribbean island which, equally predictably, is lushly chaotic and marginal. The Worlds Within Her is, none the less, a weighty novel, not only in size but in the important themes it addresses. These include transmigration, the relationship between memory and history, the extent to which personal identity is a fixed category. It is, in short, a rather typical postcolonial novel. And, as with most typical postcolonial novels, one finishes it feeling slightly better educated, slightly moved, slightly impressed. The breadth of Bissoondath's ambition and his philosophical and historiographical insights are laudable. What he lacks, though, is a feeling for hysteria, triviality, bad taste. He needs not just to write about turbulence, but to write turbulently.

fields.headline: Mass gene bank launched
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Half a million British citizens are to take part in the world's largest clinical trial in a bid to create a new generation of drugs and treatments to counter cancer, heart disease and mental illness.
fields.body:
Half a million British citizens are to take part in the world's largest clinical trial in a bid to create a new generation of drugs and treatments to counter cancer, heart disease and mental illness.

The scheme - which raises a host of major ethical problems, including controversy about the need for patient confidentiality - is to be launched next year.

It will involve taking lifestyle details, DNA samples and medical records of patients from selected GP practices to create a national biological database of unprecedented size.

Researchers will then track participants and attempt to unravel the environmental and genetic roots of the diseases that afflict them.

The programme - called the UK Population Biomedical Collection - could become a precursor of a national DNA database covering all NHS patients. It will have a start-up cost of £40 million.

The scheme is intended to give the British pharmaceutical industry a critical advantage over competitors. Using data from the collection, researchers will be able to design a new generation of drugs that will counter most major diseases. It will also be used to predict whether individuals are liable to contract killer diseases.

But the project - a direct outcome of scientists' success in unravelling the human genome - faces headaches concerning confidentiality of data, the sale of patient information to private companies, and the linking of disease susceptibilities to different ethnic sub-groups.

Health Minister Yvette Cooper last night admitted the proposal 'raised very serious ethical and practical issues' for the country. 'Patient confidentiality and consent will be the key. That is why there will be widespread consultation before any decison is made,' she added.

However, ministers also point out that the database should quickly lead to the establishment of a new type of medicine in Britain, one that is based on predictive action. This would be a severe threat to the private insurance industry.

As one Minister said, this sort of database 'means the conservatives are going up precisely the wrong path by advocating more private health insurance. Genetics will eventually mean it is possible to identify individuals prone to illness, such as cancer. They will become uninsurable.' Only a publicly funded health service would serve the needs of a community in which individuals' tendencies to become ill are known in advance.

The database project is the brainchild of the Medical Research Council and the Wellcome Trust, the principal funders of medical research in the UK, who recently set up a panel - led by Professor Tom Meade - to study the project's feasibility. In a few weeks, it will recommend the scheme be given the go-ahead.

An NHS ethical committee will then have the final say about its establishment but sources within both organisations say they are extremely confident the collection will be launched next year. Doctors at targeted practices will then be requested to ask patients within various categories, including those related to ethnic origin, if they wish to participate.

Critically volunteers will have to be between 45 to 65. 'We are looking for healthy people who are liable to get sick within one or two decades,' said Professor George Radda, the MRC's chief executive. 'If we used young people for our database they would take too long to get ill.'

Patients will be followed up regularly throughout the study with details of coronary conditions, major blood pressure problems, tumours and other problems being added to their files. By linking these developments with information about their genetic make-up and their social sta tus and lifestyles, it will be possible to tease apart their conditions' genetic and environmental causes.

A key factor in establishing the scheme has been the setting up of a national DNA collection in Iceland. However, the establishment of the Icelandic database has been mired in controversy because patients have had to opt out of involvement. In Britain, an 'opt-in' system will be used.

'Involvement is going to be entirely voluntary,' stressed Professor Meade. 'That is critical part of this project.'

fields.headline: Genetic code
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Exploitation of the human genome represents one of the great ethical challenges of our time. The fragile strand of DNA that defines so much of what we are has the potential to revolutionise healthcare in the new millennium. But between the individual's ownership of his genes and public necessity, there lurks a worrying gulf: medical science's ability to identify the genes that make individuals predisposed to certain diseases. Soon it will be possible for doctors to identify an infant's future health risks by examining its DNA.
fields.body:
Exploitation of the human genome represents one of the great ethical challenges of our time. The fragile strand of DNA that defines so much of what we are has the potential to revolutionise healthcare in the new millennium. But between the individual's ownership of his genes and public necessity, there lurks a worrying gulf: medical science's ability to identify the genes that make individuals predisposed to certain diseases. Soon it will be possible for doctors to identify an infant's future health risks by examining its DNA.

This transparency about our genetic predisposition to disease will, by necessity, demand we rethink health provision: funding of healthcare through private insurance - the mainstay of the Tory health policy - must be abandoned. When we can predict who may become ill, how many and from what, only a properly funded National Health system makes sense.

The plan by the Medical Research Council and the Wellcome Trust to make a British DNA collection throws up a second concern: ownership of the intellectual rights to the mapped genes. The stampede by laboratories and drugs companies to patent human genes has led to distasteful conflicts of interest, not least in America where a company is claiming intellectual rights to a breast cancer gene, doubling the cost of genetic screening of British women particularly at risk.

Creating a DNA collection is to be welcomed, but must come with cast-iron guarantees, for individuals involved and society as a whole. Most obvious is the requirement of confidentiality and support for those who take part in the project. But we require a wider guarantee. Any exploitation of a genetic map of Britain must be for benefit its people. Our genes are our common heritage, not a cash cow for drugs companies.

webTitle: Haider the pariah finds an ally

fields.headline: Haider the pariah finds an ally
fields.standfirst:
The Austrian far right in power: special report

Neal Ascherson in Vienna reports on the far-right leader's Bavarian fellow-travellers and the refugees who now fear expulsion from Austria
fields.trailText: 'Take care of Austria for me!' The Chancellor's voice was almost a whisper, strangled with misery. Viktor Klima, head of government and leader of the Social Democratic Party which had been in office for 30 years, was handing over power.
fields.body:
'Take care of Austria for me!' The Chancellor's voice was almost a whisper, strangled with misery. Viktor Klima, head of government and leader of the Social Democratic Party which had been in office for 30 years, was handing over power.

He spoke like a farmer abandoning his home to foreign conquerors: be gentle with my cow, don't strip my old tractor's clutch... Klima's successors in Vienna's Hofburg Palace are Austrians too, of course. The new Chancellor is little Wilhelm Schüssel from the People's Party. But it's the presence of the far-right Freedom Party in the new coalition, directed off-stage by Jörg Haider, which makes old-fashioned Austrians feel that invaders from another culture have taken over their venerable political landscape.

And was that old Austria worth taking care of? This is the question which still puzzles the opposition to the new regime. Although the government has had no time to do anything concrete, the mere fact that Haider has won a grip on power is causing more damage to Austria's reputation every day. But is it a real response to the crisis merely to restore the cosy old corporatist power-club which has run the country almost uninterrupted for 50 years?

The past week has shown that Haider - as many feared - is, in effect, in charge. He remains the Governor of Carinthia in distant Klagenfurt, not in the Vienna Cabinet. But on Thursday he called all the new Freedom Party Ministers to Klagenfurt to get their instructions. Dutifully they went, their fresh suits, shiny shoes and glossy coiffeurs making an odd contrast with the louche appearance of Haider himself - ill-shaven, a jacket thrown over an old sweatshirt.

The first meeting of the coalition Cabinet itself (Haider's people have half the ministries) could not take place until they had returned. Haider does not mean to 'do a Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises' - stay away from the capital to keep people guessing about his plans. Haider means to keep control.

The magazine Profil' writes: 'Inside a week, Austria, a respected member of the European Union, became a pariah among states. On the whole continent, only Serbia is more isolated.' Shocking, but less than the truth.

While France and Belgium lead the European boycott of bilateral relations, while Israel and the United States mutter warnings, and Claudia Cardinale, with Catherine Deneuve, refuses the invitation to Vienna's Opera Ball in March, Haider is also making some very interesting foreign friends.

The most useful is Edmund Stoiber, premier of Bavaria, with his Christian Social Union. Stoiber upset Brussels a few years ago by suggesting that a united Germany no longer needed to share its sovereignty in the European Union. He agrees with Haider that European integration has gone too far, that Germany and Austria have too many foreign refugees, and that post-communist Eastern and Central Europe should be kept out of the EU for as long as possible. Stoiber also insists that the Sudeten Germans, expelled after 1945 by the Czechs to Bavaria and Austria, ought to be compensated by the Czech Republic. Haider agrees.

Last week Stoiber enraged the German government by sending his lieutenant, Michael Glos, to Vienna to congratulate the new Austrian government. On Friday, he received President Klestil of Austria in Munich, inviting him to defend Austria's commitment to 'European values'. But the Vienna coalition was forced into its first retreat over the Sudeten Germans.

The new 'government programme' in effect had threatened that Austria would veto Czech entry to the EU if the Sudeten Germans were not compensated. But protests from the Czech Foreign Minister, Jan Kavan, were so loud that Schüssel's first policy statement to parliament dropped the threat.

Some Austrians are talking about 'Alpine Populism'. They see sympathy with Haider's prejudices not only in Bavaria but in Switzerland, in regions of northern Italy and even in French Savoy, lands where there is fear of 'swamping' by immigration and a nostalgia for old-fashioned family authority. But this is no help to the new Foreign Minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner. A People's Party diplomat with no personal taste for Haider, the lady-like 'Benita' is condemned to tour the world insisting 'that Austria is not Naziland'.

The central question is whether the 'blue-black' coalition (blue for Haider's movement, black for the conservative People's Party) can survive. The demonstrations continue nightly in Vienna and other cities; peaceful affairs now unlike the violent clashes of two weeks ago. On Saturday, there will be a real trial of strength when the 'Democracy Offensive' campaign hopes to bring the whole trade union movement and all Social Democrat supporters on to Vienna's streets.

But as an anti-Haider writer said: 'Austria has simply forgotten how to take direct action by demonstrations and strikes. It's 30 years since the unions had to lift a finger. On the other hand, that also means that people don't know where to stop. It could get nasty.'

The buzz-word is 'repoliticise', but it means something different to Right and Left. For Haider's backers (and 47 per cent of the working class voted for him, far more than for the Socialists), it means chasing out the old power-brokers and restoring a sense of national virility. For the protesters on the street, it means inspiring Austrians to build a new democracy.

The protesters beat their drums and blow their whistles. The police look on benignly - most of them are Social Democrats. That is how Austria works: the party ticket goes with the public-sector job ticket. But internal splits threaten the blue-black coalition more than drums.

The Freedom Party is notoriously quarrelsome. It is held together only by Haider's absolutely dominating personality and by fear of his hatchet-folk - such as Su-sanne Riess-Passer, now Deputy Chancellor, known as 'King Cobra' for her handling of party dissenters. And if Chancellor Schüssel's nerve breaks, he could stab Haider in the back, make a dirty deal with the Social Democrat Opposition and rule as a minority government.

Nothing enrages Haider supporters more than refugees and asylum-seekers. Balkan and African wars have doubled their numbers, and the new government threatens to close the doors and expel the undeserving - especially if they don't learn German. But the refugees I met at a Catholic hostel felt that things can hardly get worse.

Jean-Marie, a refugee from the Congo war, told of overcrowding and hunger at the Traiskirchen transit camp. After an anti-black speech by a prominent Freedom Party man (who almost became a Cabinet Minister), police raided Africans in the camp for drugs and beat them up; some were still in hospital. Gallo, a refugee from the slaughter in Sierra Leone, was jailed for two months for entering Austria without a visa. 'I heard in prison about this new government that hates foreigners, but I can't believe it.' Titty saw most of her family killed. Now she gets up at four in the morning to clean the streets. 'If the new government doesn't want me who will help?'

Khadijah was jailed after Austrian police banged on the table and yelled that she was a liar for saying that she was from Sierra Leone. 'Refugees are badly treated here,' she said. Would it get worse?

Khadijah had an unexpected reason for hope. 'All Europe is watching Austria. So maybe this government's behaviour to refugees will actually get better!'

webTitle: Gene bank will show what  makes every one of us tick

fields.headline: Gene bank will show what  makes every one of us tick
fields.standfirst:
Doctor will soon be able to predict your future illnesses - and prevent them ever happening. Robin McKie reports on an advance that will save millions of lives
Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: David Reynolds was 48 when he suffered a major heart attack. Cholesterol build-up in his arteries, lack of exercise, smoking and an inherited susceptibility combined to cause a major disruption to the flow of blood to his heart. The result was cardiac failure.
fields.body:
David Reynolds was 48 when he suffered a major heart attack. Cholesterol build-up in his arteries, lack of exercise, smoking and an inherited susceptibility combined to cause a major disruption to the flow of blood to his heart. The result was cardiac failure.

Modern medicine was able to save his life, though Reynolds was left with his heart muscles weakened and his lifestyle constrained. Never the less he has much to be thankful for: a few decades ago he would have been left for dead, such was our knowledge of coronary illness.

Yet this dramatic change is nothing compared to the one that will occur in the next 20 years. In the future, the factors that so devastated Reynolds's heart would never have touched his life because they would have been pinpointed years earlier, and action taken to block their effects.

This intervention would have come in many forms. His predisposition to high cholesterol build-up would have been spotted by DNA tests and appropriate drugs administered. He would have been warned - starkly and specifically - about his smoking and sedentary ways, and encouraged to take exercise.

This is the future of medicine. In the coming decades we will treat illnesses long before their worst effects have had an opportunity to take hold of our bodies. Prevention will be the key factor in saving lives and improving the quality of our existence.

It is with this specific aim that the Medical Research Council and the Wellcome Trust are preparing to set up the UK Population Biomedical Collection, a repository of DNA samples, lifestyle data sheets and medical records for half a million middle-aged UK residents. Armed with this information, researchers expect within the next 10 years to be able to tease out the complex, interacting strands of inherited susceptibilities and environmental influences that determine the course of cancers, heart disease and mental illnesses.

Scientists have dreamed of unravelling the influences of nature and nurture for centuries. The fact that we are now on the threshold of achieving this goal is due, almost entirely, to the success of researchers who will in the next two years pinpoint every human gene and sequence their structures.

Armed with precise details of our genetic make-up, researchers will be able to extract this data from the morass of environmental factors that also influence our wellbeing. We will learn how specific versions of genes are affected by diet, workplace and lifestyle, interactions that are the key to most major illnesses. Do certain foods make some individuals more likely to develop bowel cancer? Is alcohol more likely to trigger liver damage in some people than others? And why does smoking cause lung cancer in some people but not others?

It is a dilemma illustrated by the lives of two distinguished Englishmen: Winston Churchill, who drank and smoked to excess but lived beyond 90, and Bobby Moore, a renowned athlete, who succumbed to cancer in his early fifties. One got lucky, one did not - and scientists will soon be able to find out why.

More to the point, they will be able to use that knowledge to develop drugs and treatments that will come to the aid of those who have drawn a short straw in the lottery of life. The protein pathways that lead to their susceptibilities will be analysed in detail and chemicals designed to block their effects. In addition, it should be possible to discover why some drugs now in use help some people, but not others.

'Consider the example of tamoxifen,' says Medical Research Council chief executive George Radda, one of the masterminds of the DNA collection scheme. The project has a keen pharmaceutical edge - a point stressed by Professor Tom Meade, chairman of the panel responsible for setting up the DNA collection: 'We are not doing this for idle curiosity. A principal difficulty concerns access to the data that will flow from studies of the lifestyles and the DNA collected by the project's 500,000 participants - to be stored in mighty mainframe computers at a site that has yet to be selected.

This information will be given to pharmaceutical companies and used as the key to the development of future drugs. But the mechanism for passing it on has not yet been worked out. Which companies will be allowed access? Will invaluable data about UK residents be given to foreign drug companies?

The Medical Research Council is emphatic that a principal reason for creating the collection is to provide the British drug industry with a powerful advantage over foreign competitors. So health officials will have to pick and choose candidates to whom they will pass on data.

It is a stretch of DNA inherited from our parents. Genes dictate how our bodies grow and develop.

What does a gene do?

We are made up of thousands of different chemical building blocks called proteins. The manufacture of each protein is controlled by one specific gene.

A person can alter his or her lifestyle. Alternatively, it should be possible to develop drugs that block the protein pathway that leads to the development of that particular disease. This is the ultimate aim of the DNA collection study.

webTitle: The long trek from Kabul to the Cotswolds

fields.headline: The long trek from Kabul to the Cotswolds
fields.standfirst: Jason Burke, who has reported for The Observer from Afghanistan for two years, followed the Boeing 727 to Stansted, where the hijack's end still left much unresolvedStansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: The gunmetal grey sky that has glowered over Stansted for the last week cleared yesterday and the bulk of the passengers who reached Britain on a hijacked Afghan jet left their temporary home in the airport's Hilton Hotel.
fields.body:
The gunmetal grey sky that has glowered over Stansted for the last week cleared yesterday and the bulk of the passengers who reached Britain on a hijacked Afghan jet left their temporary home in the airport's Hilton Hotel.

Just before it started to get dark, a convoy of coaches with police escorts slid out of the hotel car park and headed to a nearyby fire station. They were then due to be taken later last night to a Home Office 'immigration reception centre'in the Gloucestershire village of Moreton-in-Marsh.

The 74 hostages took with them their luggage: piles of cheap holdalls and tightly-tied plastic bags. They left behind them the Hilton's Living Well Health Club, Amy's Restaurant, the Café Cino, the heated pool, the £202 a night rooms and the stinking, useless, unflyable shell of an old Boeing 727.

Sitting behind the glinting windows of their coaches, they showed little emotion, except for the odd diffident smile, a repeatedly stroked beard or the classic nervous Afghan gesture of readjusting the pattu (an all-purpose blanket) over their shoulders. Above all they looked bemused and bewildered; exactly like people who, having set off on a short journey within their own country, suddenly find themselves transported to what might as well be another planet. They did not look like the first wave of the invasion of the bearded benefit snatchers.

They did not look like Middle England's worst nightmare, because they're not. When they took off from their home city last Sunday, none - even the hijackers - thought they would end up in London. The idea that the UK was targeted as a 'soft touch' is just one of the various myths that sprang up, amid the bluster and the bile, last week.

The truth is - like the average room at the 'luxury hotel' where the freed hostages have supposedly been enjoying the 'high life' - actually rather uncomfortable. Most Afghans have only a fairly hazy idea of where Britain is. They certainly don't have a profound understanding of its asylum regulations. If Britain is known for anything in Afghanistan, it is for the repeated military defeats it suffered there during the nineteenth century 'Great Game', for the help it offered the Afghan guerrilla fighters who fought the Soviet occupation of their country in the Eighties and, most recently, for supporting United Nations sanctions which, in an attempt to punish the ruling Taliban regime protecting the terrorist, Osama Bin Laden, have merely made a hard life harder for most average Afghans.

Even the hijackers appear to have had little idea of their destination when, five minutes out of Kabul airport last Sunday morning, they took control of the plane. Intelligence in sources in Pakistan told The Observer that the hijackers' first demand to the pilot, Captain Sayed Nabi, and his crew was merely to fly them out of Afghan airspace. Once they had crossed the line of Amu Darya river into central Asia, the hijackers asked him to get meteorological reports for a whole range of Asian destinations.

Only when the plane left Moscow did it seem that London, Frankfurt and Paris were possible goals. Quite why the British capital was the preference is unclear. It may have been simply because at least all the hijackers had heard of it. There are gaudily-coloured pictures of the Thames and, oddly, the the Tyne, plastered to the walls of half the restaurants in their home city.

Yesterday the plane's flight crew spoke in public for the first time of their ordeal.

Captain Nabi told reporters how the kidnappers had brandished a pistol in his face. 'I just said, "We will follow whatever you command",' he remembered.

Nabi said the worst moment came when the plane landed at Stansted to be surrounded by security personnel. 'The hijackers were very nervous, and were shouting that they would blow us up,' he said. The crew had no plan to escape at first, but later fled the plane so that the hijackers would be stranded and forced to surrender.

The debate is now over what is to be done with the 164 Afghans who arrived last Sunday. Twenty-two people have been arrested and are being kept in the cells of various Essex police stations. They are likely to be charged tomorrow at local magistrates' courts, and taken on to be concentrated at Belmarsh high security prison in south-east London.

Thirty-seven others are being taken to the RAF base at Brize Norton, in Oxfordshire, from where a specially-chartered Kampuchean Airlines TriStar will take them back to Kandahar, a city in southern Afghanistan which is a 30-hour, 300 mile drive from the capital, Kabul. Thirty of the former hostages seemed undecided about what to do. Several were still being interviewed by police yesterday.

The fate of the asylum seekers depends on whether they can convince the Government that returning them to Afghanistan will mean their deaths, torture, imprisonment or harassment.

With the hijackers, the case is clear. The Taliban said last Friday that they will be tried according to Islamic law and executed if found guilty. The sentence would almost certainly be carried out in the Kabul football stadium with a machine gun after the weekly Friday prayers.

But the fate of the ordinary passengers, who it appears had no part in the hijack, is less easy to determine.

The Observer has obtained the plane's passenger list, and sources in Afghanistan and among the official interpreters at Stansted confirm that many of the names are those of relatively wealthy, middle-class Kabul residents. At least one is a medicines trader, others are low-level government officials. All were themselves rich enough, in Afghan terms, to afford the £12.50 fare (five months' pay for a teacher) for the flight to Mazar-E-Sharif. The hijackers too, sources say, are educated and from good backgrounds.

However, it is unlikely that, if they were sent home, the hostages would suffer at the hands of the Taliban. They would not, as some activists have claimed, be seen as 'enemies of Islam'. The Taliban are sensitive to world opinion.

Afghanistan has received little attention in recent years. One Afghan interpreter at Stansted reiterated a complaint often heard in his homeland. 'We had our country ruined in the war against the Soviets but when the Cold War was over, the West just let us drop,' he said. 'We have received nothing to help us get back on our feet.'

As they emerged from the hotel yesterday, the hostages all looked up at the sky. After a week of uncertainty and gruelling incarceration it was perhaps not surprising that - with its cold, blue clarity - it looked a little like the limitless expanses that arc over the deserts and mountains, battered cities, mine-strewn fields and deep, blue lakes of their distant homeland.

webTitle: Dome boss ordered to slash prices

fields.headline: Dome boss ordered to slash prices
fields.standfirst: Uninspired Money and Faith zones set to be redesignedThe millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Ticket prices at the Millennium Dome must be slashed and the Money and Faith zones redesigned to help the beleaguered attraction break even, ministers will this week tell Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, its new boss.
fields.byline: John Arlidge, Patrick Wintour and Vanessa Thorpe
fields.body:
Ticket prices at the Millennium Dome must be slashed and the Money and Faith zones redesigned to help the beleaguered attraction break even, ministers will this week tell Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, its new boss.

As the political embarrassment over the Dome flop grows, Downing Street is stepping in to ensure that Gerbeau makes swift and radical changes to boost visitor numbers. The move is backed by sponsors who sacked Jennie Page, Gerbeau's predecessor last week.

Ministers want mid-week ticket prices slashed. One source said: 'One way of giv ing the thing new appeal is by cutting the ticket price - not necessarily at the weekends when things seem to be going OK but certainly during the week.'

A day at the Dome costs £20 for adults, £16.50 for children and £57 for a family ticket. Critics point out that a family day out can cost more than £100 with travel, food, drink and souvenirs.

Dome sources say children's tickets could be cut to £9.99 and adults' tickets to £14.99, from 1 May when the crucial summer season begins. Dome chiefs are pinning their hopes on a sharp increase in visitor numbers.

When he started work last Monday Gerbeau announced a review of ticketing, man agement and the operation of all the zones and attractions. Although he hinted he did not want to cut admission charges because of lost revenue, a Dome spokesman said: 'The chief executive will be reviewing all the marketing strategies. His job is to turn this into a success over the next 11 months, to deliver on the business targets. If that requires a different approach to marketing, he will obviously do what needs to be done. If that means changing the structure of ticket prices, I am sure he'll do it.'

Reducing ticket prices was one of the main elements in the strategy to revive the fortunes of Disneyland Paris during Gerbeau's time there.

Ministers also say that the Money and Faith zones, which have been dismissed as 'uninspired and dull', should be 'jazzed up'. Dome sources say new 'bells and whistle' will be added but one insider said: 'We will do what we can but, let's face it, they were never going to be the star attractions.'

Senior staff working at what they now refer to bleakly as 'Doomworld' say that as well as the Faith and Money zones, the biggest changes will take place in the 'dead spaces' between the zones which Dome bosses acknowledge are 'scrappy'. The biggest dead zone of all is the centre of the Dome, which is completely empty when the Millennium Show is not in full swing.

Gerbeau and the director of the show, Mark Fisher, are to work together to bring more life to this vast auditorium. Street theatre, gymnastics and music are planned.

The team working on the show believe the PR message about the Dome became so blurred that expectations were impossible to match. 'The ticket sales were not the real problem,' said Fisher. 'What the Dome needs is a new lease of confidence. Most people with a shrewd understanding of the entertain ment business would say that our sales were actually pretty good for January. It was never about that.'

Ministers are encouraged by the decision to reduce the number of visitors needed to break even from 12 million to 10 million.

They have also expressed satisfaction at a new valuation which suggests that the sale of Richard Rogers' building will net at least £30m - more than twice the original estimate. Gerbeau has already staring hiring new advisers. On Friday the corporate affairs expert Nigel Whittaker was brought in. Whittaker, a regular broadcaster on BBC Radio 4, is a lawyer by training and the former Group Corporate Affairs Director for Kingfisher plc which he co-founded in 1982.

Gerbeau has already staring hiring new advisers. On Friday the corporate affairs expert Nigel Whittaker was brought in. Whittaker, a regular broadcaster on BBC Radio 4, is a lawyer by training and the former Group Corporate Affairs Director for Kingfisher plc which he co-founded in 1982.

webTitle: How clever of Alastair to kills two birds with one stone

fields.headline: How clever of Alastair to kills two birds with one stone
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: I find myself absurdly fascinated by this bizarre hijacking. It's not just the intrinsic news value: I find myself mesmerised by precisely what the first-ever conversation between the Taliban and Essex Police was actually  like ('Problem is, mate, we've got this new guv'nor, bloody woman, no pleasing her today, probably her time of the month or something. You what?    Well, that's a  bit drastic, mate, but yeah, I mean, along those lines, yeah!').
fields.body:
Monday: I find myself absurdly fascinated by this bizarre hijacking. It's not just the intrinsic news value: I find myself mesmerised by precisely what the first-ever conversation between the Taliban and Essex Police was actually like ('Problem is, mate, we've got this new guv'nor, bloody woman, no pleasing her today, probably her time of the month or something. You what? Well, that's a bit drastic, mate, but yeah, I mean, along those lines, yeah!').

Anyway, they've decided not to go with Alastair's proposed solution: that we pretend to refuel the plane but give it just enough juice to get into the air for three minutes before plunging directly onto the Dome and solving all our problems. Besides, the Greenwich problem seems to be being sorted at last. Although it's a bit of a shame I suppose that the EuroDisney bloke, who Falconer swore was the finest troubleshooter known to mankind, turns out to have spent two weeks there in 1997 as a stand-in while Pluto was being treated for trench foot.

And I do think, in the interests of harmonious relations, it would be a good idea for Al to stop referring to him as 'the man from Mauschwitz'.

Tuesday: This is getting absurd. I mean, who in this country, apart from the Mail, can seriously believe that this hijack was pulled off by cynical asylum-seekers; and who in their right mind would want to send them straight back to face certain death?

Wednesday: Sorry, I forgot about Jack.

Tony's eye not on that ball as much as it should be, I have to admit; he's more worried by the hostage situation in Wales. They're offering to give us Alun Michael back, but the terms seem to be confusing. They've asked 'the right to elect someone with backbone and principles'. Millbank translators hard at work, but struggling.

Thursday: It's over. Michael is back in the fold, and Tony has bravely, wisely, astutely and courageously welcomed him like a long-lost brother, promising him there will always be a place in Cabinet for loyal supporters called Alan. Except ones who can't spell their first names. And who embarrass him by being crap and getting found out.

Ireland situation increasingly worrying. Gerry Adams arrived to make a serious, honourable, personal pledge that decommissioning would happen, which almost swayed Peter and Tony. But I think it might have been more impressive had he not signed it with a pen marked 'Invisible Ink', and written it on rice-paper, and swallowed it immediately afterwards.

Friday: What a fate. I can hardly bear to think about it. This is cruel, vicious, unthinking, even for Jack. It turns out some of the hostages are going to be deported after all. To Wales.

fields.headline: Non-accidental attacks of Internet anarchists
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The 'denial of service' attack which brought Yahoo! to its knees last week prompted much editorial spluttering about the dangers of so-called hacking and e-terrorism. 'The fact that Yahoo! was taken down means,' said one alleged security expert, 'that nobody is really safe'. (Yahoo! is one of the biggest sites on the Web in terms of the number of virtual visitors it attracts every day.)
fields.body:
The 'denial of service' attack which brought Yahoo! to its knees last week prompted much editorial spluttering about the dangers of so-called hacking and e-terrorism. 'The fact that Yahoo! was taken down means,' said one alleged security expert, 'that nobody is really safe'. (Yahoo! is one of the biggest sites on the Web in terms of the number of virtual visitors it attracts every day.)

Denial-of-service attacks attempt to overwhelm a server by flooding it with timewasting requests. Up to now they have been easy to detect and relatively simple to counter. But what made last week's attacks problematic was that the deluge of requests came not from a single source, but from about five sites around the Net. It was reported that at one point, the Yahoo! servers were trying to deal with bogus traffic reaching a thousand megabytes a second.

The threat of such 'distributed coordinated attacks' has been well known and widely discussed for months, so it was only a matter of time before someone got their act together. The day after Yahoo! was hit, four other prominent sites were struck. The trouble is, the only way an e-commerce site can be completely safe is if it shuts down and disconnects from the Net, which rather undermines the case for getting into e-commerce in the first place.

Then again, if lossmakers such as Amazon went off-line for a while, think of all the money they would save! Maybe that will be the next twist in the dot.com spiral - companies shutting down their sites and seeing their share prices go even further through the roof.

What the humiliation of Yahoo! demonstrates (not to mention the rout of , whose share price has plummeted since its misguided attack on a group of Internet activists) is that the online community can be a fearsome opponent. The corporate suits and entrepreneurs who see cyberspace as the next Klondyke overlook this at their peril. The suits come from a culture where those with the most expensive lawyers and the deepest pockets tend to come out on top.

But this doesn't hold on the Net, where the collective IQ of the programming community far exceeds anything the corporate world can muster. Most so-called 'hackers' are not much enamoured of the gold-rush mentality which is currently running riot in Wall Street and the City. Au contraire: many of them rather like the idea of the Internet as a meritocratic commons - what writer Richard Barbrook memorably called 'a high-tech gift culture' - rather than a capitalist jungle.

So whenever the corporate world starts throwing its weight about on their patch, it can expect the same kind of trouble as brought Yahoo! down last Monday.

 A business asks me whether he should be worried about the Net. I reply that unless he is an undertaker the answer is yes.

As if to underscore the point, the Ford Motor Company has announced that anyone wishing to do business with it in future will have to do it via the Web. Daimler-Chrysler is following suit, and you don't have to be a rocket scientist to understand why. It costs these companies something like $65 to process a paper-based transaction, but they have to pay less than $5 for the online equivalent.

Now the message has crossed the Atlantic. Shell Services International, for example, is putting all its procurement online. And National Power, having discovered that it was costing £75 to purchase £50 of stationery, is now buying online at an average cost per transaction of less than £10.

The time is rapidly approaching when the most fervid Internet evangelist in a company will be the purchasing manager.

 john.naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: The racism that belittles Britain
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Blair government dismissed the Austrian neo-fascist Jörg Haider's claim that his own political programme and attitudes closely matched those of New Labour. But Mr Haider will have noted the British attitude towards more than 70 Afghan asylum seekers on the hijacked plane at Stansted airport. The immediate assumption, shared only in the Right-of-Centre press but implicitly by the BBC, was that the affair was an elaborate deception aimed at securing illegal immigration into Britain.
fields.body:
The Blair government dismissed the Austrian neo-fascist Jörg Haider's claim that his own political programme and attitudes closely matched those of New Labour. But Mr Haider will have noted the British attitude towards more than 70 Afghan asylum seekers on the hijacked plane at Stansted airport. The immediate assumption, shared only in the Right-of-Centre press but implicitly by the BBC, was that the affair was an elaborate deception aimed at securing illegal immigration into Britain.

The widespread view is that Britain is a soft target for asylum seekers. The truth is different. Britain has so tightened up its asylum rules that the country is effectively impenetrable, with among the lowest rates of asylum seekers in the West. The level of financial support is minuscule and the welfare state is so inadequate it hardly offers protection for native Britons, let alone asylum seekers. Worse, there is an inbuilt racism in our system, so that even those few asylum seekers who clear the obstacles to entry find that winning work is almost impossible. Qualified scientists and teachers tagged with the odium of being asylum seekers find British employers will simply not hire them. The Government connives in this quiet and unreported racism.

People need to be desperate to leave the country of their birth; most asylum-seekers are bona-fide applicants fleeing from oppression. Democracy and the rule of law are frail plants beyond the West; globalisation, intensifying the gap between rich and poor, is making weak political regimes in less developed countries readier to resort to oppression and torture to stay in power. Unless the world order changes the flow of genuine asylum seekers will grow and their desperation will make them resort to any means to save their lives.

Already essential British liberties and standards of legal and natural justice have been compromised by our response to this phenomenon. We need to close down the supply lines of asylum seekers by pressing for reform of the way the global system operates, insisting that every country adheres to the UN Declaration of Human Rights and backing it with a genuine ethical foreign policy.

We need a commonly agreed international system so that every country in the West has the same rules and the burden of sharing asylum seekers is equitably shared. And when they enter, we need to ensure that natural justice is applied. That their claim is genuine unless proved otherwise, and, if accepted, that they have every right to be treated as properly as we would if the same tragedy befell us. The implicit racism expressed last week from the floor of the Commons to the Nine 0'Clock News disgraced and belittled us all.

webTitle: Chechens trapped in the factory of death

fields.headline: Chechens trapped in the factory of death
fields.standfirst:
Crisis in Chechnya: special report

Russia holds hundreds in the hunt for rebels
fields.trailText: It is an ugly name for an ugly place. Outside Chernokozovo 'filtration camp' relatives wait for news of their menfolk. Inside, according to human rights groups, Russian soldiers are beating, raping and torturing Chechen prisoners.
fields.body:
It is an ugly name for an ugly place. Outside Chernokozovo 'filtration camp' relatives wait for news of their menfolk. Inside, according to human rights groups, Russian soldiers are beating, raping and torturing Chechen prisoners.

Chernokozovo, with about 700 detainees, is the largest of four camps in which the Russians are 'separating' terrorists from civilians. Many of the men have been summarily arrested on the flimsiest of pretexts.

The camp, a former Soviet factory 30 miles north of Grozny, has been thrown together from red brick and barbed wire. The factory's tall water coolers have been converted into watchtowers; high walls make it impossible to see what is happening inside.

News from behind the huge sliding doors is scarce. Relatives of those detained wait in the nearby market place for scraps of informa tion brought out by locals employed in the prison.

Magomadovo Umarovna was yesterday waiting by the gate holding five garlic heads which she hoped to be able to pass to her detained son, Adlan Basayev. The orderly who serves food to the inmates had managed to smuggle out a note from him, begging her to send some kind of medicine to protect against tuberculosis.

In detention since 13 January, her son's only crime was to have the same surname as the Chechen warlord Shamil Basayev. 'They checked his papers and decided he must be a relative. Why should he suffer because of his surname? None of us have ever even set eyes on Basayev. The system is very cruel,' she said.

'He wrote that there was a TB epidemic inside. I can't get the right tablets to send him. I hope the garlic may help.' His note had given few details of life within the camp. 'They're scared to write much, in case the letter goes astray. But I know things are bad for him there. Someone who was recently freed told me my son's nose was broken when he was beaten in the toilets.'

This is the detention centre where Russian war correspondent Andrei Babitsky - arrested for reporting from Grozny without military permission - was allegedly held by the Russian security services, before being handed over to Chechen fighters last week in a prisoner swap. He is thought to have been badly treated during his stay. On Friday a funeral was held in Chernokozovo for another inmate who died after being beaten. 'Sometimes at night people living near the prison say they can hear the noise of people being tortured,' Umarovna said.

Last week a letter detailing the brutality of the camp regime, apparently written by a Russian soldier there, was leaked to the media. He described how Chechen inmates were being systematically beaten, raped and killed. He said that Babitsky 'was beaten so badly that his glasses were flung in the air, poor guy'. The soldier expressed his sense of guilt at his participation in the brutality.

Human rights organisations have also expressed concern at the conditions within these centres, set up with the aim of filtering out fighters from civilians. There is evidence that large numbers of young Chechen men are being rounded up arbitrarily and detained.

Peter Bouckaert, Human Rights Watch's representative in the region, said: 'These men are being taken to unknown detention facilities and their families are not being informed of where they are. Some men are never heard of again. Given the massive abuses that took place in these centres during the last war, we are gravely concerned about this developing trend.'

Explaining the scale of what the Russians insist on calling a 'cleansing operation', he said he had evidence that 120 men had been arrested en masse in Shami-Yurt, near Grozny, earlier this month. Fighters and civilians are arrested together, but there is no information to explain if and how the Russian military sets about distinguishing between the two categories. No international monitoring organisation has been permitted to visit any of the four main camps.

The camps became notorious during Russia's last war with Chechnya, when many Chechen men died during their detention and many more died shortly after their release. Then human rights activists gathered horrific stories of torture - with former inmates describing being held in airless cells, or in dark mud pits dug out from the ground, often knee-deep in water. Many said they had been the victims of both psychological and physical torture.

In Grozny, the war goes on. And not all of the city's residents are entirely hostile to the Russian forces. Some of Grozny's residents say they are grateful to the Russian soldiers for their drive to clear the city of fighters. Standing outside the blackened remains of the grandiose entrance to Grozny's main park (still named the Park of Culture and Rest in the name of Lenin), Pyotr Sidorov, 64, a Russian who has lived in Chechnya for most of his life, said he approved of the campaign.

Behind him as he walked to collect a bucket of water for his family, a panorama of total destruction was visible. Not a single building in Grozny remains intact. 'The Russians were right to do this. We need to fight to put a sensible government in power here,' he said.

webTitle: Caught between Jack Straw and a hard place

fields.headline: Caught between Jack Straw and a hard place
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: How does a Home Secretary convince the public that he is the real figure of substance and his Opposition counterpart merely the shadow? The answer was clear last week, as passengers on- board the hijacked Ariana Boeing from Afghanistan began claiming asylum at Stansted.
fields.body:
How does a Home Secretary convince the public that he is the real figure of substance and his Opposition counterpart merely the shadow? The answer was clear last week, as passengers on- board the hijacked Ariana Boeing from Afghanistan began claiming asylum at Stansted.

For Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe, it was the signal for war - not a clash of principle, but an unseemly tussle to occupy the moral low ground on the right of asylum in Britain. In the process, it has grown hard to tell them apart. On asylum issues, there is now one monstrous, hybrid Minister of the Interior, inveighing against all claimants and contenders.

Hijacking, too, is a monstrosity. Nobody doubts it. And according to the Daily Mail , so are asylum seekers. When the people freed from a hijacked plane start lodging asylum claims, the very notion of asylum is dragged into disrepute. Yet as our new, double-headed Minister of the Interior knows, under the UN Convention on refugees, to which Britain is signed up, they are entitled to make those claims. Each case will now have to be judged on its merits.

It is anyone's guess how many passengers on the plane hoped to snatch some tenuous advantage from misfortune, and how many may have been complicit in the hijack. The tabloids, of course, have been full of conjecture. And the muddier the conjecture, the better it sticks, especially to asylum seekers.

We do know, however, what the Taliban is and how it came into the ascendant, as Western cold-war imperatives paved the way for religious intolerance in Afghanistan during the 1980s. Afghans are living with the results. There is a debt here, on which Britain would happily default. Our cold-war allies have done better. In the last few years, thanks to the lobbying efforts of American feminists, there has been a sharp rise in the number of Afghan women granted asylum in the US.

Whatever the fate of the passengers, 'asylum hijacks' have a promising future, for the simple reason that asylum seekers now have almost no lawful means of entry into Britain. As soon as a country starts generating refugees, a visa regime is imposed: Sri Lanka in the 1980s; Algeria, Sierra Leone and Colombia in the 1990s. The UK now requires visas from 108 countries. Applying at an embassy for sanctuary abroad is a loser's game.

Fifteen years ago, airlines were a neutral force for refugees running a gaunt let of hostility. But Britain now imposes heavy fines on companies carrying passengers without proper documentation. The carriers have become dutiful enforcers of political priorities - low immigration targets, above all - which are at odds with Britain's obligations as a signatory to the UN Convention.

Meanwhile, UN resettlement schemes have dwindled to nothing. In the 1970s, the UN found places in the wealthy democracies for roughly one in four of the world's refugees. Today, the figure is more like one in 500. As the number of refugees has increased, governments in the West have simply got cold feet.

For people in fear of their lives, in their own country or one door down - and Pakistan is a dangerous place for exiles from neighbouring Afghanistan - the best shot at a safe haven in the West is breaking and entering.

Hijacking is an outrageous route to asylum, but the higher the fortifications Western Europe builds against intruders, the more extravagant their means of getting here will become. This is true not only of asylum seekers but of other disadvantaged people - so-called 'economic migrants' from poorer states in the former Eastern bloc and the developing world.

Most people agree that the points of entry to their countries should be carefully patrolled. It is not consensus within states that matters, however, so much as consensus across them. The members of a wealthy nation may respect its borders, yet if enough people beyond those borders see them only as a barrier to safety or prosperity, then they are no longer a matter of consensus but a matter of dispute.

The answer was clear last week, as passengers on- board the hijacked Ariana Boeing from Afghanistan began claiming asylum at Stansted. In the process, it has grown hard to tell them apart. On asylum issues, there is now one monstrous, hybrid Minister of the Interior, inveighing against all claimants and contenders. Hijacking, too, is a monstrosity. Nobody doubts it. And according to the Daily Mail , so are asylum seekers. When the people freed from a hijacked plane start lodging asylum claims, the very notion of asylum is dragged into disrepute. Yet as our new, double-headed Minister of the Interior knows, under the UN Convention on refugees, to which Britain is signed up, they are entitled to make those claims. Each case will now have to be judged on its merits. It is anyone's guess how many passengers on the plane hoped to snatch some tenuous advantage from misfortune, and how many may have been complicit in the hijack. webTitle: The slow death of Abbey Life

fields.headline: The slow death of Abbey Life
fields.trailText: A million and half holders of Abbey Life insurance policies, pensions and other investments will soon get letters telling them their £11 billion fund has been closed to new business. They join a growing number of savers whose polices are in financial limbo.
fields.body:
A million and half holders of Abbey Life insurance policies, pensions and other investments will soon get letters telling them their £11 billion fund has been closed to new business. They join a growing number of savers whose polices are in financial limbo.

Abbey Life will carry on taking premiums and paying out on death or retirement, but it will not accept new customers. Its fund will live only as long as the last policyholder - which could be as long as 60 years. Then it will be quietly put to sleep.

The Abbey Life fund is being closed following the acquisition of the mutual insurer Scottish Widows by Abbey's parent, Lloyds TSB. The bank wants to concentrate on selling through its branches and independent advisers, and no longer wants Abbey's army of salesmen. Instead of selling the whole business, it is selling the salesforce to Allied Dunbar and keeping the customers in its closed fund.

Other firms have closed all or part of their funds for different reasons. Some have given up writing with-profits business (where policyholders take a share of the growth in the fund); some have decided the costs of getting new business are too high; some were too financially stretched to survive.

As competition increases, more and more firms could close their funds. But what does it all mean to policy holders?

The answer will vary depending on the type of policies issued by the fund that is closing, the method of closure and the way it will be run in future. In Abbey Life's case, the impact will be minimal.

The two main concerns when a fund closes are costs and performance. The costs of running the fund may well fall initially, as it saves the expense of getting new business. As it reduces in size, however, the costs become proportionately larger: the price of managing 100,000 policies is not that much smaller than the costs of running 10,000. That can hit those whose policies have a long time to run.

Investment managers can lose their incentive to per form when their fund is closed and they no longer need a good record to attract new business. A number of specialist firms, such as Century Life and Windsor Life, have emerged to acquire closed funds and, by pooling investment and administration, keep costs down and performance up.

But Abbey Life should not suffer from either drawback. Almost all its policies were unit-linked so, unlike with-profits funds, the charges are fixed.

Any increase above their set level has to be met by Lloyds TSB shareholders rather than by policyholders, although they will also bene fit from any reduced costs initially.

Investment performance, will be protected by the fact that the management will be taken over by Scottish Widows, which will be competing for new business. It would not want its reputation dented by a slip in the performance of Abbey Life.

webTitle: Israel vows to blitz all of Lebanon

fields.headline: Israel vows to blitz all of Lebanon
fields.standfirst:
Israel and the Middle East: special report

Barak threatens 'pain' over Hizbollah raids and the Middle East peace process is at risk
fields.trailText: The future of the resumed Middle East peace process hung by a thread this weekend after Israel, the regional superpower humiliated in Israeli-occupied south Lebanon by just a few hundred guerrillas, promised 'very painful' reprisals against the whole of Syrian-controlled Lebanon.
fields.body:
The future of the resumed Middle East peace process hung by a thread this weekend after Israel, the regional superpower humiliated in Israeli-occupied south Lebanon by just a few hundred guerrillas, promised 'very painful' reprisals against the whole of Syrian-controlled Lebanon.

The possibility of the 30,000 Syrian troops stationed in Lebanon being drawn into the conflict in the absence of a settlement grew after both Israel and the United States accused Syria of failing to restrain the Hizbollah fighters who have killed seven Israeli soldiers in south Lebanon in 18 days.

As Hizbollah ordered an alert in the southern suburbs of the capital, Beirut, in anticipation of an Israeli strike, the Lebanese Prime Minister, Selim Hoss, called on Washington to 'prevent' Israel from attacking civilian targets. His appeal followed a night of air raids last week that targeted power plants in northern, eastern and central Lebanon. The attacks wounded 17 civilians, caused damage estimated at $50 million and plunged much of the country into darkness.

Human rights monitors said Israel's reprisals, a tacit admission of its inability to defeat Hizbollah on the battlefield, violated the Geneva Convention's ban on collective penalties.

But the Israeli government, struggling to fulfil an election pledge to extricate its army from south Lebanon within five months, accused Hizbollah last week of violating the separate, so-called April Understanding - the American-brokered rules of war agreed to protect civilian life in the wake of an Israeli shelling that killed 105 Lebanese villagers in a United Nations shelter almost four years ago. The Israelis made it clear that they now consider the understanding a dead letter.

Emboldened by Washington's refusal to criticise the blitz against Lebanon's national grid, and by its insistence on blaming Hizbollah alone for the growing crisis, Israeli officials said future attacks on their army of occupation would pave the way for new attacks on Lebanon's civilian infrastructure.

The Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, said on Friday: 'We shall respond when and how we want with very painful strikes against Lebanese territory.'

Barak was speaking after the Israeli delegation had walked out of an emergency meeting of the group monitoring the April Understanding - seen by many as the last hope of containing the violence.

Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy had warned earlier that 'the soil of Lebanon will burn' if Hizbollah fired across the border.

Under the understanding, Israel and Hizbollah are permitted to attack each other's forces inside south Lebanon but may not target civilians or fire across the border. Israel claims Hizbollah has violated the agreement by launching attacks from Lebanese villages.

Hizbollah insists it is honouring the understanding. It says only Israel is causing civilian casualties; that not a single civilian has been harmed in the attacks in which its own fighters have killed six members of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia this year in addition to the seven members of the Israeli forces.

Concern about Israel's intentions in Lebanon grew after its delegation failed to join the representatives of the United States, France, Syria and Lebanon meeting in the southern town of Naqoura on Friday to try to save the agreement. Israel claimed it withdrew after Hizbollah killed another soldier just inside Israel's 'security zone'. Other delegates said the boycott was planned all along.

Hopes of saving Lebanon from another round of bloodshed far greater than the last now hang on a resumption of the Israeli-Syrian peace talks that began again in December after a four-year hiatus. The talks, in Shepherdstown, Virginia, were suspended on 3 January after a leaked document showed that Israel was planning not a 'withdrawal' from the occupied Golan Heights - Syria's price for peace in south Lebanon - but a 'redeployment' that could leave 17,000 Israelis settled on Syrian soil.

Unable to defeat Hizbollah militarily or diplomatically, Barak now seems set on blasting his way out of south Lebanon if he cannot leave by agreement with Syria.

As Israeli jets carried out a 'routine' bombing, Sabah Safieddine angrily gestured to her daughter's bed in their home in the port of Tyre, badly damaged by Israeli rockets last Tuesday.

Six-year-old Nahla would have been badly wounded had she not been out when the rockets pierced it with thick spears of glass, said her mother. 'Israel shoots at children. Hizbollah only shoots at soldiers. This is our land. Israel will never leave of its own accord. We have to punch them out.'
