webTitle: Selling New Labour to the highest bidder

fields.headline: Selling New Labour to the highest bidder
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Articles or political speeches on the general doltishness of the British start so often with one of two lazy introductions that many of us believe there must be some diktat in the unwritten constitution which prohibits fresh thought.
fields.body:
Articles or political speeches on the general doltishness of the British start so often with one of two lazy introductions that many of us believe there must be some diktat in the unwritten constitution which prohibits fresh thought.

If the writer fancies himself to be an intellectual, they begin: 'This is the only country in the world where "clever" and/or "academic" is an insult' (the Guardian/Observer/Independent); if he does not, they try the alternative: 'Petty academics and so-called intellectuals haven't a clue about what real people really think about the real world' (the Star/Sunday Sport/Chris Woodhead).

You glimpse the muddle that passes for the mind of David Blunkett, Her Majesty's Secretary of State for Education and Employment, when you read that he simultaneously articulated the contradictory prejudices of the senior common room and the golf club in a single sinister address to the Economic & Social Research Council earlier this month.

Blunkett's rant started in the traditional high-brow style - 'there is a seam of anti-intellectualism running through Government which has served to alienate academia'. But within seconds he abandoned the reading room for the nineteenth hole and grabbed a large G and T to wave at the audience. The universities were to blame for Ministerial contempt, he continued. They were not addressing issues which were 'relevant' to politicians. 'Perverse' researchers 'driven by ideology' failed to take into account the 'reality of many people's lives'. Wary commentators detected the faint, ripe whiff of the banana republic. It is not the business of a politician in a free society to order researchers, or anyone else for that matter, to think what the state wants them to think and deride as 'ideological' those who find uncomfortable facts, just because they can't quite see the splendour of the Third Way. Blunkett was duly condemned in the Times Higher Education Supplement.

What was striking was that his audience, who might have been expected to be unsettled by Blunkett's bullying, did not join its defence of intellectual freedom. The Council is the largest single patron of social science research in the country and dispensed £67.5 million of public money last year. A spokeswoman said her academics and bureaucrats were delighted with Blunkett's address and agreed absolutely with his demand for news he could use from the universities.

The caricature of the bearded don or Monsoon-dressed lecturer, suspicious of power, and jealous of their independence, which still seems to infuriate Blunkett, does not appear to have much connection to a 'real world' in which business sponsorship and, well, ideology permeate every cranny of the public sector.

Take a report on the supermarket cartel sponsored by the council and puffed in its journal as one of its intellectual high points of 1999. Dr Mark Harvey of Manchester University had concluded that British supermarkets offer 'choice, quality and convenience', the council said, and it was simplistic to accuse them of overcharging. Would it have made a difference to civil servants and journalists who consumed its findings if the following declaration had been added? 'We acknowledge that Keith Brandon, Chief Executive Officer of Tesco, is a member of our governing body. Our "Eating Food and Health Link Management Committee" has found seats for representatives of Nestlé, Sainsbury's and Kellogg. Indeed, the food industry has a loud voice in our senior appointments. Lord Sainsbury, the unelected Minister for Science, who is working hard to undermine the public's rejection of GM food, appointed our latest council members. Both came from big business, since you ask.'

The council spokeswoman seemed to regard me as a madman for raising the question. I was not, I assured her, suggesting that Dr Harvey had altered his findings to suit fat cats. (They are far more critical than the press coverage and the council's journal suggested. He told me he was 'astonished by the positive spin' put on his work.) She assured me in turn that rigorous peer review maintained the highest standards and was shocked when I said Labour MPs had noticed that the council seemed to be remarkably close to the big corporations and were threatening to raise the matter in Parliament. The danger they see was exemplified by her baffled response. It is not that this or that piece of research is biased. But that public and the business interests have become so mixed up that few in authority can see there could ever be a conflict. Harvey himself warns that colleagues who are hard on supermarkets risk seeing grants from industry disappear.

The academe is not an isolated case. Tesco has more representatives on Government task forces than any other company and its logo is all over the dismal Dome. New Labour hired the management consultants McKinsey - the finishing school of William Hague and the Asda boss, Archie Norman - to investigate regulation. Far from condemning a planning system that allows supermarkets to appeal when an application for an out-of-town store is rejected, but offers no similar rights to local protesters when it is accepted, the management consultants said the rules were too harsh and must be relaxed. Yesterday, the Department of Trade and Industry released the results of an investigation that largely cleared supermarkets of charges of price-fixing.

Its report will be read with surprise in Alnwick . By 1993, the Northumberland town was fed up with the quasi-monopoly position Safeways enjoyed and believed itself to be the victim of profiteering. The Duke of Northumberland offered to help. The council agreed to give him planning permission for a superstore on the edge of town. Everyone expected a competitor to open on the site. But the aristocracy did not get where it is by being paternalistic, and His Grace promised his land to Safeways and put it in a position to close its town-centre store and knock out small shopkeepers who relied on passing trade. John Prescott, quite rightly, refused to let building go ahead. Safeways sued the council. Last week the tiny local authority's insurers reached a settlement with the conglomerate and the Duke and agreed to hand over £2.6m compensation. This atrocious deal was hailed as a bargain for Alnwick, and the Duke was praised for his generosity. The council might have had to pay £4.6m if he had not graciously moderated his demands.

I would have thought that a system which allows corporations to dominate small towns and then receive lavish recompense on the rare occasions when they cannot get their own way was worthy of the most piercing academic investigation. But, doubtless, I'm a 'perverse' leftie hack, 'driven by ideology' and as clueless as the citizens of Alnwick about life in the real world.

If at first you don't succeed, rig and rig again

This notebook, as regular readers know, is one of the last homes of restrained journalism. It is not for me to let out an enormous, rib-shuddering roar at the life-affirming, hope-reviving victory of Rhodri Morgan over Tony Blair and his poll- riggers (although my colleagues did accuse me of doing a convincing impersonation of Meg Ryan in When Harry Met Sally as the news came through).

Because Wales is all but ignored by the 'national' media, it took last week's crisis to bring home a simple message: Blairism is inherently unstable. Its control-freakery is not the result of over-rigorous toilet training, but a political tactic to ensure that New Labour can carry on where the Conservatives left off.

To do this, candidates must be imposed and ballots stuffed to ensure their victory. Manipulation seems to work at first. Alun Michael, Blair's robotic favourite, lost every poll of party members and trade unionists, but still beat Morgan in the loaded competition. It is still possible that Frank Dobson will win the Labour nomination for the London mayor on the same basis.

So what? snarl the intellectual policemen of the Third Way. Red Ken's dangerous, Morgan's 'silly'; Dobson and Michael may be boring, but they will win support by pragmatically seeing through the necessary business of devolved government.

Wales has proved, and I suspect London will prove, that on its own realist terms their argument is a failure. Alleged modernisers can't grasp that in a modern democracy, a rigged election is an insult to everyone. The conservative-minded will happily vote for Livingstone. Morgan was being deluged with congratulatory e-mails last week from people of every persuasion.

Electors from the Right and Left sense that a government that denies a voice to its own supporters will do the same to them - and indeed is doing just that by removing the power of citizens to say whether their neighbours are innocent or guilty in jury rooms.

The first consequence is that support for New Labour collapses - in the Welsh Assembly elections after the imposition of Michael, Labour's vote fell in every seat. The second is that even if Labour manages to form a minority administration, as it did in Wales, it lacks all legitimacy because Blair doesn't allow his creations to get ideas above their station.

The realist case for Michael/ Dobson is that they will be able to negotiate a far better deal for Wales/ London than a popular outsider. Yet Michael fell because there was a pot of European Union money waiting to be spent in the poorest districts of his country and he couldn't persuade Gordon Brown to release it.

He was a messenger boy, not an equal, and his resignation shows that 'political realists' are the most credulous innocents you are likely to meet outside a kindergarten.

But the aristocracy did not get where it is by being paternalistic, and His Grace promised his land to Safeways and put it in a position to close its town-centre store and knock out small shopkeepers who relied on passing trade. John Prescott, quite rightly, refused to let building go ahead. Safeways sued the council. Last week the tiny local authority's insurers reached a settlement with the conglomerate and the Duke and agreed to hand over £2.6m compensation. This atrocious deal was hailed as a bargain for Alnwick, and the Duke was praised for his generosity. The council might have had to pay £4.6m if he had not graciously moderated his demands. I would have thought that a system which allows corporations to dominate small towns and then receive lavish recompense on the rare occasions when they cannot get their own way was worthy of the most piercing academic investigation. But, doubtless, I'm a 'perverse' leftie hack, 'driven by ideology' and as clueless as the citizens of Alnwick about life in the real world. If at first you don't succeed, rig and rig again This notebook, as regular readers know, is one of the last homes of restrained journalism. It is not for me to let out an enormous, rib-shuddering roar at the life-affirming, hope-reviving victory of Rhodri Morgan over Tony Blair and his poll- riggers (although my colleagues did accuse me of doing a convincing impersonation of Meg Ryan in When Harry Met Sally as the news came through). Because Wales is all but ignored by the 'national' media, it took last week's crisis to bring home a simple message: Blairism is inherently unstable. Its control-freakery is not the result of over-rigorous toilet training, but a political tactic to ensure that New Labour can carry on where the Conservatives left off. To do this, candidates must be imposed and ballots stuffed to ensure their victory. Manipulation seems to work at first. Alun Michael, Blair's robotic favourite, lost every poll of party members and trade unionists, but still beat Morgan in the loaded competition. It is still possible that Frank Dobson will win the Labour nomination for the London mayor on the same basis. So what? snarl the intellectual policemen of the Third Way. Red Ken's dangerous, Morgan's 'silly'; Dobson and Michael may be boring, but they will win support by pragmatically seeing through the necessary business of devolved government. Wales has proved, and I suspect London will prove, that on its own realist terms their argument is a failure. Alleged modernisers can't grasp that in a modern democracy, a rigged election is an insult to everyone. The conservative-minded will happily vote for Livingstone. Morgan was being deluged with congratulatory e-mails last week from people of every persuasion. Electors from the Right and Left sense that a government that denies a voice to its own supporters will do the same to them - and indeed is doing just that by removing the power of citizens to say whether their neighbours are innocent or guilty in jury rooms. The first consequence is that support for New Labour collapses - in the Welsh Assembly elections after the imposition of Michael, Labour's vote fell in every seat. The second is that even if Labour manages to form a minority administration, as it did in Wales, it lacks all legitimacy because Blair doesn't allow his creations to get ideas above their station. The realist case for Michael/ Dobson is that they will be able to negotiate a far better deal for Wales/ London than a popular outsider. Yet Michael fell because there was a pot of European Union money waiting to be spent in the poorest districts of his country and he couldn't persuade Gordon Brown to release it. He was a messenger boy, not an equal, and his resignation shows that 'political realists' are the most credulous innocents you are likely to meet outside a kindergarten.

webTitle: Scandal of playing fields that Labour didn't save

fields.headline: Scandal of playing fields that Labour didn't save
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: As pre-election pledges go, it was crystal clear. Tony Blair, the would-be Prime Minister, promised to stop the Tories' scandalous sale of playing fields. Labour's promise to protect our sporting heritage was unequivocal. 'We will end the policy of selling playing fields,' thundered its manifesto for sport.
fields.body:
As pre-election pledges go, it was crystal clear. Tony Blair, the would-be Prime Minister, promised to stop the Tories' scandalous sale of playing fields. Labour's promise to protect our sporting heritage was unequivocal. 'We will end the policy of selling playing fields,' thundered its manifesto for sport.

Three years on, scores of sports fields are still being sold for housing, car parks and supermarkets. Labour stands accused of breaking its promise - and fiddling the figures to cover up its failure.

Ministers boast they have 'virtually halted' the sale of playing fields through 'tough measures'. But an Observer investigation shows this is untrue and that the new measures have made little difference. Inquiries revealed that:

* Hundreds of playing fields have disappeared during Labour's time in office.

* More than 100 school playing fields have gone in the past 15 months alone.

* Pupils are being deprived of access to recreational facilities because schools are selling valuable sports sites to build new classrooms.

* Two Cabinet Ministers have been given special power to prevent sell-offs - but have saved just four playing fields from developers.

* Objections to proposed sales raised by the official watchdog for playing fields are being overruled.

* The Government is ignoring a growing clamour from bodies such as the Football Association and Rugby Football Union for sell-offs to be halted immediately.

* Ministers are hugely embarrassed by the continuing disappearance of recreational green spaces, but admit the sales raise hundreds of millions of pounds.

Criticism of the Government's performance is rising. The Central Council of Physical Recreation, which represents the governing bodies of sports such as football, cricket and tennis, condemns it as 'a disgrace'. 'We were led to believe they would stop the sale of playing fields - after all, that's what they said they would do in their manifesto - and they haven't,' says spokesman Nigel Hook.

The National Playing Fields Association is equally blunt. 'The Government's record is pretty abysmal,' claimed director Elsa Davies. 'I'm an ex-teacher, and if I was marking their performance on playing fields, I would give them just two out of ten.'

Since May 1997, Labour has introduced a number of measures which it claimed would make selling playing fields difficult. John Prescott, the Secretary of State for Environment, Transport and the Regions, and David Blunkett, his opposite number at Education and Employment, were handed new powers to veto 'unnecessary' sales.

Prescott can stop a sell-off if Sport England, formerly the English Sports Council, which by law has to be consulted about proposed sales in England, has objected to it but the local council has decided to approve it anyway. While 17 such cases have been referred to him since December 1998, he has 'called in' just one - later withdrawn - overruled the sports council's advice on 10 others and is 'still considering' another six.

In another change from the Tories' time in power, any school in England wanting to sell a playing field now has to first obtain Blunkett's permission and must satisfy 'tough, rigorous new criteria'. But in the 15 months to the end of 1999, Blunkett rejected just two of 103 proposals.

Critics agree Labour's stipulation that money raised from a sale now has to be ploughed back into sport or education is a step forward. But Davies points out that, while schools are no longer forced to dispose of playing fields, schools needing cash to build classrooms find this ring-fencing offers them incentive to do just that. In Croydon, for example, the local council intends to sell playing fields attached to Haling Manor School in order to pay for expanding the school.

One local Labour councillor claims that the plan could 'open the floodgates' to the disappearance of other school playing fields.

Unpublished figures collected by the sports council show that, in the past four months of 1999 alone, it was consulted about 236 proposed sell-offs.

Blunkett has decided to reconsider one of his previous rejections, the proposed construction of 96 houses on Foster's Field, a nine-acre playing field in the middle of the Dorset town of Sherborne.

'Dorset County Council propose to spend £1 million of the £4m they'll get from selling Foster's Field into replacement pitches a mile and a half away,' says local campaigner Douglas Hosking. 'But why should the last piece of green space in Sherborne be sold to benefit education elsewhere in Dorset? That should be paid for out of central government funds.'

An sports council document passed to The Observer predicts that, given pressure on land for house-building, sell-offs will continue. In some areas, it says, 'the needs of current and future generations for playing fields will never be met'.

The watchdog is frustrated that, although it can object to developments, it cannot actually thwart them.

webTitle: Bitter last hours of Blair loyalist

fields.headline: Bitter last hours of Blair loyalist
fields.standfirst:
Fallen First Secretary Alun Michael was hopeful of rescue by Liberal Democrats
Devolution in Wales: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Alun Michael is out walking the hills this weekend, contemplating his political future and perhaps privately regretting that he ever accepted Tony Blair's call to make Wales his political home.
fields.body:
Alun Michael is out walking the hills this weekend, contemplating his political future and perhaps privately regretting that he ever accepted Tony Blair's call to make Wales his political home.

There is a lot of sympathy for the fallen First Secretary, whose first political love always seemed to be Westminster. Having sacrificed a job as Home Office Minister after Ron Davies's 'moment of madness' on Clapham Common, Michael was seen as representing Westminster in Wales, not vice-versa.

By the end, he stood on a ledge of political support so narrow it took only a slight push to send him down. Yet he seemed blind to how precarious his situation was. Almost to the end, he thought he could survive, either by striking a pact with Welsh Liberal Democrat leader Mike German to avert the prospect of a 'no confidence' vote, or by whipping Labour assembly members into line so he could face down the assembly if the other three parties combined against him. Three setbacks in his final 36 hours of office finally destroyed him.

Strike one came when Labour assembly members came together for their normal monthly meeting on Tuesday morning. Chief whip Andrew Davies said the crisis in the assembly was growing. The situation was that a successful 'no confidence' vote would force Michael to resign, but leave his Cabinet in office for the few days it took Labour to reinstate Michael or choose a replacement.

But Davies warned that the opposition parties were planning to use what Rhodri Morgan called 'the Nagasaki after the Hiroshima' by stripping Cabinet of delegated powers. Moreover, assembly chairman Dafyd Elis Thomas was adamant Michael could come back once after a vote of 'no confidence' but if the assembly ousted him again, that would be the end. In effect, Michael was told that, if he clung on, he would provoke a crisis which would put Wales temporarily back under direct Westminster rule.

But Michael did not trust his chief whip to give disinterested advice. Davies had openly supported Morgan against him in the contest for the Labour leadership and he suspected Davies of manipulating the crisis to bring in the leader he wanted. A week earlier, Davies had been loudly berated in the assembly building by Michael's political adviser, Julie Crowley, for alleged disloyalty. Michael listened in silence - obviously believing Crowley was right.

Strike two came late that night. Michael presumed that his Liberal Democrat opposite number, Mike German, would be amenable to a deal which could avert the vote of 'no confidence' altogether. He was even prepared to offer the Liberal Democrats two seats in Cabinet, after opposing any coalition government.

His overtures had the powerful backing of Tony Blair, who rang the Liberal Democrat, Charles Kennedy, several times pleading for Michael's political life. His last call was on Tuesday evening. Kennedy replied that devolution implies that these crises must be sorted out locally, without London interference.

Still Michael did not give. For about three hours on Tuesday night, he waited in an upstairs room in the assembly with Welsh Secretary Paul Murphy and Rhodri Morgan, hoping German would drop in to talk. The door was open. There was a bottle of wine ready.

But downstairs the six-strong Liberal Democrat group were so hostile to a deal that they refused even to allow German to go upstairs to say goodnight. In an extraordinary snub, they sent German's adviser, Mike Hines, to tell Michael's adviser that there was no prospect of a deal. The embarrassed Hines found himself drawn into the room to meet the three most important politicians in Wales. 'I said, "the group's not talking - they're saying enough is enough". It was a bit hard to tell someone that that's the end,' Hines said.

Still Michael did not give. The next morning he came up with a strategy seemingly modelled on John Major. Facing a crisis in his own party in 1995, the Tory PM resigned, daring opponents to run a candidate against him. Michael decided that he, too, would resign, pre-empting the assembly's vote of no confidence. There would then have to be a new election of a First Secretary. Michael intended to run and, provided he had the backing of the 28 Labour assembly members, he was sure to win. He relayed his plans to Downing Street and was promised Blair's support.

Then the third and fatal strike. No sooner had he stepped down than support for Michael among Labour assembly members vanished. At 1.50pm, ten minutes before the assembly session was due to begin, he was told he could count on the support of only six out of 28 members of the Labour group. The six were Michael himself, group chairman Ann Jones, three whips who resigned in the wake of Michael's fall - Lorraine Barrett, Huw Lewis and Janice Gregory - and Lynn Negal, who is married to Lewis.

Completing Michael's humiliation, Dafyd Elis Thomas let the 'no confidence' vote go ahead. When the Welsh Cabinet decided later that day to nominate Rhodri Morgan as the acting First Secretary, the game was up. One Labour politician who played a prominent role in bringing Michael down said yesterday: 'His heart was always in Westminster. The tragedy is that he did his master's bidding. There is a great deal of sympathy for him.'

webTitle: Rights Act will put British way of life on trial

fields.headline: Rights Act will put British way of life on trial
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Daily life in Britain could be about to undergo its most radical transformation since the Second World War. The police, courts, Whitehall and local government are in-volved in a review of their powers and authority as they prepare for a wave of legal challenges on human rights grounds this autumn.
fields.body:
Daily life in Britain could be about to undergo its most radical transformation since the Second World War. The police, courts, Whitehall and local government are in-volved in a review of their powers and authority as they prepare for a wave of legal challenges on human rights grounds this autumn.

One Minister warned: 'We are about to be hit by an avalanche of cases and the political consequences are highly unpredictable. Over time, it could change the face of the administration of Britain.'

The cases range from the right to fertility treatment to major issues of constitutional principle, such as the use of public interest immunity certificates. The spate of legal cases, already forcing the Lord Chancellor to appoint a raft of new judges, will start clogging the courts when the Human Rights Act comes into force on 2 October. The Act, passed in November 1998, incorporates the European Convention on Human Rights into English law, thus speeding access to the Convention's rights.

The roots of the big political controversies of last week - Clause 28, the age of consent, new police surveillance powers and even the deportation of the Afghan asylum-seekers - can all be traced back to rulings from the European Convention. Now that the Convention is being incorporated into British law, its fundamental principles will have even more impact.

In Scotland, where the law has been incorporated since last year, startling judgments are already being made. Last week three Appeal Court judges ruled that the law which demands motorists specify whether or not they were driving at the time of an alleged offence breaches the right to remain silent under the Convention. The decision, now being appealed, raised widespread fears of drunken drivers going free.

The Scottish courts have also ruled that judgments by temporary sheriffs (because they can be sacked by the Lord Advocate, who is a member of the Executive) breach the Convention's criteria for a fair trial. The ruling probably renders 1,400 temporary English judges unlawful.

In public, Home Secretary Jack Straw has acclaimed the Act as the harbinger of a new 'rights and responsibilities' culture, but in private there is nervousness that once the full implications of the Act come into play, there will be a backlash from Conservatives angry at the attack on parliamentary sovereignty, even though it has nothing to do with the EU.

Already an internal Whitehall audit is throwing up a series of human interest issues on which the Government believes it may be vulnerable. A paper presented by the Home Office Human Rights Task Force - set up to educate public bodies on the Act - has illustrated the convention's potential impact by looking at the Health Department. It points out Article 2 of the Convention protecting the right to life could see issues of health care rationing tested, including the standard of treatment for the chronically sick. NHS trusts could be sued if someone died because of the lack of a doctor.

Meanwhile, Article 3 - on degrading treatment and punishment - could spell the end of mixed wards and Article 5 - the right to liberty and security - could see challenges to treatment and detention under the Mental Health Act.

The relationship between parental rights and child protection may be affected by Article 8 - the right to respect for private and family life, while Article 10 - the right to marry and found a family - may require more provision of fertility treatment.

School exclusions and school admissions policy could also be challenged under the Act. The police are also taking its impact seriously. Groups such as Liberty and Charter 88 have both identified stop and search powers as open to challenge. The Home Office is likely to face challenges on immigration cases. Northern Ireland security laws, including the new Terrorism Act, parades bans and detention rules will be quickly challenged.

One of the first victims of the Act may be Lord Irvine himself, ironically a champion of the legislation. The European Court has ruled that the right to a fair trial was breached when the Bailiff of Guernsey ruled one of the island's flower growers had broken planning laws. The Bailiff had been responsible for passing the law, and had therefore not properly separated his judicial and political functions.

Just the same principles would apply if Lord Irvine heard any case involving the incorporation of the Convention. It may mean that Lord Irvine will never be able to sit in judgment again.

What it could be like in rights-friendly UK

The Human Rights Act could mean:

 Health care rationing outlawed

 No more mixed-sex wards

 More fertility treatment

 Age discrimination out

 Close-circuit television challenged

 No more compulsory property purchase orders

 Employers not allowed to impose dress codes

 Schools' admissions and exclusion policies questioned

 Repeated immigration challenges

 Police stop-and-search powers in question

 Northern Ireland security legislation in doubt

fields.headline: McCain's one final mission
fields.standfirst: How a network of Vietnam veterans is helping to galvanise the military vote
fields.trailText: The most heart-wrenching sight in America is suddenly the stuff of raw electoral politics, as John McCain and George W. Bush face off in the South Carolina primary and in the increasingly thrilling contest beyond.
fields.body:
The most heart-wrenching sight in America is suddenly the stuff of raw electoral politics, as John McCain and George W. Bush face off in the South Carolina primary and in the increasingly thrilling contest beyond.

It happens many times every day: an elderly couple, or maybe a mother and son or daughter, descend the ramp alongside The Wall of Silent Names that is the Vietnam Memorial in Washington DC, almost suffocating at its deepest point. They are given a piece of tracing paper, a crayon, an envelope and maybe a step ladder, and find one of those engraved names, all that remains of a loved one lost decades ago. They rub the name on to the paper, linger awhile staring at that piece of wall, then they climb - solemnly, sometimes tearfully - back up the ramp, clutching the envelope.

The Vietnam gash is America's deepest and unhealed wound, but has been politically sidelined until this election, when a convergence of factors has brought Nam back into frame. This time around, the veterans and those families whom the dead left behind at The Wall are vital political statistics. One factor is John McCain's remarkable Vietnam record of courage in the face of torture - especially as contrasted with that of Bush, who dodged the war with help from his father to sit around as a National Guardsman in Texas. McCain is trying all he can to translate his life story into votes.

But the McCain mutiny is in turn symptomatic of something which cuts much deeper: a growing popular conviction that the Vietnam War was, after all, a just war, that its veterans and bereaved families should be vindicated not reviled, that the peacenik Sixties got it wrong.

It is a mood-swing ex-pressed in a new book by anti-war Democrat Michael Lind, the title of which speaks for itself: Vietnam: The Necessary War. Maybe not The Good War - as Studs Terkel's cult book described World War II - but getting better.

The veterans of Nam now targeted by McCain were, most of them, the poor from the prairies, mountains and ghettoes who returned to face the hatred of the military establishment for losing and of the liberals for having gone in the first place. They watched 'Hanoi' Jane Fonda marry a media mogul and draft-dodger Bill Clinton become President.

But now, says Rand Lewis, a veteran who teaches Vietnam classes at Idaho University, 'finally, after all these years, the American public has accepted the veterans back into the fold'. Not only that, but they have a presidential candidate from among their own.

McCain is now a serious politician and has done the mathematics. There are 8.5 million veterans of Vietnam-age or younger. Three million of them served in Vietnam, of whom 300,000 were wounded like him. South Carolina boasts the heaviest concentration per capita: 450,000 vets - 10 per cent of the state's population (second is New Hampshire). If they all voted for McCain, he would need no one else.

And if he can win South Carolina on 19 February, McCain's campaign goes truly national - to all those tens of thousands of places where the black flag of the veterans and 'POW/MIA' (prisoner of war/missing in action) movements flies from city hall or state Capitol.

So McCain's election poster shows not the present-day, bouncy candidate in very late middle age but a strikingly handsome young Navy pilot in full flying regalia with the ironic slogan 'McCain 2000' beneath. On the podium in Sunter, South Carolina, McCain thunders: 'How are we going to get a future generation of Americans to serve, if we don't look after those who already have?'

McCain has named veterans co-ordinators in each of South Carolina's counties, all reporting to a retired colonel, Phil Butler. McCain's latest leaflet, sent to every registered war veteran in South Carolina (with all other primary states to follow) addresses his former comrades thus: 'I Ask You To Join Me In One Last Mission.'

The crucial questions are: Will they? And: Who else will join McCain on that last mission, but who never picked up a gun? Richard Quinn, McCain's strategist in South Carolina, presumes it 'likely' that 'a person who has a military background will vote for McCain'.

And yet the veterans are many and their vote is not monolithic. Even Colonel Butler concedes that 'we probably don't have as much of the veteran vote as we should'. Now Bush must confront the veteran vote and fight for it - without seeming to fight McCain. This is perilous territory for Bush, after revelations that once his military service alibi in higher education had expired, a carefully placed phone call by his father enabled the young Harvard 'Frat Brat' to jump a queue of 100,000 and join the safety of the Texas National Guard while those whose votes he now seeks were out in the killing fields.

But Bush's machine in conservative South Carolina has found the way of selling its non-veteran candidate to veterans: you call his rival a bleeding-heart liberal. 'McCain is a Democrat-lite,' says Wayne Crockfield, a disabled veteran who sits on the local anti-abortion committee and dislikes McCain's 'flip-flops' on the issue.

Because McCain is also a veteran, many vets hold him to higher standards than other candidates, or have higher expectations to disappoint. Many in the powerful POW/MIA movement - which believes successive administrations have connived to betray remaining prisoners and missing comrades - object to McCain's push to improve relations with Communist Vietnam and even accuse him of a 'cover-up'. One MIA activist website in Kansas posits that McCain was brainwashed by his captors into maintaining a rapport with Hanoi.

But veterans like Jim Skinner of Orgeon, who made a peacemaking journey to Hanoi last year and 'liked the beer they got there', applaud McCain's efforts. 'It's time to shake hands and move on,' says James McKinnon, a vice-commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars association, a McCain man. So Bush should tread carefully through the dichotomy of the veterans' hawkery and their maturity. But in Florence, South Carolina, last week he blundered in what may be remembered as a seminal moment in the campaign; he tried to touch an American nerve, and sliced it instead.

Bush fielded Thomas Burch Jnr, chairman of the National Vietnam and Gulf War Veterans Committee, who accused McCain of failing his kind - opposing measures to deal with Agent Orange poisoning, and legislation to help families of those whom veterans hold sacred, the 'POW/MIA' boys. 'He came home,' said Burch, a Vietnam veteran, 'and forgot us.' Burch's attack backfired. The response from the veteran movment was one of outrage. Edward Timperlake, Assistant Secretary for Veterans' Affairs in the Administration of Bush's own father, said: 'Attacking John McCain on veterans' affairs is wrong. It's over the line.' Five senators (one a Republican) wrote a furious letter expressing 'dismay' and demanding an apology to McCain.

McCain spoke only of the letter's authors: 'Their friendship is all the honour I need in my life, and more than compensates for the temporary irritation of baseless attacks by apparently desperate political campaigns.'

Until Florence, analysts had seen a possibility of Bush maybe inviting McCain to be his running mate one day soon, but not now.

fields.headline: Duelling Hague draws blood
fields.standfirst:
The Tory leader fought Portillo's faction to a standstill last week, but can the party peace hold? Andy McSmith weighs the chances
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague plans to traverse the country on the back of a lorry this week preaching his 'Common Sense Revolution' to the people. He had the chance to take an entourage of pretty young women, loaned by the millionaire nightclub owner Peter Stringfellow.
fields.body:
William Hague plans to traverse the country on the back of a lorry this week preaching his 'Common Sense Revolution' to the people. He had the chance to take an entourage of pretty young women, loaned by the millionaire nightclub owner Peter Stringfellow.

The Tory leader allegedly turned it down because Ffion, his wife, objected. But it is equally possible that he fears ridicule of the kind he attracted on the occasion he hoped to look cool by donning a baseball cap for the camera.

The story of the spurned offer from Stringfellow was the only interesting morsel of information to emerge last week from a private lunch which Hague held for Sunday newspaper journalists.

Hoping to improve the dismal coverage Hague had been attracting, even from the Tory press, his aides invited correspondents from newspapers judged to be susceptible to the Tory leader's charm. Newspapers who might make trouble, including The Observer, were not invited.

But lobby journalists have specialised tastes. It is not the food they care about at such lunches, but the texture and aroma of the information and gossip. Hague's advisers placed only one item on the menu - the itinerary of the campaign lorry in the run-up to the May council elections. This was not substantial enough fodder. In a week full of rumours about intrigue and backstabbing between Hague loyalists and the 'Portillistas' who have rallied to Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo, the guests wanted a taste of some of that, too.

Hague refused to discuss internal party affairs. He took his leave, followed by his main press aide, Amanda Platell, leaving her deputy, Nick Wood, to handle the carefully vetted but now thoroughly disaffected guests.

Relations around the table deteriorated, with Wood accusing the journalists of bad behaviour. To punish them, he released the story of the flat-bed truck to yesterday's papers, denying the Sundays their exclusive.

While this might be seen as evidence that Hague's staff cannot organise a meal in a restaurant, it should not detract from the truth that Hague has had rather a good week. He scored a win against Tony Blair during their weekly exchange in the Commons, boosting Tory morale. A Gallup poll for the Daily Telegraph put support for the Government below 50 per cent for the first time since Labour won power. And in the contest which fascinates Tory MPs more than any other - the one between Hague and Portillo for control of the party - Hague ended the week in a marginally better position than he began.

At the start, there was talk - again - that Hague might not survive to lead the party into the next election. Portillo had done well in his new job, chucking away discredited policies on a minimum wage and the Bank of England. The Right was dividing between Portillistas and the smaller and politically more way-out contingent who could be expected to back John Redwood in a leadership contest. Hague's small circle of loyalists appeared to be hopelessly outclassed - until they showed they could fight back.

It had been assumed that Robbie Gibb, chief of staff to the outgoing Shadow Chancellor, Francis Maude, would do the same job for Portillo. Gibb has a formidable reputation as a wheeler-dealer and devoted Portillista.

But he had made enemies, including Platell and another member of the Hague circle, the former Olympic athlete and ex-MP, Sebastian Coe. They persuaded Hague to block Gibb's appointment, and it is now likely that Gibb will leave Westminster.

On a more important level, Hague won a skirmish over who ultimately controls Tory economic policy. Last autumn, when Portillo was out of politics, Hague delivered his famous 'tax pledge'. In the hope of restoring Conservative credibility as the tax-cutting party, he made an absolute promise that a Tory government would reduce the proportion of Gross Domestic Product collected in tax - which would be a rare turnabout.

The pledge has been an open goal for Labour. Every time the Tories attack cuts in the defence budget, the health service or any other public service, Ministers throw it back in their faces, saying that, if taxes are going to come down under the Tories regardless of circumstances, essential services will suffer.

Even those who back the pledge, like Tory vice-chairman Andrew Lansley, accept they cannot dodge certain basic questions like 'what happens if there is a recession?'

As a former Treasury Chief Secretary, Portillo privately decided that the whole policy was an unnecessary hostage to fortune. If the 'pledge' was repackaged as an 'aspiration' all awkward questions could be sidestepped. During an interview early in the week, he dropped a hint that it was being reconsidered.

Several leading Portillo supporters duly briefed that the pledge was unworkable. One - MP Eric Forth - said so publicly. According to one insider, they were gearing up for an announcement in about two weeks that the pledge was no longer a pledge.

This brought John Redwood out of his corner, ready to fight the Portillistas whom he blames for his sacking nearly a fortnight ago. He publicly defended the tax pledge on Wednesday lunchtime. Two hours later, Hague was taunted about it by Blair, and asserted: 'The tax guarantee stands, and it will continue to stand.'

As well as publicly demonstrating his authority, Hague had private words with his new Shadow Chancellor. Faced with a leader who would not budge, the Portillistas had no choice but to back down.

By the end of the week, it was also clear that Portillo had calculated that he had as much to lose as Hague - if not more - when his courtiers were seen to be undermining the leader. The word went out that Portillo wanted the warring to stop. With the Tories facing long years in Opposition and an agonisingly slow crawl back into power, it remains to be seen if the faction bosses can stop their lieutenants from feuding.

webTitle: PM pleaded with LibDem leader to save Michael

fields.headline: PM pleaded with LibDem leader to save Michael
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair pleaded with the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy to save the career of his man in Wales, Alun Michael, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Tony Blair pleaded with the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy to save the career of his man in Wales, Alun Michael, it emerged yesterday.

The Prime Minister telephoned Kennedy 'several times' hoping to persuade the Liberal Democrats to withdraw their support from the 'no confidence' motion in the Welsh Assembly that forced Michael out of office last week. The final call was made less than 24 hours before Michael quit to avoid being publicly sacked.

Blair warned him that the whole devolution process - which Labour and the Liberal Democrats supported against Tory opposition - could be undermined if Michael were brought down.

But Kennedy, who visited Cardiff yesterday to speak in memory of Lloyd George, retorted that devolution implied that decisions such as the choice of a First Secretary had to be made locally.

On Tuesday, the popular Rhodri Morgan will be voted into office to succeed Michael. All three opposition parties have signalled that they will back his appointment, which many politicians see as the start of a new era in Welsh politics. Plaid Cymru Assembly member Phil Williams claimed: 'In the streets of Wales there is a feeling that our man is in now.'

He said Morgan's election would be welcomed by nationalists, despite the risk that they will suffer in the polls if Labour is led by a local leader with a popular touch.

Morgan is expected to hold talks with other parties about the possibility of informal co-operation around a jointly agreed political programme, but he is unlikely to offer them any Cabinet seats.

He needs to build bridges with a minority in the Welsh Labour leadership who stayed loyal to Michael to the bitter end. By the time he was forced from office last Wednesday, Michael could count on the backing of only five of his 27 fellow Labour assembly members. Three have since resigned their positions as party whips, accusing the chief whip Andrew Davies of having plotted against Michael.

His defeat is expected to harden opinion in the national Labour Party against using complicated electoral colleges to choose candidates for the leadership of the Scottish and Welsh assemblies or for city mayors.

In the original contest between Michael and Morgan for the top Welsh post, Morgan won the higher number of votes, but Michael was elected because he had more support from MPs and union leaders using the block vote.

Labour General Secretary Margaret McDonagh has accepted that the use of an electoral college in Wales and in the London mayoralty contest has provoked a backlash.

webTitle: Family flying to be with 'ailing' Pinochet

fields.headline: Family flying to be with 'ailing' Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Relatives of General Augusto Pinochet were reported to be rushing to his bedside yesterday after claims that his health had seriously deteriorated.
fields.byline: Andy McSmith, London and Jonathan Franklin, Santiago
fields.body:
Relatives of General Augusto Pinochet were reported to be rushing to his bedside yesterday after claims that his health had seriously deteriorated.

But his supporters were accused of fabricating the crisis, said to involve a severe bout of depression, in order to put pressure on the British courts to release the 84-year-old former dictator.

They are anxious to get Pinochet freed before 11 March, when the incumbent Christian Democrat President Eduardo Frei will hand over power to his socialist successor, Ricardo Lagos, who was jailed under the former dictator.

Monica Werhahn, of the Pinochet Foundation in Santiago, said family members were breaking off their holidays to take the first available flights to Britain after a 'serious and worrisome' deterioration in the former dictator's health.

Luis Cortes Villa, head of the foundation - which hands out military scholarships and promotes the General's public image - told Chilean radio yesterday: 'He does not get out of bed, he hardly talks with anyone... and it has left his entire family worried.'

But a Home Office spokesman said: 'We have checked these reports out and they appear to be pure speculation.'

A spokeswoman for the Chilean Committe for Justice in London suggested the reports were fuelled by the Pinochet camp's disappointment over last week's court ruling which has prolonged his stay in Britain.

The latest legal argument thrown up by Spain's request to extradite the former dictator is over whether a medical report drawn up last month should be published. The report prompted Home Secretary Jack Straw's announcment he was 'minded' to allow Pinochet to return to Chile.

Last week the courts unexpectedly ruled that the issue could go to a judicial review, which is likely to be taken all the way to the law lords for a final decision.

webTitle: Pilots vent fury at RAF on Web

fields.headline: Pilots vent fury at RAF on Web
fields.trailText: Britain's top fighter pilots are using an Internet website to vent their fury at the RAF.  Pilots currently serving in the Gulf, and others recently back from Kosovo, are so angry about defective equipment and low morale they are flooding the secret site with complaints aimed at senior officers.
fields.body:
Britain's top fighter pilots are using an Internet website to vent their fury at the RAF. Pilots currently serving in the Gulf, and others recently back from Kosovo, are so angry about defective equipment and low morale they are flooding the secret site with complaints aimed at senior officers.

One codenamed 'daftsod' says: 'Fact: I'm off. Endless steering groups, surveys, review bodies and promises. Nothing ever tangible ... When I hear the Minister for Defence telling the nation there isn't a morale problem - frankly I despair.'

Perhaps the most revealing insight comes from a pilot who says he is an RAF captain. He starts: 'I joined the RAF to fly. At the moment when I am in the UK I am lucky to get one sortie a week.' He admits that when out of the UK this improves, but complains that his aircraft is 'over 30 years old'.

The captain goes on: 'The number of sorties lost due to unserviceability is way too high. I now find that I have to accept faults to get the job done that a few years ago I would not have done ... Although I have a few worries about the structural strength of the airframe I am convinced that we are going to have a major problem due to some esoteric fault.'

The pilot is highly critical about difficulties in finding replacement parts for jets. He said: 'We struggle to get spares, some parts have to be manufactured over and over. We use the cheapest contractor we can find.' He says technical problems almost stopped him flying across the Atlantic. The pilot said: 'We were almost put into a position in which we could not cross the Atlantic due to our nav kit [navigation] restrictions, and now we have the kit we have no training aids and the simulators bear no resemblance to the real aircraft.'

His descriptions of duties when he is not flying paint a depressing picture: 'You can find yourself spending hours typing in meaningless figures  that can be used to prove just about anything.'

He appeals for senior air force personnel to listen to his and other pilots' complaints. He concludes: 'For my part I still enjoy my job and will give it my all until I leave. I will however go when it suits me and not the RAF. My loyalty has been tested to the limit. I now treat this as purely a job. Sad.'

Another pilot responds: 'The state of our jets is starting to worry me as well. Two engine changes in two flights is not a state to be proud of.'

There is also a large amount of criticism about the 'bad decision making' which has cost millions.

One user of the website, codenamed Firestreak, said: 'Who allowed the F2/F3 [fighter planes] into service with virtually a non-existent radar?'

Last month The Observer published details of the poor state of the RAF's frontline forces. The paper highlighted the hundreds of grounded jets, the lack of flying, the shortage of pilots, the chronic morale and the exodus of trained pilots leaving to join commercial airlines.

Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon dismissed these concerns in the House of Commons, saying there is no morale problem.

But the website tells a different story. One pilot said: 'Someone should copy all this stuff to the politicos. Let them know what's really going on. It's a damn shame.' The website is full of similar pleas for senior staff to listen and take action.

The Observer pointed the website out to Liberal Democrat defence spokesman Menzies Campbell.

He said: 'We now have a great deal of evidence from a great variety of sources about the strain on the RAF. It is not enough for the Government to simply shrug off these reports.' An ex-RAF officer involved with the website said: 'This site has amazed me. I believe that things were getting better but what this shows me is that no corner has been turned. Things seem to have got worse since I left three years ago. Some e-mails are coming from the Gulf. It is truly sad that serving pilots who are risking their lives have to resort to the Internet to air their views.'
antony.barnett@observer.co.uk
What the flyers are saying
After The Observer broke the story of the RAF's problems on 23 February, the MoD played it down. But a website shows how pilots are feeling the strain.

12 February

'It is revealing that the "B word" (Air Marshall Bagnall - head of personnel) still insists that "we are getting there" despite the compelling evidence on this site that they are not. Is he really that stupid or arrogant? Or perhaps their airships (senior officers) don't actually care?'

9 February

'When did anybody last see their AOC (air officer commander) on their station? Let alone any of the faceless ones from the MoD-box (headquarters)?'

12 January

'There is nothing new in a mass egress when the civvy market is buoyant. So long as no war crops up where we have to show our experience and ability we will continue to bluff the public.'

8 January

'My prediction is that CAS (chief of air staff) will use the Act (Official Secrets Act) to close this sub-forum. Just think of all the little hints and tips about morale etc an interested party could glean.'

fields.headline: Prince's repairs funded by MoD
fields.standfirst: Taxpayers' money helped foot the bill for Edward's £2m home renovation
fields.trailText: The ministry of defence paid hundreds of thousands of pounds towards the restoration of Prince Edward's 50-room country mansion,  The Observer has discovered. Buckingham Palace has always insisted that no taxpayers' money was involved in renovating the former Army property.
fields.body:
The ministry of defence paid hundreds of thousands of pounds towards the restoration of Prince Edward's 50-room country mansion, The Observer has discovered. Buckingham Palace has always insisted that no taxpayers' money was involved in renovating the former Army property.

The disclosure adds to controversy over the Earl of Wessex's finances. He is currently at the centre of a financial dispute over the £2 million refurbishment of Bagshot Park, in Surrey, after refusing to pay builders £600,000 towards the cost. The building firm has now collapsed with the loss of 85 jobs.

The Observer has discovered that the Ministry of Defence handed over a significant sum for Bagshot Park to the Crown Estate - the body which manages all property and land owned by the royal family.

The Crown Estate sold a 50-year lease to Edward for Bagshot Park, now the headquarters of his ailing TV company Ardent Productions and the marital home he shares with the Countess of Wessex, the former Sophie Rhys-Jones.

Under the terms of a confidential deal struck between the MoD and the Crown Estate, the Ministry agreed to pay for 'dilapidations'. This means that significant sums of taxpayers' money would have been paid to the Crown Estate to restore the decaying property to a reasonable condition, such as repairing roofs, gutters and windows.

The MoD, Buckingham Palace and the Crown Estate last week confirmed that money was paid by the Government. But they refused to reveal how much, citing 'commercial confidentiality'.

One source close to the refurbishment contract believes the sum paid by the MoD could be more than £1m.

It has long been a mystery how the Earl of Wessex could afford such expensive restoration, when his businesses were still losing money. Edward's salary at Ardent is £144,125 a year (he awarded himself a 20 per cent pay rise last year). He also receives £96,000 a year from the Queen for royal expenses.

The Palace has always refused to comment on the renovation, saying it is a private matter for the Prince, and insisting no taxpayers money has ever been involved. More embarrassing details of the £2m renovation project are likely to emerge if the Prince finds himself in court over his non-payment for building works. Friends of the Prince claim the builders are at fault and that a fair offer was made to collapsed contractors C J Sims to settle the dispute. The firm has blamed the Earl's 'dithering' for pushing up the cost of the project.

A director of C J Sims, which had a Royal Warrant, claimed Edward was always changing his mind and was incapable of deciding on wallpaper patterns or colour schemes. Receivers of C J Sims have now threatened to take Edward to court if he does not pay up.

The Observer has discovered that Edward set up a separate company to oversee the renovation project, called Eclipse Nominees. The receivers suggest that this might allow him to liquidate the company without having to pay his bills, although receivers admit that this is unlikely given the negative publicity it would create.

The row surrounding Bagshot Park is the latest in a long line of damaging disclosures about the Prince. Last year he was attacked after he claimed in a US newspaper that the British hated anyone who succeeded. The com ments backfired when the Prince's own business failures were highlighted and he was forced into a humiliating apology.

Ardent Productions racked up its sixth straight year of losses since its creation in 1993, losing £1.7m and sending its credit rating to zero.

Edward has also been fiercely criticised for cashing in on royal connections to boost the firm's fortunes. Ardent's recent productions include Edward on Edward , a documentary about his great uncle Edward VIII.

In November he earned £30,000 for a lecture he gave at Windsor on the fire at the castle and the resulting repairs - also paid for with taxpayers' money.

fields.headline: West End theatres bought for £16m
fields.trailText: London's Theatreland has changed hands again. Nine of the West End's most successful auditoriums have been bought by the Ambassadors Theatre Group in a £16 million deal to be announced this week.
fields.body:
London's Theatreland has changed hands again. Nine of the West End's most successful auditoriums have been bought by the Ambassadors Theatre Group in a £16 million deal to be announced this week.

The group, which previously owned only the New Ambassadors and the Duke of York's, has beaten off interest from the Broadway theatre magnate Max Wietzenhoffer and will now be the proud owner of the Piccadilly Theatre, home of Spend, Spend, Spend - the musical about pools winner Viv Nicolson which is tipped to win an Olivier Award on Friday - and of the Donmar Warehouse, the artistic base of the young British film director and Oscar-hopeful Sam Mendes.

It will also take on the stewardship of the Albery, the Comedy, the Phoenix, the Criterion, the Playhouse, the Whitehall and the Wyndham theatres. All the venues were previously owned or run by Associated Capital Theatres.

The glittering wholesale purchase will divide the ownership of London's theatres between two new main players, Lord Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Group, with 13 theatres, and the Ambassadors, with 11. Lloyd Webber bought up the 10 Stoll Moss theatres earlier this year, making 2000 already a year of unprecedented activity in the West End.

Lloyd Webber's purchase for £87.5m followed the decision of West End proprietor Janet Holmes a Court to concentrate on business interests back home in Australia. The composer already owned the Palace, the Adelphi and the New London Theatres.

The two relatively high-price buys reflect a boom in ticket sales and a growing faith in the ability of good programming, combined with star names, to pull in the crowds.

Under David Parkhill, ACT's managing director, the group flourished with a series of award-winning productions. Box office went up by as much as 30 per cent in some houses. And the trend seems to be continuing. This month John Hurt opened in Samuel Beckett's Krapp's Last Tape , an adventurous avant garde choice, and the acclaimed revival of Tom Stoppard's The Real Thing, also tipped to be acknowledged at the Olivier's this week, is still drawing big audiences at the Albery.

The Office of Fair Trading will be alert to the changes of ownership. While there are other theatre proprietors on the West End scene, none of them owns anything approaching the number of theatres of the Really Useful or the Ambassadors.

This weekend a spokeswoman for the OFT said the sale would be examined in case it was considered to affect the public interest.

'We look at deals involving companies worth more than £70m and when more than 25 per cent of the market is affected,' she said. 'This certainly may well qualify.'

Analysts in the theatre industry doubt, though, that the overall impact of this year's game of theatrical musical chairs will be investigated.

'It is really only the names that have changed,' said one. 'It's just that Really Useful is a little bigger than Stoll Moss was and the Ambassadors is a little bigger than ACT was.'

The cinema, television and theatre production arms of ACT were all disposed of late last year just before the departure of Marc Vlessing, the chairman brought in to revitalise the group. Under Vlessing and Parkhill ACT had set up a production and programming division which many current hits can be traced back to.

The daring bid to bring 'quality drama' back to the West End stage and to attempt to rival the South Bank's upper middle class audience monopoly was orchestrated by Nick Salmon, director of production and programming, and Brigid Larmour, artistic director.

Creative responsibility for the seven theatres formerly owned by ACT now switches to Sonia Friedman, another of the rising female artistic forces in the West End who began her career on the street-cred fringe.

Rupert Gavin, chairman of the Ambassadors Theatre Group, said he could not confirm the price or the closure of the deal.

webTitle: Death row love splits prisoners' pen pal group

fields.headline: Death row love splits prisoners' pen pal group
fields.trailText: She was a middle-class professional from London's commuter belt. He was a double murderer from the American Deep South on death row.
fields.body:
She was a middle-class professional from London's commuter belt. He was a double murderer from the American Deep South on death row.

Sue Fenwick never expected to fall in love when she started writing to Bobby 'Tennessee' Lusk, at the high-security Union Correctional Institution in Raiford, Florida. But her marriage to the 49-year-old former truck driver has divided the anti-death penalty lobby on both sides of the Atlantic.

As a prominent member of LifeLines, a British civil rights group whose members write to US prisoners on death row, Fenwick has infuriated fellow activists, who believe romantic relationships between inmates and their pen pals should be strongly discouraged.

The organisation's prominent patrons include Labour peer Helena Kennedy, Michael Mansfield, the barrister in the Stephen Lawrence case, and authors Lady Antonia Fraser, A.S. Byatt and John Mortimer.

Issues raised by the unlikely romance have embroiled Amnesty International, human rights lawyers and senior figures in the death penalty abolition movement. The row has split LifeLines members down the middle, with some saying Fenwick is a victim of internecine rivalries.

Before her marriage in December, Fenwick acted as a LifeLines co-ordinator for pen pals writing to prisoners on death row in Texas, but she has since resigned her post. She has has now joined a rival organisation, Human Rights.

A letter to all members of LifeLines sent out at the end of last month condemned her action: 'There is a real conflict of interest if a co-ordinator finds himself or herself in this position. LifeLines policy has always been to encourage friendship free from romantic involvement.

'The danger is that a co-ordinator in this position would send out all the wrong signals about the organisation; he or she would be out in an impossible situation when counselling individuals.'

Fenwick told The Observer last week said she did not wish to talk about her marriage: 'I'm not the first (to marry a prisoner) and I won't be the last. My private life is my private life.'

Shelley Bovey, press officer for the organisation, said every effort was being made to allow Fenwick to continue with LifeLines in an advisory capacity: 'We are still trying to find a way of getting her back without compromising the organisation.' You can't legislate against someone falling in love and we may have to rethink our policy as a result of this.'

Mike Radelet, Professor of Sociology at the University of Florida, who has been a friend of Lusk's for 17 years, said: 'From his perspective it is great, but Sue knew exactly what she was getting into. Those rules are there for excellent reasons. The prison authorities in Florida have always been suspicious of LifeLines.They see it as an organisation for people looking for romance. This is not like adopting zoo animals.'

Lusk was condemned to death in 1980 for killing another prisoner. He was already serving a life sentence for armed robbery and murder committed in Miami in 1976. Grey-haired and slightly deaf, Lusk has been in prison since 1977, when he was 26 years old.

Three years ago campaigners succeeded in having his sentence commuted to life after it was discovered that prosecution lawyers withheld evidence that the prisoner he killed was a homosexual who had previously assaulted him.

Fenwick wrote to him for several years before their marriage. She had also visited him in jail before their friendship grew romantic. The wedding took place within the prison walls at Christmas.

The couple are believed to be applying to have Lusk serve parole in England when he finishes his 25-year minimum sentence, but a Florida activist told The Observer: 'That's as likely as a blizzard in Miami in midsummer.'

fields.headline: Branson admits lottery deal bid
fields.standfirst: Libel battle forgotten as Sir Richard invited US giant GTech to join him
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson tried to strike a secret deal with GTech, the US lottery company he accused of offering him a bribe to drop his lottery bid last time.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson tried to strike a secret deal with GTech, the US lottery company he accused of offering him a bribe to drop his lottery bid last time.

In an extraordinary U-turn the man jointly heading up Branson's People's Lottery, John Jackson, telephoned GTech's British boss Dennis Mahoney last September asking the company to ditch Camelot and join Branson's bid.

Up until then the two sides had been bitter enemies. Five years ago Branson famously accused GTech's former chairman, Guy Snowden, of bribing him to drop out of the lottery race. In 1998 GTech was forced to sell its stake in Camelot after Snowden lost a libel action against Branson who was awarded £100,000 by the High Court. GTech turned down Branson's offer because it had already agreed to work with Camelot on its bid to win a new licence when the current one expires next year.

A spokesman for GTech admitted the company was 'very surprised' about Branson's overture given the past history between the rivals. Simon Burridge who jointly heads the People's Lottery with Jackson said: 'We invited all companies involved in lotteries to bid to supply The People's Lottery and GTech was one of those. But we don't hold grudges. Richard's complaint was against GTech's former chairman who no longer works for the company.'

These disclosures emerge as a row erupted between the People's Lottery and Camelot over Branson's claims that his bid is a 'not-for-profit' bid. The corporate partners Branson has signed up for his bid stand to make millions from his 'not-for-profit' lottery bid, if he wins his battle to take over the National Lottery from Camelot next year.

Despite Branson's pledge that there would be no 'fat cats' in his People's Lottery, several large companies involved in the bid, such as US computer giant Compaq and German industrial group Siemens, would make handsome profits.

Both teams are preparing their final bids, which need to be in by the end of the month. A winner is expected to be chosen by June. Last week Branson announced an alliance with the world's richest man, computer billionaire Bill Gates. Microsoft was signed up to provide technical support and build the computer infrastructure for the National Lottery. While Microsoft is promising to give a slice of its profits to good causes, the other companies Branson has signed up to supply equipment and services will make a 'commercial return'.

One expert estimated that, if Branson wins the licence, operating costs of the National Lottery are likely to be around 4 per cent of profits. This would amount to around £200 million a year on current estimates.

Assuming the companies involved demand a reasonable profit margin of 10 per cent, this would result in £20m a year in clear profits being shared by a number of multinationals. Camelot's suppliers would make a similar level of profits, but any extra is taken by Camelot itself - an amount which last year came to £50m. It is this slice of takings which Branson has promised to channel into good causes.

Other companies signed up by Branson which will profit from a successful bid by him include US cereals company Kelloggs, US lottery operator AWI, and advertising agency J Walter Thompson whose managing partner, Simon Burridge, is jointly running Branson's lottery bid.

Burridge denied Branson was misleading the public: 'It is a completely ludicrous claim. The People's Lottery will make no money out of the lottery at any time, now or in the future.'

Branson has pledged that, once the operating costs have been met, every extra penny will go to good causes. He believes this pledge will help bring back to the lottery many of the 12 million adults who do not play it now. Branson claims if a quarter of all lapsed users begin playing the lottery again, an additional £1 billion would be raised for good causes.

webTitle: Fiery fate of a pimp who took too much

fields.headline: Fiery fate of a pimp who took too much
fields.trailText: It looked like the work of teenage vandals. When fire fighters arrived at the disused butcher's shop in Windemere Avenue, Wembley, north west London, they found an armchair ablaze in the old cold storage room.
fields.body:
It looked like the work of teenage vandals. When fire fighters arrived at the disused butcher's shop in Windemere Avenue, Wembley, north west London, they found an armchair ablaze in the old cold storage room.

But once the flames were doused the sickening truth was revealed: a person had been tied to the chair before it had been set alight. The body was burned beyond recognition; intense heat had melted parts of the face. It was impossible to tell whether the victim was young or old, male or female, black or white.

A post mortem examination revealed it was a young man. He had been severely beaten: two front teeth were kicked out, there were bruises all over his face and apparent restraining marks on his wrists. He had choked to death on his own vomit before being torched.

Police managed to take fingerprints from one hand. The victim was identified as 28-year-old William Senyanga, a Ugandan asylum seeker.

Senyanga, who arrived in London in March 1991, had told immigration officials that his father, a prominent political activist, had been murdered by an outlawed rebel faction. His only contact with the police had been an arrest for driving while disqualified. He seemed the unlikely recipient of such a brutal end.

But detectives found the death threw open a secret world of escort agencies, vicious rivalries, brutal exploitation and enormous sums of money being made. In London, the trade is estimated to be worth £200 million a year. Next week, after a year-long probe into the seedy world of vice and call girls, the killers will finally be sentenced.

The story began in late 1996, when Senyanga moved into a council flat in the plush Pimlico area of central London. Once there, he set up several escort agencies supplying prostitutes to a wide range of clients. All business was conducted on the phone. He recruited girls and sought clients through advertisements in free newspapers. His flat had six telephones. Senyanga would answer each one with a different company name: Ambassadors, 18 & New, Girls-R-Us and so on. He had more than 60 women on his books and they charged clients a minimum £150 per hour. Senyanga would take a third and the girl the rest. Clients were able to pay with credit cards. Working 6pm to 6am seven days a week, Senyanga was soon raking in more than £5,000 a week.

Detective Inspector Chris Foster, the man leading the investigation, realised that Senyanga's business dealings held the key to his death. A search of the Pimlico house revealed that the agency boss kept meticulous records of all girls working for him and Foster began to contact them.

They also found a scrap of paper in his waste basket with 'Room 22, Wembley Hotel' written on it. But the hotel's register showed that room was not used the weekend Senyanga died.

As prostitutes began to talk, it seemed Senyanga had been a fairly popular employer, hiring drivers for his girls and insisting they call before and after each visit to confirm they were safe. But he had enemies too. As few of the girls had met him in person, he would often anonymously pose as a client and 'test' them, revealing the truth later. There were doubts about his fairness with their money.

One girl, Alison, told detectives she started working for Senyanga in December 1997. The 21-year-old university student had run up massive debts in her final year and, ashamed to ask her well-to-do accountant father for help, turned to prostitution.

One night she was sent to a regular client, a well-known art critic who paid her £2,000, by credit card to spend the night with him. When Alison tried to get her money, Senyanga told her the transaction had not gone through. Alison continued working for Senyanga, but felt increasingly bitter towards him.

Foster called the last few numbers that had been dialled on the six phones. Most belonged to prostitutes employed by Senyanga. 'One time a man answered and I explained who I was,' he says. 'There was a pause then he told me that his name was Michael and that he couldn't talk at that point because he was in a wine bar with friends. He admitted being a client of Senyanga but said he could never say too much because he was married. He promised he'd call back... but he never did.'

Piece by piece, police built up a picture of Senyanga's final hours. On Good Friday he started work at the usual time and sent six girls out. 'Don't bother calling me back until 10 or 11,' he told each in turn. 'There are some friends that I've been neglecting and I'm going out to see them.' This was totally out of character as Friday was one of his busiest days. Just after 7.15, he took all his phones off the hook and left his flat. He was never seen alive again.

Foster focused on the abandoned butcher's shop. Among mail piling up were letters addressed to a Wesley Jackson. A day or so earlier an anonymous informant had called the incident room and told them to look for 'Jazzy Jackson', who rented the shop the previous year and wanted to get into the escort agency business.

Jackson turned out to be the alias of 39-year-old unem ployed Vincent Keith Reid, a man with a record of minor offences. He lived opposite the Wembley Hotel.

Foster felt he had sufficient grounds for a search warrant. Detectives burst into Reid's house and found him in bed with his 19-year-old Bosnian refugee girlfriend, Suada Gredelj. They were separated and questioned. Reid denied any contact with, or knowledge of, Senyanga. Gredelj, on the other hand, said that until a few months earlier she had worked for Senyanga as a prostitute.

Foster knew Reid was lying - he recognised his voice as 'Michael', the man who claimed to be a married client of Senyanga earlier in the investigation. When bloody handcuffs were found in Reid's garden, it all started to fall into place.

A chamber maid at the Wembley Hotel admitted that Reid had booked room 22 on Good Friday, but had asked for it not to be recorded in the register. A search of the room found blood belonging to Senyanga and Gredelj. It seemed she lured Senyanga to the room, where he was attacked by Reid.

Alison was re-interviewed and burst into tears. She admitted Reid was her driver when she worked for Senyanga. She had complained constantly about being ripped off. 'Don't you know anyone who could sort him out for me?' she asked one day. 'Don't worry,' Reid had replied. 'It's sorted.'

At first, Reid claimed Alison arranged the murder but as evidence piled up, he cracked. Next week, he and Gredelj will be sentenced after pleading guilty to the manslaughter of William Senyanga at an earlier hearing.

Detectives believe Reid wanted to take over Senyanga's business and may have accidentally killed him while torturing him. They fear he may have attempted to pull the same trick on other London escort agencies. Foster suspects other workers may have been kidnapped or assaulted but have not come forward.

'We know there are turf wars going on, we know there are disputes over territory,' he says. 'What we don't know is the scale of the problem.'
