webTitle: Prisons chief admits reign of terror by jail staff

fields.headline: Prisons chief admits reign of terror by jail staff
fields.trailText: There is a 'culture of violence' in Britain's worst jails allowing officers to abuse inmates with impunity, according to prison chief Martin Narey. His comments, in an exclusive interview with  The Observer, will send shock waves through Britain's prison service, where violence against prisoners by staff has been traditionally swept under the carpet.
fields.body:
There is a 'culture of violence' in Britain's worst jails allowing officers to abuse inmates with impunity, according to prison chief Martin Narey. His comments, in an exclusive interview with The Observer, will send shock waves through Britain's prison service, where violence against prisoners by staff has been traditionally swept under the carpet.

He said in many cases staff were simply too terrified to report abuse by colleagues.

Narey, who has said he will resign if he cannot turn around the notorious Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London, said he still had serious concerns about other prisons, including Wandsworth in south London and Portland prison on the south coast, which he described as 'bleak and militaristic'.

Heralding a new spirit of openness, which will be welcomed by civil rights groups and penal reformers, he said he wanted to create a new generation of 'decent and courteous' prison officers: 'There are still a minority of officers who abuse prisoners and, more worryingly, a larger minority of staff who don't abuse prisoners but who don't blow the whistle on those who do.'

Twenty-seven prison officers from the Scrubs - around 10 per cent of the workforce - face criminal charges for violence against inmates. 'In some parts of the prison there was a culture of violence and it has to be eradicated,' said Narey. 'The segregation unit was clearly an evil place.'

He described as 'devastating' last year's report on the Scrubs by Chief Inspector of Prisons Sir David Ramsbotham. He repeated his promise to resign if things did not improve in a prison that he said acted as a symbol for the whole service. 'I acknowledge that the Home Secretary would be entitled to be concerned about my stewardship of the service if I couldn't rise to a challenge as serious as Wormwood Scrubs,' he said.

Inspectors at Wormwood Scrubs and Wandsworth found high levels of violence and described a mafia-like culture among officers. However, Narey said the fault lay with managers rather than the Prison Officers' Association. 'If you give a trade union the scope to protect its members at the expense of prisoners you shouldn't be surprised when they do just that,' he said, adding that the POA had been instrumental in helping turn around the two prisons.

But he revealed that senior members of the prison service had already drawn his attention to a culture of violence at Portland young offenders institution on the south coast. 'I was distressed at what I found there, especially in the treatment of under-18s,' said Narey. 'There was a very militaristic air about the place. The conditions in which young people were living and the bleakness of the cells were unacceptable.'

Frances Crook of the Howard League for Penal Reform said: 'His comments bring attention to the macho culture of bullying that pervades the whole system. But his tenure will be judged on how much the system is changed.' The Howard League is demanding a full inquiry into allegations of violence against young prisoners at Portland prison.

Speaking on the first anniversary of his appointment as director general of the prison service, Narey said he had been deeply impressed by private sector prisons he had visited this year and believed they could provide a more cost-effective option to public sector control.

A clearly difficult first year had been punctuated by areas of positive news, such as the fall in rates of drug misuse due to random testing and improvements in levels of literacy and numeracy.

He would be astonished, he said, if inspectors, who returned to Wormwood Scrubs last week, did not record 'very significant improvements'. Prisoners now spend more time out of the cells and attend classes in an education department that was 'near moribund' last year.

POA spokesman Brian Caton said last night: 'If there are people who abuse prisoners then they should be weeded out. But the real problem is the erosion of the authority of officers.'

webTitle: Ministry man tops music's power list

fields.headline: Ministry man tops music's power list
fields.trailText: An old Etonian who once lent Peter Mandelson his chauffeur-driven Rover has been voted the most powerful man in dance music, beating chart star Fatboy Slim and celebrity DJ Pete Tong.
fields.body:
An old Etonian who once lent Peter Mandelson his chauffeur-driven Rover has been voted the most powerful man in dance music, beating chart star Fatboy Slim and celebrity DJ Pete Tong.

James Palumbo, 36, is more Beethoven than Basement Jaxx, yet the owner of south London's Ministry of Sound night club has toppled Tong from the number one spot in Muzik magazine's survey of dance music's pantheon. 'It shows how much dance music has grown up,' says editor Dave Fowler. 'People who used to work on pirate radio are now the top DJs.'

The list is a vivid illustration of the transformation of a youth subculture into the mainstream - and into big business. The table features few women or black people, and half the top 10 are connected to Radio 1. 'Dance music is not a subculture anymore - the charts are dominated by club music,' says James Barton, founder of the influential club Cream in Liverpool, and No 2 on the list.

Palumbo's club accounts for less than 5 per cent of the company's turnover. His power comes from his record label interests - the million-selling compilation series and a spate of innovative joint ventures that tempted top executives from the major record labels to head five new independents. Last year these labels were responsible for 15 top 20 hits.

Club culture has now taken over at Radio 1. Five of its DJs feature in the Musik top 20 and have massive influence over the record-buying public. All have complementary outside interests, ranging from Pete Tong's directorship at a record company to Dave Pearce's tabloid newspaper column. 'If I'm hot on a record, I'll break it in on the radio, in clubs and in the Sun . I have powers of persuasion,' says Pearce, No 5 on the list. Trevor Nelson, at No 6, a Radio 1 DJ and MTV presenter, is one of just three black people on the power list. Fowler says: 'At a grassroots level dance music is multi-racial. At a power level it isn't.'

Palumbo is now about to launch into e-commerce. This could see the Ministry's value, already more than £100m, soar in advance of a possible flotation. He recently sat on the Government's millennium products and charter mark committees and some suggest he will soon make a move into politics. A ministry in Whitehall perhaps?

fields.headline: Singles fall for seduction school
fields.standfirst: On the eve of Valentine's Day, John Arlidge  reports on the latest aid to finding a mate: classes in flirtation, from dilated pupils to pointing feet
fields.trailText: On the eve of Valentine's Day, John Arlidge  reports on the latest aid to finding a mate: classes in flirtation, from dilated pupils to pointing feet.
fields.body:
Julie tiptoes her way to the bar and reaches inside the jacket of 'that cute guy'. She finds the label, fixes him with her blue eyes and gushes: 'Just checking you were made in heaven.'

The stranger grins a grin so wide it threatens to disfigure his face. It won't be long before Julie has a phone number and a date for St Valentine's Day tomorrow.

As Valentine's Day approaches, sad singles are enrolling on Flirting Safaris to learn how to find a mate. The evening classes, run by the Midlands-based firm 2meetyou, teach 'basic flirting skills' in real life pick-up joints.

Surveys show that seven out of 10 Britons cannot recognise even the most obvious flirty signals and a staggering 90 per cent cannot tell if someone fancies them. Joy Penzer, who runs 2meetyou, says simple tips like how you sit, make eye contact, even where your feet point, can make the difference between finding love and going home alone.

Bar 44, between Bentley Furnishings and Spicy Nights Takeaway in Leamington Spa, may not look like the jungle of love but Penzer says it is ideal for safaris. 'Look around. There are single men and women everywhere. Are they engaging or are they simply setting up barriers? Every move says something. What I am trying to do is help people spot the signs that say "I fancy you" and how to react.'

Sarah, 33, a healthcare worker from Tredington, near Stratford-on-Avon, is a keen pupil at the school for seduction. She has already attended a couple of Flirting for Fun day courses run by Penzer and immediately goes to work on a guy she already knows and has 'fancied for some time'. A couple of hours later she has a date.

'I did everything I had learnt. I listened closely to him, asked him more about himself, looked into his eyes to see if his pupils were dilating, whether he was matching and mirroring my movements - holding his hand that way, his drink that way, pointing his feet at me.'

'He asked me if I had ever considered having another relationship. I said there was one person who I would consider. "Who?" he asked. "Actually," I said, "it's you." He looked amazed and asked me out.'

Although she says women are better flirts than men, Penzer insists they still have a lot to learn. 'Every girl dreams that some knight is going to sweep her off her feet, but that kind of stuff just does not happen. You have to make yourself desirable.

'You can't go round flopping everything out. That's yuk, hideous. Like you are on heat. Flirting is a delicate skill and the more you practise the better you become.'

As All Saints coo 'Voulez-vous coucher avec moi?' on the stereo, Dave is beginning to behave like a flirtophobe on Viagra. 'He's really pissed and he just came over and said "I'm leaving now girls", like we would follow him. As if,' complained Alison, a 23-year-old student.

'Why can't guys just come over like normal people and ask if they can join us, buy us a cocktail. I like the Del Boy ones with lots of umbrellas. When a bloke sends one of those over, it really breaks the ice.'

Rob, in the blue pinstripe suit, paisley tie and brogues, is a Safari virgin. His seven-year marriage broke up three years ago and he is 'learning how to be single again'.

He heard about Penzer at a dining club and decided to pay the £50 fee and go on safari. 'I am an engineer. Most of the people I work with are men. I am heterosexual. Women engineers tend to be a bit dry.

'I've been going on blind dates for the last couple of years. Sometimes I thought I had been struck by lightning, but in fact I was just struck by lust.'

He did not get lucky in Bar 44 last week but he is convinced that he will soon be fluent in the fine art of flirting. So what will he be doing on Monday night? 'I'll be raising a toast to Valentines to come.'

How to trap your prey

Women

Witch is out. Wench is in.

Cluster your movements - look, look away, look back, smile, touch your hair and turn your body towards him. Look at your feet then look back at him. Gaze from his eye to his lower lip.

If he smiles, move on to the intimate gaze - all the way down and back up again. Then smile again.

Peep - make frequent short eye contact.

Show vulnerability. Men like to step in and take charge.

Keep a proud posture. Sitting up straight shows confidence.

Work on that 20-Marlboro-a-day voice - but not the 20-a-day look.

Smile, simper, twinkle and flatter.

Men

Open your body. Put one hand on your hip and one hand in your pocket.

Be well groomed. Wear something touchy. Women can't resist.

If you get tongue-tied, apologise and play the little boy lost.

Don't chew gum. You may think it looks cool, but it distorts your face and most men don't close their mouth when they eat.

Believe you are a hero. Really occupy your personal space.

Don't invade her space - stay at least three feet away in the 'social zone' until you are confident. Then move to arm's length.

Don't touch unless she touches you first.

Listen to her.

webTitle: Filling - but it's not a patch on real chips

fields.headline: Filling - but it's not a patch on real chips
fields.trailText: An electronic 'food' patch is being developed that, when worn like a nicotine patch, could satisfy hunger for at least 24 hours without the wearer having to chew or swallow anything.
fields.body:
An electronic 'food' patch is being developed that, when worn like a nicotine patch, could satisfy hunger for at least 24 hours without the wearer having to chew or swallow anything.

A silicon chip in the patch would assess dietary needs and then activate a micro-electrical system to transmit the nutrients required into the bloodstream. Electronic impulses would be used to open the skin pores on the arm through which the nutrients would be pumped directly into the blood capillaries.

Called the Transdermal Nutrient Delivery System, the patch is being developed by the US military. Initially it is targeted at soldiers operating in extreme conditions where eating food is too difficult or impractical. The soldiers would be able to remain in peak condition without leaving the battlefield.

Gerald Darsch, the joint project's director at the US Department of Defence, said: 'The patches would be used during periods of high-intensity conflicts. But it is not intended that they ever replace a turkey dinner with all the trimmings.'

Darsch explained that the patch's ingredients could also include chemicals which fool a hungry person's brain into believing his or her stomach is full. Other chemicals could help reduce stress, tiredness and muscle fatigue.

Dr Patrick Dunne, of the department's combat feeding programme, said the patch would have civilian uses. He was talking to private companies about developing products for a wider market.

They are most likely to be used by people in hazardous jobs, such as fire fighting, where eating can be impossible. There are plans for them to be used by astronauts on space walks and they would be useful for mountaineers, explorers or aid workers.

Food experts can see the patch's potential as a diet aid or for busy executives. But celebrity chef Antony Worrall-Thompson reacted with horror.

'There is more to healthy eating than simply the nutrients and vitamins that the food contains - the textures, the aromas and the pleasure of chewing... not to mention the company.'

webTitle: London and Dublin in rift on IRA

fields.headline: London and Dublin in rift on IRA
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A serious rift has emerged between the Irish and British Governments over whether the IRA has really shifted its position over disarmament, following the dramatic reimposition of direct rule from London.
fields.body:
A serious rift has emerged between the Irish and British Governments over whether the IRA has really shifted its position over disarmament, following the dramatic reimposition of direct rule from London.

British governmental officials believe Sinn Fein's claim of a last-minute breakthrough on Friday night was a tactical ploy and does not reflect any genuine change in the IRA's position.

They are also angry that General John de Chastelain, chairman of the independent decommissioning body, came under intense pressure from Dublin to write an optimistic second report on his discussions with the IRA.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, yesterday rounded furiously on Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson, accusing him of bad faith and of siding with unionism to protect the political position of David Trimble, the First Minister.

At 8pm on Friday, Dublin even urged Tony Blair to rescind the suspension of the Northern Ireland Executive which was due to come into force at midnight. The British Prime Minister refused, saying the latest statements from the IRA given to De Chastelain lacked the necessary clarity about a timetable for decommissioning.

The Irish Prime Minister, Bertie Ahern, told Blair that the IRA statement marked a breakthough, because it was the first time the IRA had set out the context in which it would decommission.

The two governments are also at loggerheads over whether the North-South bodies can be suspended. Adams claimed he had informed the British 12 hours before Friday's 5pm suspension of the Executive that a breakthrough from the IRA was imminent. He claimed Irish officials working through Thursday night were informed of the breakthrough at 4.30am. He added that he told Blair at midday. Further details were given to Mandel son in a phone conversation at 3pm, two hours before the Northern Ireland Secretary stuck to the 5pm deadline.

Adams went public with his breakthrough minutes after the 5pm deadline, so conveying the impression that the British had acted precipitately. But British sources said that, in his phone call with Mandelson, Adams had given no indication of a breakthrough, nor in subsequent discussions with Blair. They added that during the Belfast all-night session between Sinn Fein, the IRA and Dublin, different papers were produced but their status was never clear.

'We did not know if they were drafts, the IRA view, whether the IRA would say this to De Chastelain, or whether De Chastelain would be allowed by the IRA to put them into his report,' a source said.

In talks with De Chastelain on Friday, the IRA said it would decommission 'in the context of the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement and the removal of the causes of conflict'.

However, the statement did not set out the IRA view of the causes of the conflict, so leav ing the timetable for decommissioning up in the air. Mandelson had settled on suspension on Friday as the only way of preventing Trimble from resigning as leader of the Ulster Unionists.

Trimble, speaking after a meeting of the 800-strong Ulster Unionist Council, said yesterday that his party would not rejoin the Executive without clear undertakings from the IRA.

webTitle: A patron saint for a people without flags

fields.headline: A patron saint for a people without flags
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: 'I refuse to hand over St Patrick to the Roman Catholic Church, or to the embrace of the Pope and the IRA.' The Rev Ian Paisley was in vintage form at Stormont on Monday. The DUP leader was speaking in one of the last debates in the now suspended assembly, supporting a call for St Patrick's Day to be made a public holiday in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
'I refuse to hand over St Patrick to the Roman Catholic Church, or to the embrace of the Pope and the IRA.' The Rev Ian Paisley was in vintage form at Stormont on Monday. The DUP leader was speaking in one of the last debates in the now suspended assembly, supporting a call for St Patrick's Day to be made a public holiday in Northern Ireland.

The motion was proposed by Kieran McCarthy of the Alliance Party, who believes it is high time for the people of Northern Ireland to share in the celebrations which take place in Dublin and New York and other cities across the world.

At the moment, 17 March is a bank holiday in the Province, but the fact that it is not an official public holiday means that the labouring classes 'simply have to plod on'.

Not all of Paisley's supporters shared his enthusiasm for celebrating Ireland's patron saint. Sammy Wilson of the DUP argued that 'no self-respecting Protestant would take part in a St Patrick's Day parade'. But the mood of the debate was good-humoured and the assembly voted overwhelmingly for the motion, and for an amendment that the Union Flag should be flown from public buildings on 17 March. It seemed an ecumenical compromise, reconciling the symbols of both traditions and thus thoroughly worthy of the hopes which were vested, for 72 days, in the new assembly.

There have been other signals of the unionist community's desire to reclaim St Patrick as a patron saint for both sides. In Derry last week, the Apprentice Boys, closely identified with unionist history, announced a programme of events for St Patrick's Day weekend.

Alistair Simpson, the governor of the Apprentice Boys, explained: 'Our aim is to reverse the Protestant community's increasing alienation from the national saint, by providing something which Protestants can feel part of and proud of.'

Not all of the celebrations for St Patrick's Day are so harmonious. In Belfast, the city council has refused to fund the carnival which takes place annually in West Belfast, on the ground that it represents only one section of the community.

The problems of marking St Patrick's Day in Northern Ireland are rooted in the old historic quarrel. Now many people want to leave this behind and have a holiday which both communities can share. At least they are not part of the kind of prejudice which mars the St Patrick's Day parade in New York.

For the past 10 years the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organisation, a group based in New York, has been fighting for the right to march, under its own banner. The route takes it up Fifth Avenue, where the marchers stop in front of St Patrick's Cathedral and are blessed by Cardinal O'Connor.

The organisers have always refused to allow the Irish gays to march, on the ground that this is a private occasion where they have the right to exclude groups and individuals of whom they do not approve. This has led to ugly confrontations between the New York Police Department (another traditional Irish American stronghold) and members of ILGO.

The row has added piquancy this year because Hillary Clinton has been invited to lead the St Patrick's parade. This has been widely seen as a tribute to the Clintons' support for the Northern Ireland peace process.

In recent years, the traditional Irish American community in New York has dispersed. But the Irish vote is still important to any Democratic candidate. A refusal by Mrs Clinton to take part in the parade would be interpreted as a snub.

There is also the gay vote to be considered. The Democratic candidate for the Senate will not want to offend gay sensibilities.

At last week's assembly debate at Stormont, one of the speakers expressed the hope that St Patrick could be a positive influence, allowing Irish people to celebrate their diversity. Maybe, some time in the future. There is a legend that on the Last Day, St Patrick will lead all the souls of Ireland to God's judgment seat.

They will include unionist and republican, Catholic and Protestant, gay and straight. The argument over decommissioning will be finally laid to rest, and there will be no flags.

webTitle: England ugly and grey, say tourist guides

fields.headline: England ugly and grey, say tourist guides
fields.trailText: England's  'green and pleasant' land has never looked so tatty. After London was dismissed as 'squalid' by one tourism guide last week, a rival book to be published this week dismisses some of England's best-loved villages and towns as mean, cold, ugly, clapped-out dumps.
fields.body:
England's 'green and pleasant' land has never looked so tatty. After London was dismissed as 'squalid' by one tourism guide last week, a rival book to be published this week dismisses some of England's best-loved villages and towns as mean, cold, ugly, clapped-out dumps.

Authors of the new Rough Guide to England say their book reveals the country 'as we found it, in all its tatty glory'.

The West Yorkshire village of Haworth - home of the Brontë sisters - is 'wretchedly over-visited'. The whole county of Northamptonshire is dismissed as 'somewhere you pass through on the way to somewhere else'.

The Cotswolds is 'afflicted by plagues of tea-and- souvenir shops'. Blackpool is full of 'predatory half-dressed gangs' of stag and hen parties. And although nothing can completely destroy the beauty of Land's End, the Rough Guide says, 'the colossal theme park built behind the majestic headland in 1987 comes close to violating irreparably the spirit of the place'.

Tourism officials across England were last night firing off indignant letters of protest. They are furious at the battering leading attractions have taken in the latest crop of guidebooks which follows the recent decision by France's top gourmands to downgrade England's restaurants. Only one restaurant now enjoys the coveted three Michelin stars - compared with 21 in France.

Weston-super-Mare is 'rather moth-eaten' and Torquay, the Rough Guide judges, has taken on the persona of its most famous fictional inhabitant, Basil Fawlty, 'whose jingoism and injured pride perfectly encapsulate the town's adaptation to the upper-class image'.

The Isle of Man is a 'tax haven for greedy Brits and a refuge for the sort of people who think that even Victorian values were a bit on the lax side'.

Other attractions given health warnings include England's beach resorts, 'far too many of which', the authors point out, 'fail to meet EU pollution standards'.

Even the favourite subject of English conversation - the weather - is lampooned. Visitors are warned that the term 'bracing' is really a northern euphemism for 'stinging cold'. The authors add: 'Considering the temperateness of the English climate, it's amazing how much mileage the locals get out of the subject.'

Last night some of the towns ridiculed in the guide defended themselves. George Bancroft, deputy leader of Blackpool Borough Council, admitted the resort had a cer tain 'brash charm' but insisted much was being done to improve what the book described as its 'highly debatable' sea water qualities.

'Beauty is in the eye of the beholder but there's no doubt about it - Blackpool is in your face.'

John Arnold, the leader of Southampton City Council, said: 'Southampton is a prosperous city with a wide range of commercial activities. It is a city that's concerned with earning a living. The Rough Guides are designed for people who are making very short visits to Britain on holiday and that's their judgment.'

And although nothing can completely destroy the beauty of Land's End, the Rough Guide says, 'the colossal theme park built behind the majestic headland in 1987 comes close to violating irreparably the spirit of the place'. Tourism officials across England were last night firing off indignant letters of protest. They are furious at the battering leading attractions have taken in the latest crop of guidebooks which follows the recent decision by France's top gourmands to downgrade England's restaurants. Only one restaurant now enjoys the coveted three Michelin stars - compared with 21 in France. Weston-super-Mare is 'rather moth-eaten' and Torquay, the Rough Guide judges, has taken on the persona of its most famous fictional inhabitant, Basil Fawlty, 'whose jingoism and injured pride perfectly encapsulate the town's adaptation to the upper-class image'. The Isle of Man is a 'tax haven for greedy Brits and a refuge for the sort of people who think that even Victorian values were a bit on the lax side'. Other attractions given health warnings include England's beach resorts, 'far too many of which', the authors point out, 'fail to meet EU pollution standards'. Even the favourite subject of English conversation - the weather - is lampooned. Visitors are warned that the term 'bracing' is really a northern euphemism for 'stinging cold'. The authors add: 'Considering the temperateness of the English climate, it's amazing how much mileage the locals get out of the subject.' Last night some of the towns ridiculed in the guide defended themselves. George Bancroft, deputy leader of Blackpool Borough Council, admitted the resort had a cer tain 'brash charm' but insisted much was being done to improve what the book described as its 'highly debatable' sea water qualities. 'Beauty is in the eye of the beholder but there's no doubt about it - Blackpool is in your face.' John Arnold, the leader of Southampton City Council, said: 'Southampton is a prosperous city with a wide range of commercial activities. It is a city that's concerned with earning a living. The Rough Guides are designed for people who are making very short visits to Britain on holiday and that's their judgment.'

webTitle: Real IRA sets up wing in London

fields.headline: Real IRA sets up wing in London
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The political wing of the Real IRA, the terrorist group that carried out the Omagh bombing, yesterday established a branch in Britain,   prompting fears of a renewed republican bombing campaign in London.
fields.byline: by Denis Campbell and Tony Thompson
fields.body:
The political wing of the Real IRA, the terrorist group that carried out the Omagh bombing, yesterday established a branch in Britain, prompting fears of a renewed republican bombing campaign in London.

Francie Mackey, chairman of the 32 County Sovereignty Movement, used a secret meeting in London's Irish heartland to attack the Sinn Fein leadership for its participation in the peace process.

However, only about a dozen dissident republicans attended the invitation-only meeting in the back room of the social club of the Church of the Sacred Heart in Kilburn, north London.

The hall had been booked for 'a family reunion'. When management of the hall were alerted by The Observer to the real identity of those present, the republicans were asked to leave.

At a hastily arranged press conference in a nearby pub, Mackey castigated Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness for involving Sinn Fein in a peace process that had left 'the republican argument seriously damaged and has led to a partitionist settlement'.

Sinn Fein's involvement had resulted in 'the damaging of a just and honourable movement and a just and honourable cause', said Mackey, who split from Sinn Fein in November 1997.

Mackey, who was arrested by police after the Omagh bombing in August 1998 that left 29 dead and hundreds injured, refused to condemn the use of violence. 'True republicans should concentrate on building a movement that will force the British Government to relinquish their illegal claim to sovereignty over part of Ireland.'

Mary Palmer, manageress of the social club, was furious that she had been duped and the hall had been used for political reasons. 'We were told that it was a family gathering. I am outraged. This place is used for baptisms and weddings and lies at the heart of the community.'

The parish priest, the Rev Paschal Dillon, knew nothing about the booking either.

fields.headline: Rip-off Britain 'is a myth'
fields.trailText: The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, was accused this weekend of falsely undermining consumer confidence in British products and shops. The Shadow Trade and Industry Secretary, Angela Browning, said the Government's own international price comparison, published in full today for the first time, explodes 'rip-off Britain' as a myth.
fields.body:
The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, was accused this weekend of falsely undermining consumer confidence in British products and shops. The Shadow Trade and Industry Secretary, Angela Browning, said the Government's own international price comparison, published in full today for the first time, explodes 'rip-off Britain' as a myth.

The results of the £100,000 study show that - with eight exceptions such as Coca-Cola and CDs - the prices of commonly-bought goods are 'broadly similar' in the UK, France, Germany and the United States.

Browning said: 'Labour Ministers, among them the Prime Minister, Gordon Brown and Stephen Byers, have leapt on the "rip off Britain" bandwagon because it is a convenient soundbite.

'It now seems that they have made a grave miscalculation and in so doing undermined confidence among consumers in British goods and services.'

But Byers, the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, said the intense spotlight turned on retailers by the Government and the media was largely responsible for the favourable results.

He credited 'people power' with wiping £500 million off British high street prices and accelerating the demise of 'rip-off Britain'. He said a cultural shift among traditionally mild-mannered British shoppers had forced UK prices down.

But the basket of goods checked - from milk to computer games - shows that prices are still on average 5 per cent lower in France and Germany and 15 per cent lower in America. 'We should not underestimate how much we are paying,' said Byers.

He warned retailers: 'We are going to study very carefully why these areas are significantly higher and why the British consumer is paying significantly over the odds. If there is no good reason I have the power to refer [cases] to the Director-General for Fair Trading for more detailed investigation. I am prepared to use that.'

The price gap would have been bigger, but retailers began slashing prices in March last year, he explained. 'I happen to believe this was a response to consumers becoming far more assertive about the products they were prepared to buy and the prices they were prepared to pay. There has been a real change in the culture of shoppers in the UK.'

Researchers from AC Nielsen compared 10,649 prices from 330 shops in London, Manchester, Paris, Lyons, Hamburg, Dusseldorf, Atlanta and Chicago.

Retailers seized on the fact that just 56 of the 106 items on the DTI's original wish-list were included in the final comparison. This is because the other products could not be compared accurately on a like-for-like basis. Retailers said this vindicated their claims that price differences are due to factors outside their control, such as taxes, distribution costs and rents.

Byers' pledge to study the reasons behind any price differentials was 'good news', said the British Retail Consortium's acting director-general, Mark Bradshaw.

The eight items that cost less everywhere else were the Sega Dreamcast (most expensive in the UK at £200.12, and cheapest in the US at £132.26); the top 10 CDs, a two litre bottle of Coke, tinned dog food, a can of lager, shampoo, ground coffee and a four-roll pack of toilet tissue.

Byers added: 'If you have washed your hair and settled down to listen to a CD, just fed the dog, been to the toilet and are about to drink Coca-Cola, lager or coffee you probably are being ripped off.'

fields.headline: Big Ben is watching you
fields.standfirst: MPs have to work somewhere. But surely even they deserve something better than the refurbished Portcullis House in Westminster
fields.trailText: MPs have to work somewhere. But surely even they deserve something better than the refurbished Portcullis House in Westminster.
fields.body:
The best way for Members of Parliament to get to their new offices in Portcullis House, the latest and most conspicuous extension to the Palace of Westminster, is to take the Jubilee Line to its very own Tube station. And not just because it keeps them in touch with their constituents. By train, they can get to their specially designed desks without so much as a glimpse of the exterior of the building. So, instead of being confronted by one of London's most disappointing new architectural experiences, they will surface in the middle of one of its most exceptional public spaces.

As they step off the platform, they will find themselves at the foot of a soaring, vaulted interior, very much like a fragment of the atrium of the Lloyds building, sunk 10 floors down into the ground. High above them, sitting on a spider's web of concrete beams, is Portcullis House itself. Banks of escalators, supported on grey steel trusses, and slung between polished concrete columns slide diagonally back and forth across the void. It is one of the most spectacular and generously proportioned Underground stations in the world.

But if MPs turn up by car, from across Westminster Bridge, or on foot from Parliament Square, they will get to see more than enough of Portcullis House, the overcooked, confused tip of an otherwise impressive iceberg. An iceberg that has shouldered its way into the middle of London's most beautiful riverside site, between Big Ben and Norman Shaw's original Scotland Yard. Supple, disciplined, and distinguished below ground, Westminster Station is everything that Portcullis House is not.

Extraordinarily, both are the product of the same architect - Michael Hopkins. With the south stand at Lord's, the opera house at Glyndebourne and the tax office at Nottingham under his belt, Hopkins is one of Britain's most skilled and successful architects. As a one-time associate of Norman Foster, he has an unassailable pedigree as a designer of deft modern architecture. But more recently he has assumed something of the mantle of the late Hugh Casson, semi-official architect to the establishment, reckoned to be a safe pair of hands when it comes to dealing with sensitive sites and highly charged public commissions.

Portcullis House is certainly both of these. It is also one of London's great architectural lost opportunities. It tries to be simultaneously sensitive to context and 'interestingly' contemporary. In so doing, it manages to be neither. The most conspicuous and jarring element for what is, after all, at heart an office block, is the forest of tubular steel chimneys ranged in great black rows on the skyline. Compared to the delicate stone pinnacles of Pugin and Barry's Westminster, which they forlornly hope to evoke, the chimneys are heavy handed and intimidating. They suggest nothing so much as the soot-streaked smoke stacks of a Victorian engine shed. The effect is heightened by clusters of what look like smoke ducts which slope diagonally toward each chimney. From a distance, these ducts make it look as if the roof is in the grip of a pair of giant, four-fingered hands attempting to prise off the top floor.

As architecture, it is blunt, even bloody-minded, and if only Hopkins had left it at that, it might have come off. But he seems to have lost his nerve halfway through and attempted to pretty up the elevations to ingratiate passers-by. Protruding from the attic storey downward are row upon row of dormer windows, each of them topped by a stainless steel flap.

They look like nothing so much as the gun ports of a man o' war, ready to unleash a broadside at Big Ben. Both these elements are, one hopes, the product of Hopkins's laudable concern for environmentally responsible architecture. The flaps are presumably there to cut down on solar gain and the chimneys are part of a natural ventilation system, rather than an alibi for an architect who belongs to the generation that believed ornament was crime and who now wants a way to smuggle in a bit of decoration. But even if that is so, it's a case of the tail wagging the dog. There is no reason for a green building to display its greenness so blatantly.

Portcullis House has been 30 years in the making. The first step in its gestation was an architectural competition won in 1972 by Robin Spence and Robin Webster, to find a way of accommodating an army of MPs without offices. They came up with a scheme that would have been as radical as a Pompidou Centre transplanted to the centre of London, a steel-and-glass box hoisted up to leave the ground open and accessible to the public, with giant TV screens relaying parliamentary debates to the street. It was too much for parliamentarians, even if they were desperate for a desk of their own. The scheme's opponents seized on the 1973 oil crisis with relief - this was no time to be seen spending lots of money on well-upholstered politicians - and they killed it off.

But the accommodation shortage, the product of a Parliament in which MPs were expected to maintain a career outside the House and operate from the corridors and the lobbies, would not go away. Casson was brought in for advice on what to do. He took the chance to design a scheme for the entire block, stretching all the way from the river to Whitehall, that mixed new building with refurbishment. Only part of it was executed, and Hopkins was eventually brought in to design something with a little more presence on Victoria Embankment.

Hopkins is an ex-modernist now. He was shocked by the planners' rejection of his attempt to demolish the postwar Bracken House under the shadow of St Paul's. Without skipping a beat, he came back with a scheme that retained part of the structure, and developed a new approach to architectural context. He turned his gaze to a mannerist palazzo in Turin, and half-closed his eyes so as to come up with a paraphrase of the complexities of historic buildings in London.

Unlikely as it sounds, it worked well enough for Bracken House, and for a while it became the received wisdom that the 'half-closed eye' trick was the best way to develop new buildings in sensitive areas. With any luck, Portcullis House will finally kill off that particular architectural strategy.

In Westminster, the context is Norman Shaw's boldly modelled New Scotland Yard, half baroque brickwork, half Scots baronial turrets and chimneys. Hopkins duly responded with a stripped, restless façade, with a steep, pitched roof, a profusion of what might be chimneys, a façade that includes honey-coloured stone, interrupted by distracting stripes and dots, and an awkward arcade at street level.

Rather than live up to its magnificent setting, however, Portcullis House lays bare the emptiness of the approach. To make a new building that looks like a crude model of an old one does nothing to minimise its impact. And because Portcullis House crowds into so many of the historic views of Westminster from across the river and even into Parliament Square itself, it ends up looking both embarrassed and embarrassing.

Parliamentary buildings are never an easy commission for an architect. There is simply too much at stake. They are used to make big symbolic statements about how a country or a city sees itself. The competition to build the Victorian Houses of Parliament, for example, insisted on Tudor or Gothic as the national style. Now Edinburgh's Parliament, designed by the Catalan Enric Miralles, is a nod to the prosperity and dynamism of Barcelona as a model for the new Scotland. But the politicians in Edinburgh have got even more hung up on the shape of the chamber.

They have a touching belief that Westminster-style debating chambers somehow encourage confrontation, unlike those of our allegedly gentler partners in mainland Europe with semi-circular chambers. Miralles had constantly to redesign his chamber to meet this search for harmony by the Scots, who seem to have overlooked the constant outbreaks of fist-fights and worse that take place in circular parliamentary debating chambers.

At the same time, architects have become obsessed with the idea of transparency, which means glass as a means of putting democracy on show. It's the model for both Norman Foster's London Assembly, the seat for the new Mayor, and for Richard Rogers's Welsh Assembly in Cardiff. But at least none of these will be quite so overwhelmed by a building as conspicuously bureaucratic as Portcullis House.

webTitle: Watch out Today - Five Live will eat you for breakfast

fields.headline: Watch out Today - Five Live will eat you for breakfast
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Give me a child before he is seven, a Jesuit priest used to say, and he's mine for life. Radio works on much the same principle. Give a station your attention between 6am and 9am and the chances of your staying loyal to it for the rest of the day are that much higher.
fields.body:
Give me a child before he is seven, a Jesuit priest used to say, and he's mine for life. Radio works on much the same principle. Give a station your attention between 6am and 9am and the chances of your staying loyal to it for the rest of the day are that much higher.

Take Radio Five Live. According to the latest Rajar (Radio Joint Audience Ratings) figures, half a million new listeners did just that last year, the biggest recorded increase ever. The Five Live breakfast show has won umpteen awards and is now compulsory early-bird listening for the younger, sportier, chattering classes. Two million tune in to hear Five Live Breakfast presenters Julian Worricker and Victoria Derbyshire banter between news, sport, traffic updates and general chitchat about whether Marmite makes your breath smell or the time that tennis reporter got stuck in a lift with Anna Kournikova, lucky devil.

Hidden away on unfashionable medium waves, you have to twiddle long and hard to find Five Live. How much Nicky Campbell's popularity is due to the head start he gets from the Breakfast show - he hosts the 9am phone-in directly after - is hard to gauge; he certainly doesn't lose by it. Five Up, Four Down was the popular consensus when new Radio 4 controller James Boyle announced his controversial changes in April 1998, resulting in plummeting ratings immediately afterwards.

The Today programme was no exception. In its Timpson-Redhead heyday, it boasted eight million listeners and carried serious political clout. When a Today producer snapped his fingers, Cabinet Ministers jostled to get to the headsets first. But Boyle's new, extended version of Today was criticised by furious listeners for abandoning the broadcast equivalent of broadsheet journalism and replacing it with tabloid trash.

Had the Today editors followed Boyle's original brief, the programme would probably sound uncomfortably like Five Live Breakfast - uncomfortable because John Humphrys, James Naughtie and Sue MacGregor are not Julian W and Victoria D. Like Ishiguru's butler, they find bantering difficult. Boyle wanted them to gossip with the weathergirl and chummy up to the newscaster, but these are serious political animals and proud of it. And like their listeners, they are older - the average age of a Today listener is 54 compared to Five Live's 25 to 49 target audience.

MacGregor, Humphrys and Naughtie know what their listeners want to know about at seven in the morning, and it isn't the merits or otherwise of being stuck in a lift with Anna Kournikova. (Interviewing an Italian football manager the other day about the pros and cons of players having sex before a big match, Humphrys just could not bring himself to use the obvious terminology - sex, bonk, how's yer father; 'indulging in, er, um, a little amorous activity' was the best he could do.)

The fact that, despite Boyle's tinkering, Today 's audience is now six million and climbing is clear proof that it's listeners who phone and e-mail the programme in their hundreds every day want it exactly the way it is - rolling news, hard-hitting interviews, in-depth foreign news coverage and not too much sports or arts. Above all, the programme operates on the built-in assumption that it is broadcasting to an intelligent audience, so they don't have to say Cairo, Egypt.

Today 's present editor, Rod Liddle, wants to distance the programme still further from the dumbing-down criticism; he wants more investigative journalism, more stories like the one about the young woman who smeared Nick Brown's face with an eclair: it was the Today news sleuth who revealed that she had been advised by publicist Max Clifford. The acid test will come when Humphrys and MacGregor, both heading towards retirement age, have to be replaced. It won't be easy filling any of their Hush Puppies.

If it really is the early-morning show that attracts and keeps radio listeners, BBC breakfasts are proving more digestible than those served up by their independent rivals. More people listen to BBC radio than to all the commercial stations put together. Five and a half million TOGs (Terry's Old Geezers) tune in to Wake Up With Wogan on Radio 2 every morning. fields.headline: Truly, madly, Ripley
fields.standfirst: The Talented Mr Ripley is hotly tipped for the Oscars. Its director explains why he believes that there's a little bit of Patricia Highsmith's murderous hero in all of us...
fields.trailText: The Talented Mr Ripley is hotly tipped for the Oscars. Its director explains why he believes that there's a little bit of Patricia Highsmith's murderous hero in all of us...
fields.body:
Just after I graduated from university, I was commissioned to write a small play for a local theatre company. The opportunity came on the back of a fledgling excursion into writing when, as a student, I had sufficient hubris to present a musical, which I also directed, acted and sang in. I cringe at the thought of it.

Nevertheless, playwright Alan Plater, then chairman of the theatre company, saw enough in my crude efforts to give me the chance to work with professional actors. I duly wrote the play and directed it. My chief memory of the experience was at an early performance on tour in Grimsby, where our audience comprised mainly elderly coach parties.

The play began with a bleak monologue in the dark. I thought it extremely dramatic. After a few minutes, the audience felt moved to complain noisily of what they assumed was an electrical failure. Then they proceeded to head for the exit. Alan's programme notes described the play as being in the spirit of Patricia Highsmith. I had never heard of Highsmith, but thought I should find some of her work. The book I stumbled across concerned the exploits of a young American living in Europe called Tom Ripley.

Almost 20 years later, Sydney Pollack, another mentor, asked me to adapt The Talented Mr Ripley for his company. At that time, I was marooned in my attempts to make The English Patient and felt - on the basis of my one, specious, and not entirely auspicious connection to the author - that it might be something to consider.

In the Ripley novels, of which The Talented Mr Ripley is the first, a person can live or die, sometimes literally, on the strength of their choice of cocktail. Taste is everything. Highsmith rarely describes the physical geography, eschews adjectives, sketches out a moment in impatient and irritable prose. There seems little distance between her own baleful view of the world and that of her protagonist's, who travels through a handful of novels, behaving badly, never caught.

You enter into an airless, claustrophobic world with Tom Ripley. Almost no other character is fully alive, and his cool, dislocated perspective lures the reader in, convincing us that what objectively might be heinous makes perfect sense inside Ripley's head. The world, experienced through this skinless sensibility, is an alarming place - Ripley feels so intensely, can be giddy with excitement or despair. He is always an outsider, straining for companionship but destined to be alone.

His actions are an extreme response to emotions all of us recognise: the sense that there is a better life being lived by somebody else, somewhere else, someone not trapped inside the hollow existence in which we find ourselves. It's one of the things which makes us human. We've all been Tom Ripley, just as we've all known a Dickie Greenleaf, the man who has everything, whose attention makes us feel special. We've all basked in the sunshine of that attention and felt the chill of losing it.

It was this unsettling connection to Ripley and the anxiety that what happens to him is familiar, at least in nightmares, that prompted me to make this film. Not the empathy for a hero, but the queasy recognition that this plausible misfit is not so far from one version of ourselves; not approval but an acknowledgment that this is where we might end up without the reassuringly tight belt of morality around our waists.

In adapting the novel to film lay the challenge of exciting the audience to commit to the material as I did as a reader, to inhabit each step of Ripley's journey. Adaptation for film is, by definition, a process of editorialising. The dramatist is obliged to make innumerable decisions - what is the book about? How will it fit into the prescribed length of a movie? How to dramatise the secret thoughts the novelist can describe but the film can only suggest; where to begin; how to end; how to collect the tone of the prose.

The answer to these questions must inevitably speak as loudly about the preoccupations of the film-maker as they do about the contingent issues of phrasing the material and organising the story for a film audience. Part of the business of reading is to create an inner cinema on which the events play out. And we can be sure that for each reader the film is different. Adaptation is, finally, sharing one's inner cinema with an audience - this is how it felt to me; this is what I thought I was reading. The dramatist becomes an enthusiastic messenger, bringing news from somewhere else, remembering the best bits, exaggerating the beauty, relishing the mystery, probing the moral imperative, watching for gasps or tears, orchestrating them and, ideally, prompting the captive cinema audience to make the pilgrimage back to the book, which remains blessedly itself.

But as Italo Calvino said of storytelling, the tale is not beautiful if nothing is added to it. The demands of film are also a release, enabling the writer to emphasise and mute by turns. The screenplay is both an argument with the source material and a commentary on it. The uninflected brilliance of Highsmith's novel, its disavowal of moral consequence, Ripley's solipsism, the author's acerbic judgment of everybody other than Ripley, the book's heavy employment of devices - letters, coincidences - do not sit easily within the context of film.

But if the intimate gestures of a novel, its private conversation between writer and reader, are not available to the film-maker, they are exchanged for other, equally powerful, tools. Film grammar, with its unique ability to manipulate images, flexing from the intense close-up to the broadest vistas, is perfectly placed to situate personal behaviour in a public landscape. It can contextualise action, remind us that we are as individuals in thrall quite literally to the bigger picture.

'This was the clean slate he had thought about on the boat crossing over from America. This was the real annihilation of his past and himself, Tom Ripley, who was made up of that past, and his rebirth as a completely new person.'

My reading of Ripley's isolation at the end of the novel, however much he fantasises about the freedom his lies and improvisations have earned him, is that it contains an implicit cautionary tale. What the reader knows is that Ripley's clean slate is an illusion. The rebirth is a temporary disguise and, worse, one that condemns the impostor to a constant fear of exposure.

To be uncovered as a sham is the very thing which prompts Ripley to sham in the first place. And so the film came to hinge on a central premise - Ripley's credo that it is better to be a fake somebody than a real nobody. It becomes a story about class. The novel is about a man who commits murders and is not caught. And so the film is about a man who commits murders and is not caught. But it departs in one crucial sense by concluding that eluding public accountability is not the same thing as eluding justice.

The film has a moral imperative: you can get away with murder, but you don't really get away with anything. Ripley, always looking for love, has to kill his opportunity for love. He ends the movie alone, free, in a hell of his own making. Just as in Dante, where purgatory is some karmic reflection of life - flatterers pitched in manure, adulterers chasing for ever - so in annihilating self, assuming someone's identity, Ripley is condemned never to be free to be truly himself. This tragic dimension provided an architecture for the screenplay. Its ambitions were to maintain the narrative ambivalence of the novel - not telling an audience what to think, not opting for an announced moral closure, but intensifying the consequence of Ripley's actions on the soul.

Without the reassuring appearance of a judge, the audience is asked to be a jury. A number of choices stem directly from this strategy. A signal adjustment to the novel is that Ripley does not plan to kill Dickie; quite the reverse. The death scene begins with Ripley revealing the depth of his feelings for Dickie, horribly miscalculated, cruelly rejected. Dickie dies in an eruption of rage and it is his own capacity for violence which exacerbates a reflexive swing of an oar into a do-or-die struggle. It's an accident which provides Ripley with a defining opportunity.

And, as so often in this story, it's an opportunity he seizes as much in shame as in calculation. His journey to purgatory begins with the borrowing of a jacket, because he doesn't possess a decent one of his own. It continues, for what he feels are the same reasons, with the borrowing of an identity.

Peter Smith-Kingsley, mentioned only in passing in the novel, becomes a fully-fledged character in the film. His acceptance of Ripley suggested itself as a required irony, a way of dramatising what Highsmith called the annihilation of Ripley's past and himself; in killing Peter he murders his own chance of happiness. Peter, the most centred character in the film, also serves as a reminder that Ripley's pathology is not explained by his sexuality. Similarly, Herbert Greenleaf's relationship with Dickie developed into a crucial strand. The film's mechanism of lies and escape depends on a father's lack of faith in his son, a prejudgment that makes him incapable of seeing Ripley's hand in what has happened. In this way, Ripley can appear to be the better version of Dickie, the son Herbert wishes he had.

No one in this story sees truth in front of them because of the distortions of their own prejudices and preconceptions. Only Marge Sherwood, in a more substantive role than the novel allows, has a sufficiently uncluttered spirit to both welcome Ripley and then suspect him. But the collusion of men, such a feature of this story and of the times, undermines her. They are too busy covering up, preferring to interpret Marge's unerring radar for the truth as the misguided forensics of heartbreak.

Meredith Logue, a new character for the film, gives Ripley the chance to create his own version of Marge, just as he creates his own version of Dickie. Her presence also accentuates that this is principally a story about young people, each of whom has run away from something, making themselves up in the context of a foreign country, partners as Meredith observes giddily, in disguise . The foreign country is Italy.

For two generations before Ripley, Americans had been coming to Europe to explore issues of identity and sexuality. It's no accident that Highsmith had settled in Europe in the Fifties and would have been a contemporary of Marge and Meredith. Nor is it an accident that her book is loosely based on The Ambassadors.

The idea of the Grand Tour, of exploring the Old Country, of soaking in the culture of Europe, continues to exert an irresistible tug on American travellers long after Europe's culture has been conquered and transformed by America. Italy, a substantial character in this film, its landscape largely intact from the Renaissance paintings which celebrate it, its history as the artistic and classical heart of the Continent, has particular appeal.

'Was it, in short, ever well to be elsewhere when one might be in Italy?' wrote Edith Wharton. By locating the movie a year or two later than the novel, there was an opportunity to explore a significant moment in Italian history, where a thin veneer of the modern had glossed but could not hide the primitive mores of the country.

Italy is a place I love above all other places, but it's always possible to detect a darker note under its breezy melodies. And this dissonance seemed to speak of the film itself, apparently sybaritic, but lounging on a volcano. Mongibello, the name Highsmith gave to the fictional village on the Amalfi coast where Dickie and Marge are living, is a local name for Vesuvius.

Finally, a film called The Talented Mr Ripley had to address Ripley's talents. If Ripley is blessed and cursed by one thing, it is his ability to turn on a sixpence, to reel off the most elaborate and plausible riffs of fantasy. In identifying this, the importance of music grew in my mind, replacing the more literary motif of painting in the novel. Music for period, music for place, music for argument. And so the screenplay also became a kind of libretto, working out relationships in musical terms, pitting Dickie's identification with jazz, its mantra of freedom and existentialism, against Ripley's classicism and asserting that, just as in music, where truly great extemporising begins with Bach and Mozart, so it is Ripley who proves to be the more genuine improviser.

When I adapted The English Patient, I was accompanied on an adventure that involved wholesale reimagining of Michael Ondaatje's novel. Patricia Highsmith died as I began writing the first draft of Ripley and before I could meet her. If I were to have pleased anybody with this adaptation, I would have liked it to have been her and I worked with her own pungent words about fiction as a touchstone. She imagined Ripley sitting at the typewriter with her as she wrote her novel. I imagined her sitting with me as I wrote my screenplay.

'If a suspense writer is going to write about murderers and victims, about people in the vortex of this awful whirl of events, he must do more than describe brutality and gore. He should be interested in justice or the absence of it in the world, good and bad, and in human cowardice or courage - but not merely as forces to move his plot in one direction. In a word, his invented people must seem real.'

fields.headline: In bed with Quentin Crisp
fields.standfirst: What would you do if you found the eccentric Englishman's grubby mattress on a pavement? Miguel Adrover used it to make clothes and is now the chic name in New York fashion, writes  Tamsin Blanchard
fields.trailText: What would you do if you found the eccentric Englishman's grubby mattress on a pavement? Miguel Adrover used it to make clothes and is now the chic name in New York fashion.
fields.body:
Miguel Adrover knew Quentin Crisp like many New Yorkers 'knew' the eccentric Englishman. For eight years, he lived two apartments along from Crisp, in a light-starved basement on 3rd Street. And for eight years, they said hello to each other when they passed in the street, and nodded across the tables of the local diner they both frequented.

'It was enough just to see each other,' says Adrover. 'Sometimes, you don't have to speak to understand someone.' If Crisp were alive today, he might have put a name to the face of the long-haired Spaniard who has been hailed by the fashion press as New York's new fashion superstar. He might even have sat and watched his show, the 34-year-old designer's second.

Inside, it devoted almost two columns to the Majorcan-born, self-taught Adrover, breathlessly calling the collection 'a near-perfect expression of talent, polish and the bravado that comes of natural guts and having no retail accounts to lose'.

If Quentin Crisp had still been alive, however, the collection's pièce de résistance would not have made it on to the stark, black catwalk. Shortly after Crisp's death last year, Adrover spotted a mattress lying out on the pavement, not an unusual sight in the East Village. But it caught his eye because it was just what he was looking for.

The self-taught designer had an idea to make an outfit out of traditional mattress ticking. He wanted to make a comment on the homeless people being cleared from the streets of Manhattan by Mayor Giuliani and thought a few lengths of the stuff would be just the thing. He'd seen the fabric, but, penniless himself, didn't have the money to pay for it. And there was this abandoned mattress.

It turned out that it had once belonged to Crisp. 'It was not a nice mattress,' says Adrover. 'It was dirty and stinky. But maybe if you sleep on the same thing for years and years, you don't consider it to be dirty.'

This was a mattress that held a lot of history in its seams. So Adrover couldn't resist. He dragged it into his basement and proceeded to unpick it and salvage the fabric. He washed it about six times by hand, careful not to remove the stains and dirt completely, and set about making one layer of fabric into a jacket and the other into a skirt. The result is an extraordinary piece of clothing, stained and holey, patched-up, sad, macabre and full of emotion and life, an instant museum piece, priceless and irreplaceable.

A small pile of messy entrails from the mattress lies in a heap in the hallway leading into Adrover's tiny, windowless studio where he created his collection, called Midtown because it's where uptown New York meets downtown. He offers me a swatch, but I don't want to deprive him of a precious resource.

In New York fashion circles, where volume and sales count for everything, innovation and fashion are rarely spoken in the same breath. Puff Daddy, who made his debut as a designer at the menswear shows in the city last weekend, will sell clothes because he is a celebrity name.

Ralph Lauren will sell clothes because, well, he's good at selling clothes. And he knows how to give his name a bit of extra kudos by inviting Prince Andrew to watch his show, and by putting the pneumatic Brazilian model, Gisele, into a teeny-weeny bikini top, just to pep up those newspaper headlines.

But for bright young talent, like Adrover, and Bruce, a partnership of two friends who are also acknowledged as rising talent, business is tough. Bruce's small, focused collection, shown on shop mannequins in a low-budget hall at a Lower East Side college, was one of the few highlights of the week.

It seems that there needs to be an element of hardship for a designer to produce a collection that has any more consideration and originality to it than a Simplicity pattern. Once the money rolls in, the ideas dry up.

But the $15 Adrover claims to have in his bank account ($16 after I swapped him a dollar for one of the 300 $1 bills which he illegally stamped with the details of the show, and sent out as invitations) will not allow him to put his collection into production. He needs a backer.

Still, Crisp would certainly have appreciated Adrover's inventiveness and sense of humour - a shirt worn back to front with a tie wrapped at the nape of the neck; a pair of New York Yankees baseball caps sewn into a sweatshirt as shoulder pads, and a traditional Burberry coat made into a dress by wrapping it around the body inside out, and back to front.

'I think wherever he is, he'll be really proud. It was his spirit walking on the catwalk,' says Adrover. 'He's always been so elegant.' The mattress outfit, which Adrover will not lend out to fashion stylists unless he accompanies it to the photo shoot, was even teamed with a scarf tied at the neck, a fake Fendi bought from Canal Street, in homage to Crisp's own jaunty style.

fields.headline: I've heard that somewhere before...
fields.trailText: London Sinfonietta | Steven Herbert Smith |  Luciano Berio
fields.body:
All composers are magpies. A few, usually of the second rank, try to deny it, as if their music is an immaculate conception, unsullied by overheard tunes and half-remembered rhythms. Stravinsky, a master pilferer, famously summed the matter up: 'A good composer does not imitate, he steals.'

His words might apply to any great artist. Yet of all the arts, music is the most elusive, its effects abstract, fleeting and immeasurable in a way that words or images are not. For most of us, the connections between one composer and another are essential to our enjoyment and comprehension. How else can sound be described except by comparison?

The London Sinfonietta took Stravinsky as a starting point for a concert celebrating the idea of creative pilfering - a debate prompted by an important new study of Stravinsky by Stephen Walsh, who introduced the concert and quizzed the thieves in question - Oliver Knussen, Julian Anderson and Geoffrey King-Gomez. All freely confessed their debt. Oliver Knussen went so far as to claim he couldn't have written a single note of his music without Stravinsky (just as Stravinsky, too, he pointed out, couldn't have written the Rite of Spring without the great nineteenth-century Russians).

The centrepiece was an enthralling new work by Julian Anderson, Alhambra Fantasy. This Sinfonietta commission for 16 players (and lasting as many minutes) began with a spare, bare luminosity of the sort we associate with Stravinsky and exploded into a raucous hammering to convey imaginatively the construction of the Alhambra Palace. Anvils, cowbells and a large corrugated dustbin all contributed to the ear-ringing metallic turbulence. After a quiet, song-like passage, the music gathered force again for a jubilant, strident conclusion. This is Anderson's most freely expressive and daring work to date. Following only a week after the exciting premiere of George Benjamin's meticulous and arresting Palimpsest for the LSO, the new century already looks auspicious for British music.

Or fairly bright. If the message is alive and well, the medium can sometimes be disastrous. The bait of a two-part piano recital at St John's Smith Square was the chance to hear a compendium of recent British piano works by everyone you've heard of - Richard Rodney Bennett, James MacMillan, Michael Berkeley, Stephen Montague, Edwin Roxburgh, John Woolrich, Howard Skempton and George Benjamin. The performer was an American, Steven Herbert Smith. That he describes himself as 'an artist-professor of piano' from Penn State University and that this was his British debut even though he gave his first concert in the 1960s should have sounded warning bells. This information only became evident from the programme note, by which time one was already captive - and you do feel captive when you constitute such a large percentage of the audience. It was one of the most dispiriting events I've attended. Smith, for all his efforts, was merely a workmanlike performer who made all these quixotically different composers sound the same, a feat of insensitivity.

The BBC's Composer Portrait devoted to Luciano Berio was a cheerier affair, with a stunning performance of Sequenza XII by Pascal Gallois, who turned a solo bassoon, lit only by a single spotlight, into a dizzying, acrobatic creature capable of breathtaking flights of fantasy. There was also the 50-minute Coro , a heartfelt ballad for 40 singers and 40 players, consisting of fragments of Pablo Neruda, folk song and Hebrew, Croatian, Persian, French and German texts. Berio, too, has always delighted in musical kleptomania. Where he, like the others, is not just a thieving magpie is that he shares his loot (plus interest) with all of us, giving more than he took.

London Sinfonietta Royal Festival Hall

Steven Herbert Smith St John's Smith Square

Luciano Berio Queen Elizabeth Hall

fields.headline: MPs revolt at low-pay freeze
fields.standfirst: Government facing unprecedented vote by Labour backbenchers over its decision to rule out rise in minimum wage ruled out until at least April 2001
fields.trailText: Millions of low-paid workers will be given the bad news this week that there is to be no increase in the £3.60 an hour national minimum wage until April 2001. A further blow for tens of thousands of young workers is that Ministers have decided not to lower the age for qualifying for the adult rate from 22 to 21.
fields.body:
Millions of low-paid workers will be given the bad news this week that there is to be no increase in the £3.60 an hour national minimum wage until April 2001. A further blow for tens of thousands of young workers is that Ministers have decided not to lower the age for qualifying for the adult rate from 22 to 21.

The announcement by Trade Secretary Stephen Byers, which has been pencilled in for Thursday, threatens to trigger a major revolt on Labour's backbenches and among trade union leaders. It flies in the face of advice from the government's independent Low Pay Commission, which has recommended a 10p an hour increase, and that the minimum wage should apply to 21-year-olds.

Opposition to the proposed freeze is already growing on Labour's backbenches. Last week TUC General Secretary John Monks spoke to a meeting of about 50 MPs with union backgrounds. His call for an increase this year was supported by almost everyone in the room.

This week Ministers face an unprecedented vote against government policy at the weekly meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party, open to all MPs. There has not been a vote at any PLP meeting since 1997, which operates by 'managed consensus', but six Labour MPs have forced a motion on to Wednesday's agenda, saying 'this PLP believes the National Minimum Wage should be uprated annually in April'.

Byers will justify the freeze by saying that the Government needs time to measure its effect on jobs.

But government caution comes when it appears the political battle over a minimum wage has been decisively won. On the employers' side the CBI has acknowledged it has not caused major job losses, although it has increased the burden of regulation for small businesses.

The Conservatives - whose leaders once forecast that the minimum wage could cost up to two million jobs, depending on the level at which it was set - have now withdrawn their threat to abolish it.

And, according to the independent employment monitoring organisation Income Data Services, statistics have not borne out dark warnings made before the introduction of the minimum wage last April. There is no evidence, the organisation says, that jobs have been lost or inflation stoked because of the minimum wage, or that skilled workers have put in demands for pay increases to protect wage differentials.

The Byers announcement is likely to be sugared by strong hints that there will be a generous increase next year. As it is widely believed that Tony Blair will call a general election for May 2001, a large increase in the minimum wage a month earlier will be seen by many as a transparent election ploy.

The driving force behind Wednesday's PLP vote, Gordon Prentice, has written to fellow Labour MPs urging them to attend and condemning the rumoured plan to raise the minimum wage in the run-up to a general election as 'the worst kind of gesture politics'.

In December a petition organised by Labour MP Diana Organ in favour of uprating the minimum wage drew support from 93 Labour MPs.

Party business managers are already alarmed by the prospect of a formal vote which could reveal the extent of Labour opposition to the Government.

There is likely to be heavy pressure on the rebels in the next three days to have a debate but not force a vote.

Prentice forecast: 'The pressure will be absolutely immense. I'm going to speak to people on Monday and Tuesday and work out how to proceed, but the reality is that if it is not pushed to a vote now it could be long time before there is another opportunity.'
