webTitle: Phil Hogan gets the Cambridge blues

fields.headline: Phil Hogan gets the Cambridge blues
fields.body:
It seems ages since we last made the children despise us for forcing them to do something gratuitously uninteresting, so what better than a cultural excursion to nearby historic Cambridge, where a combination of punts, mediaeval architecture and emaciated music students trying to earn money for lager and drugs by adapting Elvis Presley classics for French horn and washboard succeed in drawing Japanese tourists from all over the country? The downside is it's blowing a gale out there and we're halfway up the M11 on two wheels before my wife decides we ought to take advantage of the city's enviable park-and-ride scheme, thus avoiding the centre, which the council has now successfully turned into a cycling area for the partially sighted. But, as I explain to the children before they get the chance to start wondering too loudly what's the point of having your own car if you have to leave it in a different town and run for a bus, it doesn't take that much longer than queuing round the outskirts for days until such time as the authorities bite the bullet and question the wisdom of having all these identical old university buildings all over the place when you could very easily knock one down without anyone noticing and make way for a decent multi-storey right next to the shops.

So we get the No 77 and wind our way in over every traffic hump in East Anglia, and before long we are promenading the venerable greensward and cloisters of hushed academe, telling the children about how Henry Tudor defeated Ethelred the Unready during the Battle of Boswell before coming to Trinity to take a double third in politics and metallurgy. The houses round here are nice, too, even the one that has sought to improve on the prevailing Edwardian aesthetic of line and form with a sign saying, 'Wheel clamps in operation'.

'Any questions?' I ask.

'When can we go to Pizza Hut?' asks the six-year-old.

Pretty soon, as it happens, but on the way I just need to pop into a shoe shop offering 25 per cent off 'selected' lines of the kind aimed at people with surgically enhanced feet, so I leave the others outside to get swept along in a demonstration to free the Cambridge Two, who have been jailed for aiding and abetting people less fortunate than themselves, which is against the law in towns entitled by Royal Charter to retain Section 27, forbidding the promotion of asking if you've got any spare change or keeping an unshampooed dog on the end of a length of string. I am minded to rush into the street and wave my fist in the air, but the woman is still busy finding out for me whether they've got the taupe boots in a brown suede, only with a crepe sole and different eyeholes in a broad size eight, and by the time it turns out that they don't do custom-made footwear at Oxfam prices, the children are hankering to be fed, so off we go trying to find Pizza Hut on the map and at last we're in the queue just behind the entire cast of Battleship Potemkin.

'Eat what you want for £4.49,' says the sign. Excellent! Count me in for lobster thermidor with shallots on a green yam mash teamed with a couple of Yorkshire puds in a truffle gravy, I'm thinking, but my wife is already suggesting that McDonald's might be a bit quicker, so off we go, but this is packed, too, so there's a bit of a scramble, which is my fault for being the first customer since records began to ask if it's OK to pay by cheque, and by the time we get everything back to the table to see what mystery item they have added or subtracted from our order this week, the toddler has got himself into the kind of humour that involves sticking his straw in my eye while I'm trying to break up an argument about which large fries is the largest.

Afterwards, my wife is keen to visit a house that she has seen on Home Front that used to belong to someone interested in pebbles - obviously a must-see in its own right - but also there's an art gallery just around the corner, which is a bit of luck because we've been looking for a toilet for ages. We take a polite stroll round the exhibition, even though it is ominously called 'Noise' and has pulsing music and flickering screens and digitised interference and a simulation of what the world sounds like if you're a deaf person unlucky enough to be fitted with an ear implant. Plus, for some reason, they've got Charles Babbage's brain pickled in a jar.

'Look,' I say. 'That's the brain of the man who invented the computer.'

'Who Bill Gates?' says the eldest.

'Well, no,' I say gently. 'He's still using his.'

But by now the toddler is showing an interest in unplugging a TV showing someone walking backwards and forwards, which generally means it's time to go. 'Come on, then, back to the car,' I say.

Now where did we leave it

 honorary doctorates to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Free thoughts
fields.standfirst: It is a decade since Nelson Mandela finally walked to freedom. But has the new republic of South Africa lived up to the vision he nurtured in prison?
fields.trailText: It is a decade since Nelson Mandela finally walked to freedom. But has the new republic of South Africa lived up to the vision he nurtured in prison?
fields.body:
For 18 of his 27 years in prison, a small cell on Robben Island was, for Nelson Mandela, the only here and now. Yet in a very real sense it also encompassed all there was of 'there' and of 'then', of 'before' and 'after'. And perhaps it was precisely his ability to see beyond the here and now of cell and island, the full complexities of a larger world, that enabled Mandela to assume, upon his release into that world, all the bearable heaviness of his country.

In South Africa today, there are other complexities attached to our notions of where we are, where we come from, where we may be heading. I remember from years ago in Port Elizabeth in the Eastern Cape the sense of existential disorientation caused by a blank wall in the airport building (at the time still ominously known as 'HF Verwoerd') announcing very emphatically, 'YOU ARE NOW HERE', unaccompanied by any plan or map. This may not be unlike the puzzle of the new South Africa. Exactly 10 years ago, our version of the Berlin Wall collapsed with the unbanning of liberation movements and the release of Mandela. Today, many South Africans argue that life is going on exactly as before, while many others insist everything has changed, and changed utterly. The question may well be how we arrived here from where we were. Or, more succinctly, where exactly is 'here'?

An answer is complicated by the fact that the two main players of 1990 have both left the official scene. Of course, Mandela remains a significant presence in the conscience of the world, but de Klerk's historical role has rapidly faded ('Oh, was he the one who ?'). This in itself may suggest something about the present and the possibilities for the future. De Klerk was the man with the mentality of a civil servant thrust by history into a role too big for him. Moreover, he acted palpably against his own inclination, trying to thwart, every inch of the way, the process he himself had set in motion. Ever since February 1990 he has missed each of his appointments with history - most lamentably when, in his appearance before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, he hid behind legalistic ploys to shirk his ultimate responsibility. The one quality sadly missing from his performance has been that of vision.

And vision was exactly what Mandela brought to the situation when faced with the challenge of reconciling the myth he had become during his years in prison with the human being he was. This does not mean that he made no mistakes. Those invariably arose from a refusal to accept that allies or friends could have feet of clay, a negligence of nuts and bolts in favour of the larger view, an old-fashioned authoritarianism. But his errors of judgement were amply offset by his integrity, his sense of humour, his forgiveness of human frailty, his generosity of spirit, his faith in reconciliation - and, above all, by the sacrifices he had personally made.

It is easy, today, to forget how close to the abyss we came several times since that momentous day he left prison. One of the great imponderables of the situation was the threat of violence from the Afrikaner Right, drawing on the mythology of heroism going back to the Boer War and beyond. But this threat collapsed when, in the run-up to the elections of April 1994, the attempt to take over the black homeland of Bophuthatswana ended in messy failure. It marked a turning away from violence as a solution for difficult or dangerous situations, towards the politics of peaceful negotiation. This ensured that the country would remain a beacon to the world, no longer as a reminder of the racism lurking in the darker recesses of practically every human society, but as an example of a different mode of thinking, a new way of viewing problems as challenges. And it is important, not just for South Africa but for the world, that we succeed. The alternative is Bosnia, Rwanda, or Chechnya.

The free elections of April 1994 might have been a moment so brief and bright that it appeared all too easy, afterwards, to discount it as illusion. But in the long course of history, these are the defining instants in the wind we live by. Without them we must flounder. They keep us going, the dreams that ultimately justify the effort and disillusionment leading to the renewed dedication without which human progress is unthinkable. Those of us who stood in the long queues of that April day to perform the simplest of actions imaginable - drawing a cross in a square - will never forget the exhilaration in what the writer Njabulo Ndebele has called the rediscovery of the ordinary. Nothing could have been more momentous than discovering that all of us, rich or poor, black or white or anything in between, business executive or street sweeper, student or prostitute, were ultimately involved in, and defined by, this part of Africa.

Of course, the euphoria didn't last. But that doesn't mean it never happened. And having happened, it became part of the possible. It is in our nature to move between hope and despair. The point is which one we would choose to define ourselves by: the moments of light, or the dark intervals in between. Perhaps neither should be thinkable without the other. If humanity makes sense, it is not because it is capable of the best, or of the worst, but of both. The road we embarked on in February 1990 brought South Africa face to face with two crucial challenges: the need to confront the truth about the past, and the need to reconcile the almost irreconcilable. This made the Truth and Reconciliation Commission a defining factor in the equation. In many respects the exercise was flawed; judged by the narrowest definition, it probably failed.

Almost anyone acting in bad faith could jeopardise the process. Yet any comparison with situations elsewhere in the world, where a transition has been attempted without such a process, brings to light the profound need for it. Perhaps failure or success is not even important; the test lies in the 'will' to move towards truth, and towards reconciliation. Surely the Pinochet affair has demonstrated this more devastatingly than ever before.

Not that South Africa has done enough. Much in the country has gone wrong. Over-the-top affirmative action has brought advancement to some, and misery to many; progress has been bedevilled by the arrogance, corruption and sheer stupidity of many newcomers to the ranks of well-paid power-mongers; a wave of violence (much of it, but not all, the legacy of apartheid injustices and inequities) threatens to engulf the country; the lofty ideals of transparency, accountability and - yes - democracy once so proudly proclaimed by the ANC have become jeopardised by the actions of many of its own power elite; minority rights are threatened by the tyranny of the majority. But that is not all that has happened. There have also been massive advances in education; progress in the provision of housing, electricity and running water; an opening up of new opportunities to the previously disadvantaged; a buoyancy in the economy; and, indeed, faith in the future.

Much of where we are - and where we may go from here - may well depend on the performance of President Thabo Mbeki. Mandela's is a near-impossible act to follow. Mbeki's early manoeuvring to get rid of potential rivals raised fears of a Mugabean lust for power. His recent kowtowing to China by pretending to be 'too busy' to meet the Dalai Lama had little to commend it. Some of his appointments in the cabinet and diplomatic service have been depressing. But there is something reassuring about his non-ideological pragmatism, whereas his inclusive notion of an African renaissance testifies to a certain visionary quality, too. He appears to respect the constitutional process, and a clear understanding of where the abuse of power inevitably leads. In many respects, he may be exactly the kind of person the present situation requires: a man who can work with here and now without losing sight of other times and spaces.

Against this background, the question about 'where is here?' may no longer be quite so daunting. We may not yet be where we'd like to be, but at least we're no longer 'there' any more. Most importantly, we seem to be on our way 'somewhere'. Our peculiar cell may yet expand to the dimensions of a larger and more human world.

 André Brink's latest book, The Rights of Desire, will be published in August by Secker & Warburg

fields.headline: Guilty, m'lud
fields.standfirst: Archaic laws mean you've probably committed more crimes than you'd confess to
fields.trailText: Archaic laws mean you've probably committed more crimes than you'd confess to
fields.body:
The Section 28 debate on homosexuality, and the recent repealment of a 220-year law banning dancing on Sundays has thrown a spotlight on antiquated British rules. Here are some more:

A bed may not be hung out of a window

All Englishmen over 14 are meant to carry out two hours of longbow practice a week supervised by the local clergy

A Chelsea Pensioner may not be impersonated

It is illegal for a lady to eat chocolates on a public conveyance

Throughout the whole of England, it is illegal to eat mince pies on the 25 December

Any boy under the age of 10 may not see a naked mannequin

It is illegal to leave baggage unattended

Picking up abandoned baggage is an act of terrorism

It is illegal for a member of Parliament to enter the House of Commons wearing a full suit of armour

In York, upon sight of a Scotsman, it is still legal to shoot him with a bow and arrow, except on Sundays

It is legal for a man to urinate in public, as long as it is on the rear wheel of his motor vehicle and his right hand is resting on the vehicle

Anal sex is prohibited

Companies may vote in local elections

It is illegal for two adult men to have sex in the same house as a third person

In Chester, you can only shoot a Welsh person with a bow and arrow inside the city walls and after midnight

In Hereford, you can shoot a Welsh person all day in the Cathedral Close, but only on Sunday with a longbow

In Scotland, you may not fish on Sundays; it is illegal to be drunk in possession of a cow; if someone knocks on your door and asks to use the lavatory, you must let them.

These laws and more can be found on www.dumblaws.com
The Law Commission would not comment on these specific examples

fields.headline: All about Yves
fields.standfirst: He invented the trouser suit, put transparent tops on the catwalk as long ago as 1968 and was the first couturier to open a ready-to-wear boutique. But Yves Saint Laurent's troubled personal life has also often put him in the spotlight. In a rare interview, he talks about dogs, death and dresses
fields.trailText: He invented the trouser suit, put transparent tops on the catwalk as long ago as 1968 and was the first couturier to open a ready-to-wear boutique. But Yves Saint Laurent's troubled personal life has also often put him in the spotlight. In a rare interview, he talks about dogs, death and dresses
fields.body:
Over recent months, Yves Saint Laurent has been responsible for making much ink flow. First came the hot news that Gucci had bought up YSL's ready-to-wear and perfume businesses, that the Italian house's designer Tom Ford was taking over as creative director of both, and that one of its major backers, François Pinault, had separately snapped up Saint Laurent's haute couture house. Then came the women's spring/summer collections in October, where Saint Laurent's influence was as strong as ever. Prada's seminal 'Lady' collection drew heavily on YSL references. His signature pussycat bows appeared time and again on the international catwalks, and the trench coat (which he introduced into the female wardrobe back in the 60s) established itself as one of this season's major trends. Finally, this January, Saint Laurent organised a party at the newly refurbished Pompidou Centre in Paris to celebrate the reopening of its modern art museum. The designer and his business partner Pierre Bergé had partly sponsored the renovation with what was only the latest in a series of generous donations to art institutions. In 1997, for example, an Yves Saint Laurent room was opened in the French-painting wing of the National Gallery in London after the pair handed over a gift of £1 million.

At the Pompidou Centre party, the designer posed in front of a Matisse and then a Miró. He smiled for the cameras with close friends, such as Betty Catroux and Loulou de la Falaise, and surprised everyone by staying for hours. Indeed, he surprised everyone by simply turning up. For nowadays, his public appearances are few and far between. For at least a decade now, he has lived as a near recluse. In 1998, he told the trendy fashion magazine Dutch: 'I can't go out. I am afraid of the outside world, of the street, of the crowd. I only feel comfortable at home with my dog, my pencils and my paper.'

In general, the only sightings of him are limited to his twice-yearly haute couture shows. He comes out at the end to take his bows, looking rather uneasy and grimacing a smile. The idea of appearing in front of an audience obviously terrifies him, and you find yourself praying that his unsteady legs will actually carry him to the end of the catwalk and back.

The idea of meeting journalists is also something he quite obviously does not cherish. The interviews he gives are few and far between (an average of not more than two a year), and Saint Laurent has been known to escape out of the back door of his couture house at the last minute to avoid a meeting. While his press officer goes to welcome a journalist, he quickly makes his getaway so that when she returns, Monsieur Saint Laurent is no longer to be found.

The one quality absolutely necessary if you do wish to meet him is patience. It was actually one of Saint Laurent's press officers who suggested that I interview him. That was last January. Yet it was not until more than a year later that an appointment was finally arranged. Two days later, that was cancelled, another organised, and I was beginning to suspect that the meeting would never happen. I was therefore far from reassured when I finally turned up at the agreed time only to discover that fashion's greatest living legend was not actually there. A quick call was put through to Saint Laurent's apartment on the Left Bank, and the news came through that he was on his way. Some 20 minutes later, I had made it. I was being led to his office.

It is situated on the first floor of the Napoleon III building on Paris's Avenue Marceau, which had been home to his couture house since 1974. In the corridor, you walk past an Andy Warhol screen print of the young Saint Laurent. Tall, tan leather-coloured doors open up into what is a surprisingly small but richly decorated room. It is a crimson and gold affair. To one side is a coffee table and screen by Jean-Michel Frank. On a mantelpiece stands a painting of Diana Vreeland by French artist Christian Bérard. To one side is a large photo of Saint Laurent's mother. Between the two windows is an imposing portrait of his great-great grandfather, the lawyer who drew up Napoleon Bonaparte and Josephine's wedding contract. The desk on which it was signed is now Saint Laurent's. On it stand two ornate drop-crystal lamps, a vase full of pungent lilies and a pot crammed with blue HB pencils.

The designer himself is dressed in a dark suit, white shirt with black stripes and a checked tie. Wearing his trademark glasses, he chain-smokes throughout our meeting. Part-way through, we are joined by his nine-year-old French bulldog Moujik III, after he starts scratching at the door. Saint Laurent takes him everywhere and informs me that he is the sweetest-natured of all the dogs he has had (his predecessors, Moujik I and Moujik II, were also bulldogs). Once the door has been opened, Moujik III rushes in, sneezes loudly, and then proceeds to chew on my left trouser leg.

I must admit to approaching the meeting with a certain amount of trepidation. I had seen a TV interview with the designer a couple of years ago, during which his answers were so short and sweet they were more or less monosyllabic. I thus expected it to be incredibly hard work. Plus, there is also the preconception that Saint Laurent is not quite all there. 'Was he out to lunch?' asked a journalist friend when I told her that I had met him. My answer was a quite categorical, 'Not at all'. Indeed, those close to him say that he has quite a lot of mettle. 'He's very shy, but very determined,' says Loulou de la Falaise. 'He's actually really quite feisty.'

In person, his speech is a little laboured and there are the odd moments of unease. At times, for example, he bows his head to the left, seems to freeze and remains silent for a good 10 seconds at a time. At first, you wonder whether everything is all right. Then you realise he is simply weighing up the best way to talk about an extremely delicate and personal subject. Otherwise, he is almost the total opposite of most people's perceptions of him. He is totally on the ball, really quite funny, friendly, charming, courteous and surprisingly chatty. He takes obvious delight, for example, in recounting the episode in the 70s when it was announced on the radio that he was dead. 'So many journalists besieged Monsieur Bergé's office,' he recalls. 'He told them, "It's not true. He is busy working on his next collection." And they replied, "Despite all the faith we have in you, our editors made us promise to see Monsieur Saint Laurent in the flesh." So, Bergé left the door of the studio where I was working ajar, and I saw all of these heads popping round it. I didn't have time to talk to them because I was busy. In any case, they had just come to check that I was still alive.'

Saint Laurent often displays a quite childlike glee in the telling of his stories, and there is certainly something of the Peter Pan about him. 'He has the vision of a child,' says Bergé, 'and is also someone full of mystery.' That may certainly be the public image, but in conversation, he displays a quite courageous openness and honesty. He talks freely about his battles with alcohol, his problems with others, and even admits to a certain lack of generosity. A few years ago, he told the German magazine Focus that he was 'terribly bored'. Today, however, it seems that Saint Laurent is finally getting the upper hand over his demons.

'When I stopped drinking, I had a lot of trouble communicating with other people,' he says. 'It's taken me 10 years to start to get things into order, but now I am becoming the person I once was again. Things are starting to sort themselves out.' His last haute couture collection, much of which was based on a Spanish theme, certainly exuded a new energy. In the boleros and gypsy dresses, there was much more freedom and fantasy than has been seen from Saint Laurent in a long while. 'I designed it with a lot of joy,' he tells me. 'Of course, there were moments of panic and doubt, but much less than usual. I was much more serene about it.'

He remains haunted by a desire for perfection and is still extremely worried about the reactions of the press and his clients to each collection, which seems like a quite ridiculous anomaly. After all, in fashion terms, Saint Laurent really has nothing left to prove. Almost any other leading designer will cite him as their idol. Marc Jacobs refers to him as God. Tom Ford and Jean-Paul Gaultier call him their mentor. His place in the annals of fashion is well-assured. For autumn 1965, for example, he rocked the world with his Mondrian print dresses. For spring 1966, he created the first female tuxedo and was the first designer to show transparency on the runway in 1968. In 1966, he also became the first couturier to open a ready-to-wear boutique, and on French television at the end of the 60s, Coco Chanel pronounced him her spiritual successor.

'I learned a lot from her, even though I didn't know her,' he tells me. 'She wanted to meet me. Monsieur Bergé was very friendly with her and she kept saying to him, "Bring Saint Laurent to see me", but I was too scared of her. I was much shyer back then and felt very intimated by her. Nowadays, I really regret not having known her. The only encounter I had with her was when I bumped into her at the Ritz, where she was having lunch. She told me, "No more miniskirts, Saint Laurent!"'

For many, the zenith of his career came in 1976, with the presentation of his famed Ballets Russes collection. The designer himself believes the collections, inspired by Picasso (winter '79/80) and Braque (summer '88), were his best, and that his greatest contribution to fashion was 'having put women into trouser suits and given them men's clothing which was adapted to their bodies. I also feel that I have managed to create my own style and to consolidate it. A couturier who doesn't have his own style is not a couturier. Fashions change, but a style remains.'

Yet his professional success has long been counterbalanced by a problematic personal life. 'It was in achieving his dreams that he closed the door to his own life,' says the fashion editor of Le Monde, Laurence Benaïm, in her Saint Laurent biography. His troubles and woes have been well documented: the times he spent in the American Hospital in Neuilly for depression in the 70s, as well as his battles with alcohol and drugs. He initially started taking pills and drink around 1958. 'It was a way for me to escape reality,' he says. 'A means of seeing life in a different light, as more beautiful than it actually is.'

This inability to cope with the realities of the world is surely one of Saint Laurent's greatest tragedies. Rather than facing up to the challenges of existence, he prefers to disappear off into some dream world, a universe quite Proustian in nature. His passion for the writer is well known. He sometimes refers to himself as 'Swann' and has named each of the rooms in his Normandy château after a character in Remembrance of Things Past. Living in this parallel universe, however, has ultimately distanced him from life. 'At one time, he was drinking two or three litres of Pastis a day and also taking amphetamines,' says the former model Victoire, who helped Saint Laurent set up his own house. She also reveals that he was in a coma for a number of days at the beginning of the 80s.

'I am a very unhappy person,' he affirms. 'I do harm to myself, but I think it's something which will wear off. It's difficult because I'm an extremely complicated being.'

His life never seems to have been easy. He was born in 1936 into a bourgeois family in Oran, Algeria. As a gay aesthete, he was taunted at school ('Being homosexual in Oran was like being a murderer,' he has said) and seems to have taken a long time to come to terms with his sexuality (he only openly admitted to being gay in a 1991 interview in the French daily Le Figaro). He originally dreamed of becoming a theatre set designer after seeing a production of Molière's The School of Women on which Christian Bérard had worked. Instead, at the age of 17, he won third prize in a prestigious fashion competition and the following year, moved to Paris to study at the Ecole de la Chambre Syndicale. He arrived with an introduction to the director of French Vogue, Michel de Brunhoff, who would later set up a meeting for him at Dior. Hired immediately, he was taken under Christian Dior's protective wing. 'Monsieur Dior was quite wonderful,' he remembers. 'He was both an extraordinary designer and an extraordinary man. He was perfect. So kind and generous. For me, he was very much like a father.'

In October 1957, Dior went away on holiday to Montecatini in Italy. On the day of his departure, he said to his sales director, 'I am going away without any worries. I am leaving you with Yves.' Dior would never return. On 24 October, he died of a heart attack and on 15 November, Saint Laurent was named as his successor. His first collection, the Trapeze line, was a triumph, pushing up sales 35 per cent. Two and a half years later, however, he was sacked. The news came after he had suffered a nervous breakdown just 20 days into his national service. The excuse was a bad collection. The reality was probably that the owner did not like him.

fields.bodyText: Over recent months, Yves Saint Laurent has been responsible for making much ink flow. First came the hot news that Gucci had bought up YSL's ready-to-wear and perfume businesses, that the Italian house's designer Tom Ford was taking over as creative director of both, and that one of its major backers, François Pinault, had separately snapped up Saint Laurent's haute couture house. Then came the women's spring/summer collections in October, where Saint Laurent's influence was as strong as ever. Prada's seminal 'Lady' collection drew heavily on YSL references. His signature pussycat bows appeared time and again on the international catwalks, and the trench coat (which he introduced into the female wardrobe back in the 60s) established itself as one of this season's major trends. Finally, this January, Saint Laurent organised a party at the newly refurbished Pompidou Centre in Paris to celebrate the reopening of its modern art museum. The designer and his business partner Pierre Bergé had partly sponsored the renovation with what was only the latest in a series of generous donations to art institutions. In 1997, for example, an Yves Saint Laurent room was opened in the French-painting wing of the National Gallery in London after the pair handed over a gift of £1 million. At the Pompidou Centre party, the designer posed in front of a Matisse and then a Miró. He smiled for the cameras with close friends, such as Betty Catroux and Loulou de la Falaise, and surprised everyone by staying for hours. Indeed, he surprised everyone by simply turning up. For nowadays, his public appearances are few and far between. For at least a decade now, he has lived as a near recluse. In 1998, he told the trendy fashion magazine Dutch: 'I can't go out. I am afraid of the outside world, of the street, of the crowd. I only feel comfortable at home with my dog, my pencils and my paper.' In general, the only sightings of him are limited to his twice-yearly haute couture shows. He comes out at the end to take his bows, looking rather uneasy and grimacing a smile. The idea of appearing in front of an audience obviously terrifies him, and you find yourself praying that his unsteady legs will actually carry him to the end of the catwalk and back. The idea of meeting journalists is also something he quite obviously does not cherish. The interviews he gives are few and far between (an average of not more than two a year), and Saint Laurent has been known to escape out of the back door of his couture house at the last minute to avoid a meeting. While his press officer goes to welcome a journalist, he quickly makes his getaway so that when she returns, Monsieur Saint Laurent is no longer to be found. The one quality absolutely necessary if you do wish to meet him is patience. It was actually one of Saint Laurent's press officers who suggested that I interview him. That was last January. Yet it was not until more than a year later that an appointment was finally arranged. Two days later, that was cancelled, another organised, and I was beginning to suspect that the meeting would never happen. I was therefore far from reassured when I finally turned up at the agreed time only to discover that fashion's greatest living legend was not actually there. A quick call was put through to Saint Laurent's apartment on the Left Bank, and the news came through that he was on his way. Some 20 minutes later, I had made it. I was being led to his office. It is situated on the first floor of the Napoleon III building on Paris's Avenue Marceau, which had been home to his couture house since 1974. In the corridor, you walk past an Andy Warhol screen print of the young Saint Laurent. Tall, tan leather-coloured doors open up into what is a surprisingly small but richly decorated room. It is a crimson and gold affair. To one side is a coffee table and screen by Jean-Michel Frank. On a mantelpiece stands a painting of Diana Vreeland by French artist Christian Bérard. To one side is a large photo of Saint Laurent's mother. Between the two windows is an imposing portrait of his great-great grandfather, the lawyer who drew up Napoleon Bonaparte and Josephine's wedding contract. The desk on which it was signed is now Saint Laurent's. On it stand two ornate drop-crystal lamps, a vase full of pungent lilies and a pot crammed with blue HB pencils. The designer himself is dressed in a dark suit, white shirt with black stripes and a checked tie. Wearing his trademark glasses, he chain-smokes throughout our meeting. Part-way through, we are joined by his nine-year-old French bulldog Moujik III, after he starts scratching at the door. Saint Laurent takes him everywhere and informs me that he is the sweetest-natured of all the dogs he has had (his predecessors, Moujik I and Moujik II, were also bulldogs). Once the door has been opened, Moujik III rushes in, sneezes loudly, and then proceeds to chew on my left trouser leg. I must admit to approaching the meeting with a certain amount of trepidation. I had seen a TV interview with the designer a couple of years ago, during which his answers were so short and sweet they were more or less monosyllabic. I thus expected it to be incredibly hard work. Plus, there is also the preconception that Saint Laurent is not quite all there. 'Was he out to lunch?' asked a journalist friend when I told her that I had met him. My answer was a quite categorical, 'Not at all'. Indeed, those close to him say that he has quite a lot of mettle. 'He's very shy, but very determined,' says Loulou de la Falaise. 'He's actually really quite feisty.' In person, his speech is a little laboured and there are the odd moments of unease. At times, for example, he bows his head to the left, seems to freeze and remains silent for a good 10 seconds at a time. At first, you wonder whether everything is all right. Then you realise he is simply weighing up the best way to talk about an extremely delicate and personal subject. Otherwise, he is almost the total opposite of most people's perceptions of him. He is totally on the ball, really quite funny, friendly, charming, courteous and surprisingly chatty. He takes obvious delight, for example, in recounting the episode in the 70s when it was announced on the radio that he was dead. 'So many journalists besieged Monsieur Bergé's office,' he recalls. 'He told them, "It's not true. He is busy working on his next collection." And they replied, "Despite all the faith we have in you, our editors made us promise to see Monsieur Saint Laurent in the flesh." So, Bergé left the door of the studio where I was working ajar, and I saw all of these heads popping round it. I didn't have time to talk to them because I was busy. In any case, they had just come to check that I was still alive.' Saint Laurent often displays a quite childlike glee in the telling of his stories, and there is certainly something of the Peter Pan about him. 'He has the vision of a child,' says Bergé, 'and is also someone full of mystery.' That may certainly be the public image, but in conversation, he displays a quite courageous openness and honesty. He talks freely about his battles with alcohol, his problems with others, and even admits to a certain lack of generosity. A few years ago, he told the German magazine Focus that he was 'terribly bored'. Today, however, it seems that Saint Laurent is finally getting the upper hand over his demons. 'When I stopped drinking, I had a lot of trouble communicating with other people,' he says. 'It's taken me 10 years to start to get things into order, but now I am becoming the person I once was again. Things are starting to sort themselves out.' His last haute couture collection, much of which was based on a Spanish theme, certainly exuded a new energy. In the boleros and gypsy dresses, there was much more freedom and fantasy than has been seen from Saint Laurent in a long while. 'I designed it with a lot of joy,' he tells me. 'Of course, there were moments of panic and doubt, but much less than usual. I was much more serene about it.' He remains haunted by a desire for perfection and is still extremely worried about the reactions of the press and his clients to each collection, which seems like a quite ridiculous anomaly. After all, in fashion terms, Saint Laurent really has nothing left to prove. Almost any other leading designer will cite him as their idol. Marc Jacobs refers to him as God. Tom Ford and Jean-Paul Gaultier call him their mentor. His place in the annals of fashion is well-assured. For autumn 1965, for example, he rocked the world with his Mondrian print dresses. She told me, "No more miniskirts, Saint Laurent!"' For many, the zenith of his career came in 1976, with the presentation of his famed Ballets Russes collection. The designer himself believes the collections, inspired by Picasso (winter '79/80) and Braque (summer '88), were his best, and that his greatest contribution to fashion was 'having put women into trouser suits and given them men's clothing which was adapted to their bodies. Yet his professional success has long been counterbalanced by a problematic personal life. 'It was in achieving his dreams that he closed the door to his own life,' says the fashion editor of Le Monde, Laurence Benaïm, in her Saint Laurent biography. His troubles and woes have been well documented: the times he spent in the American Hospital in Neuilly for depression in the 70s, as well as his battles with alcohol and drugs. He initially started taking pills and drink around 1958. 'It was a way for me to escape reality,' he says. 'A means of seeing life in a different light, as more beautiful than it actually is.' This inability to cope with the realities of the world is surely one of Saint Laurent's greatest tragedies. Rather than facing up to the challenges of existence, he prefers to disappear off into some dream world, a universe quite Proustian in nature. His passion for the writer is well known. He sometimes refers to himself as 'Swann' and has named each of the rooms in his Normandy château after a character in Remembrance of Things Past. Living in this parallel universe, however, has ultimately distanced him from life. 'At one time, he was drinking two or three litres of Pastis a day and also taking amphetamines,' says the former model Victoire, who helped Saint Laurent set up his own house. She also reveals that he was in a coma for a number of days at the beginning of the 80s. 'I am a very unhappy person,' he affirms. 'I do harm to myself, but I think it's something which will wear off. It's difficult because I'm an extremely complicated being.' His life never seems to have been easy. He was born in 1936 into a bourgeois family in Oran, Algeria. As a gay aesthete, he was taunted at school ('Being homosexual in Oran was like being a murderer,' he has said) and seems to have taken a long time to come to terms with his sexuality (he only openly admitted to being gay in a 1991 interview in the French daily Le Figaro). He was perfect. So kind and generous. For me, he was very much like a father.' In October 1957, Dior went away on holiday to Montecatini in Italy. fields.headline: Under D influence
fields.standfirst: Vitamin D appears to be more important for our health than previously thought, so ensuring we produce enough over the winter months is a priority
fields.trailText: Vitamin D appears to be more important for our health than previously thought, so ensuring we produce enough over the winter months is a priority
fields.body:
Not only do the darker winter months do little for our moods, but the lack of ultraviolet (UV) rays also deprives our body of its major source of vitamin D - a nutrient we need principally to work in conjunction with calcium to produce strong bones and teeth. The action of the sun's UV rays on our skin stimulates the body to produce its most active and effective form of vitamin D, known as 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, but between the months of October and March, few UV rays reach us, which means that to meet the necessary levels, our bodies have to rely both on vitamin D accumulated during the sunny months and stored in the liver and body fat, as well as far less efficient dietary sources.

Although relatively rare, extreme lack of vitamin D (especially during times of rapid growth in adolescence) causes the bones to become weak and leads to the development of either rickets or osteomalacia. This condition more commonly affects old people, who have inadequate vitamin D intake (either through lack of appetite, or poor choice of foods) and, more significantly, very little exposure to natural sunlight. Rickets and osteomalacia are the commonest signs of deficiency, but vitamin D deficiency, or calciferol deficiency, as it is also known, may also manifest itself as defective calcification of the dentine of the teeth and can cause an increased susceptibility to dental caries. Even the ear can be affected, causing conductive hearing loss: lack of vitamin D reduces the concentration of calcium in the fluid of the inner ear, causing the formation of a new type of spongy bone, which interferes with sound transmission, and is one of the signs of a condition known as otosclerosis.

Exposure to the sun's UV rays keeps the majority of the developed world's population free of such diseases. However, rickets and other deficiency symptoms can occur in children who are either exposed to physical neglect, or have poorly balanced dietary intakes, sometimes the result of extreme and faddy diets - following a macrobiotic way of life, for example, or eating an unbalanced vegetarian diet. By the way, if you are vegetarian or vegan, you should be aware that animal-derived vitamin D is sometimes added to manufactured products. A list of animal-free products can be obtained from the Vegetarian Society (0161 928 0793).

Deficiency can also occur in children who are placed on so-called healthy eating regimes, in which they have no visible fat or dairy products and who eat a diet built primarily around vegetables and fruits, with a few whole grains thrown in (they are sometimes referred to as 'muesli babies'). The belief that this is a healthier way for children to eat is misplaced. It's very important that children have some fat in their diet to help their body absorb the fat-soluble vitamins - A, E and D - which is why I recommend they drink full-cream milk up until the age of five and have full-fat cheese and yoghurt. That way you're giving them an invaluable source of these essential vitamins, as well as a hefty dose of calcium.

The body needs to receive a daily dose of calcium to work with the vitamin D to form new bone tissue. Ideally, you should get it from calcium-rich foods, such as cheese, yoghurt and milk - aim for 1 1/2 pints of milk, 400g/14oz of yoghurt or 100g/4oz of cheese a day. Non-dairy sources include green, leafy vegetables, such as spinach, canned fish with soft, edible bones (sardines, pilchards, salmon and mackerel), sesame seeds and tahini, almonds, brazil nuts and hazelnuts, calcium-enriched soya cheeses and milk. These non-dairy sources don't contain as much calcium as dairy products, however, and are not as easily absorbed, so you will need to eat a lot more of them to derive the same amount of calcium. Calcium supplements are an option, especially for people with poor appetites, but you should talk to your doctor first.

Meanwhile, vitamin D's strengths don't just lie in the bones - scientists appear to be coming to the conclusion that since vitamin D has a role to play in cell differentiation, keeping the body well stocked with vitamin D may help to prevent and treat certain cancers (the breast, colon, rectum and prostate). You can avoid tipping the balance towards obesity and heart disease by not overindulging in dairy products.

In the majority of cases, we manage to produce enough vitamin D through safe exposure to the sun's UV rays, during the spring and summer months, to last us throughout the year. Sun creams do not inhibit the production of calciferol, so you must protect the body from the harmful sun's rays, while exposing your skin. Deficiencies occur most commonly when someone is kept out of the sun for long periods of time, perhaps if they have to spend a long time in bed through illness or live in institutions where little time is spent outside. Without sufficient exposure to the sun, it's vital to keep up the body's calciferol levels by ensuring a diet rich in vitamin D. The most valuable sources include oily fish such as tuna, mackerel or sardines, cod liver oil, liver, eggs, butter and margarine, cheese, milk and yoghurt. If you are not exposed to daylight on a regular basis, you need to consume 12-micrograms (500IUs) of vitamin D every day to maintain the 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol levels - which in real terms equates to 150g sardines or smoked mackerel and about 5g of cod liver oil. (You'd need to consume 150g margarine to derive similar quantities.)

If you're prepared to eat oily fish every day (sardines on toast, smoked mackerel with poached egg) or take some cod liver oil in the morning, then the requirement can be easily met. However, for the majority of people in the 'at risk' groups (those that are not exposed to sunlight on a day-to-day basis or have malabsorption problems), especially children and old people with poor appetites, it's simpler to take a 10-microgram (400IU) supplement or whatever dose your dietitian prescribes. In addition, however, you should still include as many vitamin D-rich foods as possible in your diet, because the body will glean other beneficial nutrients (such as vitamins A and E - both strong antioxidants) as part of the package.

Some people may become depleted of vitamin D, not as a result of lack of sunlight or poor dietary intake, but simply because they have difficulty absorbing vitamin D from the gut. This can occur with people who suffer from conditions such as Crohn's or coeliac disease, or who have liver problems, as a result of alcoholism or otherwise. If you suffer from any of these conditions, discuss the issue of vitamin D supplementation with your doctor and try to assist your body by keeping active in the bright months. Just for comparison, the body can produce roughly 380IU vitamin D a day, from exposing just 1cm of skin in the summer - which just shows why we should encourage our children to play outside and advise carers to take someone vulnerable out of doors as much as possible. Even a walk in the park for half an hour on a regular basis can ensure the body's vitamin tanks are well stocked.

Even the ear can be affected, causing conductive hearing loss: lack of vitamin D reduces the concentration of calcium in the fluid of the inner ear, causing the formation of a new type of spongy bone, which interferes with sound transmission, and is one of the signs of a condition known as otosclerosis. Exposure to the sun's UV rays keeps the majority of the developed world's population free of such diseases. However, rickets and other deficiency symptoms can occur in children who are either exposed to physical neglect, or have poorly balanced dietary intakes, sometimes the result of extreme and faddy diets - following a macrobiotic way of life, for example, or eating an unbalanced vegetarian diet. By the way, if you are vegetarian or vegan, you should be aware that animal-derived vitamin D is sometimes added to manufactured products. A list of animal-free products can be obtained from the Vegetarian Society (0161 928 0793). Deficiency can also occur in children who are placed on so-called healthy eating regimes, in which they have no visible fat or dairy products and who eat a diet built primarily around vegetables and fruits, with a few whole grains thrown in (they are sometimes referred to as 'muesli babies'). The belief that this is a healthier way for children to eat is misplaced. It's very important that children have some fat in their diet to help their body absorb the fat-soluble vitamins - A, E and D - which is why I recommend they drink full-cream milk up until the age of five and have full-fat cheese and yoghurt. That way you're giving them an invaluable source of these essential vitamins, as well as a hefty dose of calcium. The body needs to receive a daily dose of calcium to work with the vitamin D to form new bone tissue. Ideally, you should get it from calcium-rich foods, such as cheese, yoghurt and milk - aim for 1 1/2 pints of milk, 400g/14oz of yoghurt or 100g/4oz of cheese a day. Non-dairy sources include green, leafy vegetables, such as spinach, canned fish with soft, edible bones (sardines, pilchards, salmon and mackerel), sesame seeds and tahini, almonds, brazil nuts and hazelnuts, calcium-enriched soya cheeses and milk. These non-dairy sources don't contain as much calcium as dairy products, however, and are not as easily absorbed, so you will need to eat a lot more of them to derive the same amount of calcium. Calcium supplements are an option, especially for people with poor appetites, but you should talk to your doctor first. Meanwhile, vitamin D's strengths don't just lie in the bones - scientists appear to be coming to the conclusion that since vitamin D has a role to play in cell differentiation, keeping the body well stocked with vitamin D may help to prevent and treat certain cancers (the breast, colon, rectum and prostate). You can avoid tipping the balance towards obesity and heart disease by not overindulging in dairy products. In the majority of cases, we manage to produce enough vitamin D through safe exposure to the sun's UV rays, during the spring and summer months, to last us throughout the year. Sun creams do not inhibit the production of calciferol, so you must protect the body from the harmful sun's rays, while exposing your skin. Deficiencies occur most commonly when someone is kept out of the sun for long periods of time, perhaps if they have to spend a long time in bed through illness or live in institutions where little time is spent outside. Without sufficient exposure to the sun, it's vital to keep up the body's calciferol levels by ensuring a diet rich in vitamin D. The most valuable sources include oily fish such as tuna, mackerel or sardines, cod liver oil, liver, eggs, butter and margarine, cheese, milk and yoghurt. If you are not exposed to daylight on a regular basis, you need to consume 12-micrograms (500IUs) of vitamin D every day to maintain the 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol levels - which in real terms equates to 150g sardines or smoked mackerel and about 5g of cod liver oil. (You'd need to consume 150g margarine to derive similar quantities.) If you're prepared to eat oily fish every day (sardines on toast, smoked mackerel with poached egg) or take some cod liver oil in the morning, then the requirement can be easily met. However, for the majority of people in the 'at risk' groups (those that are not exposed to sunlight on a day-to-day basis or have malabsorption problems), especially children and old people with poor appetites, it's simpler to take a 10-microgram (400IU) supplement or whatever dose your dietitian prescribes. In addition, however, you should still include as many vitamin D-rich foods as possible in your diet, because the body will glean other beneficial nutrients (such as vitamins A and E - both strong antioxidants) as part of the package. Some people may become depleted of vitamin D, not as a result of lack of sunlight or poor dietary intake, but simply because they have difficulty absorbing vitamin D from the gut. This can occur with people who suffer from conditions such as Crohn's or coeliac disease, or who have liver problems, as a result of alcoholism or otherwise. If you suffer from any of these conditions, discuss the issue of vitamin D supplementation with your doctor and try to assist your body by keeping active in the bright months. Just for comparison, the body can produce roughly 380IU vitamin D a day, from exposing just 1cm of skin in the summer - which just shows why we should encourage our children to play outside and advise carers to take someone vulnerable out of doors as much as possible. Even a walk in the park for half an hour on a regular basis can ensure the body's vitamin tanks are well stocked.

fields.headline: Health report: Hard facts
fields.standfirst: Recent research shows that impotence could be an early-warning sign of heart disease. Peter Baker investigates
fields.trailText: Recent research shows that impotence could be an early-warning sign of heart disease. Peter Baker investigates
fields.body:
Tomorrow is Valentine's Day, an opportunity for lovers to express their affection for one another. It is also National Impotence Day - a timely, and perhaps rather cruel, reminder that one man in 10 is consistently unable to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for the sex he desires. The advent of Viagra in 1998 has not changed the fact that erectile dysfunction (ED) - the medical term for impotence - remains one of the most common and distressing health problems affecting men in Britain today.

Men with ED now have another reason to worry about their condition: it could be an important early-warning sign of heart disease, according to research recently presented to an American Heart Association conference.

Dr Marc Pritzker, director of heart failure and transplantation at the Minneapolis Heart Foundation, examined 50 men with ED who had sought prescriptions for Viagra. Although none of them had any symptoms of heart disease, six had blockages in all three major heart arteries, seven had two arteries that showed narrowing, and one artery was blocked in another seven. Overall, 40 per cent of the men were at significant risk of angina or a heart attack.

'We now understand that atherosclerosis [the thickening and narrowing of blood vessels] detected in one set of blood vessels markedly increases the chances of having this form of blood-vessel disease in other areas of the body,' says Dr Pritzker. 'Because the blood vessels that supply the penis are narrower than arteries in other areas of the body, atherosclerosis may manifest itself as erectile dysfunction before the disease becomes apparent in other arteries.'

Some doctors use an 'exercise stress test' - an electrocardiogram (ECG) conducted while the patient is physically active - to detect cardiovascular anomalies. Dr Pritzker believes erectile dysfunction could be called a 'penile stress test' and may be another way of detecting diseased blood vessels. Dr Pritzker, however, is quick to point out that 'we don't want every male who's running around with erectile dysfunction to think he's at risk of dropping dead from a heart attack'. He also freely admits that the 50 men he examined were already considered to be candidates for a cardiovascular disorder because there were no other obvious explanations for their erection problems and most of them had at least one other risk factor for heart disease, including smoking, high cholesterol levels and high blood pressure. Still, he thinks that men should be aware: 'If you've been used to regular sexual activity and then things don't work as well, it's a sign that something might well be wrong.'

Heart disease is not the only problem for which ED can be an early symptom. Diabetes can damage the nerves that cause the blood vessels of the penis to expand and also lead to a hardening and narrowing of the blood vessels supplying the penis. Up to 25 per cent of all diabetic men aged 30-34 experience erection problems; by 60-64, 75 per cent of diabetic men are affected.

The links between ED and potentially life-threatening health problems make it essential that men seek medical help as soon as possible. Unfortunately, feelings of embarrassment or shame mean that men often wait a long time before seeing their GP. An Impotence Association survey of more than 430 men with erection problems found that 41 per cent tried self-help - such as mechanical devices, videos, books or creams - before visiting a doctor.

Some men are known to have waited up to 40 years before seeking the medical help they need. Alan Riley, professor of sexual medicine at the Lancashire Postgraduate School of Medicine and Health, says that 'while we know 10 per cent of men have problems, this number aren't actually seeking help'.

The government's recent guidelines on the treatment of ED, introduced because of fears that the demand for Viagra would create an astronomic increase in NHS spending, have also confused patients and deterred many men from coming forward for treatment, according to Dr Ian Banks, a GP and chairman of the Men's Health Forum. Since July 1999, GPs have only been able to prescribe drug treatments on the NHS to men whose ED is caused by a limited range of specific conditions. These include diabetes, spinal-cord injury and treatment for prostate cancer - but not cardiovascular disease.

More worryingly still, GPs responses to men with ED can be woefully inadequate. 'It's still common for some GPs to treat impotence as a joke, and I don't think many are good at looking for underlying diseases,' says Ann Craig, director of the Impotence Association. Men who are concerned about their GP's approach should not hesitate to ask for a referral to a specialist.

Dr Pritzker has no doubt about what should happen when a man tells a doctor he's impotent: 'We have an opportunity to look for heart disease, make a diagnosis and offer appropriate prevention.' That could mean a healthier diet, more exercise and quitting smoking. This may not be the Valentine's Day message you want to hear, but it could be a real life-saver.

 For further information, call the Impotence Association helpline on 020 8767 7791

fields.headline: Bread winners
fields.standfirst: Elbow work is essential for good home-made bread, discovers Andrew Smith
fields.trailText: Elbow work is essential for good home-made bread, discovers Andrew Smith
fields.body:
It's in bread, Marmite, beer. I like yeast. But not half so much as Dan Lepard and Jason Warwick. As senior bakers at the indescribably wonderful Baker & Spice bakery in London's Mayfair (46 Walton Street, London SW3; 020 7589 4734), they speak of yeast as of a close friend or lover. 'It's getting a bit stressed, it needs a rest,' Lepard will say, tenderly gazing down at a doughy blob that looks like the Quatermas experiment.

People get passionate about this stuff. And why not? Yeast has a life of its own. There is a company in the US which claims to sell cultures that have been continuously tended since antiquity. It was 6,000 years ago that the Egyptians discovered that adding beer froth to dough caused the mixture to rise. When the Romans landed in Britain, they found the Celts doing the same thing with the 'barm' from beer (hence the term 'barmy'). Louis Pasteur later established that carbon dioxide produced by fermenting sugar fungus is responsible for this miracle, and also for the distinctive acid-sour flavour of sourdough bread, which should be 'perfumed rather than pungent', according to Lepard.

You can use commercially cultivated yeast, but this leads to a more nondescript finished product than if you use the naturally occurring 'wild' yeast in the air. When you make a 'starter' for one of Baker & Spice's breads, what you're doing is trying to persuade this fickle yeast to settle and make a home on your dough. You entice it, seduce it, with things that it loves, such as malt, vitamin C, and perhaps a little Roberta Flack. If you create the right conditions, it'll stay with you for as long as you look after it, and will provide the basis of great bread forever.

The most distinctive, basic bread Baker & Spice produce is its thick-crusted, flavoursome pain au levain. The starter for this contains no more than wholemeal and strong white flour, water, honey and orange juice, with the later addition of salt and semolina to the finished article. The recipe is detailed in Lepard and Richard Whittington's indispensable Baker & Spice: Baking with Passion (£18.99, Quadrille), and looks easy as sin when you watch the experts do it. Or you can learn how to make croissants instead.

Baker & Spice's buttery croissants are meals in themselves. They use a drier dough than is traditional, for a crisper finish. We begin by mixing together one sachet of fast-action yeast (any brand will do), 100g of strong white flour (must be stone-ground: Dove's Farm organic, or Churchill's are recommended) and 110ml of warm, bottled water, then covering with clingfilm and leaving to stand for two hours. It rises by a third and is combined with the remaining ingredients: 400g of flour, 110ml cold milk, 20g fine-ground Maldon salt and 70g caster sugar. These can be mixed automatically, then kneaded by hand to develop the gluten. Fluency at kneading is more difficult to acquire than I'd expected. Push forward with the heel of your hand, fold in half, stand on end and push again, until you're terrifically bored. Now wrap the dough in clingfilm and leave overnight in the fridge.

The rest of our lesson is conducted Blue Peter style, with dough that Lepard made earlier. A 250g pack of butter ('the best you've got, unsalted') is bashed between wrappers, with a rolling pin, into a flat, 1cm-thick rectangle, after which the dough is rolled into a similar, though much larger, 1cm-thick shape. The butter is then placed on the flat dough and the edges pulled over it, creating a smaller rectangular parcel. Each end is folded in by a quarter, so that they meet in the middle, then in half, as if closing a book. The resulting construction is then rolled out again and the process repeated, leaving a layered parcel which is to be sealed at the edges with pressure from the rolling pin, wrapped in clingfilm and refrigerated for a further hour.

Flattened one final time, into a neat rectangle, approximately 75cm by 30cm, the pastry is cut into eight triangles and gently stretched lengthwise, before being rolled into crescents, inwards from the short side of the triangle. These are glazed with egg yolk and milk, baked in the centre of the oven at 200C for 10 minutes, then a further 20-25 at 150C. Eaten warm, they unwind and melt deliciously in the mouth.

I try some at home with the children, and they are not quite so delicate. Baking, I realise, takes practice. 'We get the bread we deserve,' Lepard observes, with a suggestion that we make a habit of requesting particular loaves from our local bakers. If your local bakery is anything like mine, wear a helmet when you do this. Bon appetit.

fields.headline: Thunder road
fields.standfirst: The well-behaved car engines of toady are a world away from the attention-seeking growlers of old. Jonathan Glancey hears the music of the gears.
fields.trailText: The well-behaved car engines of toady are a world away from the attention-seeking growlers of old. Jonathan Glancey hears the music of the gears.
fields.body:
I gotta '69 Chevy with a 396
Fuelie heads and a Hurst on the floor
She's waiting tonight down in the parking lot
Outside the 7-Eleven store

That's Bruce Springsteen singing the praises of a souped-up Chevrolet in 'Racing in the Street'. Cars have featured in many more pop songs than motor shows have been held at Earl's Court, but their motive power - engines, motors, 'lumps', 'mills' - has rarely been so celebrated.

Springsteen's song leaps out of the speakers with a tautly accurate description of a big, powerful General Motors engine. We knows its size, or cubic capacity (the swept volume of its cylinders). This is the 'three-ninety-six' or 396 cubic inches, for which read BIG. We also know, because this is the way a transatlantic 396 is, that this is a V8. We're not talking vegetable juice, but the juice or gas (petrol) that pumps through this Chevrolet's 'fuelie heads' and so into each of its eight mighty cylinders. The V8 is the legendary arrangement of nearly all great US engines. It sounds good when you say it, and when you hear one - that great woolla-woolla-woolla rumble - you don't have to look to know that a Big Yank is heading your way. A classic V8 rocks'n'rolls.

Save for unrepentant petrol-heads, such celebration must seem arcane in an age when not only does it seem somehow morally wrong to sing the virtues of power generated by internal-combustion, but when it's a fact that most mass-production car engines can now be left to their own devices - unseen and as far as possible unheard - for up to 12,000 miles, or a year's motoring. And yet, engines were once something to show and see. Not only were early motorists proud of them, but they needed to be groomed and cosseted as much as a prized hunter. Without constant attention, the engine of even a Rolls-Royce might shudder to some untimely halt. It had to be easy to get at and, because it was so much on show, it was very often a thing of substantial and gleaming copper, brass and shining steel.

This 'because-you-have-to-see-it, we'll-make-sure-it's-worth-seeing' attitude to the design of engines lasted until they be could be all but ignored. The 'maintenance' section of the driver's manual of my old 1962 3.8-litre Mk2 Jaguar opened with the word 'daily'. Now this engine was a magnificent device, the same in fact that had powered Jaguar to victory several times at Le Mans in the 50s. It was fundamentally reliable, deep-down powerful and made a glorious noise. Yet, every day, the oil and coolant needed to be checked and topped up if necessary, and a beady eye cast over rubber seals designed to keep oil and coolant flowing in their proper channels and to check for leaks.

To make this task less irksome, Jaguar styled its twin-cam XK engine to delight the eye. When Jaguar's engineers were plotting a new engine for the up-and-coming MkVII saloon in the late Forties, they agreed that a conventional push-rod, overhead-valve engine would do the trick. It would produce the required 160bhp and give the big, voluptuous saloon that their boss, William Lyons, was busy styling, an effortless top speed of 100mph, when most cars of its class were hard-pressed to top 80.

A conventional push-rod, overhead-valve engine, said Lyons, just wouldn't do. It wouldn't look special. When Jag drivers lifted the bonnet of their walnut and leather-lined luxury expresses, they should be presented with the mechanical equivalent of a Faberg egg. Which was what? Something along the lines of the classic pre-war, twin-cam sports or racing engines that powered gloriously fast Alfa Romeos. And so, the Jaguar engine, made from 1948 to 1986, with its twin-camshafts (the cases of which give such engines their stirring and distinct profile as well as their rorty performance) was as much a product of styling and marketing as it was of common-sense engineering.

Very fast cars are still powered by beautiful engines: for the point of a Ferrari, say, is not to pootle from Assisi to Bari in sybaritic comfort, but, in part, to listen to the orchestral music of its mighty quad-cam engine howling with vulpine intensity as the car rockets up and down hairpin Apennine passes. Those mercurial V8 and V12 engines from Modena are meant to thrill as a Merlin engine thrills when a Spitfire climbs, curving away from an airfield at 3,000rpm and full boost, or a brand new 3,500hp QJ 2-10-2 steam locomotive of the Chinese National Railway thrills as it barks up the daunting curves of the Jinpeng pass in Inner Mongolia, hauling an impossibly long freight train through a driving blizzard at the beginning of the 21st century. The engine in a Ford Fiesta is not meant to excite in quite the same ways.

The engines of low-powered cars can be exciting, though. Raise the wibbly-wobbly bonnet of a Citro'n 2CV and, hidden away below the gearbox and other gubbins, is one of the finest of all car engines: a tiny, twin-cylinder, horizontally opposed, all-aluminium motor, that has as few parts as possible and is all but unburstable.

A 2CV can be driven flat-out in top gear until it runs out of fuel. It even sounds good as it does so, humming along like some Olympic version of the very finest sewing machine. In other cars designed to travel slowly but surely, engines have been tucked completely out of sight, as in the case of many Volkswagens. This is either a negation of the engine, or else a vote of confidence by VW in the design and quality of its trusty air-cooled motors.

Here, then, we have the two poles of engine design: the motor shaped for speed and on display, and the motor as discreet, if not entirely silent, servant. In between is an infinite balance between performance and display. In between, too, is the language of engines. No, not Bruce Springsteen's rock'n'roll poetry, but the patois of the girls and boys in the marketing departments of car manufacturers who insist, even now, on talking techno-babble to sell machines that are fundamentally sound but ultimately forgettable. There was 'turbo' talk in the Eighties as there had been fuel-injection ('GTi' talk) in the Seventies. It was pretty much gobbledegook.

Turbocharging proved to be little more than a fairly crude and inefficient way of squeezing occasional dollops of power from essentially low-performance engines and adding a fashionable badge - 'Turbo' - to boost the sales of otherwise uninteresting cars. Yet, as 'spin' is more important in contemporary British politics than belief or positive action, so marketing is ultimately more important in the motor industry than engineering. Soon enough, few people will speak, or even dare to speak, with anything like enthusiasm for engines. The smooth chatter of advertising execs shimmering back from a focus group and the hum of electric motors will drown out for ever the wild, cowboy roar of a fuelie headed three-ninety-six.

 The Haynes Motor Museum, Sparkford, near Yeovil, Somerset BA22 7LH (01963 440 804), houses a large collection of vintage, veteran and classic cars and motorcycles. The museum is open daily March to October, 9.30am-5.50pm, and November to February, 10am-4.30pm
