We're not talking vegetable juice, but the juice or gas (petrol) that pumps through this Chevrolet's 'fuelie heads' and so into each of its eight mighty cylinders. The V8 is the legendary arrangement of nearly all great US engines. It sounds good when you say it, and when you hear one - that great woolla-woolla-woolla rumble - you don't have to look to know that a Big Yank is heading your way. A classic V8 rocks'n'rolls. Save for unrepentant petrol-heads, such celebration must seem arcane in an age when not only does it seem somehow morally wrong to sing the virtues of power generated by internal-combustion, but when it's a fact that most mass-production car engines can now be left to their own devices - unseen and as far as possible unheard - for up to 12,000 miles, or a year's motoring. And yet, engines were once something to show and see. Not only were early motorists proud of them, but they needed to be groomed and cosseted as much as a prized hunter. Without constant attention, the engine of even a Rolls-Royce might shudder to some untimely halt. It had to be easy to get at and, because it was so much on show, it was very often a thing of substantial and gleaming copper, brass and shining steel. This 'because-you-have-to-see-it, we'll-make-sure-it's-worth-seeing' attitude to the design of engines lasted until they be could be all but ignored. The 'maintenance' section of the driver's manual of my old 1962 3.8-litre Mk2 Jaguar opened with the word 'daily'. Now this engine was a magnificent device, the same in fact that had powered Jaguar to victory several times at Le Mans in the 50s. It was fundamentally reliable, deep-down powerful and made a glorious noise. Yet, every day, the oil and coolant needed to be checked and topped up if necessary, and a beady eye cast over rubber seals designed to keep oil and coolant flowing in their proper channels and to check for leaks. To make this task less irksome, Jaguar styled its twin-cam XK engine to delight the eye. When Jaguar's engineers were plotting a new engine for the up-and-coming MkVII saloon in the late Forties, they agreed that a conventional push-rod, overhead-valve engine would do the trick. It would produce the required 160bhp and give the big, voluptuous saloon that their boss, William Lyons, was busy styling, an effortless top speed of 100mph, when most cars of its class were hard-pressed to top 80. A conventional push-rod, overhead-valve engine, said Lyons, just wouldn't do. It wouldn't look special. When Jag drivers lifted the bonnet of their walnut and leather-lined luxury expresses, they should be presented with the mechanical equivalent of a Faberg egg. Which was what? Something along the lines of the classic pre-war, twin-cam sports or racing engines that powered gloriously fast Alfa Romeos. And so, the Jaguar engine, made from 1948 to 1986, with its twin-camshafts (the cases of which give such engines their stirring and distinct profile as well as their rorty performance) was as much a product of styling and marketing as it was of common-sense engineering. Very fast cars are still powered by beautiful engines: for the point of a Ferrari, say, is not to pootle from Assisi to Bari in sybaritic comfort, but, in part, to listen to the orchestral music of its mighty quad-cam engine howling with vulpine intensity as the car rockets up and down hairpin Apennine passes. Those mercurial V8 and V12 engines from Modena are meant to thrill as a Merlin engine thrills when a Spitfire climbs, curving away from an airfield at 3,000rpm and full boost, or a brand new 3,500hp QJ 2-10-2 steam locomotive of the Chinese National Railway thrills as it barks up the daunting curves of the Jinpeng pass in Inner Mongolia, hauling an impossibly long freight train through a driving blizzard at the beginning of the 21st century. The engine in a Ford Fiesta is not meant to excite in quite the same ways. The engines of low-powered cars can be exciting, though. Raise the wibbly-wobbly bonnet of a Citro'n 2CV and, hidden away below the gearbox and other gubbins, is one of the finest of all car engines: a tiny, twin-cylinder, horizontally opposed, all-aluminium motor, that has as few parts as possible and is all but unburstable. A 2CV can be driven flat-out in top gear until it runs out of fuel. It even sounds good as it does so, humming along like some Olympic version of the very finest sewing machine. In other cars designed to travel slowly but surely, engines have been tucked completely out of sight, as in the case of many Volkswagens. This is either a negation of the engine, or else a vote of confidence by VW in the design and quality of its trusty air-cooled motors. Here, then, we have the two poles of engine design: the motor shaped for speed and on display, and the motor as discreet, if not entirely silent, servant. In between is an infinite balance between performance and display. In between, too, is the language of engines. No, not Bruce Springsteen's rock'n'roll poetry, but the patois of the girls and boys in the marketing departments of car manufacturers who insist, even now, on talking techno-babble to sell machines that are fundamentally sound but ultimately forgettable. There was 'turbo' talk in the Eighties as there had been fuel-injection ('GTi' talk) in the Seventies. It was pretty much gobbledegook. Turbocharging proved to be little more than a fairly crude and inefficient way of squeezing occasional dollops of power from essentially low-performance engines and adding a fashionable badge - 'Turbo' - to boost the sales of otherwise uninteresting cars. Yet, as 'spin' is more important in contemporary British politics than belief or positive action, so marketing is ultimately more important in the motor industry than engineering. Soon enough, few people will speak, or even dare to speak, with anything like enthusiasm for engines. The smooth chatter of advertising execs shimmering back from a focus group and the hum of electric motors will drown out for ever the wild, cowboy roar of a fuelie headed three-ninety-six.  The Haynes Motor Museum, Sparkford, near Yeovil, Somerset BA22 7LH (01963 440 804), houses a large collection of vintage, veteran and classic cars and motorcycles. The museum is open daily March to October, 9.30am-5.50pm, and November to February, 10am-4.30pm

fields.headline: Sugar and spice
fields.standfirst: A child-friendly restaurant that serves decent food is still such a rarity these days that Jay Rayner even considered moving to Brighton to be near The Tin Drum
fields.trailText: A child-friendly restaurant that serves decent food is still such a rarity these days that Jay Rayner even considered moving to Brighton to be near The Tin Drum
fields.body:
I sniffed the air. Cinnamon. Definitely cinnamon. My five-month-old son grinned up at me from the changing table, nappy akimbo. I have smelled many things during this process, in the 20-odd weeks since the mantle of parenthood was thrust upon me - none of which deserves reference in a restaurant review - but I can safely say that cinnamon is not one of them. I wondered whether a trip to the paediatrician was in order. Doctor, my boy smells like a croissant from Prêt à Manger. What should I do? Franchise him? Of course, I know the rhyme about sugar and spice and all things nice, but surely this was taking it too far? And anyway, that was the verse about girls, wasn't it?

Then I spotted it: an automatic air freshener, fixed high up the wall. Normally I hate the things. But this one was different. It was subtle. It was pleasant. It was much nicer than the smells that usually emanate from my son's bottom. And that, bizarrely, was the point at which I fell in love with The Tin Drum and wished I lived in Brighton so I could visit it daily.

It was not just the presence of the air freshener but where it was located: in a baby's changing room, complete with sturdy changing table. There were also highchairs stacked up against the wall. I have come across these things before, of course, but only in motorway service stations, or those Formica-and-polystyrene fast-food gaffs eagerly selling a cheap 'family experience' to desperate parents. Restaurateurs in Britain generally do not like small children. Sure, they will tolerate them, but only in as much as they will tolerate a headache or a cold. Real restaurants serving carefully cooked adult food which also welcome babies with open arms are few and very far between. The Tin Drum is one of them. To be fair, I didn't really need to try out the changing room to spot this. I could have worked it out from the clientele: every other table in the wide, airy room had a pram or pushchair standing sentry next to it. There was a pram at either end of ours - 11-month-old Lola asleep in one, five-month-old Eddie asleep in the other - and there was still room for everybody to move about.

What's more, the high ceiling of the comfortably scuffed wood-floored room meant that the yelps and cries of even the most exuberant child were lost on the echo. If there is some connection in the decor of The Tin Drum to the Günter Grass novel of the same name, it was not immediately apparent to me, though there is a wall of secondhand books which you can buy from a shop a couple of doors down if you find a title you wish to carry away with you. As to the food, it is good, solid, workmanlike stuff; not showy, and certainly not ambitious, but good enough to remind a new parent that they are still a person. Believe me, that is a rare enough pleasure. There is a Mittel European slant to it - so a dusting of paprika here, a little sour cream there - but for the most part, it is just bistro fare, sensibly and cheaply presented. My wife had the Polish fillet steak at £6.50. It was perfectly cooked and came with a dollop of sour cream which, she announced, was such a good accompaniment to the meat that a tub of the stuff should henceforth take up residence in our fridge. Lola's dad had the pork schnitzel in a rich creamy sauce at £7.95 (the most expensive dish on the short lunchtime menu). He, too, gave a satisfied thumbs up. Lola's mum and I both had the chicken and bacon salad. It was a straightforward piece of assembly, though the dressing was a little underpowered. I said as much to the waitress, and she swiftly brought me a jug of something a little more ballsy. All the dishes came with a heap of big chunky chips that were so crisp they rustled against each other when the plate was disturbed.

For pudding, my wife had the pecan pie. She declared herself a little disappointed: it was more of a solid cake than the nut-and-caramel crusted tart we have become used to, and it came with a slick of crème anglaise rather than the ice cream she had asked for, but she was in a forgiving mood and somehow forced herself to finish the lot. I had the apple strudel, which was a good mix of sweet and sour. This time, the advertised ice cream did turn up. It was cinnamon flavour. In Proust's Remembrance of Things Past it is a Madeleine cake dipped in tea which transports a character back to his childhood; at the Tin Drum it was a scoop of cinnamon ice cream which transported me back to my son's bare bottom. What an aid to digestion.

 The Tin Drum, 95-97 Dyke Road, Brighton (01273 777575). Lunch for two, including drinks and service, £35

fields.headline: Nine of the best
fields.standfirst: Restaurants for Valentine's Day meals and shops for the perfect Valentine's gifts
fields.trailText: Restaurants for Valentine's Day meals and shops for the perfect Valentine's gifts
fields.body:
Most starry-eyed lovers will have spotted 14 February looming and made arrangements accordingly. But it is still possible to buy a few last-minute heart-shaped tokens - for example, a hand-moulded brioche at £1.80 from Betty's (1 Parliament Street, Harrogate, North Yorkshire, 01423 502746; with branches at 32 The Grove, Ilkley, 01943 608029; 188 High Street, Northallerton, 01609 775154 and 6-8 St Helen's Square, York, 01904 659142). Chocolate is a Valentine's staple, and Betty's offers a small box containing seven heart shapes - a mix of white, milk and dark - for £4.45. Betty's Swiss-trained chocolatiers use Belgian chocolate with 57 per cent cocoa solids; not too bitter, and easy to work with and mould.

At Carluccio's (shop at 28a Neal Street, London WC2, 020 7240 1487; Café at 8 Market Place, London W1; 020 7636 2228), milk-chocolate hearts come small and foil-wrapped at 10p each, or large at £1.10 each. Indeed, you can have almost any item you like so long as it is heart-shaped: a bitter-chocolate truffle cake (£8.50), biscuits decorated with scarlet and gold (£2.50), a heart loaf with a rosemary arrow (£1.50 or £3), and even a heart-shaped vegetable pie for two with cavolo nero, artichokes, pine nuts, yellow peppers and red salsa (£7). Alternatively, they will sell you a scarlet box (£38) containing the wherewithal to 'make your own instant dinner for two'; it consists of asparagus, egg pasta with truffle sauce, peaches in dolcetto, toroncini almond bars, the heart-shaped loaf and arrow mentioned above, and a half bottle of Pinot Grigio.

Among posh hotels, The Connaught (16 Carlos Place, London W1; 020 7499 7070) seems to have gone further than most by instituting a Valentine Truffle Trail, from now until next Sunday. Informal lectures and presentations precede specified lunches (£60) and dinners (five courses plus coffee for £75, plus 15 per cent service charge in each case), but the truffle menu (which includes filet d'Angus aux diamants noirs and supreme de turbot demi-deuil) will be available until mid-March.

If being treated to an expensive night out - with every gastronomic luxury you can think of - is an aphrodisiac, then any number of places will oblige. Orrery (55-57 Marylebone High Street, London W1; 020 7616 8000) is serving up a five-course meal (£90 a head) that includes ravioli of lobster and white asparagus, and duck with cep jus. Claridge's (Brook Street, London W1; 020 7629 8860) offers a Menu for Him (including oyster cappuccino Aphrodite, and roast fillet of lamb with foie gras) and a Menu for Her (including chicken with truffle cream) at £75 a head, with 'a box of chocolates for ladies' thrown in. The Menu for Sharing (£150 for two) takes in smoked salmon and caviar, beef Wellington with truffles and pink Champagne sorbet, and ends with a chocolate 'indulgence'. Out of town, 'the century's first Valentine's Day' can be celebrated at The Lygon Arms (High Street, Broadway, Worcestershire; 01386 852255), with dinner in the barrel-vaulted Great Hall, Champagne on arrival, a night's accommodation and English breakfast, all for 25p short of £200 a head.

There are less expensive options for a Monday evening in mid-February. Belair House (Gallery Road, West Dulwich, London SE21; 020 8299 9788) weighs in with five courses (among them oysters, and fillet of beef with foie gras and wild mushrooms) for £49.50. Pink Champagne and foie gras (along with lobster and scallop ravioli) are part of the Valentine's attraction at County Hall Restaurant (County Hall, London SE1; 020 7902 8000), where four courses will cost £39.50.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of 'The Good Food Guide'

fields.headline: Focus groups
fields.trailText: The knowledge that artists of the past used lenses and mechanical aids is hardly new (Focus, last week). Albrecht Durer, one of the All Time Greats, published a wood-engraving demonstrating the use of a pinhole for perspective in 1525. A pinhole is the simplest sort of lens. You can bet that if Durer had owned a slide-projector, he would have used it. Canaletto, painting his perspectives of the Venetial canals, used a camera obscura.
fields.body:
The knowledge that artists of the past used lenses and mechanical aids is hardly new (Focus, last week). Albrecht Durer, one of the All Time Greats, published a wood-engraving demonstrating the use of a pinhole for perspective in 1525. A pinhole is the simplest sort of lens. You can bet that if Durer had owned a slide-projector, he would have used it. Canaletto, painting his perspectives of the Venetial canals, used a camera obscura.

As any aspiring artist knows, owning the latest camera does not make one a genius. For a painting, a lens can save time and tedious effort but has little to do with talent. Using a word processor to write a book does not make it a lesser or greater creation, and it's not morally superior to using a quill pen.
Merryl Cook
Stockport

webTitle: It's not the IRA who are at fault

fields.headline: It's not the IRA who are at fault
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) writes that the peace process is on the brink of collapse 'because the IRA will not keep its promise about decommissioning'. That view cannot be justified for the simple reason that the IRA has never promised to decommission any of its arms. Nor has Sinn Fein promised to get the IRA to decommission any of its arms.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) writes that the peace process is on the brink of collapse 'because the IRA will not keep its promise about decommissioning'. That view cannot be justified for the simple reason that the IRA has never promised to decommission any of its arms. Nor has Sinn Fein promised to get the IRA to decommission any of its arms.

The Good Friday agreement commits all parties to the agreement (including Sinn Fein) 'to use any influence they may have' to achieve the decommissioning of all paramilitary arms within two years following endorsement in referendums North and South of the agreement [that is, 22 May this year].

That does not require the actual decommissioning of IRA weapons prior to Sinn Fein's participation in the Executive. All it requires is that Sinn Fein, and all other parties to the Agreement, 'use any influence they may have' to achieve decommissioning. It does not require the use of influence on anybody's part to be successful.
David Morrison
Belfast

Your review of arms in Northern Ireland (News, last week) fell short of being complete. There are five 'groups' holding arms at present - the British Army, the RUC, the Catholic terrorist groups, the Protestant terrorist groups, and approximately 9,500 individuals, all of whom legitimately carry handguns for self defence.

The last group includes many if not all of the Protestant politicians involved in the current processes. When Trimble, and every other high-profile Northern Ireland politician, holds forth on disarmament one cannot help wondering if he has a loaded handgun tucked in his belt!
Graham R Brown
Ampthill
Bedford

fields.headline: Sky's the limit
fields.body:
Could the BSkyB company which is currently complaining about the BBC being able to cross-subsidise News 24 by any chance be related to the News International corporation which used profits from the Sun to subsidise a cut in the price of the Times as part of an attempt to drive another newspaper out of business? I think we should be told.
Dr Martin Cloonan
Glasgow

webTitle: Take the capital out of London

fields.headline: Take the capital out of London
fields.trailText: Messrs Reeves and McSmith fairly accurately described London's theft of the UK economy but then incorrectly claimed this cancer on the UK makes a disproportionately high economic contribution to the country (Focus, last week).
fields.body:
Messrs Reeves and McSmith fairly accurately described London's theft of the UK economy but then incorrectly claimed this cancer on the UK makes a disproportionately high economic contribution to the country (Focus, last week).

This calculation ignores investment classed as 'national', hence the distortion of allocation of lottery funds, the unfair (and disastrous) allocation of millennial spending and the, much more important, concentration of government and company head offices in the capital. Not only does London rob the rest of the country of this investment it then forces people like me to subsidise it.

Most the political problems posed by devolution, migration to the South-East and the growing North-South divide could be solved at a stroke - kick London and the South-East out of the UK.
Roger Marston
Craven Arms
Salop

There are two Londons. There is the London of the West End, the galleries and museums, the chic restaurants, the money and the power. Against this, there is the London where the inhabitants have never been to see a production in the West End, who will never set foot in an art gallery, who cannot afford to wine and dine in elegant restaurants, and who have little money, less power and to whom the first London seems like a different place with a distinct and alien culture. London vs Britain is a false argument. Inequality, in all forms, needs to be addressed and we must not mislead ourselves with 'red herring' debates.
Andy Walsh
Carlisle

Yes, London is too dominant. Some redress could be achieved by moving parliament to a deprived, northern area. It would be followed by the civil service, much of the media, the middle-class think tanks, the lobbyists, and those who spent years currying favour to obtain top positions. The outcome would not only reduce the power of London, it would also inject economic resources and public attention to the North.
Bob Holman
Glasgow

Most the political problems posed by devolution, migration to the South-East and the growing North-South divide could be solved at a stroke - kick London and the South-East out of the UK. fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Screenwriter and director Neil Jordan and actor Stephen Rea have a bad track record when it comes to owning race houses, but when it comes to making films, they are a perfect team
fields.trailText: Screenwriter and director Neil Jordan and actor Stephen Rea have a bad track record when it comes to owning race houses, but when it comes to making films, they are a perfect team
fields.body:
Neil Jordan I'm not sure when and where we first met, but I do remember seeing him with a whole lot of other people in a pub on the Ball's Pond Road in Islington. The Duke of Wellington is a meeting place for Irish expats, with a theatre in the back room. I saw him in a production of a play by Tom Murphy called The Blue Macushla. It was done like a film noir, and directed by Jim Sheridan, and I thought Stephen had a remarkable cinematic quality, a great ability with silence. Most actors find it very hard to do nothing - that's my experience anyway. Later, when we did The Butcher Boy, there was the party scene, and it was like a battle of lessness. Stephen was doing so little; and all the other actors were trying to do as little as Stephen, but they actually couldn't manage it.

I deliberately wrote the screenplay Angel with him in mind. Well, it was about the north of Ireland, where he's from. And it worked, because he had the courage to carry the meaning of the film. He's wonderful to work with, a delightful person and he gives a deeply considered performance. When you watch the rushes of a day's filming, the sum of what he's doing is not always evident. It's only later that his full scope emerges; he has a unique way of carrying the intelligence of a movie.

Angel was the first Irish feature film with an Irish crew - rather than American. It was the early 80s, which was a very black time with all those sectarian murders. I used to play in a band, and we would perform at Queen's University in Belfast and drive back at night, which was quite scary because the road would be blocked off. A band was actually killed.

You always thought that musicians were like sports personalities or circus performers - immune to violent conflict. So that put the idea in my mind for this person Danny, who Stephen played, who gets drawn into the conflict. I didn't plan to keep casting Stephen, but it kept happening. Once you work with people you like, you work with them again, if you're lucky enough to get them. In The Butcher Boy, he plays the part of the father, which on the face of it is quite small, but I can't think of another actor who would have the nous to realise that it's the commanding role, the binding one. He brought a great sense of comedy to those voice-overs. He has a great gift for comedy which I haven't been able to utilise because I'm not that kind of writer.

We offered the part of Henry, the cuckolded civil servant in The End of the Affair [at cinemas nationwide], to a whole lot of people and they all got offended. I suppose there's not much for an actor to latch on to in the role. But when you can take something as insubstantial as that, when you can make an unglamorous man live, it's far more of an achievement. Stephen turned it down initially and I asked him to read the part again. I felt that there was more to it than he thought. After talking to him, I did develop the dignity of the role towards the end of the film. A relationship with an actor does affect the writing. Stephen is a very private person and highly politicised. His choice of work is proof of that. I know that fatherhood is hugely important to him and that he's devoted to his two sons, Danny and Oscar. You can just tell from watching them together. Our kids socialise a bit. We also used to own a racehorse together called Christie's Picnic. It lost a lot of races. We got another one called Butcher Boy which won nothing, as well.

I certainly want to work with him again, but there's nothing in the pipeline right now. I'd actually like him to direct a film. In a way, he's too bright to be an actor. If you've got the intelligence to see beyond your role, then at a certain stage acting can become unsatisfying I know that's a terrible thing to say.

Stephen Rea I think we first met some time between 1978 and 1980. We were part of the same literary crowd. I just knew him as a writer of amazing short stories - they have as strong an atmosphere as James Joyces's Dubliners and they're every bit as cinematic. We went for a drink, after he saw a show I was in, and later he gave me the screenplay of Angel to read.

When you look at Angel everything is there, in place, right from the beginning. Oscar Wilde said that only mediocrity improves, and in a sense his work is the same now, except that his ability to compose shots and control the experience for the audience has developed a lot.

As a person, he's only changed in that he's become much more open socially. He used to be desperately shy. So much so that it was sometimes difficult to know what he was talking about; he would start in the middle of a sentence. Still, he has enormous confidence in his own ability, in the importance of his vision, which I envy. Our backgrounds are very different. His father was a teacher, who made him read a lot, and his mother was an artist. My father was a bus driver, so I don't think it was as great a leap for Neil to write as it was for me to act.

He writes his own screenplays so you don't have to waste time begging him to understand the writing in the way that you have to with some directors who aren't writers. I'm always amazed that he allows actors to change the script. Sometimes, I think what he wrote was better.

We don't work together in a planned way. He'll amble along and say, 'I'm doing this thing. Do you feel like' or 'you should be in this,' or 'the script is written. What do you want to do?'

In The Crying Game, I played Fergus, an IRA man. We made the film in 1992, which was a very dark time in Northern Ireland, and a lot of people were angry that I portrayed an IRA man as a human being. It would have been good if Fergus's colleagues had been played in a more rounded way, too. But our perspectives on Northern Ireland are different. I grew up in Belfast, while he grew up around the same time in Clontarf, north of Dublin. His Ireland had a lot of poverty and repression, but it was relatively peaceful. His attitude to the border is similar to that of a lot of people living in southern Ireland, in that they couldn't care less about it, whereas I do care.

When Neil first talked to me about The Crying Game, he didn't send me a script, he told me the story over dinner. He wanted to see my reaction when he said those words 'She's a man'. My jaw dropped and I wanted to roar with laughter, just as the audience in the cinema do.

Neil's work has been a substantial part of my career. I've done 24 films in all, but not many that are as good as his.

fields.headline: Pity Primrose
fields.trailText:
I was appalled by Nicci Gerrard's comments about Dr Harold Shipman's wife, Primrose (Review, last week). However terrible her husband's crimes may be, they are his murders. The highly personal attacks on an innocent indiviual ruined what was an otherwise sensible and thought-provoking piece.
Tim Hoof
Ware
Herts

Oldham

fields.headline: Drugs abuse
fields.body:
It is time for New Labour and their drug tsar to put up or shut up (News, last week). Unsurprisingly it is police officers who are bearing the brunt of the failed policy. The question is not if, but when, the Government admits it is throwing good money after bad and 'brings its boys home'.
Danny Kushlick
Transform Campaign for Effective Drug Policy
Bristol

fields.headline: Reunite Hungary
fields.body:
At the end of the First World War, we 'the victors' gave away two thirds of Hungarian territories and a large proportion of its population to Romania, Yugoslavia, Slovakia and Austria. Germany has been reunited with its wartime territorial losses and people, is it not about time that the same thing happened to Hungary? Or is it one rule for the rich and one for the poor?
Stuart Harding
St Albans
Herts

fields.headline: John Mortimer's country folly
fields.trailText: John Mortimer claims that the Government's decision to exclude the Countryside Alliance from a Downing Street gathering on rural Britain was 'like having a party for theatricals and failing to invite anyone from the Royal Shakespeare Company' (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
John Mortimer claims that the Government's decision to exclude the Countryside Alliance from a Downing Street gathering on rural Britain was 'like having a party for theatricals and failing to invite anyone from the Royal Shakespeare Company' (Comment, last week).

In reality, I would contend, it was like rather failing to invite the Cheam Players or the Lyminge Amateur Dramatic Society. The Countryside Alliance (née British Field Sports Society) has nothing to contribute to the countryside debate, other than a desire to retain a leisure activity which involves setting a pack of dogs on a wild mammal for personal gratification. And yet the Alliance claims that it represents all of rural Britain.

As the RSC never said: 'Is this a blagger I see before me?'
Mike Baker
International Fund for Animal Welfare
London SE1

I could imagine John Mortimer drinking warm beer while watching a cricket match, when he wrote the piece which appeared in your paper on Sunday.

He should visit the once mining villages of Easington and Dawdon among many others in East Durham, or Ashington in Northumberland, or Consett in West Durham to temper his enthusiasm for the rural glades of the Chilterns. There are quite a few families who have lived in this area for 70 years who have also suffered from government neglect. They cannot sell a Land Rover or two to make ends meet or let cottages to weekenders.

Stick to writing humorous stories about the law Mr Mortimer and leave the economics to Messrs Blair and Brown. They are doing quite well at the moment thank you!
R.A. Golightly
East Boldon
Tyne & Wear

John Mortimer blames rural decline on many things including what he describes as the previous government's mishandling of the BSE crisis.

No matter how many times this is repeated and no matter how many chocolate éclairs are thrown at Ministers, the fact remains that no government ever ordered any farmer to feed the remains of dead animals to cows, the classic herbivores. Unnatural practices in agriculture tend to produce some very unnatural consequences.
Brian P. Moss
Tamworth
Staffs

Your reports last week showed up the insane distribution of resources in contemporary Britain.

Jamie Doward estimated that the City advisers to Vodaphone in its takeover of Mannersmann have 'earned' about £400m (Business, last week).

John Mortimer reports that the Government is not willing to find £350 million to match European Union funding for farmers hit by the gyrations of the world agricultural markets (Comment, last week).

In my local area, £400m would roughly double the incomes of the entire population of West Newcastle for two years. But such beneficial transfers are unthinkable in Blair's Britain.
Jamie Gough
Newcastle upon Tyne

fields.headline: Culture clash fuels race riots
fields.standfirst: After three days of mob rule in southern Spain, Moroccans used as cheap labour are more sinned against than sinning
fields.trailText: The smell of blood hangs around the makeshift plastic tents housing 300 frightened Moroccans. Tonight, at least, the only victim is a goat slaughtered for supper by men who might easily be descendants of the Moors who ruled southern Spain for 700 years.
fields.body:
The smell of blood hangs around the makeshift plastic tents housing 300 frightened Moroccans. Tonight, at least, the only victim is a goat slaughtered for supper by men who might easily be descendants of the Moors who ruled southern Spain for 700 years.

Once again they have crossed the Mediterranean to seek their fortunes, this time as labourers in Almeria's blooming agricultural sector. And this time, too, the clash of cultures has brought violence. For three days last week gangs of Spaniards, furious at the murder of a local women, went on the rampage around the town of El Ejido, burning Moroccan homes and cars and trashing shops known to serve the foreigners.

The government, which has vowed to overturn a new law easing restrictions on illegal immigrants, has sent in hundreds of extra police, bringing a semblance of peace. But thousands of Moroccans are now on strike, an ominous development for the farmers making millions from the labour-intensive vegetable harvest.

Almeria was once known for desert landscapes that doubled for the American frontier in spaghetti westerns. Now it hosts massive greenhouses raised on every inch of ground between mountains and sea.

The production of tomatoes, cucumbers, aubergines, beans and other vegetables is now worth £980 million a year - which is why the town of El Ejido has 50,000 people and 49 banks. But the farmers need workers: hence the constant arrival, often by rickety wooden boats, of Moroccan immigrants. In January alone, 800 were arrested trying to enter Spain.

In Almeria they generally earn around £200 a month and live in shacks without light or water. They are barred from most local cafes and seen as criminals.

Mohamed Chograni, 31, did not make enough as a civil servant in Morocco to support his mother and siblings and so, a year ago, he made the perilous journey to Spain. 'If a man in Morocco has no work, but has children he must feed and send to school, well, he does not think about where he will sleep, he thinks only of them. The father of the family must sacrifice himself.

'There is a lack of knowledge between the Spanish and the Moroccans. There are people who ask, "Why do your men kiss each other?" Well, because it's a different culture. We have our culture, the good and the bad.'

Tensions have been rising in El Ejido since the double murder in January of two Spanish farmers, allegedly by a Moroccan employee. Anger exploded last weekend at the funeral of Encarnacion Lopez, a young woman stabbed by a Moroccan youth who tried to rob her. Her death confirmed the stereotypes - 'they' steal, 'they' rape, 'they' kill - even though her murderer is believed to be mentally ill.

The toll for last week's violence now stands at 84 wounded, 42 arrested and 18 in prison for violent attacks. 'People have just gone mad over the past few days,' says Javier, a Spanish worker farming peppers. 'The Moroccans do have a lot of right on their side because many of them have been abused.'

This attitude is not the norm in El Ejido. 'They say the Spanish are racists and we're not. They get exactly the same as us, wages, housing, everything, and then they kill people,' says Antonio, a farmer picking tomatoes. His mother, Maria, says: 'They need to adapt to our customs.' Which is presumably why every Moroccan must answer to a Spanish name. Apparently Mohamed is too complicated - Manolo is easier.

The Almeria growers have now agreed to compensate those Moroccans who lost homes and possessions in the riots - and have raised one million pesetas, around £4,000. They claim the strike is being ignored by most workers, yet also claim to be losing vast sums because of the stoppage.

Enlightened employers do exist: José Andres Rodriguez and his father employ a team of 12 Moroccans, some illegals, and house them, rent-free, in a property with power and water. He would love to legalise his workers but last year, of more than 8,000 work permits requested by Almerian farmers, only 2,600 were granted. And no one is sure yet what the new law really means for illegal immigrants.

With one of the lowest birth rates in Europe, Spain will soon be desperately short of workers - yet the farmers claim there are now too many Moroccans in Almeria. The immigrants say they will not work unless they are given decent housing, the chance to legalise their situation, and a bit of dignity. They impress impartial observers with their cleanliness, especially since most have to carry home water and wash clothes by hand. Nor do they seem to use drugs. There is some petty theft - clothes from lines and food from kitchens - but police admit most serious crime in the area is committed by Spaniards.

Everyone agrees, however, that the government is to blame for failing to regulate immigration and to meet basic social needs - at least the new law grants access to schooling and healthcare for all. Lawyers from SOS Racism are now in El Ejido, informing the immigrants of their rights and helping those arrested - but it is an uphill task.

'There is xenophobia here, but it is also a problem of integration, because the government has not done enough to help them join the local population,' says Angeles Garzon, an SOS Racism lawyer.

'People have just gone mad over the past few days,' says Javier, a Spanish worker farming peppers. 'The Moroccans do have a lot of right on their side because many of them have been abused.' This attitude is not the norm in El Ejido. 'They say the Spanish are racists and we're not. They get exactly the same as us, wages, housing, everything, and then they kill people,' says Antonio, a farmer picking tomatoes. His mother, Maria, says: 'They need to adapt to our customs.' Which is presumably why every Moroccan must answer to a Spanish name. Apparently Mohamed is too complicated - Manolo is easier. The Almeria growers have now agreed to compensate those Moroccans who lost homes and possessions in the riots - and have raised one million pesetas, around £4,000. They claim the strike is being ignored by most workers, yet also claim to be losing vast sums because of the stoppage. Enlightened employers do exist: José Andres Rodriguez and his father employ a team of 12 Moroccans, some illegals, and house them, rent-free, in a property with power and water. He would love to legalise his workers but last year, of more than 8,000 work permits requested by Almerian farmers, only 2,600 were granted. And no one is sure yet what the new law really means for illegal immigrants. With one of the lowest birth rates in Europe, Spain will soon be desperately short of workers - yet the farmers claim there are now too many Moroccans in Almeria. The immigrants say they will not work unless they are given decent housing, the chance to legalise their situation, and a bit of dignity. They impress impartial observers with their cleanliness, especially since most have to carry home water and wash clothes by hand. Nor do they seem to use drugs. There is some petty theft - clothes from lines and food from kitchens - but police admit most serious crime in the area is committed by Spaniards. Everyone agrees, however, that the government is to blame for failing to regulate immigration and to meet basic social needs - at least the new law grants access to schooling and healthcare for all. Lawyers from SOS Racism are now in El Ejido, informing the immigrants of their rights and helping those arrested - but it is an uphill task. 'There is xenophobia here, but it is also a problem of integration, because the government has not done enough to help them join the local population,' says Angeles Garzon, an SOS Racism lawyer.

fields.headline: Revealed: German behind Net chaos
fields.standfirst: Free speech on the net: Special report
fields.trailText: The German man who supplied the firepower for last week's attacks on major commercial websites says he did it for the good of the Internet.
fields.body:
The German man who supplied the firepower for last week's attacks on major commercial websites says he did it for the good of the Internet.

The 20-year-old from the Hanover area would only be identified as 'Mixter'. He said in an e-mail interview that he posted the devastating software and instructions on the Web four months ago.

He denounced the use of his Tribal Flood Network package by unidentified hackers to attack at least seven major sites as 'stupid and pointless'. He said his motive was to aid security standards on the Internet.

But Internet security chiefs denounced him as a 'bomb-maker' who had 'thrown a loaded gun into a room crowded with kids'.

The FBI was last night continuing its hunt for those who planted Tribal Flood Network programs on hundreds of host 'zombie' computers, timed to flood the targets with messages.

These are know as 'denial of service' attacks since they cause the target to crash under the volume of incoming traffic. They do not compromise data such as credit card details.

The identity of the hackers, probably an organised group, who launched the attacks is unknown although a theory was that they were protesting against increasing political and commercial control of the Web, and the fortunes being made in Internet stocks. FBI investigators and computer security experts traced the attack to two universities in California, a location in Oregon and one in Germany.

A desktop computer at the University of California in Santa Barbara was used for Tuesday's attack on CNN while while on-line trader eBay was hit in part from an Internet router at Stanford University. In neither case were the university authorities aware of the use to which the equipment had been put.

fields.headline: In love with love
fields.trailText: Love? On the whole, we're in favour. Over the centuries it has inspired heroism and fine poetry and, Trojan wars notwithstanding, generally keeps bellicose young men off the streets, providing a peaceable outlet for the adolescent rush of testosterone. Even in an age when the language of passion has coarsened beyond Lady Chatterley's worst nightmares, we celebrate our belief in the real thing with an orgy of hearts and roses on the feast of Saint Valentine. Everybody loves lovers: their eyes shine and they smile uncontrollably which makes life more agreeable for us all.
fields.body:
Love? On the whole, we're in favour. Over the centuries it has inspired heroism and fine poetry and, Trojan wars notwithstanding, generally keeps bellicose young men off the streets, providing a peaceable outlet for the adolescent rush of testosterone. Even in an age when the language of passion has coarsened beyond Lady Chatterley's worst nightmares, we celebrate our belief in the real thing with an orgy of hearts and roses on the feast of Saint Valentine. Everybody loves lovers: their eyes shine and they smile uncontrollably which makes life more agreeable for us all.

Love makes the world go round, they say. It also warms the bed, smooths life's ragged edges, irons shirts, rocks the cradle, bandages knees and worries about the future. It can sometimes ignore the lie, forgive the deception and hope for the best. Occasionally it retains enough energy to provide friendship until death intervenes. The virtues of love, thus listed, would appear to be of more use to men than women and there is statistical evidence that being married improves men's earnings and health. Women, on the other hand, live longer and more healthily outside marriage and, being financially able to, now initiate the majority of divorces.

So, here's the mystery. Why do men continue to treat love as a pleasant hobby, while women, at least according to current dogma, persist in making themselves miserable by chasing the chimera of everlasting love?

webTitle: These days, anyone can do it

fields.headline: These days, anyone can do it
fields.standfirst:
Free speech on the net: Special report

Using advice posted on the Internet, even rank amateurs can cripple corporations.
fields.trailText: Using advice posted on the Internet, even rank amateurs can cripple corporations.
fields.body:
'Dread' watches his PC boot up, then double-clicks his Internet service provider. He downloads a bulletin board for hackers and notes the day's latest tips. Minutes later, he's trying to rewrite the code for a university homepage, scribbling his name on the title page to prove his presence.

'Tips on how to break into websites are all over the Internet,' he says. 'There are bulletin boards for them, discussion groups, chat rooms and web magazines. Almost all of them say the information is to be used solely for self-protection - rubbish. It's all there to be used.'

Dread is 27, single, and working in the IT industry. His main targets are university sites. His motivation, he explains, is the sheer pleasure of knowing he can break into a site. Others have a more dangerous sense of mischief.

The Internet, with its emphasis on free speech, undoubtedly encourages subversive behaviour and also provides access to hacking methodology.

One revolutionary arm of the Internet is the bulletin board, where users swap gossip and expertise. Regularly updated information allows hackers to beat latest security measures.

One bulletin board tells how to retrieve emails from Hotmail accounts. The instructions are easily discovered and downloaded and easy for even novice hackers to understand. Last year, Hotmail's global service was disrupted for five hours when hackers broke in, and closed it down. The ease with which even elaborate servers are infiltrated is worrying to those trying to implement security. 'Online security must be a priority for companies wanting to trade on the Internet,' says Jason Wu, head of NetFront Communications, a California-based security firm that provides privacy for firms who do business on the Internet.

'Most of the hackers who have penetrated websites this week are amateurs,' he continues. 'None of them has resurfaced to boast about their exploits and successes, which is really how professionals make a reputation for themselves. These hackers don't seem to have any agenda either. They just want to shut down the Internet to other people.'

But these 'script kiddies' are increasingly chasing monetary gain. Last Christmas, CD Universe, a leading online music retailer, had its database of 300,000 accounts hacked into.

The hacker demanded $100,000 in ransom. When the company refused, the hacker threatened to post its customers' credit card numbers on the Internet. The bank details of 25,000 stolen accounts were made available for free.

Only the intervention of a service provider ensured the offending web page was removed from the Internet.

fields.headline: Inside the hacker's web
fields.standfirst: The computer genius whose virus crippled global websites has defended his creation.
fields.trailText: The man who calls himself Mixter is a German who has been in trouble with the law, but claims to be on the side of the angels. He is the inventor of the cyberweaponry which last week brought chaos to at least seven of the world's most important websites.
fields.body:
The man who calls himself Mixter is a German who has been in trouble with the law, but claims to be on the side of the angels. He is the inventor of the cyberweaponry which last week brought chaos to at least seven of the world's most important websites.

In an electronic interview with the New York Times, Mixter, who identified himself only as a 20-year-old German from the Hanover area, said last week's attacks had been 'stupid and pointless'.

He defended his publishing of the cyber disruption program 'Tribal Flood Network' on the Internet four months ago as a necessary step in the evolution of defensives measures which the Web must develop against the army of black-hat (malign) hackers motivated by mischief, spite, greed or, more honourably, by a desire to keep the Internet free from commercial and political control.

While Mixter said he was 'not trying to play down the negative aspects and dangers of this decision', he called last week's attacks 'an inevitable price to pay to be able to develop counter-measures and fixes'.

He said that security sites on the Internet were posting details which meant that 'everyone has an equal chance of informing himself about them and coming up with counter-measures'. This was 'only fair' because everyone on the Net could be affected by security issues.

But security experts, and even other hackers, criticised his explanation as disingenuous. One said it was like 'leaving a loaded gun in a room full of kids'.

Significantly, two of the computers believed to have been used to launch the 'denial of service' attacks - so called because they swamp target sites with millions of messages, causing them to crash - were located at universities in California, spiritual home of the Web as a liberating and democratic force.

A desktop computer at the University of California at Santa Barbara was used for the attack on CNN on Tuesday, while eBay was hit the same day by data transmitted in part from an Internet router at Stanford University. Investigators were also 'zeroing in' on locations in Oregon. Another source was said to be a computer in Germany, since disconnected.

The US Justice Department wants much tougher penalties for malign or mis chievous hacker attacks. FBI investigators - spurred on by the direct interest of President Clinton, who has called a 'summit' in Washington this week - are searching for the origins of the attacks.

The 'cybervandals' planted 'daemons' (disk and execution monitors) on hundreds of unwitting 'zombie' computers. They were programmed to launch 'co-ordinated packet flooding denial of service attacks'.

The US National Infrastructure Protection Centre posted a warning about 'Tribal Flood Network' earlier this month. It said it was 'highly concerned' because it had been reported on so many systems and appeared to be 'undergoing active development, testing and deployment'.

Mixter is one of thousands of computer virtuosi who inhabit an ambiguous world in which good may masquerade as evil and vice versa.

The computer industry has an established tradition of hiring 'tiger teams' of professional hackers who attack systems to test their security.

But that tradition has grown to embrace unauthorised attacks in which programmers find a way to invade or cripple a system, publish the details of the vulnerability and often accompany them with software that exploits the weakness.

The terms 'white hats', 'black hats' and 'grey hats' are used to classify hackers, but the lines are often vague. White-hat hackers grew out of the tiger teams. Since the Seventies, a number of US government laboratories have deployed special groups of employees who try to bring down systems in 'digital war games'.

Charles Palmer, manager of network security and cryptography at IBM Research, leads a squad of white hats who are paid by companies to attack their computer systems.

'A white hat does it when asked, under contract, with a "Get out of jail free" card,' Palmer said. 'We'll do the job, evaluate it, and tell the customer what we're doing.'

The grey-hat hackers straddle both worlds, sometimes acting like malicious hackers but in pursuit of some greater good, real or imagined.

Mixter says he is a grey-hat hacker who recently turned white hat. He said the conversion came when he crossed a few 'legal borders' in 1998 and 1999 and fell foul of German law officials.

Now, Mixter said, 'I am a white hat, the definition meaning that I am trying to contribute to improving security by doing what I do, and completely acting within the law and hacking ethics.'

Mark Rasch, a former federal prosecutor who is now a vice-president at Global Integrity, a computer security consulting firm in Reston, Virginia, said: 'There's always been a hacker ethos, and even the bad guys have thought there are some things you can do and some things that are off limits,

'I think we've reached a point where this kind of activity is almost universally decried as being off limits.'

Still, he added, even if Mixter had posted with the intent that attackers would use them, 'it's wrong, but probably not a crime'.

A member of the hacker group Cult of the Dead Cow, who goes by the handle Death Veggie, condemned the attacks as 'digital vandalism'.

'It doesn't take any skill, and it's purely destructive,' Death Veggie said. 'Once a hacker starts becoming really destructive, they stop being a hacker and become a criminal.'

Yet the Cult of the Dead Cow itself produced a program that enables a hacker to control another computer from a remote location.

Palmer consorts with such groups but refuses to recruit from their ranks, even if they claim to have gone straight. 'I don't hire reformed hackers because, let's just say, I've never really found one,' he said. 'It's like hiring an arsonist to be your fire marshal. Can you ever really sleep at night?'

At the same time, Palmer occasionally attends Defcon, an annual three-day hacker gathering in Las Vegas. He said: 'A lot of these guys get enough money to keep them in pizza. So many of them are so talented and a lot of these kids are absolutely gifted.'

Rasch, who was the lead prosecutor in a high-profile computer crime case from 1988-90, said he did not entirely agree with his former employer, the Justice Department, which is calling for stiffer penalties.

'There isn't a single case that we can point to and say, "If only the penalties were greater, the person would not have done this",' he said.

The denial of service attacks did not compromise data or sensitive commercial information like credit card details. But perceptions of Internet security took another hit on Friday when a small California Internet company said an unrelated hacker attack on its system last week had apparently gained access to consumer credit card numbers.

RealNames, a business in San Carlos, California, said the extent of the damage was hard to assess because the attack had come through mainland China, and the connection appeared to have shut down while the hackers were downloading data.

'Our best guess is that this was done by a traditional hacker, whose goal is not to steal but to prove that he has the ability to steal,' said RealNames chief executive Keith Teare, whose company sells an Internet address system.

Clinton's summit is expcted to increase co-operation in a young industry that is growing fast but has not made security a priority. The industry, in turn, wants to give advice to federal regulators who are seen as too unsophisticated.

Additional reporting by Katie Hafner of the New York Times

What drives the digital destroyers

White-hat hackers

Since the Seventies, government laboratories and some corporations have deployed special groups of employees who test computer security by trying to compromise a system or bring it down in 'digital war games'.

Black-hat hackers

Adhere to the philosophy that information should be free - including information about security weaknesses. For these people, 'breaking into a system or exposing its weaknesses is a good thing because truth and knowledge must win out,' says Dan Farmer, a network security specialist.

Grey-hat hackers

These straddle both worlds, sometimes acting like malicious hackers, but in pursuit of some greater good, whether real or imagined.

Three days of web mayhem

Hackers paralysed seven service providers last week with a blizzard of signals.

fields.headline: McCain's one final mission
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

How a network of Vietnam veterans is helping to galvanise the military vote
fields.trailText: The most heart-wrenching sight in America is suddenly the stuff of raw electoral politics, as John McCain and George W. Bush face off in the South Carolina primary and in the increasingly thrilling contest beyond.
fields.body:
The most heart-wrenching sight in America is suddenly the stuff of raw electoral politics, as John McCain and George W. Bush face off in the South Carolina primary and in the increasingly thrilling contest beyond.

It happens many times every day: an elderly couple - or maybe a mother and son or daughter - descend the ramp alongside The Wall of Silent Names that is the Vietnam Memorial in Washington DC, almost suffocating at its deepest point. They are given a piece of tracing paper, a crayon, an envelope and maybe a step ladder, and find one of those engraved names, all that remains of a loved one lost decades ago. They rub the name on to the paper, linger awhile staring at that piece of wall, then they climb - solemnly, sometimes tearfully - back up the ramp, clutching the envelope.

The Vietnam gash is America's deepest and unhealed wound, but has been politically sidelined until this election, when a convergence of factors has brought Nam back into frame. This time around, the veterans and those families whom the dead left behind at The Wall are vital political statistics. One factor is John McCain's remarkable Vietnam record of courage in the face of torture - especially as contrasted with that of Bush, who dodged the war with help from his father to sit around as a National Guardsman in Texas. McCain is trying all he can to translate his life story into votes.

But the McCain mutiny is in turn symptomatic of something which cuts much deeper: a growing popular conviction that the Vietnam War was, after all, a just war, that its veterans and bereaved families should be vindicated not reviled, that the peacenik Sixties got it wrong.

It is a mood-swing ex-pressed in a new book by anti-war Democrat Michael Lind, the title of which speaks for itself: Vietnam: The Necessary War. Maybe not The Good War - as Studs Terkel's cult book described World War II - but getting better.

The veterans of Nam now targeted by McCain were, most of them, the poor from the prairies, mountains and ghettoes who returned to face the hatred of the military establishment for losing and of the liberals for having gone in the first place. They watched 'Hanoi' Jane Fonda marry a media mogul and draft-dodger Bill Clinton become President.

But now, says Rand Lewis, a veteran who teaches Vietnam classes at Idaho University, 'finally, after all these years, the American public has accepted the veterans back into the fold'. Not only that, but they have a presidential candidate from among their own.

McCain is now a serious politician and has done the mathematics. There are 8.5 million veterans of Vietnam-age or younger. Three million of them served in Vietnam, of whom 300,000 were wounded like him. South Carolina boasts the heaviest concentration per capita: 450,000 vets - 10 per cent of the state's population (second is New Hampshire). If they all voted for McCain, he would need no one else.

And if he can win South Carolina on 19 February, McCain's campaign goes truly national - to all those tens of thousands of places where the black flag of the veterans and 'POW/MIA' (prisoner of war/missing in action) movements flies from city hall or state Capitol.

So McCain's election poster shows not the present-day, bouncy candidate in very late middle age but a strikingly handsome young Navy pilot in full flying regalia with the ironic slogan 'McCain 2000' beneath. On the podium in Sunter, South Carolina, McCain thunders: 'How are we going to get a future generation of Americans to serve, if we don't look after those who already have?'

McCain has named veterans co-ordinators in each of South Carolina's counties, all reporting to a retired colonel, Phil Butler. McCain's latest leaflet, sent to every registered war veteran in South Carolina (with all other primary states to follow) addresses his former comrades thus: 'I Ask You To Join Me In One Last Mission.'

The crucial questions are: Will they? And: Who else will join McCain on that last mission, but who never picked up a gun?

Richard Quinn, McCain's strategist in South Carolina, presumes it 'likely' that 'a person who has a military background will vote for McCain'.

And yet the veterans are many and their vote is not monolithic. Even Colonel Butler concedes that 'we probably don't have as much of the veteran vote as we should'. Now Bush must confront the veteran vote and fight for it - without seeming to fight McCain. This is perilous territory for Bush, after revelations that once his military service alibi in higher education had expired, a carefully placed phone call by his father enabled the young Harvard 'Frat Brat' to jump a queue of 100,000 and join the safety of the Texas National Guard while those whose votes he now seeks were out in the killing fields.

But Bush's machine in conservative South Carolina has found the way of selling its non-veteran candidate to veterans: you call his rival a bleeding-heart liberal. 'McCain is a Democrat-lite,' says Wayne Crockfield, a disabled veteran who sits on the local anti-abortion committee and dislikes McCain's 'flip-flops' on the issue.

Because McCain is also a veteran, many vets hold him to higher standards than other candidates, or have higher expectations to disappoint. Many in the powerful POW/MIA movement - which believes successive administrations have connived to betray remaining prisoners and missing comrades - object to McCain's push to improve relations with Communist Vietnam and even accuse him of a 'cover-up'. One MIA activist website in Kansas posits that McCain was brainwashed by his captors into maintaining a rapport with Hanoi.

But veterans like Jim Skinner of Orgeon, who made a peacemaking journey to Hanoi last year and 'liked the beer they got there', applaud McCain's efforts. 'It's time to shake hands and move on,' says James McKinnon, a vice-commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars association, a McCain man.

So Bush should tread carefully through the dichotomy of the veterans' hawkery and their maturity. But in Florence, South Carolina, last week he blundered in what may be remembered as a seminal moment in the campaign; he tried to touch an American nerve, and sliced it instead.

Bush fielded Thomas Burch Jnr, chairman of the National Vietnam and Gulf War Veterans Committee, who accused McCain of failing his kind - opposing measures to deal with Agent Orange poisoning, and legislation to help families of those whom veterans hold sacred, the 'POW/MIA' boys. 'He came home,' said Burch, a Vietnam veteran, 'and forgot us.' Burch's attack backfired. The response from the veteran movment was one of outrage. Edward Timperlake, Assistant Secretary for Veterans' Affairs in the Administration of Bush's own father, said: 'Attacking John McCain on veterans' affairs is wrong. It's over the line.' Five senators (one a Republican) wrote a furious letter expressing 'dismay' and demanding an apology to McCain.

McCain spoke only of the letter's authors: 'Their friendship is all the honour I need in my life, and more than compensates for the temporary irritation of baseless attacks by apparently desperate political campaigns.'

Until Florence, analysts had seen a possibility of Bush maybe inviting McCain to be his running mate one day soon, but not now.

webTitle: Why Lady Young is wrong about gay men like me

fields.headline: Why Lady Young is wrong about gay men like me
fields.standfirst: Gay sexuality exploded into the public arena last week. The debate brought back harsh memories for  Gus Cairns, who describes his tortured experiences as a gay adolescent.
fields.trailText: Gay sexuality exploded into the public arena last week. The debate brought back harsh memories for  Gus Cairns, who describes his tortured experiences as a gay adolescent.
fields.body:
The place that symbolised why I loathe Section 28 with a passion I rarely reserve for politics was demolished a couple of years back. It was the public toilet where I first had sex. At 15 I was unpopular, fat and geeky. I hated my school photo so much I hid the copies from my family. But it wasn't just my spots and greasy hair I detested. I was convinced that anyone getting a really close look at me would divine my secret - that I was 'mo', to use the school slang. That when I gazed at my classmates' muddy bodies in the showers after football I experienced a surge of testosterone so powerful I would shake with desire.

I wasn't wrong about the need for secrecy. At my single-sex grammar, the slightest wobble on the tightrope of masculinity would render you an outcast. I will never forget the delighted hiss of indrawn breath when, in an unguarded moment, I addressed one of my classmates as 'darling'. Filled with a need as unconquerable as it was inadmissible, I took to cycling down to the toilet after school, having become intrigued a year or two earlier by the penises drawn on the wall. Inside was a society behind society. I would wait in a queue of men old enough to be my teachers for one of the two cubicles to become vacant. There was a hole between them you could slip your hand through.

I progressed from shyly looking to caressing till, at 17, in another Kingston toilet, I allowed a slim black man to bugger me. I want to emphasise I wasn't mad, drugged, deprived or abused. I came from one of those rare families that actually did consist of a mum, dad, son and daughter. My dad was a head teacher and my mum was at the BBC; they were broadminded by the standards of Sixties suburbia.

There was only one reason I behaved like an outcast - because I was one. I doubt if I would behave any differently today unless I had enough confidence to venture into a gay bar alone. And if I was growing up in Plymouth, Perth or Portadown? Well, there ain't many around anyway.

By some miracle, I never caught the clap (today it would be HIV) or got raped. But while friends were learning to splice the messy urges of sex into the rituals of courtship, my sexuality was hermetically sealed off from any kind of social relations. The result was an inability to unite sex with friendship that persisted till my mid-thirties. But at least my ravenous need for sex meant there was one part of me I couldn't deny, thank goodness, unlike those who repress it altogether until they're married or middle-aged.

A few years ago I revisited the bricked-up toilet. I imagined my 15-year-old self still imprisoned there. If Section 28 stays on the statute book, it will keep teenagers like the one I was locked in there. Not because they're innately sleazy and want to be there. Not because they need therapy or a good talk with Jesus. But because in black and white, with the full force of law, Section 28 declares what young gays already believe - that they are irreparably second-rate human beings.

It is a devastatingly concise and simple piece of slander. It consists of one Lie and one Insult. The Lie is that you can 'promote' homosexuality. It says kids don't turn gay unless they're told it's OK. It says that what homosexuals most want is that there should be more homosexuals, and that they must be stopped. It says that promoting repression is better than promoting happiness.

The truth is, of course, the exact opposite. Teenage sexuality has to have the force of an Armalite to counteract the tyranny of gender models. God, how I tried not to be gay. I remember a foursome when my friend Michael paired me off with one of his girlfriend's mates. I manfully snogged her in the cinema, dying from embarrassment and distaste. I even tried to warp my own mind when, finding myself quite unable to keep Davy Jones of the Monkees out of my sexual fantasies, I got as far as grafting women's breasts on to his imagined body.

The Insult is that gay relationships are 'pretend'. That the ad hoc families we build on the quicksand of our own needs, instead of the rock of social ritual, are thereby irredeemably fake. I bought this one hook, line and sinker. By university I'd come out and had got as far as a callow rebelliousness about being gay. Romantic love, I spouted, was a bourgeois fiction.

But just after university, at 22, I met Eamon, an 18-year-old cockney-Irish chippy, at a party. He had blazing blue eyes and the sexiest voice in the world. We spent the night snuggled in the same sleeping bag, on the floor among the fag butts, oblivious of other people's comments. He chucked me after six months, tiring of my unhappy, compulsive promiscuity.

The night he left, I experienced an overpowering blast of emotion I'd only ever read about before in Women's Own . It was 'heartbreak'. I knew that what I was feeling, crying in the phone box on Lower Clapton Road, was love.

If we are to get through to women like Baroness Young - who looks like a fundamentally nice, if uncomprehending, woman to me - we somehow have to convey the secret, twisted years of dread that virtually everyone who's been through the hell of a gay adolescence carries with them.

To achieve this we have to do two things. The first is to have enough self-respect to admit that growing up gay in a society which legally labels you as second-rate does your head in. And this means most of us don't end up behaving like angels. The second is to recognise that if there were a society where being gay was treated with the 'who cares' equality we're demanding, most gay kids would grow up behaving very differently to us.

If I had got the message at school that at least some - or just one - of the adult world thought that being gay was not sickening and pathetic, I might have broken my silence. And then Chris, the other dreamy, bookish, funny English student in the sixth form, might have broken his, too. And I wonder, I just wonder, if we'd have paired up and lived happily ever after, instead of me spending 20 years finding a way to reconcile my yearning for love with an addiction to sex with men without names.

I disown none of it. Though I've paid a price I've had a lot of fun, and I wouldn't give up for the world that knowledge of society's hypocrisy, of what goes on behind the backdrop, that fuels the productive alienation of gay artists, gay rebels, gay spies.

But I think that one of the reasons gay organisations' responses to Section 28 this time round have seemed a little lacklustre, have failed to hit the right note of true outrage, is that they want to celebrate the glamour but shy away from the pain that engenders it. Who in their right mind would want to remember?

Yet it is pain, the voice of the damaged child within, that gives politics its centre, its morality. Never mind about rescuing other kids from bullying in a philanthropic, Esther Rantzen sort of way. It is the closeted teenager inside themselves that gay people should be consciously rescuing when they tear down Section 28 brick by brick.

Gus Cairns is deputy editor of Positive Nation, the UK's monthly magazine for people with HIV. He writes in a personal capacity.
Homosexuals and the Law
1967 : The Homosexual Offences Act repealed for consenting homosexual men over 21. It remains a crime for soldiers to have gay relationships.

1986 : Tories introduce Section 28 of the Local Government Act banning local authorities from 'intentionally promoting homosexuality' in schools.

1994 : Age of homosexual consent lowered to 18.

1999 : Labour announces decision to repeal Section 28.

April : House of Lords reject plans to repeal Section 28. Commons vote to lower the homosexual age of consent to 16. Overruled by House of Lords.

September : The European Court on Human Rights finds Britain's policy of discharging homosexuals from the forces illegal.

2000: MPs vote 263-102 in favour of lowering the homosexual age of consent to 16. Lords expected to block again.

fields.headline: She who must be vilified
fields.standfirst: We build them up, we knock them down.  Maureen Freely on the abuse heaped on powerful women when their careers trip up.
fields.trailText: We build them up, we knock them down.  Maureen Freely on the abuse heaped on powerful women when their careers trip up.
fields.body:
When Peter Mandelson resigned last year, after remembering that he had forgotten about the funding arrangements of his mortgage, no one passed comment on the colour of his shoes. When Geoffrey Robinson went on the Today programme last month to defend his reputation, no one complained about his tone of voice. When Tony Blair makes a blunder during Prime Minister's Question Time, no one would dream of suggesting that the trouble might have something to do with the fact that he was a father-of-three 'with another on the way'. But if it is a woman in the hot seat, you can expect to hear about nothing else.

If it's not her credentials as a mother that are found wanting, it's her selfish decision not to have any children. If it's not her selfish decision to forgo children, it's her shoes. If it's not her shoes, it's her dress size, her taste in wallpaper, and the state of her hair. If she has a high voice, she's too silly. If she has a low voice, she's too much like a man. The higher her profile, the pettier the complaints. No matter how big her job is, it will be her personality that people argue about.

And when she fails? It's more of the same, as we saw this week in the press post mortem of Jennie Page's career at the Dome. For some, Page had failed because she didn't have children, and so didn't know how to make the Dome a place they liked. For others, it was her management style: she was 'awkward, rude and impossible to deal with'. For Stephen Bayley, the Dome's original interior designer, her tragic flaw was that she lacked the 'bravery and style' to stand up for her own ideas.

In his poison-pen portrait in the Mail on Sunday, he portrayed her as a toady run amok: 'There was never any doubt that Jennie Page, a driven, focused, frenetic woman, would do everything necessary to get the Dome finished on time and budget. This "everything" included an astonishing disdain of other people which took the form of (a) ignoring expert advice and (b) an unreflective willingness to chew up and dispose of individuals who got in the way.'

The headline for this article was 'A Noisy Mouse Who Presided Over a Disgrace.' Page, says Bayley, was 'a noisy mouse, no slave to fitness or fashion'. But other papers gave her a glossier image. In the Daily Telegraph, she is the 'Empress of the Dome'. It is hard to imagine a real-life woman who could come across as an empress and a mouse. But it is very rare to read a news report about a very important sacked or about-to-be-sacked woman in which she is not portrayed as an unstable marriage of unhappy opposites. Consider former gas industry watchdog chief Clare Spottiswoode. She stepped down as Ofgas boss when news broke of an extra-marital affair, and was called Boadicea, Annie Oakley, Mumsy, and 'Ingrid Bergman on a bad hair day'. To say that one woman could be all of these things, is to suggest that she is suffering from multiple personality disorder.

Just think of the job the press did on Harriet Harman. When she was in the Cabinet, and especially when she came under attack for reducing income support levels for lone parents, she was portrayed as cold, steely and heartless. But after she lost out in the reshuffle, the tabloids portrayed her as a cold, steely and heartless woman who was also a crybaby. Poor Harriet, they said. She just didn't have what it took. Blair's 'golden girl' had bitten off more than she could chew.

They gave a similar moral to the Nicola Horlick story. She became a celebrity not because she lost a power struggle at Morgan Grenfell, but because her high-powered career had not stopped her having five children. The tabloids dubbed her the female Icarus. She failed because she had flown too close to the sun, overestimating her abilities. 'We never called her Superwoman,' a former colleague told the Daily Mail, 'we called her Brenda like the Queen.' But now that she had been shown to be an emotional toddler, her career was doomed.

At no point during these 'so farewell then' rituals does anyone say: 'This woman cannot be trusted with power because she is a woman.' Instead, her critics seek to disqualify her by saying she is muddled, spineless, childish, wishy-washy. This is not to say that men in disgrace don't face caricature and harsh criticism, too. But there is a big difference between the sort of coverage Geoffrey Robinson has had and the coverage Mo Mowlam has been getting since her return from Northern Ireland. The question marks around Robinson concern his performance and his conduct, Mowlam's concern the very quality of her mind. Robinson's story is grounded in events; Mowlam's is grounded in a Westminster whispering campaign.

Rumours persist that the radiotherapy she received in 1997 for a benign brain tumour has left her 'without the intellectual rigour to do her job'. Some feared that she has 'lost the plot'. Others are alleged to have confessed they are 'uneasy' around her. Any reader who accepted such vicious slander at face value would not be inclined to ask why David Trimble, the only named critic in the story, might have put pressure on Blair to replace Mowlam with someone who was a 'more serious politician'. Perhaps that was the point of the exercise.

As smear campaigns go, it is still a pretty subtle one. Can this be taken as a sign of progress? In 1997, Women in Journalism did a research project in which it compared the coverage given to Alan Howarth when he left the Tories for New Labour, with the coverage given to Emma Nicholson when she left the Tories for the Lib Dems only a few weeks later. The differences were stark. While Howarth was portrayed as a man of vision acting on his conscience, Nicholson was described as witch-like and menopausal. Even in straight news stories, her decision was described as vengeful, petty and petulant. These same stories described her appearance and her family connections many column inches before they bothered to mention what she had achieved in her own career.

When the research was published, Alan Howarth himself was one of the first to say how appalling it was that Nicholson had been treated so unfairly.
