webTitle: It's not over till it's over

fields.headline: It's not over till it's over
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report

Despite the collapse of the Assembly and a split between London and Dublin, there is still hope
fields.trailText: Despite the collapse of the Assembly and a split between London and Dublin, there is still hope
fields.body:
Martin McGuinness walked into David Trimble's room at Stormont in the middle of Friday afternoon to present Northern Ireland's soon-to-be-redundant First Minister with two unattainable requests.

First, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator wanted Trimble to withdraw his letter of resignation as First Minister which was still in the hands of the Ulster Unionist Party's President Josias Cunningham. Second, McGuinness, the North's outgoing Education Minister, asked Trimble to postpone a critical meeting of his party's ruling body, the 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council, in Belfast on Saturday morning. For good measure, he added, Peter Mandelson the Northern Ireland Secretary would have to repeal the legislation suspending the power-sharing executive.

McGuinness told the UUP leader there was more on offer from the IRA regarding the vexed question of decommissioning. If Trimble withdrew his threat to pull down the 72-day-old power-sharing government and prevent the British government from suspending the Stormont executive, this would buy more time for the IRA to engage further with General John de Chastelain's international decommissioning body.

However, Trimble was in no mood to backtrack on the promise he made in Belfast's Waterfront Hall last November when he decided to temporarily enter government with Sinn Fein and wait for the IRA to decommission within three months. As one Trimble ally put it: 'David knew he would be pulled apart by his party if he compromised any further.'

Compromise, however, was a word being heavily hyped by officials from the Irish government late on Friday afternoon after it was learned that a senior IRA representative was reported to be holding further talks with General de Chastelain at a secret location in the Irish Republic.

Given the news from Dublin, Peter Mandelson and his officials at the Northern Ireland Office also sought to buy time. Mandelson held a meeting with Cunningham shortly after 2pm and pleaded for a few extra hours.

The UUP president agreed to grant Mandelson an additional two and a half-hours before he finally suspended devolution and re-imposed direct rule. Trimble and his party were determined that suspension of the executive would make headline news at teatime.

Their thinking, according to a party spokesman, was that grassroots members across Northern Ireland due to attend the UUP council meeting the next day would get the message loud and clear on the evening news - this time the British government would not let them down. Following his meeting with Cunningham, Mandelson spoke by phone with Gerry Adams. The Sinn Fein president gave no impression that a breakthrough was in the offing. Nor did Adams suggest anything dramatic when, soon after, he spoke to Tony Blair.

Shortly before 5pm Mandelson swallowed hard and prepared to release the long-awaited De Chastelain report which had been originally planned for release on 31 January. It is now known that the report was kept in cold storage at the insistence of the Irish government.

The content of the first report made grim reading for those seeking a sign that the IRA was moving from its 'no surrender' position on decommissioning. The Irish played for time too, hoping that they could modify the report in the event of new engagement between the Canadian general and the IRA.

But by 5pm on Friday evening, the British had had enough. Mandelson suspended the Executive and simultaneously published the report. It was the only way of saving Trimble from resignation. Although point three of the report noted the IRA's recent statement that it posed no threat to the peace process, the General's commission added: 'But our sole task is decommissioning, and to date we have received no information from the IRA as to when decommissioning will start.'

These words confirmed many Ulster Unionists' suspicions that the IRA was never serious about decommissioning and that, as Sinn Fein's Pat Doherty let slip in the United States last November, republicans never believed the UUP would 'collapse' the power-sharing government once the institutions were up and running. The mood within the UUP has clearly been hardening over the past few weeks.

The South Down Association, which includes loyalist heartlands like Kilkeel, a fishing port, had backed Trimble's jump into government last November. A fortnight ago party headquarters in Glengall Street asked the Association for its annual inventory of members.

The UUP in south Down whose Assembly members include Dermot Nesbitt, one of the most moderate and liberal party spokesman, refused to reaffirm its membership until after the UUP Council meeting. Maynard Hanna, a former Trimble supporter, summed up the attitude in south Down: 'We told our headquarters that they wouldn't get a single membership card until we were sure the party was holding to its line that there had to be actual decommissioning to keep us in the government with Sinn Fein.'

Mandelson's decision to suspend inevitably infuriated the republicans. The Northern Ireland Office insist they knew the IRA was holding a second meeting with De Chastelain but were totally unaware that a new breakthrough was around the corner. Twenty minutes after suspension, Adams released a statement claiming there had been a development of 'enormous significance' between the IRA and the De Chastelain commission.

Adams challenged Mandelson to immediately rescind the suspension of the Executive in the light of the new development. Republican leaders accused the Northern Ireland Secretary of bending under pressure from Trimble. McGuinness said Mandelson had done a great disservice to the peace process by 'caving in to Ulster Unionists demands'.

There is now controversy over when the British first learned of Adams's statement and a subsequent second report from General de Chastelain.

According to Mandelson's office the first the Secretary of State learned about the Adams statement was at half past five when Ulster Television's Political Correspondent Ken Reid rang the NIO.

There is also controversy over the interpretation of the new Sinn Fein initiative and the second De Chastelain report. The Irish government and the SDLP appeared to agree with Sinn Fein that it marked a significant shift in the IRA's stance on arms.

The key element of De Chastelain's second report noted that the IRA would consider putting arms beyond use in the context of the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement and the 'removal of the causes of conflict'.

'By one account this was a breakthrough, but to British and Unionist eyes the IRA would only accept the causes of the conflict so long as there was full de-militarisation, the withdrawal of British troops and the dismantling of hill-top look-out posts in south Armagh.

Mandelson suspected the breakthrough was merely a transparent attempt to shift blame for the collapse of devolution from the IRA and Sinn Fein to Trimble.

Suspension has, for the time being, saved Trimble although he still faces a potential leadership challenge next month at the UUP annual meeting.

A measure of the distrust within the broader unionist community was demonstrated by the presence of Michelle Williamson at yesterday's UUP Council meeting. Williamson, who is not a UUP member, was smuggled in to the meeting by Young Unionist opponents of the Good Friday Agreement.

The IRA murdered Williamson's parents in the Shankill bomb in 1993. Wearing a blonde wig, she managed to get on to the platform and made a passionate denunciation of Trimble's policies - and was given a warm reception from delegates.

She accused the UUP leader of being responsible for the release of the Shankill bomber who is due to be freed this July under the terms of the early release scheme.

There is even more trouble in store for Trimble regarding the suspension. It now appears that not all the institutions have been put into cold storage.

This weekend the Irish government was vigorously opposing any move to suspend the six north-south cross-border institutions. The Irish insist that the implementation bodies can only be suspended through an international treaty between London and Dublin.

The British claim that if one aspect of the Good Friday Agreement falls then all the institutions, including the north-south implementation bodies, fall too. This division of opinion on a critical aspect of the Agreement illuminates the deep divisions between the two governments over the political crisis.

The British have admitted that the detail over suspending the north-south bodies 'has yet to be worked out' according to the NIO - code for a serious difference of opinion. Even as early as last Wednesday, Labour's Lord Falconer, who was winding up the second reading of the bill enabling for the transfer of power back to London, admitted there were technical difficulties with freezing the north-south bodies.

'We shall agree to make provisions in consultation with the Irish government for the practicalities as far as the north-south bodies are concerned. The clear principle underlining the Agreement on which we shall act is that all those institutions are interlocking and interdependent,' Falconer told the Lords.

The trouble is: as late as yesterday the Irish government took a different view. Dublin sought legal opinion yesterday morning on the status of the north-south institutions which it wants to keep functioning through the work of civil servants from both sides of the border.

One of Trimble's sharpest critics, the UK Unionist MP Robert McCartney, said the British were wrong to believe they could unilaterally suspend the cross-border bodies, so beloved of republicans who see them as institutional stepping stones towards a united Ireland.

'Trimble told everyone that the Ministers would be accountable to the Assembly. But the Irish are right in the sense that the north-south bodies are subject to an international treaty signed by two parties, London and Dublin. These institutions can't just be unilaterally suspended, Trimble's analysis is wrong,' McCartney said.

A small band of loyalist extremists, mostly women, heckled UUP delegates at yesterday's meeting. They shouted, 'hang the traitors' and denounced leading pro-Agreement UUP members like Sir Reg Empey.

Inside the auditorium, the UUP agreed to set up a working party to monitor what happens when the Northern Ireland parties enter a second review of the Good Friday Agreement. The working party, according to Trimble, will embrace all wings of the party including a number of leading figures in the anti-agreement camp. Whether the group will act as a shackle around Trimble, restricting his room for manoeuvre in the proposed talks is unclear.

There was some sign of hope amid the gloom yesterday from delegates. Duncan Shipley Dalton, an English-born Assemblyman and for mer British soldier, accepted that the definition of IRA decommissioning could change and might be acceptable to Ulster Unionists.

'If the IRA mean by "putting beyond use" sealing arms dumps and ensuring they are never used again I think I could live with that,' he said. 'I don't care whether the guns are cut in half by grinders or sealed in bunkers. As long as that's verifiable and permanent, who cares?'

fields.headline: How we learnt to kill
fields.standfirst: The ascent of man from the apes was not, as depicted above, the heroic, single-line rise of a lone species. We have a bleaker past of struggle and genocide. First we wiped out our closest rivals, now it's the turn of relatives such as chimps and gorillas.
fields.trailText: The ascent of man from the apes was not, as depicted above, the heroic, single-line rise of a lone species. We have a bleaker past of struggle and genocide. First we wiped out our closest rivals, now it's the turn of relatives such as chimps and gorillas.
fields.body:
There is something very odd about Homo sapiens . Unlike other animals, we have no brother and sister species to share our world. Horses have zebra siblings, dolphins have porpoises, and lions have tigers. But we are home alone, the only two-legged intelligent primate on planet Earth.

It was not always so. Scientists have recently discovered that for most of our evolutionary history we have co-habited with many different human beings - not just a couple, as once thought, but a startlingly wide array, it appears. More than 20 types of human being are now known, and the total is rising inexorably as scientists make more and more discoveries. In the last three years finds in Chad, Ethiopia and Spain have added three new types of human being to our family tree.

Then, about 30,000 years ago, Homo sapiens suddenly found itself alone. But why? How did modern humans suddenly end up inheriting the world at the expense of sibling species such as the Neanderthals? Was it genocide or economic imperialism that led to their disappearance? In other words, does Slobodan Milosevic or Bill Gates make the best model for humanity?

These critical questions have been raised by leading palaeontologists and archaeologists in a spate of recent articles and newspapers in journals that include the latest issues of Scientific American and British Archaeology . These scientists have looked upon the bones of the prehistoric dead - and have seen evidence of a Stone Age holocaust. A tendency to genocide may be a natural part of being human, they say.

But such ideas are disputed by other scientists. They accept we were responsible for the eradication of fellow species of humans, but argue that this was the result of economic attrition. We are just overly competitive and better at securing resources, they argue.

Either way, our solo status raises worrying issues. For whether it was the result of better organisation or outright violence, we face the same question: can any species of large animal hope to share a planet with Homo sapiens in the long run, they ask?

'Just consider what happened when modern humans moved into Europe about 40,000 years ago,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer of the Natural History Museum, London. 'We had to share it with the Neanderthals who had been doing quite nicely there for at least 200,000 years. Yet within 10,000 years of our arrival, we had rendered them extinct - and they were our closest relatives.

'Of course, they shared exactly the same habitats as ourselves and so were the first to go. That much is clear. But now we are spreading, and it is the turn of more distant members of the primate family - chimps, gorillas and orang-utans. They, too, are all being driven towards extinction. You have to wonder where it will stop.'

The story of mankind's inheritance of the world began five million years ago when a population of African apes began to adapt to a lifestyle away from forests that were then dwindling due to global ecological changes. These early hominids - of which Australopithecus anamensis , afarensis and africanus are the principal types - were small of brain, but upright of posture. We can see evidence of their deft two-legged gait in the remarkable Laetoli steps, the prints of three australopithecine apemen who wandered across a field of hot volcanic sediments in East Africa 3.5 million years ago, preserving their footprints in the ashes of time.

Yet these early ancestors still retained only small, ape-sized brains and vegetarian lifestyles until about 2.5 million years ago, when signs of intellectual originality first emerged with the manufacture of the first stone tools. By this time, at least four different types of human being - Homo rudolfensis , habilis and erectus , and a separate variety of apemen, Australopithecus boseii - coexisted in the same part of East Africa. Other species also thrived to the south and the north.

'Think of that scene from Star Wars - in the bar where you see all kinds of aliens playing and drinking and talking together,' says palaeontologist Yoel Rak. 'That's what our evolutionary past was really like.'

Ours is not a story of a lone hero species' linear struggle to succeed, in other words, but one of repeated evolutionary experiments, as Ian Tattersall, of the American Museum of Natural History in New York, points out. 'New hominid species have regularly emerged, competed, coexisted, colonised new environments and succeeded - or failed.'

One of the East African Four, Homo erectus, adopted a diet rich in meat and tubers which triggered a protein influx that provided energy for brain growth, and, its wake, complex behaviour. Erectus - strong and athletic, but still only moderately endowed intellectually - then spread across the old world, leaving descendant species in various nooks and crannies.

By 100,000 years before the present, natural selection's experiments with humanity had produced three different varieties of human being: big-brained Neanderthals in Europe, a separate population of erectus -like people which scientists now believe lingered on around Java; and, in Africa, Homo sapiens. The stage was set for the Big Takeover.

Modern humans poured out of Africa and into Asia and eventually into Europe, completely replacing indigenous species of humans that stood in their way. There was no interbreeding, for no matter how hard they look at the genes of men and women today, scientists can see no signs of any input of DNA from other species.

So did these sibling people disappear because of species-cleansing by Rambo-like thugs wielding the latest in rock weapons, or was it more gradual? Anthropologist Professor Leslie Aiello, of University College London, takes the latter view. 'I don't think it was hand-to-hand combat,' she says. 'We were just the best package, and lived longer and so bred more efficiently.'

Aiello and others point to the wide web of alliances modern humans started to form when they arrived in Europe. Scientists have discovered that Neanderthal stone tools are hardly ever found more than 30 miles from their source, but those used by Homo sapiens are found up to 200 miles away. 'We networked well, and when times got hard we had kith and kin to run to,' says Professor Clive Gamble of Southampton University. 'The Neanderthals did not. It is like remembering aunties and cousins. We send Christmas cards, but the Neanderthals did not. That doomed them.'

This is the Microsoft version of evolution, in other words. We simply strangled the opposition, slowly but effectively, because we were better, shrewder operators who monopolised resources. 'Neanderthals liked to move around but returned to favourite caves when times got hard,' points out Jean-Jacques Hublin of the Musée de l'Homme in Paris. 'Slowly groups would find that when they went back to those caves they had been taken over by spreading tribes of Homo sapiens . They ran out of places to hide.'

The other scenario, that of a Stone Age holocaust, is less easy to support - for no Neanderthal skeletons peppered with arrow heads have been dug up by palaeontologists. Nevertheless, it is hard to avoid the notion that our meetings with Neanderthals were often violent and fatal. As Tattersall puts it in Scientific American : 'In the light of the Neanderthals' rapid disappearance, and of the appalling subsequent record of Homo sapiens , we can surmise that such interactions were rarely happy for the former.'

Backed by improved linguistic abilities and a capacity to use mental symbols when working out problems, Homo sapiens would have been a deadly foe, he points out. 'A creature armed with symbolic skills is a formidable competitor - and not necessarily an entirely rational one, as the rest of the living world has discovered to its cost.'

This view is shared by archaeologist Paul Pettitt, of Oxford University. 'Neanderthals had little to offer modern humans - except competition,' he states in British Archaeology . 'The attitude may have been to kill first, ask questions later. For too long we have regarded the extinction of Neanderthals as a chance historical accident. Rather, where Neanderthals and modern humans could not coexist, their disappearance may have been the result of the modern human race's first and most successful deliberate campaign of genocide.'

It is a bleak view of Homo sapiens that is perfectly encapsulated in the words of Agent Smith in the box office hit The Matrix : 'Every mammal on this planet instinctively develops a natural equilibrium with its surrounding environment. But you humans do not. You move to an area and you multiply. You multiply until every natural resource is consumed. The only way you survive is to spread to another area. There is another organism on this planet that follows this pattern. A virus. Human beings are a disease of this planet. You are a plague.'

This is overstating the case. Nevertheless, it is clear that our monopolistic status on Earth has not been a healthy one for the planet, no matter how it occurred. And there are other philosophical points to consider, as Carl Swisher, of the Berkeley Geochronology Centre in California, makes clear. 'Even atheists and agnostics have become inculcated with the idea that there is only one God, and that we - Homo sapiens - are made in his image, not a lot of other hominids, like the Neanderthals, as well.' In other words, we may have to think again about what it means to be made in His image.

robin.mckie@observer.co.uk

Robin McKie is the author of a new book Apeman, which accompanies a BBC2 series of the same name that begins at 9pm on 22 February

fields.headline: It's not fair, Gordon
fields.standfirst: Do you have a mortgage or pay tax? Are you self-employed, gay, divorced, low-paid, old or ill? If so, read on...
fields.trailText: • High streets are awash with savings accounts that pay interest at 20 per cent a year.
fields.body:
 High streets are awash with savings accounts that pay interest at 20 per cent a year.

 Agoraphobics can happily leave their houses and hold down a job.

 It is fair that honest senior citizens can be materially and financially worse off than convicted felons.

No one but an idiot would agree with any of the above statements - except, that is, er, the Government. The above bits of nonsense are part and parcel of current government policy. The system is littered with anomalies and injustices: we only have space here to look at a few.

To be fair, some financial lunacies are set to be changed. The Chancellor is considering reducing the notional interest rate that benefit claimants are assumed to earn from 20 per cent to something more akin with the best rates on the market - about 7 per cent. Other good news for claimants is that claimants' capital thresholds could be as much as trebled, according to sources close to Gordon Brown. This could be announced in the Budget on 21 March.

But do not automatically expect justice if you are poor and unimportant. MPs are bombarded with desperate pleas for help from people who have physical and mental health problems but are deemed capable of working by the Benefits Agency. In 1995, the Conservative government introduced the 'all-works test' as a way of deciding who was shirking work and who was genuinely entitled to Incapacity Benefit.

Jude Hawes, of Stoke-on-Trent citizens advice bureau, says the test was welcomed by the Tories because 'it knocked a lot of people off the benefit; you either get through the test or you don't; there is no discretion and no arguing'. As a result many alcoholics, manic depressives and agoraphobics have been told they are fit for work - and have lost their entitlement to Incapacity Benefit. The test is good at seeing whether you can hold a milk bottle, but decidedly inadequate when it comes to detecting psychological difficulties or illnesses that fluctuate in severity.

The Government came under pressure to make the test fairer last year during the course of the Welfare Reform and Pensions Bill, but decided not to. Pretending that the test was a good one saved it a lot of money. Since the plight of benefit claimants is not the stuff of high-profile media campaigns, the Government can rest happy that it will not have to change its way for a long time.

Another hidden group with (at the moment) little influence is the elderly: they are being systematically over-drugged, under-stimulated and kept on unnecessarily tight budgets in old people's homes. This will change when 'grey power' becomes a real political force in this country - but probably not before.

British lawmakers have traditionally taken a suspicious and heavily regimented approach to controlling British citizens. Our pension laws alone are twice the length of the Bible: mainly comprising complicated restrictions aimed at stopping people claiming too much tax relief.

Pensions lawyer Robin Ellison has been running a campaign to 'burn the books' and simplify pensions law. 'The people who write the laws don't trust people,' he says. 'Ministers say they want simplicity, and then they issue all this garbage. The regulations covering pensions-sharing on divorce, for instance, are likely to run to 210 pages; in European countries, it may be just a page or two. The Europeans set down the principles - not the rules - and then trust people to follow the principles.'

John Wheatley of the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux may soon be celebrating the raising of DSS capital threshold limits. Wheatley's organisation has campaigned for years for fairness in this area. But, he says, achieving change is largely a matter of luck: 'At the moment, for instance, there is a commitment to abolishing child poverty - so you get the Working Families Tax Credit, which is a step in the right direction. But some things they aren't interested in. Change requires a lot of adverse publicity. Ministers have to see letters from the public.'

We thought the least we could do was send our own open letter to the Chancellor.

fields.headline: Case studies
fields.trailText: Gillian Rooney's mother is a classical music lover, extremely intelligent, a mother of eight - and she and her children are 'deeply furious' that now, at the age of 92, she is reduced to living off £14.75 a week 'pocket money' in an old people's home.
fields.body:
Robbed of dignity

Gillian Rooney's mother is a classical music lover, extremely intelligent, a mother of eight - and she and her children are 'deeply furious' that now, at the age of 92, she is reduced to living off £14.75 a week 'pocket money' in an old people's home.

Violet (not her real name) went into the home in Surrey four years ago, having sold her Kent home to pay the fees. Under Department of Social Security rules, all the pension that she and her husband worked for, except the £14.75, is taken from her to help pay the fees. Because she and the other old ladies there can no longer shampoo and set their own hair, they pay a hairdresser once a week - and that uses up half her pocket money.

So Violet is really struggling if she wants to buy newspapers, a bit of make-up, fruit or sweets. She simply cannot afford the presents she wants to buy her children and grandchildren. If she needs a new coat, she has the embarrassment - after an adult lifetime of independence - of having to ask her children for the money.

Many of her fellow residents have no relatives left - so they wear the same old clothes in which they arrived at the home. The older they get, the more tatty they have to be.

Gillian says: 'It is like the old workhouse idea: they stripped you of everything you had, including your dignity. This pocket money allowance is official government policy.'

Tax snag stops six weeks' pay

Mrs A, a mother of four, went without pay for six weeks because of the Pay As You Earn system. She works part-time as a cook in a large hotel chain, and recently took on a second part-time job to improve her finances.

She realised there was a problem when pay day arrived but no money went into her bank account. Without her knowledge, the Inland Revenue had told the hotel to deduct tax on all her earnings there. Officials had decided her personal allowance of £4,335 should be handled entirely by her other employer.

The Revenue's instructions were inexact, so the chain backdated her tax to the start of the financial year, not realising that she had only just started her job. The hotel calculated that she had 'tax arrears' of £700, which wiped out her pay of £150 for several weeks. No one explained.

Fortunately, she heard about the charity TaxAid, and asked for help. A TaxAid spokesman says: 'It took many phone calls and a letter to the Revenue to get Mrs A's tax code corrected. The time lag in issuing the correct one and processing it meant it took six weeks to get her the right pay and a big refund ... Without specialist help she could never have unravelled the complexities.'

TaxAid provides free advice to people who cannot afford an accountant. Tel: 0171 624 3768, 10am-noon, Mondays to Thursdays.

webTitle: How to pay for your day in court

fields.headline: How to pay for your day in court
fields.standfirst: With British people following the    US trend of suing at every opportunity,  Anne Caborn  looks at the legal protection policies on offer
fields.trailText: It was always the Americans who were perceived as living their lives like an episode of Ally McBeal, where even the most mundane of events involve billion-dollar lawsuits. But if the statistics are to be believed, the British, too, are becoming more litigious.
fields.body:
It was always the Americans who were perceived as living their lives like an episode of Ally McBeal, where even the most mundane of events involve billion-dollar lawsuits.

But if the statistics are to be believed, the British, too, are becoming more litigious. The Association of British Insurers' Year Book stands testament to an increasing willingness to go to court.

The book includes British Medical Association estimates that lawsuits against doctors are increasing by 15 per cent a year. The Medical Protection Society states that cases against its members rose 40 per cent between 1990 and 1997.

According to the NHS, the estimated cost of medical negligence claims in the system totals £1.8 billion and a further £1bn in potential claims that have not yet been made.

The Department of Health says: 'Anecdotally, we believe that costs are still continuing to rise, not because the NHS has become any more negligent, but because society as a whole is becoming more litigious.'

While medicine may represent a particularly rich vein for potential claims, the national inclination to see each other in court covers a variety of areas, from neighbour disputes to consumer issues.

'The most common type of problems are boundary disputes, or faulty goods and services,' said a spokeswoman for Norwich Union, one of a number of home insurers offering legal expenses cover as a policy add-on.

The typical cost of such cover is £12-£15 a year. Legal protection add-ons to motor policies tend to be quite specific and are designed to cover uninsured losses relating to a motor claim, such as loss of earnings, or your policy excess.

Legal protection add-ons to household policies tend to be wider ranging, but always check exactly what is covered. Both motor and legal add-ons may be offered by the insurer providing the main policy, or through a broker from a separate source.

According to insurance intermediary Hill House Hammond, which provides a household add-on from DAS Legal Expenses Insurance, they are seeing more personal injury claims.

'Advertising on television by legal companies soliciting personal injury cases has also made the public more aware,' said Alex Lovesey at Hill House Hammond. According to DAS, contract disputes and employment are other areas where people are pursuing their rights.

Even without a legal expenses add on, people may have access to a legal helpline as a general benefit of motor or household policies. Helplines may deal with a broad range of issues on an information and expert advice basis.

But if you want cover in relationship to your occupation or profession, you need something more specialist. A good starting point is the professional body or trade association you may belong to. Invariably, such block insurance is more cost effective.

Insurance agents Insurance Data Services provide cover for a range of professionally recognised and registered alternative therapies, such as acupuncture and herbalism.

'People are becoming more aware of their rights,' said Ken Bachelor of IDS. 'When we first started our policy for acupuncturists in 1983 it was three years before we received our first claim. That doesn't happen any longer.'

It isn't just a question of physical - or emotional - injury, but potential claims relating to faulty, or non-completed work. The growing army of self-employed can be particularly vulnerable, as insurance may be low on their list of priorities.

A good home office policy should offer liability cover for employers, and their product - the goods they produce - as well as public liability and add-on cover for any commercial legal expenses.

This may be in a menu where you choose what you want and pay for it, rather than automatic. A home insurance policy may offer home office cover as an add-on, which may be more cost-effective than a freestanding policy, but check the limits and scope of the policy.

Basic home insurance should automatically include public third-party liability, which would protect you if someone was injured on your premises in a domestic situation and should extend to cleaners and nannies without the need for specific employers' liability cover. But always check.

However, as with any insurance, a great deal may depend on the scope of the cover, the exact wording and - in the case of legal expenses - the likelihood of success.

An insurer will not pursue a claim simply to give you your day in court.

fields.headline: Architects who need a blueprint
fields.standfirst: Saul and Nicola want advice on pensions - and investments for their baby. They talk to  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Saul and Nicola want advice on pensions - and investments for their baby. They talk to Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Saul and Nicola Golden

Ages: 30 and 29

Live in: Stoke Newington, London

Occupations: Architects

Earn: £25,000 and £22,000

Mortgage: £92,000

Debts: Student loans £30,000 (him) £400 (her)

Savings: Around £500 in Egg account

Pensions: Group personal pension (him), none (her)

Aims: To sort out a pension for Nicola, decide what to do with money for their son and start building up savings again

Saul is a US citizen. He met Nicola at Liverpool University, where they were both studying architecture; he was over on an exchange programme from Seattle. She later visited him in the US, he proposed and they were married there barely a week later. That was three years ago. Now they are settled in London, both practising architects. They bought a flat last summer, and have a four-month-old son, Jack.

One of their main concerns at present is to set up a pension for Nicola. She is on maternity leave, but will go back to work in March. Her company does not provide a pension scheme.

Saul, on the other hand, is in a group personal pension scheme with NPI through his job. His employer contributes around 2 per cent of his earnings to the scheme and Saul has also started paying in £50 a month.

Jack will be looked after at nursery when Nicola goes back to work. It will cost £640 per month ('more than the mortgage' comments Saul). This leads to another concern: how best to invest the £1,000 Jack has received in gifts since he was born.

The couple have around £500 in an Egg account. Saul is wondering about unit trusts, but is confused by the choice of managers. He is attracted by funds such as the Framlington NetNet fund.

Saul is surprisingly relaxed about his student debt. He seems rather bemused by the debate here over university fees; in the US it is common practice for students to take out one loan after another. He has four loans for a staggering £30,000, which he is now repaying at around £250 per month. Nicola, by contrast, only has around £400 in student debt.

They have no other debts apart from their mortgage, a two-year fixed-rate loan from HSBC. Their repayments are about £550 a month; a mortgage protection policy including critical illness cover brings the monthly total to around £600.

They plan to have another child, possibly in three years' time. Saul has no intention at present of going back to the US.

Adviser 1: Gordon Wilson

Saul and Nicola have taken their most important financial decision - they are planning early. Early action is the key to future financial security.

First, there is Nicola's pension. Although her employer does not offer a company scheme, it will, as it has more than five employees, have to start a stakeholder scheme by 2001. Many employers are acting sooner. Nicola should ask her employer about its plans.

One of the main attractions of a pension plan is the 23 per cent tax relief Nicola will receive. As her salary is likely to increase rapidly, she may become a higher-rate taxpayer, which makes pensions even more attractive. However, I would urge her to consider splitting her available income between pensions and individual savings accounts.

When investing for children, the source of the money is critical for tax reasons. Where it comes from a parent, it is taxed as the parent's money, though the first £100 of interest can be paid tax-free. If the money is a gift from a grandparent, friend or relative, it can be taxed as the child's, so the child's personal allowance (currently £4,335) can be used.

In this case, I would advocate investing in unit or investment trusts, with the account designated for Jack. An initial £1,000 could be invested, with the child benefit added as a regular monthly contribution. Unit and investment trusts are very flexible, the funds are accessible and returns over the long term are likely to outperform both inflation and deposit account rates. As the term is likely to be 15 to 20 years, I would be happy to recommend a more speculative investment: and technology funds, such as those offered by Aberdeen and Henderson, would be ideal.

Gordon Wilson works for Aitchison & Colegrave

Adviser 2: Martin Jones

Saul needs to be aware that US citizens must complete an annual tax return informing the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) of their income and capital gains. The system applies even to US citizens not currently resident there. All Americans, regardless of where they live, must report income and gains to the IRS. Failure to do so is a serious matter. Giving up US citizenship (the most obvious way out) is a relatively difficult and expensive procedure.

US tax rates are not penal; the objective is to ensure you are not taxed in two countries on the same income and gains. However, difficulties can arise where, for example, UK investments are either tax-exempt or taxed at a favourable rate. Obvious examples are Isas and pension funds. Just because Isas are exempt in the UK does not mean they will be in the US. Pensions are more complicated but it is important to understand the tax treatment, as this is one of the key reasons for investing in a pension; the tax-free lump sum, arguably the main advantage of a UK pension, may not be tax free in the US.

Saul should seek advice from someone with experience of both systems of taxation as soon as possible. The American Embassy can point him in the right direction. I do not feel Saul should make any further investments (other than deposits) until he is clear on his tax position.

For some UK investments where the income and gains of more than one investor are 'pooled' - for example, in a unit trust - the details required by the IRS are considerably greater than that required under the UK system. As a result, US citizens should avoid them.

Martin Jones works for chartered accountant Blick Rothenberg.

fields.headline: Prints of glory
fields.standfirst: John Windsor searches out two large collections of leading artists' work on sale at bargain prices
fields.trailText: If you know where to look, you can buy prints by leading artists for a lot less than gallery prices.
fields.body:
If you know where to look, you can buy prints by leading artists for a lot less than gallery prices. Last week I visited two big collections of prints for sale that are little known to the public - at the Royal College of Art, in west London, and in a church hall-turned-studio in leafy Duxford, Cambridgeshire.

At the RCA, Professor Chris Orr, director of printmaking, untied the ribbons of bulky portfolios in which the work of such renowned artists as Peter Blake, Patrick Caulfield, Eduardo Paolozzi, Julian Trevelyan and Paula Rego nestled between sheets of tissue paper.

The prints are among about 3,500 to have gone on sale since the college's printmaking department began publishing prints in collaboration with established artists in 1982. The artists give students hands-on experience of silk screening, etching or lithography without payment, and sometimes learn new tricks themselves. The money raised from the sales helps pay for students' materials and study overseas.

The snag - at least for the college - is that the teaching staff's first duty is not to market prints but to teach. The collection has no full-time curator to promote it, so it is virtually unknown to the public.

Its first commercial outing was at the Contemporary Print Fair last November, where I bought a rare and stunning lithograph by Zandra Rhodes - not best known as a printmaker. Entitled Many Memories From India, it was an explosion of pink and blue and cost £293.75; I would have expected to pay £450 for it in a gallery. Did they, I asked knowingly, have a copy of William Scott's abstract lithograph Composition? No: they had sold the last for £400 to a London dealer, who resold it for £2,000.

Orr told me the RCA's prints were for sale to the public at trade prices. And as stocks have dwindled, the RCA has not jacked up the prices for remaining copies in the way some galleries do.

Customers become subscribers for life by making a purchase worth at least £750, which qualifies them for discounts.

With me at the RCA was the London dealer Jonathan Blond, of Blond Fine Art, who estimated for me the retail value of some of its stock. What would the prints of the various folios fetch if sold individually at gallery prices?

Complete copies of only the first and last of the five 1982 folios are still available. They are £850 each, £750 to subscribers. Blond estimated the retail value of their contents - seven prints each - at £1,600 per folio. A typically bold Terry Frost abstract, Newlyn Rhythm , which Frost says was the artist's first successful screen print, would be worth at least £450 on its own. So would a quintessential Julian Trevelyan etching, Villa Joyosa.

There are some singles from an early, 1964 series, Shakespeare. Cecil Collins's lithograph A Midsummer Night's Dream (15 of 50 left) would cost RCA subscribers £250 - half its retail value. Sandra Blow's Hamlet, from the same series (20 left), is also £250 to subscribers, but worth about £350 retail.

A folio of 48 prints, Artists' Choice (1987), is £4,000 (£3,500 to subscribers). By Ackroyd, Ayers, Bellany, Blake, Frink, Frost, Kiff, Proctor, Tilson and Weight among others, they could fetch £6,000 retail in total. Ten are left.

Orr says: 'Such folios have a place in history. They are a panorama of what was happening in printmaking then.'

The latest collection looks set to be historic and lucrative. Called Panoramic , it contains 27 wide prints in an edition of 45, with only 10 for sale. The price is £2,500, but the prints can be bought individually; a Blake for £350, a Ray Richardson for £300, an Adam Dant, the latest wonder-boy printmaker, at £250, and a sexy print by Marcus Harvey, whose painting of child murderer Myra Hindley caused controversy, for £300. Prints by recent graduates are £100.

You can view the RCA's prints by appointment, but the next public buying opportunity will be the Art on Paper Fair at the college from 17-20 February. Blond will have a stand; his stock includes Hockneys, Hayters and Moores and Eileen Coopers. Prices range from under £50 to £2,000.

You also need an appointment to go behind a plain blue door in Duxford, to see the undiscovered collection of the printmaker Kip Gresham. These prints, too, are for sale and, like the RCA collection, they have never been properly marketed. There is no showroom, not even a shop window. Viewing is by appointment.

Half the images are ordered by commercial galleries, museums and Cambridge colleges. The other half - the collection's strength - are collaborations with famous artists that Gresham originated. They form a panorama as historic as the RCA collection.

The public pays Gresham's recommended retail price, which is often lower than gallery prices for the same prints.

Gresham and his master printer, Ian Wilkinson, have a reputation for pushing print-making processes to their limits, which is why some of Britain's best artists go to Duxford to stand with them at their work bench.

I saw what must be John Bellany's finest effort to date, Odyssey , a massive 25-colour screenprint, priced at £1,000 in an edition of 100. It is one of 19 collaborations with Bellany to be exhibited in Cambridge in June.

Gresham's stable of artists includes Alan Davie, Peter Griffin, Kim Lim, Richard Long, John McLean, Bill Penny, Jo Taylor, Matthew Hilton and Anthony Frost. 'The big privilege,' says Gresham, 'is touching so many fascinating lives and seeing living evidence of that in the finished work.'

The RCA is at Kensington Gore, London SW7 (tel: 0171 590 4426). The Gresham Studio is at 4 Chapel Street, Duxford CB2 4RJ (01223 576558), website www.gresham.demon.co.uk

webTitle: How to cash in with the must-have deal

fields.headline: How to cash in with the must-have deal
fields.standfirst: Almost all savers are better off with these tax-free products, writes  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: The cash mini-Isa is a 'must have' investment for anyone with savings in an instant access or notice account and anyone who needs a 'rainy day' fund or pays tax.
fields.body:
The cash mini-Isa is a 'must have' investment for anyone with savings in an instant access or notice account and anyone who needs a 'rainy day' fund or pays tax.

Even if you just want an account to hold money for regular expenses, there are plenty of Isas suitable for you.

The cash Isa's predecessor, the Tessa, required you to lock away your money for five years if you wanted tax-free interest, but Isas do not. Except for notice account-style Isas, which demand a certain number of days' warning before you withdraw money, most let you take out some, or all, your cash immediately without any penalty.

They have the flexibility that a saver needs from an instant access account, combined with interest rates that compare well with much higher risk corporate bond funds.

And as David Hanratty of Chester independent financial adviser Nelson says, you can invest your money without fear of losing your capital in a stock market slide, and without paying initial and annual management fees to a fund manager.

While this year's cash Isa allowance of £3,000 - and £1,000 in subsequent tax years - is unlikely to meet the needs of income-seeking investors, it can form a secure starting point for a portfolio.

The only acceptable excuse for not opening a cash mini Isa this tax year is that you want to invest your £7,000 Isa allowance in shares. By opening any mini-Isa, be it cash, insurance or stocks and shares, you automatically prevent yourself from opening a maxi-Isa, limiting the amount you can invest in stocks and shares to £3,000.

And although some investment companies are offering a cash fund option in their maxi-Isas, these tend to pay lower interest than bank and building society cash mini-Isas.

But beware. The personal finance industry has again complicated a simple idea by coming up with many different variations.

Watch out for:

 Minimum transaction levels: If an account has a high minimum for deposits and withdrawals, it is not suitable for people wanting to save small regular sums or to pay day to day bills.

Notice periods: 30, 60 or even 90 days may not seem long to wait for your cash when you are feeling flush. If you need it in a rush it can seem like an eternity. You can usually get the money straight away if required, but you will lose interest earned during your notice period.

Some of the interest rates advertised include a bonus you get only if you make a very limited number of withdrawals.

Check how your chosen bank or society is treating its remaining Tessa investors.

Many picked out the highest-paying Tessa, but the rate dropped to well below average once their money was tied up. Transferring your money could mean penalties of £30 or £50.

The Government has set of a voluntary standard, the Cat mark, to help savers to identify Isas that have reasonable charges and fair terms.

However, it is not terribly hard for an Isa to qualify. It must have no charges, provide access to cash within seven days and have a minimum transaction size of no more than £10.

The interest rate must not fall more than 2 per cent below the Bank of England base rate. But you may be better off with a non-Cat product that pays more.

Except for notice account-style Isas, which demand a certain number of days' warning before you withdraw money, most let you take out some, or all, your cash immediately without any penalty. They have the flexibility that a saver needs from an instant access account, combined with interest rates that compare well with much higher risk corporate bond funds. And as David Hanratty of Chester independent financial adviser Nelson says, you can invest your money without fear of losing your capital in a stock market slide, and without paying initial and annual management fees to a fund manager. While this year's cash Isa allowance of £3,000 - and £1,000 in subsequent tax years - is unlikely to meet the needs of income-seeking investors, it can form a secure starting point for a portfolio. The only acceptable excuse for not opening a cash mini Isa this tax year is that you want to invest your £7,000 Isa allowance in shares. By opening any mini-Isa, be it cash, insurance or stocks and shares, you automatically prevent yourself from opening a maxi-Isa, limiting the amount you can invest in stocks and shares to £3,000. And although some investment companies are offering a cash fund option in their maxi-Isas, these tend to pay lower interest than bank and building society cash mini-Isas. But beware. The personal finance industry has again complicated a simple idea by coming up with many different variations. Watch out for:  Minimum transaction levels: If an account has a high minimum for deposits and withdrawals, it is not suitable for people wanting to save small regular sums or to pay day to day bills. Notice periods: 30, 60 or even 90 days may not seem long to wait for your cash when you are feeling flush. If you need it in a rush it can seem like an eternity. You can usually get the money straight away if required, but you will lose interest earned during your notice period. Some of the interest rates advertised include a bonus you get only if you make a very limited number of withdrawals. Check how your chosen bank or society is treating its remaining Tessa investors. Many picked out the highest-paying Tessa, but the rate dropped to well below average once their money was tied up. Transferring your money could mean penalties of £30 or £50. The Government has set of a voluntary standard, the Cat mark, to help savers to identify Isas that have reasonable charges and fair terms. However, it is not terribly hard for an Isa to qualify. It must have no charges, provide access to cash within seven days and have a minimum transaction size of no more than £10. The interest rate must not fall more than 2 per cent below the Bank of England base rate. But you may be better off with a non-Cat product that pays more.

webTitle: A mini or a maxi? You can't wear both

fields.headline: A mini or a maxi? You can't wear both
fields.standfirst: David Hunt  looks back on several months of Isas - and finds widespread confusion
fields.trailText: They may not have got off to a particularly good start, but the public seems to be warming to the Individual Savings Account (Isa).
fields.body:
They may not have got off to a particularly good start, but the public seems to be warming to the Individual Savings Account (Isa). Over the first six months of the scheme, the Inland Revenue reported sales of £12.7 billion, 40 per cent more than went into Peps and Tessas in the same period the previous year, and the market has been even busier since.

Of that money, £6.5bn went into mini-Isas, most of it in cash. Just over £6bn went into maxi-Isas, of which £5.7bn went into stocks and shares. The life assurance Isa element was not a popular option, however, capturing just £26 million of investment in total.

Research from fund management group Fidelity, shows that awareness of Isas has soared, with around three-quarters of the adult population now aware of their existence. But the research also found a lot of confusion about how they work, with only 27 per cent of those interviewed understanding that you cannot have a mini- and a maxi-Isa in the same tax year.

Research group MarketMinder also found that 20 per cent of the Isa holders did not even know whether they had a maxi- or a mini-Isa (MarketMinder says as many as 50,000 people may hold both). Around two-thirds of investors had no idea whether their Isa was Catmarked or not. 'There's a high level of confusion out there,' says MarketMinder's Mike Hare.

With investors who inadvertently run foul of the rules, the Inland Revenue is taking a fairly hard line. A spokesman said anyone taking out more Isas than the rules allow would have the second ruled invalid and be asked to pay any income or capital gains tax due.

Cash Isas have got off to a flying start, and volumes have generally been main tained. Providers are wary about letting the competition know how much money they have actually taken, but the Halifax has said that it had more than 800,000 cash Isa accounts towards the end of December.

Now, as the end of the tax year approaches, investors are expected to pile into equity Isas in the way they did into Peps.

Back to basics

 Isas are a tax-free shelter for savings and investments available to residents of the UK over the age of 18.

 Money can be withdrawn at any time without loss of tax benefits.

 Each Isa can contain one, or more, of the following components - cash, stocks and shares or insurance.

 All three elements can be offered in a maxi-Isa, though you don't have to invest in all three.

 Alternatively, you can have a mini-Isa comprising just one element. You can have one mini of each type, from different providers.

 You cannot have a mini and a maxi-Isa in the same tax year.

 If you have a maturing Tessa, the capital proceeds (maximum £9,000) can be transferred into a Tessa-only Isa. This is in addition to any mini or maxi-Isas.

 Maximum investment in a maxi-Isa is £7,000 (£5,000 next tax year). All of this can be used for stocks and shares, or you could put up to £3,000 in cash (£,1000 next year) and £1,000 in insurance and the rest in equities.

 Maximum investment into a mini-Isa is £3,000 in equities, £3,000 in cash (£1,000 next tax year) and £1,000 in insurance.

webTitle: Family investment hits a flat note

fields.headline: Family investment hits a flat note
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
My sister and I and our two spouses bought my mother's leasehold council flat in 1981. She was a entitled to the maximum discount under the Right-to- Buy scheme. We hoped it would be a long-term investment for us all.

We bought it through a deed of trust, at the insistence of my mother's solici tor. My mother has 60 shares, and the four of us have 10 each. In her will, she leaves her shares to us equally.

But now my mother is 91, and needs residential care. Her only income is the state pension and income support. She has £3,000 in a building society. The local authority has indicated it will pay all her care fees, but it is not aware of the trust. Are we obliged to inform it that my mother has these 60 shares, and can it insist that we sell the flat? If we do so, can the trust be varied so that only the four of us, who funded the purchase, will benefit?

AT, Whitley Bay

You have a potential problem. You should tell the local authority because this is an asset she owns, although you might be able to negotiate. The council could argue that you, not your mother, benefited from a substantial discount when buying her flat and should not expect it to pay for her long-term care as well. It might ask what you will do with the flat when your mother goes into care. Will you sell it and keep the money yourselves? Will you let it and keep the rent? Or will you accept that 60 per cent is hers and hand her the money? And what would happen to your shares if you four died before she did?

You could counter that, because you paid all the money and will recoup any profit, she is a legal owner but not the beneficial owner of the flat, which is important in assessing eligibility for help with care costs. A trust can, with difficulty, be changed if all the beneficiaries agree, but the council can still make your mother pay by saying she deliberately deprived herself of an asset to obtain financial help.

I telephoned the AA to renew my membership a few days before it was d

August.

On 19 August, I received a letter saying the payment had not been taken. I rang again and was told that the office had the wrong account number. On 23 August, an AA adviser took the correct number, and confirmed I had been covered from 1 August.

But later the AA ruled me ineligible for a Centrica windfall because, it said, my renewal was received and put through more than 28 days after the expiry of my membership.

I appealed: it was not my fault the payment was delayed, and it went through on 24 August, within the deadline. I have not yet had a response.

SC, Poole

Several readers have contacted Money Writes after they were refused windfalls.

The AA has investigated, and accepted that in every case it was wrong to exclude them from the payouts.

To you, it says: 'At the time of the sale of the AA to Centrica, we received a high vol ume of applications, many to take advantage of the windfalls. Regrettably, Mrs C's direct debit renewal suffered inordinate delays in being processed, so she was omitted from the list of eligible members.

'That was not her fault - it is the AA's.

'Consequently a cheque is to be issued to Mrs C.'

My son persuaded me to pay for his AA membership with my credit card, as a loan. The AA refused him a windfall because he did not pay himself. That it was a loan was made clear in our attempt to argue the case ourselves. Our argument, even submitted to the chairman, was rejected without explanation.

MS, Maidenhead

The AA says: 'Mrs S's son is eligible to receive the Centrica windfall payment. At the time of drawing up the list of eligible members prior to the special general meeting in September, his inclusion on that list was approved. But due to an administrative oversight, that approval was not carried forward. As yet, we do not know why that happened.

'A cheque for Mr S is to be drawn up and issued very shortly.'

Refused without an explanation

Returning from holiday last August, an AA membership renewal form was among the letters waiting for us. Obviously, because of

inent payo

<

renewed.

However, we did not receive a windfall payment cheque. In November, we received a curt reply to our query, telling us we were not eligible for the money, but the letter did not not explain why.

I wrote again but have not had any response.

PM, West Kirby

The AA now ackowledges that it was wrong. It says: 'We accept that Mrs M did make every effort to renew her membership within the allotted 28 days laid down in the AA rules, so she will be receiving her cheque.'

fields.headline: Think globally... then invest  globally
fields.standfirst: As trade barriers fall and the Internet brings the world closer, more people are investing in world-class companies. Should you join them?  Alexander Garrett  investigates
fields.trailText: As trade barriers fall and the Internet brings the world closer, more people are investing in world-class companies. Should you join them?
fields.body:
While campaigners at the recent World Economic Summit at Davos in Switzerland were busy protesting about the effects of globalisation, investment company Mercury Asset Management is taking a more sanguine view.

'Something really big is happening,' says Richard Royds, managing director of Mercury's unit trust arm. 'Trade barriers are coming down, the European market is opening up and the Internet is bringing the world together. Companies are discovering that they can operate globally.'

The result is the Mercury Global Titans fund, a new unit trust which will invest in the world's largest companies - those with an average market capitalisation of more than $100 billion. It is available at an introductory initial charge of 3 per cent until the end of May, and Royds says 40,000 brochures were sent out in the first three days.

'A lot of people would like to invest in world-class companies,' enthuses Royds. 'This is a new movement and it's growing fast, and it is appealing to investors because of the efficient way in which these global players can manage their capital and their costs.'

Mercury's Global Titans unit trust is one of a pair of new Isa offerings with a global theme being promoted this spring. The other is Fidelity's Triple 2000 Isa, which is actually a neat package of three existing funds, which will each take a share of investors' proceeds. The funds in question are: Fidelity American (50 per cent); Fidelity Japan Special Situations (25 per cent); and Fidelity South East Asia (25 per cent).

Fidelity is aiming to capitalise on is the large number of investors who bought Peps for many years, and now have portfolios heavily weighted towards the UK and Europe, with little exposure elsewhere. Fidelity has reduced the Isa's initial charge from 3.25 per cent to 2 per cent until 20 February.

Under the old Pep rules, you were allowed to invest only £1,500 each year in funds that had less than half their money invested in the UK and Europe. As a result, many people completely ignored regions such as the Far East and North America.

Fidelity spokeswoman Jo Rodda says: 'We're saying that you have to make sure your portfolio is diversified, and there are a lot of people who have taken out Peps year after year who simply aren't.'

The extent to which you should attempt to spread your investments around the world - as opposed to investing closer to home - is still controversial. Most financial advisers suggest that UK investments should make up around 50 per cent of your portfolio, even though the UK represents only a tiny part of the world's stock markets.

The reason, they say, is twofold. First, investment in the UK market is not subject to currency risk. The Asian crisis of the late nineties represented a double whammy for investors. Not only did share prices plummet, but most South-east Asian currencies went into freefall, making the overall effect far worse.

Second, it is easier to understand what is going on in the UK market. By assiduously reading the business pages, you may be able to correctly identify a good time to buy a small companies fund in the UK.

But when you invest in a global fund, you are placing yourself entirely in the hands of the fund managers. 'If you were to be ruthlessly logical, you would probably send most of your money overseas,' says Tom McPhail of financial adviser TQ Direct. 'On the other hand, if you opted for a total comfort zone, you would probably invest none overseas and keep it all in the UK. In practice, most advisers would suggest a blend of the two.'

The risk of eschewing global investment is that you miss out on the best opportunities. Mark Dampier, of financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown, says: 'Economies such as those of Korea, Malaysia and China are all growing again at around 7.5 per cent a year, which is around twice the rate in Europe. Do you want to miss out on that?'

Of the two new Isa offer ings, he is much more taken by Mercury's, which, he says, has a definite theme: 'I wouldn't buy the Fidelity package.'

'They are just putting three funds together - it's a nice piece of marketing but your investment isn't really managed; Fidelity isn't going to write to you and say you should sell Japan now.'

As a vehicle for global investment, Dampier is keen on Sarasin's EquiSar fund, which is also available as an Isa. 'It follows five themes across the world: e-commerce, technology, world energy, industrial deflation and corporate restructuring. These are five of the most important themes.'

Global investment is hardly a new idea, of course. Investment trusts such as Foreign & Colonial pioneered the concept many years ago. Fidelity's Triple 2000 Isa may not be the most innovative product in terms of latching on to contemporary themes, but the company claims that the results speak for themselves. A £7,000 sum invested five years ago in the combination of funds chosen would be worth £24,318 today, it says. This compares with an average return of £13,237 in the Global Growth unit trust sector. In the past year alone, the Triple 2000 Isa would have generated a return of 103 per cent.

The protesters at Davos may not like it, but as business becomes more global, investors are inevitably going to want to invest in the most competitive companies, wherever they are based.

As McPhail puts it: 'If you are really investing for the long term - over 20 or 30 years, say - you really should take a global view, because nobody knows how well our economy is going to fare over that time. You only have to look at the downfall of Japan in the 1990s, or the way the American economy has been revitalised to see that.'

For fund managers, that may mean fewer meetings with companies in City boardrooms, and a good deal more time spent with their eyes glued to the Internet.

webTitle: It pays to pick your own shares pays

fields.headline: It pays to pick your own shares pays
fields.standfirst: Design your own tax-free portfolio.
fields.trailText: Disappointed with the performance of your investments? Feel you could do better yourself? A self-select Isa may be just what you're looking for.
fields.body:
Disappointed with the performance of your investments? Feel you could do better yourself? A self-select Isa may be just what you're looking for.

These allow you to pick which stocks to buy and sell, allowing you to design your own tax-free portfolio.You can include investment trusts and usually unit trusts as well. And because the Isa manager is just an administrator and doesn't choose the shares, the charges are usually very low.

A final advantage is that using this sort of Isa means you can avoid the hassle of having to detail all your share dealings on your tax returns.

Whether your returns will be better than they would be if you simply handed your investment to a unit trust Isa manager is another matter. Providers of self-select Isas argue that no special expertise is required to run one. Colin West of NatWest Stockbrokers says: 'All investors really need is common sense, some understanding of financial and economic issues and the confidence to back their own judgment.'

Having chosen this type of Isa, the most important factors to consider are charges, investment choice and service. The brokers which offer them include traditional and telephone-based firms as well as the stockbroking arms of banks and building societies.

The average minimum initial investment level is around £1,000 and both mini- and maxi- self-select Isas are available. If you have existing holdings of shares that you would like to put in your Isa, you will find that most managers operate special terms to 'bed and Isa' such shares.

Charges normally comprise an annual management fee - typically starting at 0.5 per cent - and a dealing commission. With management fees, look out for any minimum or maximum charge and watch the frequency of charging. Some managers try to make their charges look more competitive by quoting a quarterly rate. For example, the charges of leading telephone broker Charles Schwab sound attractive at just 0.1875 per cent a quarter. But this is equivalent to 0.75 per cent annually, and there is a minimum fee of £20 a year for a maxi-Isa.

Yet Barclays Stockbrokers charges only 0.5 per cent a year, and has no minimum.

Some managers have a flat rate charge. Leeds-based Redmayne Bentley, for example, charges £40, which is equivalent to an annual charge of 0.57 per cent on a £7,000 investment. Assuming the value of your Isa rises, this fee structure is attractive.

The more often you intend to trade the shares in your Isa, the more important the cost of dealing. Commission rates usually start at around 1 per cent, with minimum charges typically of between £10 and £20.

But look out for special deals. If you only want to buy and sell modest amounts of FTSE 100 shares, the Share Centre's Isa, which charges a minimum of just £2.50 for purchases and £7.50 for sales, looks good.

Another cheap deal is offered by the savings arm of the Alliance Trust. But it has restrictions: you have to buy at least one share in the investment trust itself (cost around £40) and your choice of shares is limited to those in the FTSE 350 Index plus 170 investment trusts. However, as long as you are happy to deal on a weekly basis, you will be charged a flat rate of commission of just £5 for purchases and £25 for sales. What's more, the Alliance Select Isa has no annual management fee.

Cost is not everything, however. Many investors value quality of service, and Redmayne Bentley and Charles Schwab were highly rated for this in a recent investors' poll.

fields.bodyText: Disappointed with the performance of your investments? Feel you could do better yourself? A self-select Isa may be just what you're looking for. These allow you to pick which stocks to buy and sell, allowing you to design your own tax-free portfolio.You can include investment trusts and usually unit trusts as well. And because the Isa manager is just an administrator and doesn't choose the shares, the charges are usually very low. A final advantage is that using this sort of Isa means you can avoid the hassle of having to detail all your share dealings on your tax returns. Whether your returns will be better than they would be if you simply handed your investment to a unit trust Isa manager is another matter. Providers of self-select Isas argue that no special expertise is required to run one. Colin West of NatWest Stockbrokers says: 'All investors really need is common sense, some understanding of financial and economic issues and the confidence to back their own judgment.' Having chosen this type of Isa, the most important factors to consider are charges, investment choice and service. The brokers which offer them include traditional and telephone-based firms as well as the stockbroking arms of banks and building societies. The average minimum initial investment level is around £1,000 and both mini- and maxi- self-select Isas are available. If you have existing holdings of shares that you would like to put in your Isa, you will find that most managers operate special terms to 'bed and Isa' such shares. Charges normally comprise an annual management fee - typically starting at 0.5 per cent - and a dealing commission. With management fees, look out for any minimum or maximum charge and watch the frequency of charging. Some managers try to make their charges look more competitive by quoting a quarterly rate. For example, the charges of leading telephone broker Charles Schwab sound attractive at just 0.1875 per cent a quarter. But this is equivalent to 0.75 per cent annually, and there is a minimum fee of £20 a year for a maxi-Isa. Yet Barclays Stockbrokers charges only 0.5 per cent a year, and has no minimum. Some managers have a flat rate charge. Leeds-based Redmayne Bentley, for example, charges £40, which is equivalent to an annual charge of 0.57 per cent on a £7,000 investment. Commission rates usually start at around 1 per cent, with minimum charges typically of between £10 and £20. But look out for special deals. fields.headline: Beware those musical chairs
fields.standfirst: At new year managers move, and that can be bad news for investors.
fields.trailText: The new year has the reputation of being a dangerous time for fund management groups as star managers, sated with their end of year bonuses, move on to pastures new. This can spell bad news for investors.
fields.body:
The new year has the reputation of being a dangerous time for fund management groups as star managers, sated with their end of year bonuses, move on to pastures new. This can spell bad news for investors.

In the first weeks of 2000, there has been no shortage of highly-ranked fund-runners feeling the itch. And a warning is in order: changing managers can seriously damage your performance.

One of the most high-profile changes this year is William Littlewood, the highly-rated manager of Jupiter Income fund, which is popular among Pep and Isa holders with £1.6bn under management. Littlewood, it was announced in January, would be stepping down for three months because he is 'exhausted'.

According to Jason Hollands of Best Investment, the sabbatical comes after Jupiter Income's worst quarter ever. 'They underperformed the All-Share by 15 per cent,' he says.

Littlewood's position has temporarily been taken by his number two, Prakesh Rajasekaran, who has announced that he will be reversing the recent strategy for Jupiter Income by switching back from value stocks to technology shares. Long-term investors should be extremely happy with their returns: Jupiter Income has turned £100 into £295 over the last five years, outperforming the All-Share index by 14 per cent. But such performance will be difficult to maintain.

Investors in Perpetual's Far East Growth and Japan Growth funds may also be disappointed to learn of the departure of the man minding their money, Scott McGlashan. McGlashan, head of Japanese investment at Perpetual, is setting up his own fund management business.

'He's always demonstrated considerable aptitude at reading the Japanese market,' says Hollands. 'He was one of the first to say get out of Japan, and he came back as a raging bull a year ago.'

Over the last five years, £100 invested in the Japan Growth fund would have turned into £117 - a meagre return but still an out-peformance of 9 per cent against the MSCI Japanese index.

McGlashan is being replaced by Paul Chesson, who has run Perpetual's offshore Japanese fund since 1997. Hollands says there are other Japanese fund managers with a better track record.

For any fund manager, there is nothing worse than finding yourself on Best Investment's list of 'dog' funds. Such is the fate of Credit Suisse Income, a former star performer whose managers appear lately to have mis-read the runes

The fund used to be run by Bill Mott, who remains head of equities, but its day-to-day running has been taken over by a more junior member of the team. 'The CS funds have taken a value-based approach,' says Hollands. 'That started to go wrong at the last election. They expected the economy to change, bringing sectors such as manufacturing back to favour, and taking the focus away from the consumer. In the event, we've had a prudent Chancellor, and that hasn't happened.'

Over the three years to 31 December, a £100 investment in Credit Suisse Income would have provided a return of £155 - an under-performance of 12 per cent relative to the FTSE All Share return of £177.

Another popular fund that has recently seen a change of manager is CGU's Monthly Income fund, which pays an income of around 6.9 per cent in monthly tranches. The fund has invested in some of the 'racier' areas of fixed interest, according to Hollands, including preference shares and high yielding bonds. 'But that means that the contibution of the manager has been higher than normal,' he says. The new manager does not have a record of out-performance, he believes.

Finally - it is not all gloom - a fund management group Hollands believes is worth looking out for is Apam, set up a year ago by two former fund managers from Ivory & Sime, Mark Tyndall and John Dodd, who have teamed up with the venture capital house Apax Partners. 'Because of the share arrangements they have been given, they are very incentivised to grow quickly, and maybe become a new Jupiter or the like,' he says.

In its first year, Apam's Artemis Smaller Companies fund has tripled in value, outperforming the Hoare Govett Smaller Companies index by 94 per cent, while the UK Growth fund has returned a highly respectable 71 per cent. You have to invest a minimum of £10,000, which means that neither fund can be put in an Isa. But the returns may provide some consolation.
