webTitle: Heavyweights enter battle of the bond funds

fields.headline: Heavyweights enter battle of the bond funds
fields.standfirst: Schroders and Standard Life target investors with corporate bond funds, but beware their reliance on high-risk bonds
fields.trailText: Savers investing for income are being invited to judge a bout between two heavyweights of the investment industry which are both selling new high yield corporate bond funds.
fields.body:
Savers investing for income are being invited to judge a bout between two heavyweights of the investment industry which are both selling new high yield corporate bond funds.

Standard Life, which weighs in as the third biggest UK bond manager with fixed interest assets worth £17 billion, loftily claims that its Higher Income Fund will set 'a new benchmark against which other high yield funds will be measured in terms of return on capital, clarity of charges and competitive charging structure'.

The fund's target yield is 8 per cent gross after an annual management charge is deducted, and importantly the charge will be taken from income rather than capital. This reduces the risk of capital erosion, vital for investors who need high income for years to come.

In the other corner Schroders, whose 49-strong team of fixed interest specialists handles assets worth £22bn, is promoting its Monthly High Income Fund, designed to yield 8.75 per cent gross. This, Schroders claims, will 'combine one of the highest yields in the market with a quality portfolio that is structured to capture the yield while balancing the risk'.

To attain these yields, both funds will be investing significant parts of their portfolios in 'sub-investment grade corporate bonds'- often called junk bonds. Both will invest about 40 per cent at launch.

These bonds have a low, or no, credit rating, indicating a higher risk of them not being redeemed or paid off compared to ones with a good rating. A poor rating may be given because the issuing company has only been running for only a couple of years, it might still be small and financially vulnerable, or unknown. Such bonds have to pay more to persuade investors to part with their money.

All corporate bonds react in value to changes in the Bank of England base rate, but the sub-investment is also sensitive to fluctuations in the stock market. They tend to be more volatile, rising and falling in value more like shares than bonds.

To balance the higher risk, both portfolios will also con tain high quality bonds.' Alan Burton, managing director of mutual funds at Standard Life Investments, says: 'We are bullish about equities. We believe that means the default rate on high yield bonds will be lower.'

However, independent financial advisers are sceptical about the need for two new bond funds. Ian Millward, of Bath independent financial advisers Chase de Vere, says: 'They are both good fund managers, but there's been a flood of new bond funds over the last 12 months. I think both Standard Life and Schroders are just bringing themselves into line with other fund managers which already have high yield bond funds.'

David Hanratty of Chester independent financial adviser Nelson, which specialises in advising older clients, fears most investors are being misled about what they will actually get by investing in a corporate bond fund. 'Worryingly, investors in bond funds often believe they're getting the benefits of bonds - a fixed income, for a fixed term with a fixed return on maturity. But they're not. By investing through a unit trust or an open-ended investment company, they lose all these benefits. The fund manager often sells bonds before their maturity, and there is no guarantee that investors will get all their capital back.'

Nelson prefers clients to hold bonds directly and keep them until maturity. Bonds are usually sold in tranches of £100,000, taking direct investment out of the reach of most private investors. However Nelson pools clients' money to invest in a series of bonds over different terms until they are redeemed by the issuing companies. This provides a fixed income and ensures that the investors get their capital back.

Chase de Vere and Nelson are offering free guides on investing in bonds and bond funds. Call Nelson on 0800 328 4422 and Chase de Vere on 0845 6092003.

Charges: 3 per cent initial, 0.95 per cent annual (from income).

Format: Isa, Pep transfer or for direct investment.

Schroder Monthly High Income Fund

Target yield: 8.75 per cent

Charges: 3.25 per cent initial (discounted to 2.25 per cent until March 3); 1.25 per cent annual (from capital)

Minimum: £3,000 for maxi-Isa; £1,000 for a mini; £500 thereafter.

Format: Available as Isa, Pep transfer, or direct investment.

webTitle: If you'd £50,000 to play with...what would you do?

fields.headline: If you'd £50,000 to play with...what would you do?
fields.standfirst: Rachel Fixsen asked three financial advisers for their capital growth recommendations
fields.trailText: Congratulations. You are the proud owner of £50,000. Building up that lump sum was hard enough, but sadly the work does not end there. Unless you consider carefully how you are going to invest that money, its value in real terms can dwindle.
fields.body:
Congratulations. You are the proud owner of £50,000. Building up that lump sum was hard enough, but sadly the work does not end there. Unless you consider carefully how you are going to invest that money, its value in real terms can dwindle. On the other hand, clever investment decisions can make the money grow in less time than it took to save.

So how should you invest it? We have asked three independent financial advisers how they would invest £50,000 with the aim of achieving capital growth, assuming the investor had a medium tolerance to risk.

To make clear the thinking behind each portfolio, we have asked the advisers to explain their choices; we will revisit the portfolios in six months' time to see how each has performed.

All three advisers have put together a diversified portfolio - they spread the money across as many shares as possible. The point of this is to minimise risk - if an individual company goes bust, it will have little impact on the whole portfolio.

The advisers have not only chosen investment funds such as unit trusts or investment trusts, which each hold shares in tens or hundreds of different companies, they have also decided to spread the lump sum across several of these funds.

Technology stocks have long been among the fastest-growing on the stock market, but advisers differed on whether now was a good time to include technology funds in their portfolios. One felt share prices were already so high that there was a good chance they could collapse; another felt prospects for the sector were so strong they could not be ignored, whatever the price.

Jason Hollands of Best Investment in London said his goal was to spread the investment risk across securities in the UK, Europe, North American and Asia. 'Within the UK, I have taken an equal three-way bet between the FTSE 100, mid-caps and smaller companies,' he says.

He has decided to give the growth portfolio high exposure to European shares, putting nearly 30 per cent of the money in that area, with the view that the weak euro and large-scale mergers and acquisitions in Europe present good prospects for this year.

Although he steers clear of pure technology investment funds, the sector is still represented. Hollands says: 'While I have decided not to include direct holdings in a technology fund, because I feel the current valuation bubble presents too high a risk premium, I should point out that many of these managers are willing to take sizable positions in technology and telecommunications stocks as and when they feel they are attractive - so the tech theme is not absent.'

Hollands plans to add technology exposure to the portfolio when shares in the sector have come down from current levels. He would use the Isa allowance to shelter the investment from tax as much as possible.

Kim North of London adviser Calkin Pattinson has chosen two funds which do invest directly in technology stocks to make use of the £7,000 Isa allowance for this year.

'The Internet is the most volatile area of the market, largely as a result of the extraordinarily high valuations attached to a number of such companies,' she says.

'It is now widely accepted that Internet usage will soar during the next three to five years, and the problem of PC access could disappear with the inevitable introduction of WebTV.'

She has chosen the Framlington NetNet fund and Henderson Global Technology. Henderson is one of the largest specialist technology investment managers outside the US, holding about £1 billion in funds dedicated to the area.

'This allows them access to the world's leading technology companies,' she says. 'This is crucial in both understanding the nature of the business and being able to predict future earnings growth in an area where traditional valuation methods are often ineffective.'

Stephen Dight of Grosvenor Financial Services in Henley-on-Thames uses a different method altogether. Rather than constructing the portfolio from several funds with different objectives and investment areas, he opts to leave that job to investment managers who are doing the task full-time.

'I prefer the multi-manager approach of investing in a fund of funds which would be run by a professional fund manager,' he says. Very few advisers are capable of actively managing an investment portfolio, he says, despite what they tell their clients. This is partly lack of expertise, partly lack of resources.

For the growth portfolio, he has chosen Rothschild's Private Portfolio Service, splitting the money between three growth strategies, including the potentially more volatile Emerging Markets Capital Growth Strategy. Each strategy splits the investor's money between a number of funds which invest in other funds.

To show just how broadly investment risk can be spread with this multi-manager approach, Dight points out that the Rothschild UK Capital Growth Strategy is invested in 57 different unit trusts.

'If such a portfolio were put together on an ad hoc basis with an outlay of £50,000, the amount of paperwork would be horrendous,' he says. But this way the investor can have a wide spread and expert hands-on management while still receiving only one certificate and one half-yearly report.

He is using the annual Isa allowance to invest in the Five Arrows Independent Growth Fund, which is also managed by Rothschilds.

The IFAs income portfolios will be introduced next week.

fields.headline: Home sweet home for the singleton
fields.standfirst: Single men and women are set to be the driving force of the housing boom,    writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: When it started selling the properties in its Ranelagh Place development in Leamington Spa, the property developer Alfred McAlpine noticed something unusual. 'The first 10 residents were predominantly single people,' says spokeswoman Linda Trotman.
fields.body:
When it started selling the properties in its Ranelagh Place development in Leamington Spa, the property developer Alfred McAlpine noticed something unusual. 'The first 10 residents were predominantly single people,' says spokeswoman Linda Trotman. 'The development is right in the centre of town, close to everything and just a few minutes walk from the station, so it is an easy commute into Birmingham. The apartments and mews houses have proved particularly attractive to young professionals, especially single men.'

Berkeley Homes noticed a similar trend when it began selling the flats and townhouses in its new Harrods Village development in Barnes, south London. About 20 per cent of the purchasers have been single women - about twice the proportion that Berkeley Homes would expect.

Spokeswoman Tricia Henderson says: 'Successful career women need to have all their relaxation and entertainment facilities on their doorstep. We found that female purchasers at Harrods Village have been attracted by the size of the properties available, the security and the leisure facilities offered by the development. Our findings highlight a growing trend in the market and developers need to ensure that their schemes are sympathetic to the needs of single female purchasers.'

Far from being isolated examples, these two developments show the pattern of the future. We are in the midst of a huge increase in housing demand by single people. About 80 per cent of new homes will go to single people over the next 15 years, according to official estimates. This could amount to 3 million new single households by 2015 - the central part of a massive housebuilding programme.

All the demographic and social trends are pointing this way - greater longevity; the postponement of marriage; the greater acceptability of being single and childless; higher divorce rates; a greater acceptance of gays and lesbians; and rising standards of living. In 1971, about 18 per cent of households were single, according to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. By 2011, that proportion is expected to be 33 per cent. Much depends on the imagination of property developers, a worrying prospect for people who have looked around new housing estates and developments.

Most developers focus their attention on family homes, assuming that most of us will want to fit the average unit of 2.7 people.

In the past, the single market has been badly served. Until 30 years ago, single women rarely lived alone, while single men lived in digs supported by a landlady who even made their tea. In the 70s and 80s, the flatshare market expanded dramatically, but a flatshare is often a depressing option for someone much beyond their twenties. In most of the country the vast majority of properties were houses; flats were commonplace in London, the south coast and Edinburgh. 'The single-person product has yet to be created,' says Richard Donnell of surveyor FPDSavill.

Some characteristics of the single market are emerging, however. Research published in the Royal Society of Arts Journal in December suggests that single people are 'discerning purchasers ...very conscious of their residential environment...most want two bedrooms...they want parking for their cars and they also want private open space, not a large garden but a small garden or patio.'

Community is arguably even more important to them than to larger households. Jonathan Woodfield, of surveyor DTZ, is noticing a vast increase in demand from singles in the centre of London, typically for one-bedroom flats (£215,000 - £250,000) and two-bedroom properties (£300,000-£400,000): 'They work hard and play hard. When they get back from work, they might have a shower and then go to a wine bar or to a theatre.' The planned leisure centre at the Harrods Village development includes a swimming pool, gym, sauna and business centre. Single people are also more likely to want to live close to transport so that they can meet up with other people.

The Peabody Trust is also noticing the sense of community that is developing in its new 'live/work' development in the Docklands, London. Opened last summer, the West Ferry scheme sought to provide affordable housing to people in the early stages of setting up a business.

Many of the 27 live/work units (comprising living space and a studio, as the name suggests) have been taken up by single people. There is an aromatherapist, an IT consultant and a photographer, for instance. 'They are enjoying the informal support of having like-minded people around,' says a spokeswoman for the Trust. Under the scheme, the residents get a 20-25 per cent discount on local rents - paying £4,244 a year in rent and another £2,100 in service charges (covering the provision of business advice).

Both the Peabody Trust and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation are well aware of the growing housing needs of single people - and both are running pilot schemes to encourage developers, architects, local authorities, the government and other interested parties to take the issue seriously.

Joseph Rowntree is just launching its Caspar (City-centre Apartments for Single People at Affordable Rents) schemes in Leeds and Birmingham. 'Caspar apartments are intended for those on middle incomes who do not want to buy at this time, but for whom social housing is not appropriate,' the Foundation explains. Its rents will start at £100-a-week for a one-bedroom flat. The two developments have 'high levels of accessibility', making them practical for the elderly, a growing part of the market.

The Peabody Trust is launching several innovative schemes in the London borough of Hackney, typically aimed at people who earn £16,000 to £17,000 a year. Prices have become so high in London (average price £111,000, according to the Halifax) that few single people earning less than £40,000 can afford them now - unless imaginative schemes like the Peabody's become more widespread. The Trust is experimenting in selling homes at a 35 per cent discount to people on low wages and then taking 35 per cent of the proceeds when the property is ultimately sold. The kind of properties available in local markets depends very much on local attitudes.

Sleepy cities with unimaginative property developers might not meet the need well. But some local authorities are already giving active encouragement to the regeneration of their city centres - an ideal location for single people. Birmingham, Bristol, Manchester and Newcastle are among those leading the way.

webTitle: Be a victor in lenders' price war

fields.headline: Be a victor in lenders' price war
fields.standfirst: With base rates set to go on rising,  Neasa MacErlean  seeks out the best mortgage strategies
fields.trailText: Homebuyers are being encouraged to choose discount and fixed-rate loans in the midst of a fierce price war among lenders.
fields.body:
Homebuyers are being encouraged to choose discount and fixed-rate loans in the midst of a fierce price war among lenders.

With variable rates likely to go up at most lenders from the start of March - following last week's base rate rise - discounts and fixed rate loans could look particularly attractive.

Halifax led the way in putting up rates - increasing the standard rate from 7.49 to 7.74 per cent - adding £9-a-month to a £60,000 repayment loan. Those lenders that did not follow suit last week are expected to make their announcements this week - passing on, like the Halifax, the full base rate rise of 0.25 per cent. The base rate now stands at 6 per cent.

Borrowers will see another hike in their payments in April once Miras (mortgage interest relief at source) is finally abolished: someone on a standard variable rate of 7.74 per cent will be paying about £19 more each month when the tax relief is withdrawn. Halifax, for instance, is writing to all borrowers in March, explaining that this change will hit all borrowers, including those on fixed rates.

Economists and other experts are predicting that base rates will continue to rise - pushing up variable mortgage rates - for the next year or two. London & Country Mortgages, for instance, predicts a peak at the start of 2002, when mortgage borrowers could be paying up to 9 per cent on the variable rate. A homeowner with a £60,000 loan could well be paying £60 more a month than they are now.

In anticipation of these rises, mortgage advisers are recommending fixes and discounts. Mortgage adviser John Charcol is particularly keen on two to three-year fixed rates (of which the cheapest are currently pegged at 5.5 to 6 per cent) and on five-year deals (just under 6.5 per cent).

'Lenders are falling over themselves to produce market-leading products,' says Siobhan Hotten of John Charcol. She is especially enthusiastic about Yorkshire Building Society's 5.89 per cent two-year deal, although it does have a 5 per cent redemption penalty during the two-year period.

However, some advisers are more circumspect about redemption clauses. Patrick Bunton of London and Country warns clients against these deals - particularly where they have to pay a fine if they redeem the loan a few years after the discount or fix has ended. 'At the moment,' he says, 'we are seeing people coming off fixed rates and on to variable rates, just as the variable rate is rising. The penalty makes it uneconomic to move. The lender has no interest in offering you a competitive deal if you're locked in. Their interest in you exists only if you can walk.

Bunton's favourite offers are those without penalties - Newcastle's 2.1 per cent discount on its variable rate (pegged at 7.15 per cent before the base rate rise, producing 5.05) and Portman's 6.39 per cent two-year fix.

'Discounts are fantastic value at the moment,' he says. 'There's an almighty fight for market share. Lenders are prepared to take on loss leaders.'

A major factor in the com petitiveness of the discount market is the availability of funds for lenders. The building societies and banks fund variable and discount lending from 'retail funds' - money on deposit from savers. At the moment, there is no shortage of retail funds.

But fixed rates are funded through the money markets. The lenders have less room to manoeuvre with fixed rates because they borrow chunks of money at given rates in the market.

Mortgage advisers urge anyone on a tight budget to opt for a fix so they know they can afford the repayments.

webTitle: VW bids to take wheel at Rover

fields.headline: VW bids to take wheel at Rover
fields.trailText: Volkswagen has made an audacious bid to acquire the UK's Rover cars and Land Rover businesses from rival German carmaker BMW.
fields.body:
Volkswagen has made an audacious bid to acquire the UK's Rover cars and Land Rover businesses from rival German carmaker BMW.

BMW is refusing to open talks with VW until it knows the outcome of the Brussels inquiry into £152 million aid pledged by the UK government last year to rescue stricken Rover.

But one company insider told The Observer this weekend that if Brussels blocks all or most of the aid, a deal with VW could be an 'appealing compromise' that would save the Rover brand and the giant Longbridge factory in Birmingham.

Losing the flagship - and profitable - four-wheel drive Land Rover division would be a wrench for BMW, but it may be the price of resolving the Rover problem that is causing acute headaches in Munich.

A BMW insider said BMW would keep the Mini brand and build the new version of the little car as planned at Longbridge. But VW would take over the mainstream car production lines and produce not only Rovers but cars with some of the other badges in the VW stable - Seat, Skoda, and possibly VW itself.

VW has not offered BMW any cash, but sent proposals to its Munich-based rival in the last fortnight, proposing to take over the debt-laden UK business - expected in March to reveal 1999 losses in excess of £600 million - in return for shares.

BMW would be offered an undisclosed stake in VW's Audi, Seat and Skoda businesses and 'strategic cooperation' with VW, according to Car magazine. Despite the BMW brand's record sales and profits, Rover's troubles are dragging down the whole group. Industry experts believe BMW would resist a takeover from predators such as Ford and General Motors only because the fabulously wealthy German Quandt family refuses to sell its stake.

'There are no negotiations going on with anyone now. BMW directors have cleared their minds of anything until we are clear on approval for the grant from Brussels,' the insider said.

The manufacturer is also waiting nervously for the outcome of the UK Competition Commission's report into car pricing, which is not expected for at least a month.

Rover car sales dived by 25 per cent last year to a market share of only 6.5 per cent in the UK as it phased out older models and fell prey to the 'consumer strike' which is hitting most brands in the UK. Buyers are holding off in anticipation that prices will come down. Rover cars are selling well overseas, but the high pound means volumes do not translate into profits.

Rover desperately needs to boost sales of its new 75 model executive car and its revamped 25 and 45 medium cars by the time BMW presents its UK division's disastrous 1999 results to the German investment community in March, and to shareholders at the annual meeting in May.

The source added: 'BMW needs to start looking at alternatives: selling Rover to VW would be a fair exit for BMW - and appealing for Rover because it keeps the plants open.

'If Brussels blocks the aid, the BMW board can reconsider plans for Rover - although what VW thinks it can do with Rover that BMW cannot do, I do not know.'

fields.headline: Burning question
fields.standfirst: Why did Bill Drummond set fire to £1 million? Why did he want to chop off his own hand on stage? And why did the chart-topping KLF disband? As the controversial pop-star-turned-artist hits middle age, are we any closer to knowing the answers?
fields.trailText: Why did Bill Drummond set fire to £1 million? Why did he want to chop off his own hand on stage? And why did the chart-topping KLF disband? As the controversial pop-star-turned-artist hits middle age, are we any closer to knowing the answers?
fields.body:
What were we supposed to call this? Was it art? Some kind of bizarre political statement? A bit of a larf spun horribly out of control? If it was any of these things, it was the most extraordinary example anyone committed in the last two decades of the 20th century. It went almost unnoticed at the time, because few people were prepared to countenance the possibility that it was more than a stunt, couldn't believe anyone would do such a thing, be that stupid/irresponsible/free. But it wasn't a stunt. They really did it. If you want to rile Bill Drummond, you call him a hoaxer.

'I knew it was real,' a long-time friend and associate of his group the KLF tells me, 'because afterwards, Jimmy and Bill looked so harrowed and haunted. And to be honest, they've never really been the same since'

On 23 August 1994, Drummond and his partner Jimmy Cauty travelled to the Isle of Jura and, before a sceptical invited audience, ritually burned £1 million - in notes - of their own cash. Both in their late thirties, they'd earned the money as the men behind one of the UK's most unlikely pop groups. In 1991, the KLF, an acronym for Kopyright Liberation Front, was the bestselling British act in the world. Riding the post-acid house boom in club music, they could do no wrong: every tune they touched turned to gold. But the next year, they opened the Brit Awards with a scathing performance, backed by a co-opted heavy metal band. At the end of it, a stunned audience heard them announce that 'the KLF have left the music business'. A freshly slaughtered sheep was laid at the entrance to the post-awards party, with a tag reading: 'I died for ewe. Bon appetit.' They had been presented with the coveted gong for best group, then immediately dissolved themselves. Then, in 1994, they burned most of the money they'd made up to that point. Why?

Drummond sits before me, a stubbly
but youthful-looking 47, eating a cheese omelette and chips in a north London greasy spoon, the first thing he's eaten today, at 2.30pm, in the first interview he's done in six years. He and Cauty have made a deal not to talk about the million pounds, he tries to tell me. We're fencing. I ask him how much they earned during their peak.

'Are you trying to ascertain whether a million pounds was that much to us?' he replies, fixing me with a steady gaze.

Yes, I say.

He nods slowly. 'But it wasn't about burning all the money. And it wasn't about cleansing anyone's soul. In this context, a million is a lot more than 2 million. A million is the icon. It's what we talk about, dream about. It has the power.'

Have you regretted it since?

'...No...'

Are you financially stable now?

'No, I'm not. No.'

So why did they do it, I ask, and how did
it feel to watch it wither and snake, finally, irretrievably, into the sky? The answer takes two hours to emerge, and even then I'm not sure I quite understand.
For the past few years, Drummond has been relatively quiet, living with his wife Sallie Fellowes and two (soon to be three) small children on a farm in Aylesbury. The tangled logic of his career appears to be reflected in his private life, which takes in three other children, with two other women. He is close to the eldest two, but hasn't seen the third since the child was 18 months, a situation he acknowledges as 'weird' and is understandably reluctant to talk about. At one point in his new book, 45, after having 'trashed' another relationship, he wonders whether he 'will ever get to live with any of my children'. The longer you look at his life and read his work, the more clearly do you see what looks like a pronounced and compulsive cycle of creation and destruction, stretching right back to his schooldays.

His music career fits perfectly into this pattern, and it's what makes 45 such a good book about pop: few people in Britain can be in a better position to explore the dumb, chaotic tensions that make it tick - tensions between creation and destruction, ephemera and unwitting consequence, between mythology and visceral, irreducible truth. Many of his activities look like japes, but he will admit that 'we are serious about them, ridiculously serious'. He wants them to mean something, but knows that pop usually works best when it doesn't know what it means. And he knows. He can't help it. No wonder he wants to escape, but can't.

45 purports to be a series of snapshots and memoirs taken from the year he turned 45, seemingly at random, but actually compiled with deceptive - he would say accidental - logic. An early passage finds him driving to Helsinki with his children Kate, 12, and James, 10, to deliver some records and take in a Michael Jackson concert. James has just announced his decision to give up learning to play the guitar he badgered his father into buying him and switch to bass. A row ensues.

"That's it, James. I'm not paying for your lessons any more. The only reason why you want to start playing the bass is because you think it is easier." My voice is raised, I'm losing it, something I hardly ever do with my children. A year ago he would be crying by this point; now he just sinks into sullen silence. Kate says nothing. I switch on the radio. Abba's 'Winner Takes It All'. I slip from reality into pop nirvana, where the pain of heartbreak feels like the ecstasy of submission... I hope Kate and James can't spot the tears now rolling down my cheeks.

"Don't you understand, Dad? I have to work hard at school all day, and if I come home and just spend all my time practising guitar it makes me a boring person."

"What, and lying around watching television doesn't?"

"You're just getting like all the other dads, wanting me to do what you did."

"No, I'm not. I would far rather you didn't want to be in a band. Most people who dream or struggle their youth away wanting to be in a band end up unhappy, depressed, unfulfilled, 'cause it never happens."

"It happened for you."

"That was just luck. Look, even if it does
happen, it always goes wrong. Do you think Keith from Prodigy goes home at night happy?"

"You talk rubbish, Dad. I want to be in a band because that's what I want to do; it's got nothing to do with you. And anyway, I don't want to be a bass player, I want to be a singer."

"James, all singers are thick. Think of the boy you like least in your class - he'll be the singer. Everybody hates singers."

"Crap. Everybody loves the singer most."

"I mean the other lads in the band. They always hate the singer. He's always the lazy, loudmouthed, show-off one. You don't want to be like Liam Gallagher, just standing around doing nothing but being thick."

"Oasis are one of the best bands in the world; better than the Beatles ever were - it would be great to be the singer of Oasis."

I do not rise to the bait. Silence descends.

I can't believe I've just had this conversation with my 10-year-old son. If he's like this now, what's he going to be like when he's 15 and growing dope plants in his bedroom?

When Drummond was 15, he lived in a council house in Corby, in the East Midlands. He was born in South Africa, where his father, a Church of Scotland missionary, was working, and proudly recounts that his first words were in Xhosa, the language of the Bantu people. The incoming apartheid government forced the family home to Scotland before William was 18 months old, and thence to a council house in Corby. He was impatient with school and ultimately deemed unsuitable for the sixth form, he claims, after being caught reading the NME during a study period. Noting interests that included music and 'making things', a careers adviser suggested a future as an instrument maker, which required a qualification in art. Drummond enrolled in art school, but left before long, although his passion for art remains strong. 'It didn't work out,' is all he says now.

Music provided the solution, first through membership of Liverpudlian one-hit wonders Big in Japan (with Lightning Seed Ian Broudie and future Frankie Goes to Hollywood singer Holly Johnson on - don't tell James - bass). When that collapsed, Drummond found more lasting influence as manager of fêted local post-punk outfits The Teardrop Explodes and Echo and the Bunnymen. Establishing what would later become a pattern, he severed links with the latter at the peak of their popularity and went to work in the A&R department of WEA Records, where he was responsible for signing acts to the label. The only significant thing he did at that time was to sign a group called Brilliant, which had been formed by the former Killing Joke bassist, Youth, and featured the guitarist Jimmy Cauty. After three years, Drummond left his job in ignominy, but not before he and Cauty had struck up a relationship. Their subsequent commercial success, he explains, was partly inspired by a desire to 'prove [WEA MD] Rob Dickens wrong'. So they did, spectacularly.

KLF stands for Kopyright Liberation Front. Their first album, 1987 - What the Fuck is Going On?, made use of the newly accessible 'sampling' technology to borrow parts of other records and assemble them into something new. This is routine now - just ask Fatboy Slim - but was controversial at the time and led to a lawsuit with Abba over the unauthorised use of a passage from 'Dancing Queen', after which all unsold copies of the record had to be destroyed. Presaging things to come, Drummond and Cauty travelled to Stockholm in order to present a commemorative gold disc to Abba singer Agnetha Faltskog. Also presaging things to come, they couldn't find her, so gave the disc to a prostitute they happened across in the street, and came home.

In 1988, the pair decided to have a number-one record. They changed their name to The Timelords and released a cheesy dance take on the theme from Doctor Who, 'Doctorin' the Tardis'. It duly topped the UK singles chart and inspired its authors to follow up with a book entitled The Manual (How
To Have A Number One The Easy Way).

An Austrian duo, Edelweiss, followed their instructions and shifted 2 million units of a single called Give Me Edelweiss. A year later, again operating as the KLF, Drummond and Cauty began an extraordinary run of success with a pair of juddering rave anthems called 'What Time is Love?' and '3am Eternal'. In 1990, there came the first 'ambient house' LP, Chill Out, and in 1991, a further series of hit singles and the bestselling album
The White Room. Most bizarre of all, perhaps, was a version of their song 'Justified and Ancient', which featured country star Tammy Wynette on vocals and was only kept from the Christmas number-one slot by the death of Freddie Mercury and the re-release of 'Bohemian Rhapsody'. It was hardly surprising if the duo began to imagine themselves immune to failure. They were having fun, could do anything. At the 1992 Brit Awards, they proved as much.

Drummond is wearing jeans and work boots and fluorescent-orange donkey jacket with 'K2 Plant Hire' emblazoned on the back. He is soft spoken and intense, more comfortable discussing ideas and abstracts than emotion or inner life. His second wife used to worry that he would find God and join the church without warning. It hasn't happened yet, but you can see how it might.

I'd heard that the original plan for the 1992 Brit Awards was to chop up a sheep on stage and throw the gore into the audience. Unfortunately, Extreme Noise Terror, the heavy metal backing band they used for the performance, were vegetarians and refused to be part of such a performance. Oh dear. At the same time, Drummond tells me with absolute conviction that his first wish for the 1992 Brit Awards was to cut off his hand and throw it into the audience.
'I thought that would be the ultimate thing, a way of taking it even further. I was inspired by the story of the red hand of Ulster, which you see on the Ulster flag. That comes from the story that, when the first people came to the region, there was a young man in the boat who wanted to be the first to claim it for his king or laird, so he chopped off his hand and threw it on to the beach. So in my head, I was chopping off my own hand and throwing it into the massed ranks of the music business, claiming it for myself.'

You're telling me that you seriously considered this?

'Yes, but it's hard... you end up going down an avenue where you are almost daring yourself. I bought the implement... and then... Jimmy talked me down, persuaded me that I didn't have to. The sheep became symbolic. They took the place of the hand.'

Extraordinary. I am looking at Bill Drummond, yet hearing the voices
of Hannibal Lecter and David
St Hubbins of Spinal Tap. Perhaps it's me that needs help. At the same time, subsequent events suggest that Drummond should be taken seriously. After the dissolving the KLF, he and Cauty took the additional step of deleting their back catalogue, thus cutting off future sales and royalties. Remarkably, you might think, the shortlist was the same as for that year's Turner Prize. Sculptor Rachel Whiteread won both, and was allegedly warned that, if she refused
the K Foundation's £40,000, it would be
set alight. The Turner Prize was worth £20,000. Whiteread did all right that year. Soon, however, the ante would be upped.

I want to know two obvious things, the first being what possessed Drummond and his partner to burn £1 million, the second being what he felt at the moment he knew the money couldn't be retrieved, that it was gone forever. He tries to tell me that his actions that day were just like the others.

'I think I've always done the same thing, and it's just what it looks like on the outside that's different,' he contends, unconvincingly. 'I don't know what it is, but it's dealing with that same feeling on the inside and working with that.'

certain things. Jimmy and I made an agreement not to talk about this for a certain time, because the more we did, the more its impact became dissipated. What I will say is that I've never seen it as a destructive thing. It wasn't to destroy the money. It was to watch it burn.'

fodder to rise above being mere pop music, to enter the social fabric of the nation and times
we live through, like 'Give Peace a Chance' or 'Anarchy in the UK' or 'Three Lions'. Then that night in 1997, after we daubed our message on the grey concrete and were about to speed off looking for some after-hours action, I shook our former teenage Number One Fan's hand and wished him well. Almost as powerful and strong as when I saw that bit of dark curly hair sticking out the back of that Resident's eyeball mask. In our (Jimmy's and my) short journey through pop, that moment of disillusionment was maybe our greatest creation. Without that final state of disillusion, the power and glory of pop is nothing. And when it happens (and if it has not already happened for you, it surely will), savour it, because it very quickly slithers into disinterest and gets forgotten as life marches on.

fields.headline: How to lose a billion ...
fields.standfirst: Parsimony and red tape mean UK regions miss out on EU aid, writes  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: Tony Blair may have tried to shrug off last week's resignation of Labour's man in Wales, First Secretary Alun Michael, as nothing more than malicious 'fun and games'. But he can't ignore the issue that precipitated Michael's downfall.
fields.body:
Tony Blair may have tried to shrug off last week's resignation of Labour's man in Wales, First Secretary Alun Michael, as nothing more than malicious 'fun and games'. But he can't ignore the issue that precipitated Michael's downfall.

The Government's failure to explain how it will match some £3.2 billion of European 'Objective One' funding for the country's most deprived areas with UK funds puts at risk an estimated £1bn of the money. And the issue extends well beyond Wales.

Merseyside, South Yorkshire and Cornwall also rejoiced last year when they learnt they were to receive EU money for training, business support, infrastructure programmes and community projects from 2000 to 2006.

Labour MP Dave Watts, head of the Commons Objective One group, says: 'There are very significant shortfalls. The Government has not resolved the matching issue. It's not serving people in deprived regions well.'

The debacle has been brought about by a classic recipe for chaos: too little cash, too much bureaucracy.

There is not enough money immediately available to the regions from government departments. Negotiations about increasing it will not start until the Treasury's next comprehensive spending review, this summer.

But the problems reach much deeper, into an administrative nightmare. The process starts at EU level. Officials decide which areas will receive funds by identifying those whose economic output per head is less than 75 per cent of the average. Then they calculate how much each region is to get by using a formula combining how far below the 75 per cent they fall with other factors, such as unemployment levels.

South Yorkshire should receive approximately £780 million, Merseyside £844m, Cornwall £315m, and Wales £1.2bn. But this is matched funding, so unless the UK puts up as much again, the EU money is lost.

Theoretically, the EU cash is administered by the Treasury. But since Britain is a net contributor to European funds, it does not actually receive the money from Brussels. Instead, it subtracts the £3.2bn from the amount the UK pays into EU coffers.

The Treasury has to prove to the EU that it is adding the Objective One money to the budgets of individual government departments. It cannot substitute the EU cash for spending already planned.

So far, so comprehensible, but now the descent into bureaucratic madness begins. Although the money exists to help particular regions, the Treasury decides which Objective One spending departments - Trade and Industry; Environment, Transport and the Regions; Education and Employment; Health; or Agriculture, Fisheries and Food - the £3.2bn will go to.

Next the departments work out how much of the money they are to receive will go to each of five sorts of projects eligible for Objective One help: business support, infrastructure, training, community development, and agriculture and fisheries.

The money is then distributed to departments - but it is not linked to the individual projects it will eventually be spent on, nor to the regions where it will end up.

Geoff Fieldsend, head of the South Yorkshire Forum policy unit, who is spearheading the region's attempts to get funds, says: 'If this had been done properly, we would know what funds were available for what area and for what projects. But we don't.'

The handling of the crisis in England has been better received than in Wales, where Alun Michael's attempts to raise money amounted to £25m of a £1.2bn total.

Another regional official said: 'His attempts to pass responsibility on to the regions are disingenuous. It is just hiding from the shambles and leaving us to deal with it.'

The Government likes the sound of regional democracy, but not local decision-making and autonomy over funding.

As the process unfolds, the regions will gain a louder voice at Westminster. A favourite to be the future elected mayor of Liverpool, former Defence Minister Peter Kilfoyle, made it clear that a primary reason for his resignation last month was lack of government cash to match European money.

fields.headline: Guess who's running Railtrack now?
fields.trailText: 'Prepare to advance.' The voice of the sergeant major will soon be heard on Britain's rail network as the Army is called in to get the trains running on time.
fields.body:
'Prepare to advance.' The voice of the sergeant major will soon be heard on Britain's rail network as the Army is called in to get the trains running on time.

Railtrack has declared war on laggardly workers, and on delayed maintenance trains which overrun deadlines on night-time track work, causing chaos in the morning rush hour.

Project engineers have been sent to the Army's vast Catterick camp in North Yorkshire to observe the skills of moving tanks, troops and rations to war zones around the world, and learn how to apply these skills to the more mundane task of moving track, stone ballast and sleepers around Britain's railway lines. Railtrack's staff have reportedly been spared assault courses and forced marches, but they have been treated to an exclusive performance of the Royal Logistics Corps' party piece - dismantling a huge field gun, moving the components a few hundred metres and reassembling it - in minutes.

The invaluable training will be applied to Railtrack's flagship project - rebuilding the West Coast line from London to Glasgow, which is running almost a year behind schedule and over budget to the tune of £2.9 billion. If Army methods work, they will be used across the network in future.

The company plans to recruit the services of at least one retired Army colonel from the Royal Logistics Corps, other serving officers and a team of former US marines to supervise project management. It intends to send more engineers to Catterick to mingle with squaddies and pick up the discipline of the parade ground.

Robin Gisby, Railtrack's network development director, said: 'The Army knows how to move thousands of tonnes of equipment, vehicles and people to very difficult places with tight deadlines. They are helping us to organise the very intense work of rebuilding the West Coast line without it over-running the night-time shutdown and disrupting the morning timetable.' Railtrack plans to replace all the track and signalling on the line by 2005, starting at Euston and Birmingham in the next few months.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Workers' jobs are safe, pledges new Npower boss
fields.body:
Workers' jobs are safe, pledges new Npower boss

Employees at UK electricity company Npower will be safe in their jobs, said newly appointed executive chairman, Ross Sayers. The new head of Npower, the UK business of the former National Power, has built a reputation in his native New Zealand - and in Australia and Hong Kong - as a tough, cost-cutting chief executive.

But he believes Npower is 'already efficient' and says he has no plans for a 'wholesale cost reduction and job-cutting programme.' His focus would be, he said, on expanding Npower's core business, particularly supply and energy trading operations. He added that he would like to add to generation market share as well. From a dominant position in the UK, the under-performing National Power has fallen to below 8 per cent - evoking strong criticism from the City. Sayers' appointment comes almost a year after National Power chief executive Keith Henry resigned due to pressure from investors over his handling of company strategy.

Sayers' title as executive chairman is controversial. A review of corporate governance under Sir Richard Greenbury advised against the role: it concentrated too much power in one pair of hands.

Bonanza for Share Centre customers

Customers of low-cost share dealing service The Share Centre are to be offered free shares in the firm as part of its first move towards a full stock market listing.

The offer, if taken up fully by customers, could put a value of £45 million on the firm, founded 10 years ago by former Barclays executive Gavin Oldham. The Oldham family currently have an 80 per cent holding, and although this could be knocked back to a little over 50 per cent after the share issue, it would still be worth around £22.5m.

This is thought to be the first time, other than in the flotation of a mutual organisation, that free shares have been issued to customers of a company aiming to join the Stock Exchange. Oldham, a committed Christian and a prominent figure in the Church of England, said: 'We don't want the institutions coming in and owning the stock. We want it to be there for private individuals.'

Up to 75 million shares will be offered to existing customers, provided they had an account on 8 January this year, and to anyone who subscribes the maximum amount for a 'maxi' individual savings account (Isa) with The Share Centre by 29 December this year. Existing customers' share allotments will depend on how long they have had their account, and the amount of business they have done with the firm. Share distributions will begin in June this year.

US generator plans Internet rejig

Power supplier and generator TXU will this week launch an overhaul of its business, aiming to change it from a remote utility to a customer-focused company.

The Texas-based company, which bought regional electricity supplier and power station owner Eastern in 1998, aims to use the Internet to offer consumer products such as financial services, on-line retailing, and payment of utility bills.

TXU will invest 'hundreds of millions' in customer services over the next few years, but wants to share the cost of expanding operations - including call centres and IT systems - with partners. Talks are on with VirginNet and Freeserve as well as financial services providers, thought to include one of the Scottish banks.

The move is being led by TXU executive vice president Roger Partington, who was customer development director of Safeway until last July. He wants to roll it out in the next 18 months.

fields.headline: Banking on a culture shock
fields.trailText: It's a very bad week if you work in a bank.
fields.body:
It's a very bad week if you work in a bank.

At NatWest the merger with Royal Bank of Scotland will cost 21,000 jobs. Lloyds TSB, hero of the High Street, announced respectable results - and 3,000 redundancies. Even in the pure air of central banking we had the extraordinary spectacle of Bank of England staff picketing against the loss of their privileged low mortgage rates. (To do so on the day most of us had our unprivileged mortgages put up by a quarter per cent suggests a lack of PR awareness.)

Those of us with an old-fashioned sense of equality found it rather tasteless that at the outset of the battle for NatWest the merits of rival bids seemed to revolve around how many job losses could be delivered. The ugly truth is that even 21,000 jobs from the new RBS NatWest are probably not nearly enough. (As a side issue, how will they rename it - the Royal Bank of Scottish Nationals, maybe?) And the broader problem the new entity faces is working out exactly what a retail bank will be in 10 years' time.

If they can come to any crisp conclusion, they will have beaten everyone else to it. The financial services sector appears to be in a quandary over what a bank should provide and at what cost. When Sainsbury's - via the magic of the Bank of Scotland - can produce a profitable financial services arm within two years, and when the Pru can replace its ambitions to buy NatWest itself with its online Egg product, the traditionalists are really trying to invent a wheel which no longer fits the wagon. RBSNatWest must already be looking at its new enormous wheel and wondering if it will roll fast enough.

The banking culture of dictating to the customer has fractured under extensive competition, but there are still aspects of our high street branch we are not ready to part with. Disappearing into cyberspace fails to solve all the problems; for starters, while the retail customer does not really need a branch, the small business does.

One of the key challenges Don Cruickshank faces in his report on the banking sector is finding out why banks are so uncompetitive when it comes to serving small businesses. The plain truth is probably that these are the only customers who are not able, because of their requirements, to simply waltz off to Tesco with their account. The banker's motto must be converging with that of the dairy farmer: if it stands still long enough, milk it.

Then we have the very relevant issue of social exclusion. The Government wants our banks to be competitive, but also to maintain a geographical presence in less wealthy areas to ensure that everyone can still access a bank. Little wonder, then, that companies seeking an entrée into financial services have followed the 'blank sheet of paper' approach rather than taking over an existing infrastructure.

And while our facility with call centres, disembodied bank clerks and 24-hour banking has flourished, our experimentation with digital cash has fizzled. Soon the Mondex card will be joining the Sinclair C5 and the Squarial in the garage of failed technological innovations. We love the folding stuff - so while the branch may have to go, the cash point must stay.

The 'high street bank' will become a complex fulfilment business; taking bags of notes to holes in the wall and dispatching the tea, sympathy and high charges brigade to hold the hands of budding entrepreneurs. They may even think about helping you fill in your tax form - and how much would we have paid for that emergency call-out service two weeks ago?

More branches will fall into the bleached blonde wood hands of theme bar chains, packed out with twenty-somethings, waving at the barman with the the twenty pound notes they collected from a hole in the wall. Once, these young people would have included cashiers and clerks from the local bank in their social mix. They at least will be gone forever.

webTitle: Big battalions do at least have some ammunition

fields.headline: Big battalions do at least have some ammunition
fields.trailText: When start-ups can attract valuations of £50 million and more just for mentioning the word Internet in their prospectus, a 40 per cent rise in the shares of Reuters and BSkyB following the announcement of their web strategies looks positively restrained.
fields.body:
When start-ups can attract valuations of £50 million and more just for mentioning the word Internet in their prospectus, a 40 per cent rise in the shares of Reuters and BSkyB following the announcement of their web strategies looks positively restrained.

Both already have established businesses and while both could be criticised for being rather late off the Internet starting block, investors can at least see how these businesses can migrate to the web without the rose-coloured spectacles needed to spot profits from most dot.coms.

Traditionally, Reuters has supplied its financial, news and dealing services to professionals such as bankers, brokers and newspapers. It has extended that to Internet operators such as ft.com, excite and AOL, all of which take Reuters content - indeed, the company reckons it already has 40 million users through 900 websites. But the presence of the Internet means there is no longer any barrier between professionals and others. Reuters' strategy envisages serving them all through one cheap, easily delivered product.

The plan will not be cheap for Reuters, though. It is to spend £500 million over the next four years, progressively migrating its services to the web.

It will also develop its own reuters.com website; that site currently offers little more than a link to the sites that take its feeds, aimed at the consumer finance market.

In Internet time, four years equals a couple of light years, but the timescale reflects the investment needed to transfer all its existing services to the web. Some of its brightest new ideas will, it says, be up and running long before that.

BSkyB is promising slightly faster action from its £25m investment in sky.com and skysports.com. But it will still take up to 18 months to create its vision of a seamless service, leading customers from television to Internet without them leaving their armchairs.

Coming late does not, however, mean coming last. The arrival of these big battalions - not to mention media giants Pearson and Reed International, which are at similar stages in their Internet strategies - merely emphasises what savvy investors suspect already: that the web winners will most probably be found among established businesses which have the skills and the brand name to transfer their services to it.

Even so, there is still no guarantee that any of the old media companies will be able to build a credible web strategy, let alone one that justifies the dramatic leaps in their share prices. All that can be said is that there will still be a business left if they disappoint.

Investors seem content to ignore the pressures facing those businesses while they salivate over the prospects for the web. A change in web sentiment could focus investors' attention on the fact that BSkyB may have to pay much more for its football rights or lose them entirely. They may also notice that Reuters' trading systems are already under pressure (though much of that was millennium-related) while Instinet's share dealing business faces enough threats on both sides of the Atlantic to at least raise questions over its proposed flotation.

Their shares are likely to be less severely hit than those of the racier dot.coms, but investors should still be prepared for a bumpy ride.

BA on the up

A classic assignment for new entrants to business school is to devise a strategy for running an airline. The winners are usually those who choose to focus either on the bargain basement or on the luxury market. Those in the middle just get squeezed.

British Airways is a classic example of that. Industry overcapacity, rising fuel costs and fierce competition on fares have been squeezing its profits for much of the past two years: even the most optimistic analysts expect losses to reach £200m in the year to March. But will chief executive Bob Ayling's strategy of going upmarket produce the business school result?

On the face of it, it is a sensible strategy. BA is trying to ditch unprofitable passengers, mainly those transferring from other airlines. In their place it is hoping to attract more first and club class passengers with initiatives such as fully reclining seats, revamped cabins and improved service. It is cutting capacity in the hope that this will leave it with fewer seats to offload at large discounts.

The results for the three months to December provide the first evidence that the strategy may just be working. Premium traffic rose by 6.8 per cent, offsetting a 2.8 per cent fall in the numbers of other passengers. That produced the first quarterly rise in passenger yields - the all-important measure of how much BA earns per kilometre - for almost two years. The increase, 3.2 per cent, was hardly dramatic, however.

It will still be a long hard slog. Analysts' forecasts for the year to 2001 range from breakeven to around £60m. Even if rivals play ball and keep their capacity under control, attracting enough premium passengers to get profits back to the £640m earned in 1997 will be some feat.

BA shares have been falling more or less steadily since those heady days, and now stand at less than half their 1998 peak. Analysts, convinced that Ayling's strategy will win, rushed out a raft of buy notes. Investors are clearly less convinced: the shares fell to a new low last week. If the strategy works, that will look cheap, but buyers must have the patience to wait.

The Next bargain

Next's Christmas trading statement demonstrated that it is one of the few retailers that is managing to thrive on a hostile high street. All the evidence that has since appeared suggests that it is continuing to perform. Even the sceptics at WestLB Panmure rated it as one of the 'hot' retailers on the strength of the fashion content of its spring range. Yet its shares have continued to fall and are down almost a third on where they started the year.

Analysts estimate that its profits for the year to the end of January, due to be announced next month, will be at least £195m. That puts it on a multiple of less than 12 times earnings. Institutional investors are so obsessed with getting hold of Vodafone stock and piling into the new economy that they are prepared to ignore such bargains.

It could take some time for Next's value to be recognised - and its shares could fall further before it is. But bargain hunters should consider a punt.

webTitle: Steel closure a betrayal,  says MP

fields.headline: Steel closure a betrayal,  says MP
fields.trailText: Corus, the renamed British Steel, was accused of betrayal by MPs and unions this weekend over the planned closure of its Shelton Bar rolling mill in Stoke-on-Trent.
fields.body:
Corus, the renamed British Steel, was accused of betrayal by MPs and unions this weekend over the planned closure of its Shelton Bar rolling mill in Stoke-on-Trent.

The closure, confirmed at a meeting with local MPs last Friday, will cost 216 jobs and end 150 years of steel-making in the area.

Another 60 Corus jobs went in Scotland last week. The cuts come amid mounting fears for the Llanwern plant in South Wales (with jobs for 3,000 people) following British Steel's merger with Dutch rival Hoogovens last year.

Last week Fokko van Dyne, Corus's joint chief executive, warned that the firm would have to look at UK plants if the pound remained high. The firm played down any suggestion of imminent closures, but Corus sources confirmed this weekend that a strategic review was under way. The company, which made first-half losses of £167 million, is due to unveil its results in June. News of further closures may come by the autumn, the sources said.

Only last June, unions at Shelton Bar agreed 108 job cuts and new working patterns, including12-hour shifts, to cut costs. 'The indication was that after all these steps Shelton had a future,' said Harry Cooper, local official at the ISTC steel union. 'Shelton is highly productive.'

On Friday, however, Corus confirmed that the plant would close by the end of April, and spurned offers of help from local MPs. 'They wouldn't budge. The plant and the workers have been betrayed,' said Labour MP Llin Golding.

webTitle: Ethics frozen out in the Ben & Jerry ice cream war

fields.headline: Ethics frozen out in the Ben & Jerry ice cream war
fields.standfirst: Investors have to choose between conscience and profit, writes  Christopher Reed
fields.trailText: Investors have to choose between conscience and profit, writes Christopher Reed
fields.body:
America's best loved ice cream firm, Ben & Jerry's Homemade, is known for supporting charities and doing good works - but has someone betrayed the company in an increasingly nasty takeover war?

A consortium of 17 'socially responsible investors' has entered into battle to defend the principles of small and ethical business. The knights-errant include Anita Roddick, celebrity president of the Body Shop cosmetics company. Ranged against them is the might of the Anglo-Dutch food multinational Unilever NV, which already owns Breyer's ice cream, and, to add confusion to the mixture, Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc., based in Oakland, California.

The consortium, brought together under the name of Meadowbrook Lane Capital, belongs to the Social Venture Network in San Francisco, a group of 400 business people who promote ethical standards for US corporations. Ben Cohen, one of the founders of Ben & Jerry's, is a leading member of SVN, (though he's not in the consortium) and his partner, Jerry Greenfield, used to belong.

The 17 are seeking to raise enough capital to make Ben & Jerry's a private company again. They hope to prevent the firm's trademark quirky, Sixties flavour from becoming diluted under the impersonal management of a large corporation.

But late last week their plan met with a setback when the details, subject to a confidentiality agreement signed by them all, were leaked to the New York Times, weeks after an earlier leak to the Wall Street Journal. The chief suspect was Ben & Jerry's itself. Observers believe a disgruntled shareholder was seeking to boost the Stock Exchange price, which has languished for nearly a decade.

'Ben & Jerry's is in a bind,' said an investor who wished to remain anonymous. 'If the firm is really ethical, it has to accept the Meadowbrook terms, but under US corporate law it must also do the best financially for shareholders - and the two are not necessarily compatible.'

Ben & Jerry's became a sensation in the Eighties, with annual sales increases of 120 per cent in 1984, 143 per cent the following year, and 100 per cent in 1986. The company expanded into Britain in 1994, into the Benelux countries two years later, and took Japan in 1997. From its beginnings in 1978, the public fell in love with the story of two ex-hippies who starting out making homemade 'scoops' in a converted garage in Burlington, Vermont.

They chose fun, hippy names for their flavours: Peace Pops and Cherry Garcia (after the late guitarist Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead rock group), Wavy Gravy, and, more recently, Cool Britannia. The firm was voted 'America's favourite' in an opinion poll.

Ben & Jerry's has already fought off a bid from Dreyer's, but Unilever is a new suitor. No one wants to comment on this new development. Neither company would answer press calls. Judy Wicks, owner and founder of the White Dog restaurant in Philadelphia, who is vice chair of the SVN group, had only this to say: 'We are very annoyed that someone breached our confidentiality agreement, but we cannot speculate on whom it might be.'

Lovers of Ben & Jerry's ice cream had already mounted street demonstrations against Dreyer's bids, and their prayers seemed to have been answered when Meadowbrook put in an alternative bid. It was for $32 a share - $268 million in total - and exceeded Dreyer's $31-a-share bid. But Unilever has offered $40 a share, the New York Times reported from the information 'supplied' on Meadowbrook's letterhead.

Dreyer's has offered to run any merged company as two autonomous firms 'managed independently'. But neither Dreyer's nor Unilever has publicly committed itself to continuing Ben & Jerry's social responsibility policy - the firm donates 7.5 per cent of its pre-tax profits to charities, runs a foundation, and pays premium milk prices to dairy farmers in Vermont.

The Meadowbrook 17, on the other hand, promised to make Ben & Jerry's even more socially responsible. But combining business ethics with bigger profits is not turning out to be such a gratifying mixture as the 'royal medley of vanilla ice cream, strawberries, and chocolate-covered shortbread bits' that makes up Cool Britannia.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Pure speculation
fields.body:
Pure speculation

What a difference a mood swing makes. Last autumn, when Peter Job, Reuters' chief executive, looked dour about the Internet, the media group's shares took a tumble. Last week, when Job put his smile on, they soared. With the stock now at 1418p, readers who followed our advice to buy at 575p in October have been well rewarded.

But what about Reuters' once-tipped partner, Reed Elsevier? Shares in the Anglo-Dutch publisher leapt last week on renewed speculation of a link-up with rival Wolters Kluwer, which roundly denied the talk. But the shares have done no more than recover ground lost on fears for its own Internet strategy.

Crispin Davies, Reed's new chief executive, is due to unveil the results of his strategic review on 24 February, and has much to prove. At 622p, the shares are on a heady forward multiple of 27 times. But with content providers all the rage, there may be more to go. So Reed remains a speculative buy.

Empty hamper

The same might be said for Park Group, the Christmas hamper company owned by Merseyside football boss Peter Johnson. At 19.5p, the shares have now almost halved since the firm called off bid talks three weeks ago.

Johnson has been trying to sell Park for years, but each time has balked at the price offered. Meanwhile, trading has progressively deteriorated, as has the share price. Hampers are old-fashioned, but would-be buyers have looked at other products they could push through Park's agents on the ground. The answer has always been: not enough to justify Johnson's lofty price.

The shares are a hold only if another offer is round the corner. On fundamentals, broker Charterhouse thinks they could go as low as 5p-10p. You have been warned.

Weak formula

The most remarkable thing about last week's Italy-Scotland rugby international - after the result itself - was that rather than Benetton or Pirelli, the Azzurri shirts sported the UK's Alliance Unichem as sponsor. In that respect, the tartan army can certainly claim the Italians were on a high. That's more than can be said for the pharmacy wholesaler's shares.

They now stand at 358p, a third lower than a year ago, which means the market has shown scant appreciation for Alliance Unichem's expansion overseas in a whirl of deal-making. According to broker Commerzbank, all that hard work seems set to go unrewarded, and the shares will drift further.

Slippery jelly

Now you see him, now you don't. Ed Guinan, chairman just departed of Internet wonderstock Jellyworks, that is. Guinan's exit last Thursday must be a record. For, as of tomorrow, Jellyworks will have traded on AIM for just two months.

But on 4 January, when the shares touched a giddy 120p, Guinan's family trust was still buying. On 19 January, when we spoke to him, he still had billion-pound aspirations for Jellyworks. He was still gushing a week later when Jellyworks splashed out in Germany and Howard Barclay joined the board.

By 31 January, he could have exercised an option at a profit of £20 million. Instead, Guinan walked away from all that. So what happened in the last week of January - apart from Barclay Jnr's arrival - to change his future? Jellyworks spokesman, Tom Allison of The Communication Group, doesn't have a clue.

Jellyworks made great claims for Guinan - and vice versa. In view of his exit, this could be seen as creating a false market. The Stock Exchange should certainly investigate. In the meantime, with the shares still at 87p, we repeat: sell and avoid.

 paul.farrelly@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Cloth that was cut too close

fields.headline: Cloth that was cut too close
fields.standfirst: Can the new British chairman of Fruit of the Loom save the US giant from its troubled situation?  Paul Farrelly  reports
fields.trailText: Can the new British chairman of Fruit of the Loom save the US giant from its troubled situation? Paul Farrelly reports
fields.body:
The American icon left stranded by designer brands is paying the price of having followed fashion of an altogether different sort. Fruit of the Loom's future now lies firmly in the hands of an old-fashioned Brit - and a knight of the realm to boot.

The world's biggest T-shirt maker - famous in the UK for sweatshirts emblazoned with a trademark logo synonymous with Seventies casual chic - is fighting for survival. Since the new year it has languished in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, burdened by debt, and engaged in one final attempt to stave off creditors.

Workers around the world who have been 'downsized' or were simply handed their P45 by any large corporation may be forgiven a wry smile at the immediate cause of Fruit of the Loom's misfortune: an overhasty dash to set up in sweat shop havens such as Central America and North Africa as a way of cutting wage and tax bills at all costs.

Struggling to cope with the 'yoof' trend for designer labels, Fruit of the Loom found the quality of its traditional fare so compromised that customers balked at buying them. Already 16,000 US workers had paid the price as factories across the US closed. Mismanagement also crossed the Atlantic: with more than 1,000 workers at five factories in Ireland lost their jobs. Four of the company's six plants there closed.

Now the remaining 30,000 staff, employed in 60 countries, hope that Sir Brian Wolfson, the former Wembley boss installed as chairman last month, will revitalise the brand.

'The problems are fundamentally at manufacturing level. There were problems going offshore, to Mexico, Honduras and the Caribbean, too quickly,' Wolfson said in his first newspaper interview since taking control. 'It's a hugely complicated business. It may take up to two years to sort out. But Fruit of the Loom is still the world's second most dominant apparel brand after Levi's jeans.'

The firm's 150-year history is one of US pride compromised by corporate greed. Founded in 1851, Fruit of the Loom grew from a small Rhode Island textile mill into one of the clothing world's best known brands. As well as its trademark T-shirts and sweatshirts, its white cotton briefs have clothed generations of American bottoms. The firm may never have sold a pair of knickers over here, but today it still sells 15 per cent of girl's underwear and one in three of all men's and boys' briefs in the US.

The firm's original cotton cloth was patented in the US in 1871, the first textile product to stake its claim to exclusivity. From the late 1950s it had been under the wing of an obscure conglomerate called Philadelphia & Reading. Then corporate America started to attract the vultures of Wall Street in the first great wave of restructuring. In 1985, a $1.4 billion buyout took Fruit of the Loom into the hands of Farley Industries, a swash buckling investment outfit headed by Chicago-based corporate raider William Farley.

Farley's money came from a far from impeccable source. He was a close associate of junk bond king Michael Milken, star of the now-defunct Wall Street investment outfit Drexel Burnham Lambert. Milken was later jailed for securities fraud.

An encyclopedia salesman-turned-financial-engineer-turned-industrialist, Farley amassed great wealth from his adventures. The owner of one of Jackie Onassis's former mansions, he also once had a grand New England home from which he would boast: 'I can see right into George Bush's beach house.'

Fruit of the Loom was floated on the stock market in 1987. But long before the firm finally buckled last year, Farley's record had been tarnished. In 1989, he took over bedlinen-maker West-Point Pepperell, but struggled for three years, swamped by debt and against fierce staff resistance, before creditors seized control.

He also defaulted on debts after a buyout of Condec Corp, a defence contractor. By last year, after the mishandled moves overseas (including a change of registered office to the Cayman Islands) Farley's lifestyle was also contributing to Fruit of the Loom's problems.

Included in the $1.6bn that the company owes to its banks and creditors is a $65 million guarantee given by Fruit of the Loom to secure one of Farley's personal debts. In court filings, the company has also sought to cancel a $27m severance and retirement package Farley secured from Fruit of the Loom last year. After a string of profit warnings and a $625m refinancing by Bank of America, Farley's greed was enough to push the firm over the edge.

The Wembley veteran has been on the board since 1992, but insists he has the crucial confidence of the banks. 'During the restructuring, lots of changes have been demanded by the banks,' he says. 'The firm needed an independent non-executive director at the helm, and I was really the only one who fitted the bill.'
