Colour and controversy on the road to Wembley

Sir Brian Wolfson, Fruit of the Loom's unlikely new chairman, is used to flying by the seat of his pants. Best known for the 10 years he spent running Wembley - the former owner of the national football stadium - he is a survivor and a ducker'n'diver.

He left Wembley in 1995 - part of the price of a £140 million rescue - and now numbers Playboy Enterprises, a gambling equipment firm and a supplier of natural health foods among his eclectic US interests. And Wolfson, veteran of many a corporate battle, has no plans to return to Britain.

'I'm 64 now,' he said from Chicago. 'There's plenty enough to keep me busy over here. You can't go round the world forever at my age.'

Born in Liverpool in 1935, Wolfson joined the family motor business straight from school at 15. His big break came during a property venture 10 years later when he attracted the eye of Sidney Bernstein, legendary founder of the Granada TV group. After seven years with Bernstein, Wolfson, by then 32, rose to become the youngest managing director of Granada TV rentals. In 1971 he left to seek his fortune in the US and Asia, before cropping up in the freewheeling early Eighties as chairman of stock market-quoted engineer Anglo-Nordic Holdings.

In 1982, Wolfson had a well-publicised run-in with the Takeover Panel during Anglo-Nordic's controversial bid for rival engineer Braby Leslie. In parallel to his City career, Wolfson rapidly climbed the Establishment ladder, serving on 'Neddy', the old National Economic Development Council, and, from 1993, as chairman of Investors in People. One of Lady Thatcher's favourite businessmen, he was knighted in 1990 for services to training.

That assiduous networking led in 1985 to his first involvement with Wembley, through work on the unsuccessful British bid for the 1992 Olympics.

Wolfson floated Wembley in 1987, right in the middle of the October stock market crash. Equally inauspiciously, he set about rapid expansion by snapping up greyhound tracks in the UK and US, discotheques, bingo clubs, ticketing and hospitality firms and a film company. In 1989 he was beaten by Ladbroke in a £200m bid for Vernons pools.

By 1990, as recession struck hard, Wembley's debts had grown to £120m and the next five years were spent unravelling the deals to pay off the loans. In 1995, under pressure from its bankers, Wembley installed as chief executive Claes Hultman, a no-nonsense Swede, who ran down the curtain on the Wolfson era. Along the way, Wolf son had gathered some equally controversial characters around him, including impresario Jarvis Astaire, and Tony Clegg, founder of the now-defunct Mountleigh property group. Wembley tried to merge with Mountleigh a year after flotation, but the talks were called off.

Other colourful characters stalked the Wembley wings through links with United Dutch Group (UDG), a major Wembley shareholder of which Wolfson was a director. A secretive Netherlands-based investment company, UDG was originally owned by Sasea, the defunct vehicle of jailed Italian financier Florio Fiorini, who tried to buy Hollywood studio MGM.

UDG was bought in 1989 by property trader Paul Bloomfield - who, with Alton Towers owner John Broome, tried and failed to redevelop Battersea power station - before passing to a Wolfson consortium.

UDG collapsed in 1993, but not before it helped to bankrupt Lord Beaverbrook, following a Guyanan forestry deal. There were never any allegations of wrongdoing by Wolfson.

The combative Liverpudlian continuously added to his US interests throughout, gaining a reputation as one of British Airways' most frequent transatlantic flyers.

Now Wolfson is hoping to spare Fruit of the Loom the unhappy end met by his last UK involvement after Wembley. Installed in 1996 as chairman of Colorvision, a foundering northern TV rental chain, he was too late to prevent its collapse three months later.

fields.headline: How M&S sent Green packing
fields.standfirst: The takeover rumours were becoming too much. Ben Laurance tells how St Michael fought back
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer was fed up with the uncertainty. For almost two months it had been under public threat of takeover and it wanted the matter settled. Would its tormentor bid? Or would he be forced to go away?
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer was fed up with the uncertainty. For almost two months it had been under public threat of takeover and it wanted the matter settled. Would its tormentor bid? Or would he be forced to go away?

It was Wednesday 2 February. After lunch, three men trooped into the Stock Exchange building in the heart of the City and took the lift to the twentieth floor. One was Graham Oakley, M&S's company secretary. The second was Piers de Montfort, from investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The third was Andy Ryde, from M&S's City law firm, Slaughter & May.

They were to appear before the City's Takeover Panel - a body that has no legal status, but which sets rules and acts as arbiter when one company bids, or threatens to bid, for another.

That Wednesday gathering was seen as the 'put up or shut up' meeting. Philip Green, the Monaco-based entrepreneur who made a fortune breaking up Sears in 1999, had announced on 13 December that he was considering a bid for M&S.

Now, said M&S, it was time for Green to be forced to show his hand. He had already said publicly that he had investment bank Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette (DLJ) at his side. Its people were there to help devise a structure and find the financing for an £8 billion-plus bid for M&S. And Green's allies said a number of well-known faces in the retailing world - Allan Leighton of Asda, Terry Green of Debenhams and Richard North, who worked for Burton before moving to Bass - were lined up to take key roles in a bid consortium.

So, M&S argued that Wednesday, if all this was were true - and given that it was nearly eight weeks since Green first raised his head - he must get on with it. Or he should admit that the bid wasn't going to get off the ground and he would leave M&S alone. (Under City convention, that would mean him having to wait 12 months before any fresh bid.)

The panel listened patiently to M&S. But Oakley, de Montfort and Ryde knew they had little chance of securing a quick result. There were unhelpful precedents: a decade ago, for example, when Storehouse was the subject of the nagging attentions of an American raider, the would-be bidder had been allowed month upon month to come up with an offer. And they knew that DLJ would argue that more time was needed because Christmas had slowed things down. M&S privately conceded that the best it might hope for was that the panel would set a cut-off point for a Green bid - perhaps tomorrow.

But even before the meeting started the M&S team scented blood. At last, the company might have the ammunition to fire the first volley in a counter-attack. And it had nothing to do with the panel.

Until then, M&S had been relatively content to let the Green story run. The company had undoubtedly looked vulnerable - because of its awful recent trading record and because it had been without a permanent chairman. M&S had long decided that it wanted Luc Vandevelde, formerly of Promodès, to take the post.

But negotiations to compensate him for the loss of money on share options and thus extricate him from his previous job were protracted. A deal was struck and an announcement made only on 24 January. With the chairmanship now sorted out, M&S was ready to step up a gear and go on the attack.

Late in January, M&S sent out a number of '212 notices'. These documents - their name comes from section 212 of the Companies Act - give a company the right to find out who owns its shares. On 28 January, M&S wrote to Philip Green: did he have any M&S shares?

Green replied promptly. And by the time the M&S threesome arrived at the Takeover Panel's offices five days later, they knew that his reply could be dynamite.

Green said he had no shares in M&S. But his wife Cristina did. In the week leading up to his 13 December announcement of his interest in the company, she had invested the best part of £25 million in M&S.

There was nothing wrong in that as such. People often buy shares in companies for which they are considering launching a bid. It gives a toehold before the whole world knows what is going on.

But legally they can buy shares in anticipation of a bid only if they are in a 'concert party' - a group which does the bidding. In that way they don't profit personally from the inevitable share price rise when a bid materialises. The curiosity in Green's 212 reply was that it said quite explicitly that Cristina Green was the sole beneficial owner of the shares. And Green said 'neither I nor any of the other persons disclosed by this letter are party to any agreement to which section 204 of the [Companies] Act applies'. Section 204 covers concert parties.

After Green's reply had arrived in M&S's company secretary's office, it was forwarded to Slaughter & May. The lawyers pounced on the implication of his apparent denial that his wife was in a concert party.

The issue was first raised by M&S with the panel on that Wednesday of the 'put up or shut up' meeting. By the end of the week, M&S had been told that the panel thought there was no problem: according to the Green camp, his wife's share deals had been cleared by them before she bought. The panel accepted Green's assertion that she was part of a concert party.

M&S immediately saw the potential of Green's letter. The panel may or may not have thought that everything was hunky-dory and complied with its code, but under the Companies Act, Green appeared to have a problem.

According to a briefing drawn up by Slaughter & May on 4 February, Green should have informed M&S that his wife's holding in 'Campbell'- the code-word used for M&S - was part of a concert party.

That evening, M&S and its advisers attacked. The Observer and one other Sunday newspaper got hold of Green's 212 reply. M&S said the issue would be raised with the Stock Exchange. The gloves came off.

On Saturday evening, Green telephoned his lawyers. They in turn contacted The Observer. They quoted sections of the Companies Act. 'This section [204] does not apply to an agreement which is not legally binding unless it involves mutuality in the undertakings, expectations or understandings of the parties to it,' said Green's lawyer, so he had stuck by the letter of the Act.

The legal prose was, of course, crystal clear and a ravishing read. But it didn't answer the point - whether Cristina Green's involvement in a concert party should have been declared. Green was more succinct: he threatened to sue.

From then on, Green and his advisers - DLJ and broker WestLB Panmure - were deluged with legal challenges to their replies to 212 notices.

Slaughter & May handed details of all its challenges to the Department of Trade, the Stock Exchange and the Financial Services Authority. On Monday evening, Green issued a statement: he had done nothing wrong and he and his wife had complied 'with all the relevant laws and regulations'.

Behind the scenes, his lawyers at Titmuss Sainer Dechart were less forthright. Should the concert party have been declared in Green's 212 reply? 'The matter is not free from doubt,' it said in a letter.

By Tuesday, the lawyerly spat had turned into a parody of legal life.

In one particularly acid exchange between solicitors, Slaughter & May wrote to Titmuss Sainer: 'Section 204... requires disclosure where there is an agreement between "two or more persons". You presumably accept that Mr Green is a person and that Mrs Green is a separate person.'

In the event, Green quickly folded his hand. His idea of buying M&S - code-named 'Project Mushroom' - was abandoned in the early hours of Thursday. He complained - as he had when stories about his wife's shares appeared - that he suffered 'an unjustified attempt to discredit me'.

M&S's share price, meanwhile, fell to its lowest for nine years.

fields.headline: The public's trustees on trial
fields.standfirst:
Steven Barnett asks what should be done about BBC governors

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Here's a question that may be worth at least half a million of Chris Tarrant's money: who are Professor Fabian Monds, Roger Jones and Sir Robert Smith? Here's a clue: they represent one quarter of the board which is responsible for the most powerful cultural organisation in Britain and which recently appointed its chief executive.
fields.body:
Here's a question that may be worth at least half a million of Chris Tarrant's money: who are Professor Fabian Monds, Roger Jones and Sir Robert Smith? Here's a clue: they represent one quarter of the board which is responsible for the most powerful cultural organisation in Britain and which recently appointed its chief executive.

More importantly, if you have read any of the shrill denunciations of the past few weeks, they and their fellow board members failed dismally in their public duty by not imposing certain pre-conditions on their appointee.

The men are three of the BBC's 12 governors, the new chief executive was director-general Greg Dyke, and the problem was his shareholding in a rival broadcaster.

There are other more recognisable names on the board - Sir Richard Eyre and Heather Rabatts might have jogged a few memories - but beyond the ubiquitous Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC board of governors is hardly a body packed with household names.

Their apparent failure to insist that Dyke dispose of all shares unconditionally and immediately on his appointment has again raised questions about how exactly the BBC should be run, and by whom. The announcement of a broadcasting White Paper by the end of the year will revive the issue of the BBC's constitutional position.

The 12 BBC governors - currently eight men and four women - have a monumental task. They are, in official jargon, 'trustees for the public interest'. Their task was spelt out in more detail by the BBC's most recent Royal Charter, in 1996. It states that governors must 'determine the strategy of the corporation in the manner they consider best calculated to ensure that the corporation's services, programmes and other activities reflect the needs and interests of the public.'

Their more detailed obligations now include the annual approval of a statement of promises and the monitoring of performance. The usual shorthand is to say that the board of governors determines the BBC's strategic role, while its director-general and its senior managers - all accountable to the board - carry out day-to-day management tasks. This raises two fundamental questions for the twenty-first century.

First, can one really distinguish in practice between a strategy and a daily management decision? If several million pounds of licence payers' money is to be invested in a new costume drama, that is presumably of such strategic significance to the direction of their corporation that it needs at least to be run past the governing board. But at what point and at what level of expenditure should such decisions be delegated without reference upwards?

Other changes are more subtle and incremental. A gradual shift, for example, in one Radio 2 DJ's playlist to include more 'golden oldies' and therefore, perhaps, to compete more directly with some of the commercial AM stations, is a matter of day-to-day decision making. But it may have important implications for a commercial station's profits.

This leads directly to the second question. In a world where everyone talks about convergence and the need for a coherent regulatory strategy, is it appropriate that the BBC should remain independent of any regulatory structure for the whole communications industry? Given the imminence of another tranche of communications law-making - not to mention the Independent Television Commission's barely concealed desire to take over the regulatory function of the BBC - shouldn't we now be looking to bring these 12 part-timers under some kind of super-regulator's umbrella? If nothing else, the strategic programming decisions can then be seen within a communications context wider than the BBC alone.

It is quite explicitly not the BBC's job to fit itself around the output of commercial competitors; it should provide a comprehensive service of its own. How it does this, how distinctive it should be from its rivals, where it should compete head on and where it should avoid competition, are all difficult strategic and management questions. But their resolution does not lie in giving away the BBC's regulatory function to a body which must also remain sensitive to the needs and aspirations of the commercial sector.

Just think for a minute about issues such as bidding for sports rights or introducing more episodes of a popular soap opera. Both would be justifiable BBC decisions on the grounds that it is vital to cement licence payers' affection for an organisation to which they all subscribe. Both would be bitterly contested by commercial competitors, who would vigorously lobby their common regulator. Operationally, it simply would not work to have a public body and its commercial rivals accountable to the same people.

Which leaves us with the question of whether the present constitutional set-up for the BBC is right. Any system that combines strategic management with public accountability is going to be messy - and there have been times when the calibre of those involved has called the whole edifice into question. This was particularly true in the Eighties, when the board was packed with Thatcherite second-raters.

The issue, then, is about ensuring a high-calibre governing board with sufficient awareness of the traditions and purpose of the BBC. It is unfair to question the calibre of the present incumbents simply because they got the shares question wrong. However, if they had been subjected before the appointment to a rigorous and transparent interrogation by the public's representative body - Parliament - this would have strengthened their position and forced them to think about these issues more carefully

While I would hesitate before giving any parliamentary select committee the power to appoint BBC governors, let alone one headed by Gerald Kaufman, it may be more democratic if a selection of aspirants were at least publicly questioned by the Media and Culture Select Committee. Thus, the public trustees of the BBC would themselves have been accountable to Parliament. And some bright spark MP could have asked each of them what a would-be director-general should do with his share portfolio.

Who's who in Portland Place

The current Governors?

Chairman: Sir Christopher Bland; Vice-chair: Baroness Young of Old Scone; National Governor for Scotland: Sir Robert Smith (chief executive of Morgan Grenfell Asset Management); National Governor for Northern Ireland: Professor Fabian Monds; National Governor for Wales: Roger Jones (chairman of Penn Pharmaceuticals); Chair, English National Forum: Ranjit Sondhi (Birmingham college lecturer).

Other members: Sir Richard Eyre (former National Theatre director); Adrian White (chairman of Biwater); Dame Pauline Neville-Jones (diplomat turned banker); Tony Young (Communica tion Workers' Union), Heather Rabbatts (chief executive of Lambeth Council); Baroness Hogg (journalist and thinktanker)

So how do I get to be a Governor - apart from already having a title?

Jobs are scrupulously advertised as the 12-strong board rotates. The appointment is made by The Crown. Her Majesty does not actually get out her drawing pin and list of names herself - she will of course have her hand guided by the chairman of the governors, with just a touch of input from leading politicians.

How much does it pay?

£9,250 pa. Governors are expected to attend monthly meetings.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Klaus Esser are you local?
fields.body:
Klaus Esser are you local?

We cannot be the only people to have noticed the uncanny resemblance between world industry leader Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone, and the League of Gentlemen's shopkeeper Edward in the mythical village of Royston Vaisey. In fact, Gent allegedly greeted Klaus Esser, the German head of Mannesmann, the company for which he launched a successful takeover bid, with the words, 'Hello, are you local?' There are not many other examples of leading British businessmen appearing in sitcoms in their spare time, though mayoral hopeful Frank Dobson has been noted for his erstwhile role as Uncle Albert in Only Fools and Horses

Listing of the week

There may be life after politics, but there is little dignity. Poor Mo Mowlam, who until recently was trying to broker peace in Northern Ireland, was appearing as a guest on the So Graham Norton show and 'giving away the bride in a dog wedding'.

Whatever next? Martin McGuinness and Gerry Adams doing their legendary Stephen 'the gay one out of Boyzone' Gately and Ronan Keating impressions on Stars in their Eyes ? Or maybe Senator George Mitchell sending in a hilarious home video of his cat falling off a roof to Mandy Dingle's You've Been Framed ? Or Peter Mandelson being caught, horrified, on camera when his Assembly was suspended on Game for a Laugh ?

You told me you were single!

In the share-tipping débcle at the Mirror , one small skirmish went unreported. The Sun was beside itself with delight over the embarrassment caused by senior Mirror staff, including editor Piers Morgan, being under investigation for possible dodgy deals. But in some breathless reporting of Mirror staff who jointly own a racehorse, the Sun claimed that Mirror Lawyer Martin Cruddace 'and his wife' had a share of the nag. Cue three dozen women jamming Cruddace's voice mail with 'You told me you were single!' outraged messages because, of course, he is. If that's not a cause for a writ we don't know what is .

The missing edition

Red faces at the Sunday Telegraph , allegedly. The paper has taken the cost-cutting measure of scrapping its Scottish edition, so imagine editor Dominic Lawson's surprise when, last Saturday, he wandered over to the sports desk. 'How big is this rugby defeat of Scotland by Italy?' he asked. 'Well, the champions being beaten by the newcomers in the Six Nations - that's pretty big,' responded the wise hacks. 'Ah, so what are we doing with it for our Scottish edition?' asked the editor, as editors are wont to do. Of course the answer had to be 'not much as we no longer have a Scottish edition'.

Easy mistake to make.

webTitle: Can they make me wait till 65 to retire?

fields.headline: Can they make me wait till 65 to retire?
fields.trailText: I have been with the same firm for 23 years. It has been taken over, and now plans to change the pension scheme so that we retire at 65 rather than 60. Can this be forced on us?
fields.body:
I have been with the same firm for 23 years. It has been taken over, and now plans to change the pension scheme so that we retire at 65 rather than 60. Can this be forced on us?

Your contract cannot be changed unilaterally. If you are represented by a union, your case will be handled collectively. If you have a personal contract, make your own representations.

You must have built up 23 years of contributions on the assumption that you would retire at 60. Your company cannot force you to accept a retrospective change to your entitlements, nor should you agree to a change of this scale.

If you are in a 'final salary' scheme - where you are paid a pension each year based on your final salary - your right to a pension between the ages of 60 and 65 is very substantial. If it is a 'fortieth' scheme, where each year of contributions gives you a fortieth of your annual pension (itself capped at two-thirds of your final salary), you have already earned more than half your pension.

If the worst happens, you may decide to tell your bosses that you do not accept the change. They may then fire you or, by apparent coincidence, discover that your job is now redundant.

You could then claim unfair dismissal. But at least you would still have the valuable benefit of the original terms of your pension.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.
Legal advice: Hammond Suddards.

fields.headline: Ministers widen finance probe
fields.trailText: The Government is considering mounting a vigorous investigation of the retail financial services industry as a follow- up to the banking sector probe led by former telecoms regulator Don Cruickshank.
fields.body:
The Government is considering mounting a vigorous investigation of the retail financial services industry as a follow- up to the banking sector probe led by former telecoms regulator Don Cruickshank.

Senior government figures are concerned that Britain's retail financial services sector is inefficient and lacks competition. They believe it is ripe for a thorough review.

Attention is likely to focus most strongly on the life insurance market, which the Government feels lacks innovation on products and delivery of services. But a review would cover all aspects of financial services delivered to retail customers.

The new investigation highlights concerns among Ministers that significant sectors of the UK economy are underperforming and uncompetitive.

Last year, the Government launched inquiries into competition in the water industry and the airports market, as well as initiating the Cruickshank review in November 1998.

A government source told The Observer : 'We are concerned about innovation and efficiency in several British industries, and there has to be a question mark over financial services, particularly life insurance. '

Despite deals such as last year's £7 billion acquisition of Scottish Widows by Lloyds TSB, many analysts believe the UK life insurance market is highly fragmented and ripe for consolidation.

Cruickshank - who is unlikely to carry out the next review - has been criticised for taking an aggressive line over lack of competition between high street banks.

He was initially thwarted in his attempts to investigate the sector because of the banks' refusal to provide information on the profits they make from customers and from individual products.

The industry is divided over whether his report will strike an aggressive or a conciliatory tone, and whether it will find that the main high street banks are anti competitive.

Ministers are frustrated at the slow progress of the water and airports reviews, fearing that officials carrying them out have become too close to these particular industries.

It is thought the review of the water sector will advocate far greater competition between companies which up until now have effectively been regional monopolies.

webTitle: How to calm the old Duchess down

fields.headline: How to calm the old Duchess down
fields.trailText: In the bad old days the Bank of England would tell the Chancellor that things were getting out of control, and the latter would reluctantly agree to a sharp rise in interest rates. The signal that things were out of control was not a Bank forecast suggesting that inflation could rise above 2.5 per cent in two years' time; inflation in those bad old days was always going to be above 2.5 per cent in two years' time.
fields.body:
In the bad old days the Bank of England would tell the Chancellor that things were getting out of control, and the latter would reluctantly agree to a sharp rise in interest rates. The signal that things were out of control was not a Bank forecast suggesting that inflation could rise above 2.5 per cent in two years' time; inflation in those bad old days was always going to be above 2.5 per cent in two years' time.

No, the signal was usually a deteriorating trade balance and a sterling crisis. It took an awful lot of deterioration in various economic indicators for chancellors to be persuaded a rise was necessary.

The approach was: better, when the time comes, to raise interest rates sharply, and show that we mean business. Later, one could gently test the market with a gradual easing of rates. Reductions of half a percentage point were much in vogue; it became boldly experimental to move rates by a mere quarter point.

But this was when rates were on the way down. Between them the present Chancellor and his quasi-independent Bank of England (the Bank cannot choose the most important item of all, the inflation target itself) have altered traditional market tactics. Instead of a sharp rise followed by gentle reductions, we now have a series of gentle rises, in circumstances where the markets know there is more to come; and sterling, already too strong for the health of the real economy, becomes even stronger.

It took the Chancellor and the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) 13 months to raise interest rates by 1.5 percentage points during the inflation scare of 1997-98. The last rise during this phase (a quarter point to 7.5 per cent on 4 June 1998) took place in the face of accumulating evidence that industrial confidence was on the verge of collapse.

There were six increases of a quarter percentage point between May 1997 and June 1998. During this period the financial markets knew they were on a one-way bet with both sterling and interest rates: high rates of return, and a rising pound. Despite the general belief that the pound was overvalued at DM2.80, it ended at DM2.90. True, it fluctuated, but the broad thrust of the movement was one way.

Then came the MPC's belated recognition that it risked engineering a recession, which would not go down too well with many people, including the MPC's creator, one Gordon Brown. So the august body embarked on a series of rate reductions: having led her troops up the hill, the Grand Old Duchess of Threadneedle Street led them down again, to 5 per cent on 10 June 1999.

It was not long before there was panic in the ranks and the Duchess started marching her troops up again. But there was dancing in the streets: you could hardly move in London for cranes. Cheap money had brought the property speculators out in force: I swear that in Clerkenwell, where the Observer is now situated, they were advertising Ground Floor Loft Apartments, at prices a lot nearer the sky than the said apartments.

Between 10 June 1999 (when rates had been reduced to 5 per cent) and the beginning of this month (when rates had risen to 5.75 per cent) the great sterling one-way bet had progressed from DM2.91 to DM3.19. At one stage this month it was DM3.25. This has been the background to the chorus of voices from industry saying the strong pound is hurting.

I include foreign-owned British industry. Many 'inward' investors went out of their way to assuage fears that they were putting up 'screwdriver' plants through a show of integrating with the local community and 'buying British'.

But, in common with our home-grown Marks & Spencer, Japanese and other companies here have been forced by the strength of the pound to look overseas for cheaper sources of supply. Despite this, monetary policy has continued to keep the pound strong.

The Government and the MPC profess to be mystified by the strength of sterling, but given the level of interest rates and the tactics employed, this observer is not at all surprised. Small increases do not seem overpoweringly efficacious in slowing down the economy, but this 'gradualism' does a lot of harm to the manufacturing base. This brings us to the latest little rate rise, preceded by an interview with the Chancellor in the Times which was presented as 'Interest rates should rise, says Brown.' So much, it seems, for the Chancellor's professed belief that these decisions should be apolitical.

My good friend's actual words were more circumspect: 'I would support the Bank of England in the difficult decisions it has to take. It is important to recognise that the economy is now growing and that we do not want to fall into the mistakes of the late 1980s. We are determined to avoid the problem of stop-go which bedevilled the economy in every previous cycle.'

Nevertheless it would no doubt suit even an Iron Chancellor if all the prospective rate rises were out of the way this year, so that the Duchess could march them down in time for election year.

But this does not solve the problem of what to do about a situation in which interest rates keep rising, not because sterling is weak, but in order to control a boom which is barely being experienced by manufacturing.

We have a sterling crisis, but it is one of putative strength.

fields.headline: Payout plan to save mutual
fields.trailText: Mutual insurer Standard Life may come under pressure to pay special bonuses to its investors in order to defend itself from attack by a policyholder who wants it to float on the Stock Exchange.
fields.body:
Mutual insurer Standard Life may come under pressure to pay special bonuses to its investors in order to defend itself from attack by a policyholder who wants it to float on the Stock Exchange.

The insurer's legal advisers are now examining the conversion proposal put forward last week by Australian policyholder Fred Woollard. Some building societies have successfully fought off conversion bids by declaring similar motions invalid under their rules.

If it is forced to put the motion to a vote - which could go before the annual meeting on 25 April - Standard Life plans to defend itself by emphasising its past investment record - which is one of the best in the business. But most observers believe the insurer could have a struggle to win.

David Carrington, sales and marketing director of PolicyPlus, an organisation that trades in second-hand endowments and himself a Standard Life policyholder, said people who have policies due to mature over the next couple of years could easily be tempted by windfalls. They would judge that the extra returns likely from their investments over that time would not be better than £5,000 of free shares.

Another source said clients facing shortfalls on endowment mortgages would be easily persuaded into conversion.

One defence option would be a special bonus from reserves. An actuary said: 'They might say, "We've had a jolly good spell in the stock market. Now is a good time to make a special distribution".'

webTitle: Fight to stop the mother of mutuals turning into a plc

fields.headline: Fight to stop the mother of mutuals turning into a plc
fields.trailText: In the cutthroat world of the carpetbagger, nothing is sacred. Standard Life, mother of our remaining mutuals, is on the receiving end of a bid by a group of windfall-hunters to turn it into a public company.
fields.body:
In the cutthroat world of the carpetbagger, nothing is sacred. Standard Life, mother of our remaining mutuals, is on the receiving end of a bid by a group of windfall-hunters to turn it into a public company. This would release payments averaging £5,000. There is no real commercial pressure for Standard Life to become a plc. It is as respected as any insurer can be, and features regularly in league tables for top returns to policyholders.

Nevertheless, Standard Life's management, who want nothing to do with conversion, have a battle on their hands. The customer leading the assault is a wealthy, Monaco-based Australian who shows every sign of being well organised. He looks set to be a more formidable challenger than the amateurs who attacked building societies.

Most building societies have fought off their assailants so far, but they have cards up their sleeves that Standard Life does not. The societies' branch networks give them strong local support and command loyalty among staff who stand to lose their jobs in a conver sion or takeover. They are popular institutions with reputations, not necessarily always deserved, for fair play.

Insurers, however, are not counted among the great and good of British financial institutions. The carpetbaggers' assault coincides with news for some Standard Life policyholders that their endowments may not pay off their homeloans. How handy a windfall would be in these circumstances.

The way to Standard Life policyholders' hearts will be through their pockets. The insurer will have to find ways to promise distribution of the wealth that would be released through flotation.

On a more practical note, there's no point rushing to take out a policy: the insurer has decreed that new ones won't qualify for a windfall. Those with policies should, of course, hang on to them.
